Carlos deserves mention alongside the greatest suspense thrillers ever made.
One or two provocative bits emerge from the incoherence.
What the filmmakers do capture brilliantly is the human cost of espionage and political gamesmanship.
An exhaustive and eye-opening look at natural-gas drilling and its potential dangers.
Life as We Know It turns into a reasonably honest consideration of what it might mean to have to honor the dead by raising their living, breathing, pooping, screaming progeny.
Subtlety has never been Stone's strong suit, but few filmmakers pick at our rawest societal scabs with quite as much brio and determination.
From start to finish, It's Kind of a Funny Story walks an uncommonly deft line: Playful comedy gives way to moments of shockingly immediate and honest emotion.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This strange, darkly funny documentary investigates the story of Jack Rebney, a Winnebago salesman who achieved notoriety based on outtakes of a corporate video he shot in the 1980s.
High art? Maybe not. But Valentine's Day certainly goes down easy.
[Polanski has a] knack for taking pulp and transforming it into tense, paranoid drama.

The tense dynamic between these two fine actors, not to mention Asch's confident feel for New York City circa the late-1990s, keeps this slightly undercooked but wholly engrossing melodrama on course.
It's a sobering look at how governments operate in wartime, putting a shiny spin on even the grimmest of tragedies.
Micmacs, finally, is a romp through comic cinema history in which everything zips by so fast that you're too distracted to notice that it's all completely meaningless.
It's one of the best movies ever made about the brutal and unforgiving world of show business, and what it takes to survive in it for decades.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Predators mostly just suggests a bunch of grown-up men playing with toys and not bothering to invite the rest of us into their circle.
It's lurching, desperate and borderline incomprehensible -- a movie whose characters act according to no known precept of recognizable human behavior.
Well-intentioned, if unevenly executed.
J Blakeson springs surprises that force us to re-evaluate everything that's come before.
Who would have thought Shyamalan would come up with a movie that makes his Lady in the Water look positively sensible?
War movies all too often take it for granted that some causes are worth dying for. To have characters grapple with that notion, imperfectly, is nothing short of cathartic.
This isn't a paint-by-numbers revenge plot. When the payoff finally comes, it's as satisfying as it is perplexing.

Robert Edwards, the writer and director, explores the layers of melancholy contained within these familiar but authentically drawn characters, and he cleverly doles out virtue and vice to each while weaving in acid humor borne from regret.
movie_title: One More Time (When I Live My Life Over Again) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Teetering precariously between satire and base humor, "Jimmy Vestvood" squanders opportunities for both.
Bidegain and cinematographer Arnaud Potier speak multitudes with wide-angle, slow-panning shots that immerse us in a post-9/11 quagmire that's never less than utterly personal.

Hollywood loves its heroes, even if it finds it difficult to admit that courage and honor aren't superpowers. That's why it's refreshing to see the shadow of impending doom that hovers, just out of frame.
Glatzer captures the visceral charge of moving wildly in tandem with another person, often in improvised bouts that forge strong bonds between partners, if only for a few minutes.
"Radio Dreams" is a quintessentially American story.
As Thana, Warakulnukroh radiates a sense of unadorned humanity, coupling a sense of being lost with the desire to be of service.

The mercurial nature of fame acts as an ideal metaphor for the fleeting and uncertain nature of life itself - all of which, in the masterful hands of Brydon, Coogan and Winterbottom, goes down more smoothly than a glass of Rioja.
Talking-head interviews interspersed with reenactments reminiscent of cheap true-crime shows are the filmic equivalent of a polo shirt and khakis: blandly acceptable but uninspired.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The story that is told here, with such heartbreaking clarity, is an important one, but it is hard to watch.
Sung mainly by real-life folk musicians Joe Purdy and Amber Rubarth, the songs lend the film an emotional resonance that the forced dialogue often struggles to achieve.

Krill and Linder have an understated delivery, common to the mumblecore genre. Although this sometimes works against dramatic momentum, it contrasts nicely with - and ultimately heightens - their intimate moments together.
[Specte] plods along ground so familiar, it's easy to see how Daniel Craig could have grown tired of playing James Bond.
We Are Your Friends isn't for everybody. It also isn't the hot mess of an EDM-sploitation flick that many fans of the genre had feared.
Spy finally gives McCarthy the positive showcase she deserves.
To the surprise of almost no one, M. Night Shyamalan has made 80, maybe 85 percent of an entertaining movie. The rest of The Visit, though? Hoo boy!
Black Mass may not be transcendent, but, thankfully, it also isn't Transcendence.
Hollywood wastes billions of dollars each year trying to figure out how to entertain moviegoers. In reality, it's a pretty simple formula: Space travel + '70s-era radio hits = awesomeness.
Then there's Del Toro's turn as Alejandro. Simultaneously tragic and terrifying, it's the type of subtly menacing star turn that should keep him busy throughout awards season.
Just in time for Halloween, Showtime is unleashing one of the creepiest, most depraved characters you'll ever see on television: Warren Steed Jeffs.
The franchise's signature elaborate action sequences are fewer and shorter, making for a more intimate, personal story.

Rather than focusing on the thrilling espionage of the era, director Steven Spielberg and screenwriters Joel and Ethan Coen... uncover the humanity behind a critical moment in history in this dense, well-crafted drama.
Given how much of Pan is frustratingly wrongheaded, the whole thing should have been given the hook long before it ever hit theaters.
This Snow White may not be the fairest of them all, but sometimes, especially during the heat of summer, fair-to-middling does just fine.
The action-comedy American Ultra, equal parts gonzo and ganja, is a breath of fresh, albeit smoky, air.
As bad as Pixels is, you have to hand it to Sandler for finally starring in a summer comedy that's more than just a thinly veiled and even more thinly scripted excuse for a vacation with his buddies.
The whole thing feels like much ado about a nothing.
The reliably classy Rogue Nation, which visits Minsk, London, Havana, Paris and Vienna in the first half-hour alone, concentrates on practical stunts, and the results are spectacular.
There's a decent amount of fun to be had... But considering Marvel's stellar track record and the comedic wonderfulness of its star, Paul Rudd, Ant-Man is more than a little disappointing.
It's refreshing in this summer of supersized, city-destroying mayhem to see a smaller, personal superhero story.
With its dark elves, some kind of lava beast known as the Kurse, and too much time spent walking around in cloaks, the sequel too often feels like watered-down Tolkien.
There's just not enough to the little fellas to warrant an entire movie that, even at just 91 minutes, feels padded.
Magic Mike XXL is what everyone assumed the original would be -- just a whole lotta strippin' -- and it's almost genius in its simplicity.
Once again, Wahlberg proves he's game for anything, and his dedication to the silliness is never less than impressive, even if his John seems dumber this time. (Maybe it's all the weed.)
It's all pretty heady stuff. Literally.
Jurassic World combines enough nostalgia, technical wizardry and nonsensically thrilling moments to make fans of the original feel like kids again.
A fascinating story, the power of which is only slightly diminished by Wilson's high-profile recovery and comeback.
As a summer blockbuster, it's a mod, modest success.
A rousing, gritty spectacle of a movie.

If you want to know Miles Davis' life story, read [Miles - The Autobiography]. But if you want to get a sense of what it was like being around the volatile musician, check out Don Cheadle's explosive, surreal Miles Ahead.
The best Rocky movie since the original.

Structurally, it's pretty similar to Finding Nemo, and plenty of familiar characters turn up. But the animation strides made in the 13 years between movies are remarkable. Finding Dory looks spectacular.
Dwayne Johnson has been waiting for a movie that would allow him to showcase the full breadth of his talents. Central Intelligence is not that movie. But it's a step in the right direction.
The rest of what passes for a plot in this loud, computer-generated misfire can pretty much be summarized as "stuff happens."

Me Before You is so much more enjoyable than it could have -- and probably should have -- been. Amid the patronizing writing and perfectly timed Ed Sheeran songs are some truly entertaining moments between the leads.
The mutants of X-Men: Apocalypse are fighting their greatest enemy yet: sequelitis.
Middle-earth should never feel this middling.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As an alternative for grown-ups looking to avoid the sequels and general noise of summer, The Nice Guys won't finish last. But it could have -- and should have -- been so much more.

As a movie, the debut feature from writers Ben Brewer and Adam Hirsch, directed by Ben and Alex Brewer, isn't much. Although as things deteriorate from dark comedy to simply dark, the trio do manage to elicit a few didn't-see-that-comings.
Holland's webslinger is easily Civil War's best surprise. He projects a genuine sense of awe and wonder in the presence of the other heroes.
In the end, though, it's like the aftermath of any large earthquake: You'll be glad it wasn't any worse while noticing its many faults.
The Huntsman is so muddled, it's easy to feel sorry for Hemsworth, who has to carry the bulk of the movie on his broad shoulders.
The Boss feels less like it came from a fully realized script than from a collection of ideas from a sketch-comedy journal.
As grueling as parts of it are, though, you may not love it. You may not even like it. But, regardless of your politics, you're all but guaranteed to appreciate it.
Eye in the Sky offers a ripped-from-the-headlines look at drone warfare... Most movingly, though, the tense thriller offers a final chance to enjoy the greatness of Alan Rickman.
Affleck and Gadot are impressive in their debuts, but there really are no winners in Batman v Superman. That includes moviegoers looking for anything resembling a good time.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The result is little more than a convoluted slog interspersed with plenty of posturing and brief bursts of run-of-the-mill action.

Race is at its most interesting when it all too briefly looks at the way Owens was received by a segregated America upon his triumphant return. But, just when it finally has something interesting to say, the movie fades to black.
Deadpool may not be the superhero movie we deserve. But, after an onslaught of increasingly formulaic big-screen adventures with ever-escalating stakes, it just might be the superhero movie we need.
There's simply very little reason to get excited about - let alone purchase a ticket for - the earnestly square, real-life rescue drama The Finest Hours.
Beyond its technical feats, the movie's most impressive triumph is how greatly Kaufman, Johnson and Leigh move audiences to care about Lisa.
Very nearly as murky and confusing as what really happened during those 13 hours.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The whole thing is exhausting in a spectacularly satisfying way.
When they aren't focusing on patent law, the remaining hour and 45 minutes strain mightily to come off as wacky, but they're mostly a mess not even the Miracle Mop could clean up.
The Force Awakens is just such an exhilarating experience, it's very nearly everything you could want from such a large-scale spectacle.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It isn't a bad movie. It just doesn't do anything particularly well. Which makes it a whale of a disappointment.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's just a stunning look at professionals doing a job most people would run from and doing it very well.
The resulting film is twisted and amazing, anchored by tremendous performances from Larson and especially 8-year-old Tremblay.

It's one of the ending-est movies I've seen since The Lord of the Rings: Return of the King. Unfortunately, none of those endings feels like a worthy climax for a series of films nearly four years, and more than nine hours of screen time, in the making.
There's just nowhere near as much excitement as you'd expect for a movie all about a place, "millions of exponential deviances away," built by the smartest people in the world.
When it's just Andre and Chelsea, wandering the streets of New York and getting to know each other, Top Five is as good as Rock has ever been on-screen.
The Avengers, we're told, are greater than the sum of their parts. Avengers: Age of Ultron is not. But it still boasts some pretty incredible parts. And one heck of a party.
You just get the feeling that, left to their own devices, [the three leads] could have riffed out a better movie than this.
Considering the restrictions of only telling half a story, though, Mockingjay is as every bit as good as could be expected.
There's no denying that director Christopher Nolan's challenging space odyssey is exquisitely made. He's one of painfully few filmmakers whose every effort fills me with a sense of awe.
Teller is a great conduit for the sort of drive it takes to thrive in such circumstances.
Sure, Birdman is a stunt. But that stunt pays off beautifully.
St. Vincent is all about the voyage, not the destination.
Cold, bleak and brutal, it's easily the moviegoing spectacle of the year.
I found it to be an engaging, gripping look at the ways the atrocities of war can change a man.
The Judge just sort of lays there for a taxing 141 minutes, unsure of what it wants to be.
Most of the heavy lifting is reserved for Affleck and Pike. They're terrific, together and apart, and they'll run you through a decathlon of emotions as they peel back the layers of Nick and Amy.
Although This Is Where I Leave You doesn't work as a whole, there are enough enjoyable little moments to make you feel as if you got your money's worth.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If I Stay never explains whether Mia's is a special case or if everyone who hovers between life and death has that decision to make. And if it's the latter, does that mean your gramps and meemaw simply didn't love you enough to stick around?
The Homesman is an odd, unrelentingly grim look at a largely unexplored subject, but its last 15 minutes or so are a bit of a mess.
Not surprisingly, the acting is first-rate, with the moments between Bridges' Giver and Thwaites' Receiver forming the heart of the movie.
So much could have gone wrong over the years, it's insane that any filmmaker would have tried this. But if anyone could pull it off, it would be Linklater.
Guardians of the Galaxy is just an obscene amount of fun.
That's an awfully long way to go to establish a premise, especially for what little payoff Sex Tape ultimately delivers.
While The Purge: Anarchy has some interesting ideas, like most of its victims, they're poorly executed.
[A] ridiculously entertaining, technologically stupefying sequel that's easily the summer's best blockbuster yet.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Too often, at least during its first half, Tammy feels like a case of been there, done something similar but not quite as over-the-top as that.
Oblivion delivers a blast of midsummer heat to the middle of April. And, unlike many a potential blockbuster, it's full of ambition. Just try not to think about it too much.
Snowpiercer is bonkers in the absolute best way possible.
Slate is truly something to behold.
Even when The Equalizer is in the worst throes of its style-over-substance mindlessness, you'll be hard-pressed to wipe the grin off your face.

The Drop is a small, slow-burning character study stuffed with fully realized, lived-in characters. And it further bolsters the case for Hardy's status as the film world's finest actor whom the average moviegoer still can't quite place.
Malick has a history of confounding moviegoers. But his latest piece of foggy strangeness plays like a two-hour trailer for a more linear 100-hour movie.
So much time is spent justifying the presence of all these cameras that no one bothered to create a single character worth rooting for.
Stripped of such frivolities as plot and character development, Fury Road is two hours of rolling thunder that will leave your inner 12-year-old giggling with glee.
With The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies, Jackson and company manage to stick the landing in a way that should leave fans satisfied with their final visit to Middle-earth.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The story is simply so incredible, and it's presented in such an interestingly old-fashioned way, that it's hard to leave the theater feeling less than inspired.
Hot Pursuit is a hot mess.
It's a teasingly slow build -- part love story, part science experiment -- that makes a few of the movie's twists seem even more surprising.
The victory lap of Furious 7 proves there's still plenty of gas left in the tank.
While the actors are certainly a more pleasing combination, Get Hard leaves a similarly nasty aftertaste.
The unconventional thriller is nearly as full of disillusionment as it is tension and suspense.
It comes across as a more lifeless version of last fall's Keanu Reeves vehicle John Wick.
Screenwriters Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely, who also wrote Captain America: The First Avenger, continue to make Cap the most interesting Avenger outside of Iron Man.
22 Jump Street belongs to Hill and Tatum. Thankfully, their offbeat, odd-couple vibe is still ridiculously entertaining.
Every storyline is more predictable than the first time out.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Fifty Shades isn't ha-ha cheesy fun. It isn't tee-hee quasi-dirty fun. It's terrible. On almost every level.
From start to finish, Kingsman is cartoonish -- or maybe graphic-novelish -- in the absolute best way possible, thanks to its inventive mix of action.
A Most Violent Year proves surprisingly compelling, and it wastes little time living up to its name.
If the whole thing sounds ridiculous, at least Into the Woods is in on the joke.
Cheap, obvious and lazy, The Boy Next Door only gets enjoyably, hilariously awful in its final scenes.

Credit Affleck for keeping these two wildly different ideas and tones in check. The Tehran portions would have been too grim without the humor, and the Hollywood scenes too flippant without the deadly stakes.
12 Years a Slave" is still one of the best movies of the year. It's also one of the most unsettling.
Although Inherent Vice looks good enough to justify the price of seeing it in a theater, it's the rare movie that feels as though it were made to be viewed from a beanbag chair.
Locke is nearly the very definition of ingenuity. And, in the end, you learn a little about concrete and a lot about what it takes to be a man.
"Edge of Tomorrow" is big, loud and undeniably fun.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The exquisitely odd "Under the Skin" feels like a really ambitious student film. That has nothing to do with its quality.
Gyllenhaal anchors Nightcrawler with a gonzo, transformative performance.
There's more creativity and inventiveness on display here than in the rest of last weekend's top 10 box-office draws combined.
Now that's how you make a summer blockbuster!
He's an underappreciated hero brought to life through Cumberbatch's brilliant performance. It may not be Turing-level brilliant, but it's not far off.
Ultimately, this version of The Gambler suffers from the same problem as the 1974 version, which starred James Caan at the height of his James Caan-iness: There's simply no one to root for.
While the story is a wild, eccentric ride, the biggest shock may be just how straightforward Big Eyes is.
Blackhat is a difficult movie to understand.
I'm excited to see where Man of Steel goes, now that it's accomplished its own bit of world building. There's every reason to expect the inevitable sequels will be better.
During Blart's awkward convention speech, a fellow security guard is so inspired, she yells out, "You go Paul Blart!" Yes, Paul Blart. You go. And take everybody involved with this mess with you.
A movie that has precious few moments for grownups.
For the most part, The Golden Circle only tarnishes what had been a very promising franchise.

American Assassin isn't up to Keaton's recent standards. It's closer to the movies he was cranking out while crawling back to the A-list after "Batman Returns." But he still makes the thriller worth a look, if only just.
IT makes for a fun ride. But I still don't know whether that means it's a good movie or if I just really like Stand By Me and Stranger Things.
Good Time isn't helped by the script,
Death Note ... feels like it should break through with mainstream audiences - even those who think manga is a type of fruit.
After four years away, it's far better to have too much of a Soderbergh movie than not enough.
Wind River was one of the best movies I saw at Sundance. Seven months later, it's one of the best movies I've seen in 2017.
There's a sweet innocence to James that makes the comedy feel more human than the outrageous premise would suggest. It helps make "Brigsby Bear" a triumphant celebration of the outsider in all of us.
Raw, emotional, yet ultimately uplifting.
For the most part, though, things play out like horror-movie bingo.
Through it all, An Inconvenient Sequel presents Gore as a Don Quixote figure, rushing not at windmills but toward wind farms.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: My drive to and from the theater came within 10 minutes of Kidnap's running time and delivered nearly as much suspense.
It's nice to see Cruise entering into another risky business and once again performing reckless maneuvers in the sky.
A hypnotic, almost meditative look at love, loss and legacy.
Dunkirk's relatively brief running time, though, means there's rarely a dull moment. Viewers are thrust into the action, and like many of the soldiers, they're left on their own to sink or swim.
Even if you're somehow still on the fence, by the time the stunning War for the Planet of the Apes turns into a variation on The Great Esc-Ape, you'll be beating your chest with excitement and joy.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For long stretches, "Spider-Man: Homecoming" is an above-average young-adult movie with some super powers thrown in.
Just consider it shark weak.

Cars 3 is basically Rocky IV -- minus the geopolitics and that glorious James Brown production number -- with a little of The Karate Kid thrown in, along with pretty much every sports movie cliche ever.
The Last Knight is pretty much everything you'd expect from a Transformers movie. Stuff whizzes by, bursting into flames, in a jumbled blur of random images, noises and good old-fashioned gibberish.
Despite all these connections, no one seemed to realize they were writing a script that, aside from a plane-crash sequence filmed in zero gravity, plays to exactly none of Cruise's strengths.
Throughout its brief 97-minute run time, It Comes at Night seems to be building to something that simply isn't there. If movies were still shown on film, you'd swear the final reel was missing.
Patty Jenkins proves what a talented director can do with a superhero movie. She and Gadot also contribute touches that only women can.
There won't be much middle ground. You'll either be moved and swept away by it like I was or despise it and spend the drive home plotting against whomever recommended it to you.
Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales is so convoluted, it feels like the first seafaring adventure from The Da Vinci Code's Dan Brown.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dragged down by the weight of its many conflicting ideas, "Baywatch" flails about like a drowning victim that's incapable of rescue, ultimately leaving a bloated corpse of a movie washed ashore at the multiplex.
The action scenes are simply stunning, jaw-dropping even, but there just aren't enough of them to overcome Atomic Blonde's lumbering plot.

It's nowhere near as bad as Life, this spring's other alien-running-amok-on-a-spacecraft movie. But for a franchise known for things bursting out of people's chests, this one will barely elevate your heart rate.
Without spoiling anything, there's a scene that very nearly made me lose my dinner all over my laptop.
If you want to be downright floored by Wonder Woman, check out "Professor Marston and The Wonder Women," a decidedly different origin tale.
Black Panther is an important movie that doesn't feel like being forced to eat kale, thanks to car chases, shootouts and subtle bursts of humor.
I'm not certain if Fifty Shades Freed is marginally better than its predecessors, or if I've just grown accustomed to the awfulness of the franchise.
The whole thing is so comically inept, I'm looking forward to James Franco making a movie about its production.
This certain best-picture nominee sounds almost as good as it looks.
While Hostiles may not be the Western we deserve, it's at least within a couple of hours' ride of the Western we need.
It serves as a useful explainer to viewers who aren't comedy nerds as to why the most sought after job by Harvard grads, after doctor or lawyer, is a writing gig on "The Simpsons."
It feels like a half dozen or more recent war movies,
I long to be as free as Hammer is in the scene in which Oliver dances, wildly and gracelessly, to The Psychedelic Furs' "Love My Way."
You wouldn't expect a movie that relies on pay phones, typewriters and Linotyp to be the timeliest entry of the awards season.
I haven't seen Spacey's take on the character, and probably never will, but Plummer's addition was worth every penny.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Chastain and Elba share only about seven scenes, but their chemistry is delightful, and neither is afraid of going all-in.
Employing some good, old-fashioned movie magic, del Toro has crafted a film that borders on sensory overload. It's wondrous, odd and visually arresting from the opening seconds.

A wondrous work of filmmaking, Blade Runner 2049 is something you can get lost inside for darn near three hours. Much like Villeneuve's Oscar-nominated work on Arrival, it's visceral, often spellbinding, even brilliant at times.
It's hard not to at least appreciate the effort of a movie that wears its environmental message, along with its enormous heart, on its little, Ken Doll-sized sleeve.
Aside from a handful of genuinely funny, can't-help-but-laugh moments, though, this trip to the jungle is anything but welcome.
Moviegoers won't learn much about Barnum here - and that's not really the point. The Greatest Showman is the type of spectacle he was known for delivering.
Johnson has crafted such a powerful, screaming geekgasm of a movie.
For a documentary that mostly reflects on events of decades past, The Newspaperman feels remarkably timely when it recounts the Post's battles with the Nixon administration.
movie_title: The Newspaperman: The Life and Times of Ben Bradlee (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A film whose biggest flaw is that it's occasionally too clever? That's yet another surprise in a movie that's overflowing with them.
Justice League is discordant and incomprehensible at best.

For its part, Mudbound is a powerful story about race and class, told by a bold, new-ish cinematic voice in director and co-writer Dee Rees. There were plenty of tears following the Sundance screening I attended.
After the disappointments of 2011's Thor and 2013's Thor: The Dark World, something clearly needed to be done. All Waititi did was deliver Marvel's OMG-iest movie yet.
Sean Baker is so skilled at making ugliness appear beautiful, I'd love to turn him loose on some of my childhood photos.
[Mark Felt] is a ponderous history lesson in which little is learned.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's the filmmaking equivalent of a collective exhale. At least for many of us who believe that all men and women truly are created equal.
It's the best tribute to all-American heroism to come along in a while.
Darkest Hour demonstrates how, considering that everything and most everyone were working against Churchill, it's fairly extraordinary that there's still an England.
While it's a relief to once again see De Niro in a quality project that has nothing to do with Martin Scorsese or David O. Russell,The Wizard of Lies' greatest special effect is Pfeiffer.
What distinguishes The Disaster Artist is that it celebrates drive and, much like an episode of American Pickers, turns trash into treasure.
Snatched isn't a great movie. Large parts of it barely even make sense. But it made me laugh, and that's saying something.
Bad Santa 2 is little more than a string of crude, largely unprintable, one-liners that feel more like they belong in an outtakes reel than a legitimate movie.
Cage grabs hold of the Faulkner character with all his might and won't let go. Again, much like in that Vince Neil video.

Arrival is artsy, emotional and comes across like the result of Terrence Malick having spent a weekend watching Interstellar on a loop. It's full of questions, though, and a definite mindscrew that will leave you thinking about [it].
If you're looking for a moving story, artfully told by a filmmaker on the rise, Moonlight certainly warrants the hype.

There's an awful lot of world building to do in "Fantastic Beasts," so future installments - this is the first of a planned five-part series - should run smoother. But there's already plenty to like about Newt and the gang.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's essentially a soundtrack -- and a good one at that, led by Timberlake and Anna Kendrick, with contributions from Gwen Stefani -- in search of a story.
Prometheus is undeniably gorgeous. It's hard to imagine anything looking better, especially with its brilliant 3-D that's well worth the upsell.
Even as it closely adheres to the Marvel origin story template, it's the studio's most out-there release yet -- and that's saying something after Guardians of the Galaxy.
Inferno? More like infernal.
Is The Birth of a Nation a great movie? No. But it's a brutally effective one.
If The Girl on the Train were a beer, it would be Gone Girl Lite. Sure, it's less filling and watered down. But it will get the job done if you're in a pinch and it's the only thing available.
With Burton calling the shots, there's certainly magic in some of the visuals. But overall, Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children takes its cue from its monsters. It's ultimately hollow.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's just not good. At times, it's borderline embarrassing.

Deepwater Horizon means well. It's both an attempt to explain the root cause of one of the world's worst man-made disasters and salute the heroism that took place on that fateful day. Unfortunately, though, it muddies the waters on both counts.
After a promising start, Bridget Jones's Baby gets more nonsensical as it goes, culminating in a ridiculous race to the hospital that should have embarrassed everyone involved.
Sully is a feel-good look at the surreality of instant fame and what it takes to keep it from changing you.
If you're looking for straight-up blood, guts and gore horror, you'll probably be disappointed. But if you're just in the mood for a shockingly good time, don't miss "Don't Breathe.
Ben-Hur is far from the worst movie of the year. It probably won't even be the worst movie of the month. It's just one of the least necessary.
Pete's Dragon is genial and family friendly. But there's entirely too much setup, precious little action, not much magic, and even at 103 minutes it feels at least 20 too long.
Sausage Party is so wrong, so go-for-broke insane, existing words aren't enough to describe it. Shockrageous comes close. As does horristurbing.
The result is not so much Suicide Squad as Death by a Dozen Disappointments Squad.
You don't buy a ticket for a Jason Bourne movie for its social commentary. You do it for the chases and the carnage. And on those counts -- sweet Margaret, mother of mayhem! -- Jason Bourne delivers.

Feig and company have done just about as well as they could with this nearly impossible situation. And... the ghouls and specters are mostly first-rate. But just as I ain't afraid of these ghosts, I ain't exactly entertained by them, either.
Ever wonder what your pets do while you're at work all day? Me neither. But that's the premise of the thoroughly entertaining The Secret Life of Pets.
There's simply nothing here worth yelling about.

Despite a couple of clever twists, The Wall, from Amazon Studios, is so very intimate, it's the sort of thing you'd be far more likely to enjoy if you stumbled across it on Amazon Prime rather than if you paid to see it in a theater.
There isn't anything particularly magnificent about the Seven or the movie itself, even though it makes for a fun, summery popcorn movie in the early days of fall.
Frozen it ain't. Still, Moana looks fantastic.
Hands of Stone simply never connects in the way Duran's legendary punches did.
Manchester by the Sea is a long, contemplative slice of New England life. It's also a near-lock for a best picture nomination, even though it could stand to lose a good 10 to 15 minutes.
Legend of the Sword is a stylish affair. Not only is it blessed with some visually impressive fight scenes, its wardrobe choices are inspired.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's no swelling music, no histrionics, no eloquent speeches, no impassioned pleas. Loving is as workmanlike as bricklayer Richard. And it's all the better for it.
Worse than occasionally being a downer, Vol. 2 is something Guardians of the Galaxy never was: dull, often for long stretches.
The Fate of the Furious has plenty of callbacks to previous movies for die-hard fans to enjoy, and it's the franchise's most entertaining installment since at least Fast Five.
Director Ben Wheatley, who co-wrote the script with Amy Jump, stages the sensational, real-time carnage as a parody of gun violence, and the result is a wonderful surprise.
For the most part, this Going in Style isn't going much of anywhere, and certainly not in style.
There's just not enough there to sustain interest.
The result is about as good as could have been expected. And it's certainly better than the stage version.
Reilly is jangling with pure electricity ... You'd need something a whole lot more interesting than anything else going on in "Skull Island" to pry your eyes away from him.
It's the Wolverine movie some fans have been waiting for for nearly two decades.
Get out and see it already.

There's a very good 80-something-minute movie trapped somewhere in the sprawling morass of A Cure for Wellness, a movie that's at least an hour too long. But as it is, A Cure for Wellness could serve as a cure for insomnia.
Lego Batman is crammed full of so many gags, both verbal and visual, you can't possibly catch them all in one viewing.

Everyone involved could have saved so much time and energy by charging triple the price for a ticket and combining all three books into one satisfying movie. Or at least one as satisfying as the source material would allow.
The Last Word is unconvincing at every step.
What's the point of assembling such a talented cast if you're never really going to let them act?
Miss Sloane is a gripping tale of gamesmanship, dirty tricks and backroom shenanigans. In the end, it isn't entirely believable, but it's mighty entertaining nonetheless.

What should have been fertile ground for a movie -- what it's like when you're a star famous for something that happened decades ago -- contains less insight on the subject in two hours than any single episode of Netflix's Bojack Horseman.
The fashion designer-turned-filmmaker has written and directed a stunning, visually stylish thriller-inside-of-a-thriller about intimacy and revenge. It's also a likely best picture nominee.

The movie works even if you only have a passing knowledge of the Star Wars universe or haven't seen the original in years. But there are several enjoyable callbacks and some eye-popping surprises for die-hard fans.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sing is undeniably fun. The screening I attended even quite literally had children dancing in the aisles.
Jackie paints a chilling portrait of the former first lady, spectacularly portrayed by Natalie Portman, in the moments and days after her husband's assassination in Dallas.
Washington's direction leaves Fences feeling powerful yet inert.
Passengers offers up some very cool ideas, impressive special effects and important ethical questions. But it just can't overcome the creepy awfulness of that one, easily fixable distraction.
You know exactly where Why Him? is going from the opening moments, but there are some filthy curves and gonzo detours along the way.

It's a raw, revealing, hairy-warts-and-all look inside their lives and the Beverly Hills compound... they shared. And it serves as a fitting eulogy for both, only occasionally coming across as more heartbreaking than heartwarming.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hidden Figures may be the most entertaining civil rights movie I've ever seen.
Patriots Day is too little. There's too little new information, too little character development and too little reason for it to exist.
A film for casual lovers of modern architecture and aficionados, both.
Marveling at the strangeness of it all, I was nevertheless engaged.
When the best thing about your movie is its unfamiliar location, you know you have a problem.
With its desperate -- would that it were ironic -- titular exclamation point, Aronofsky announces nothing more than bombast, and delivers exactly on that promise.
In many ways a complex exploration of the twin challenges of artistic creation and parenting, [the film] nevertheless strays distressingly from the real facts of the case.
Hall, who also wrote the script, takes his time setting up characters and situations, allowing his actors room to create meaningful relationships that earn dramatic payoffs.
It's a solid film and very entertaining, with good performances throughout, but too often marred by expositional stretches filled with on-the-nose dialogue.
By the time the film ends with Scotty's 91st birthday, we emerge feeling simultaneously soiled and invigorated.
movie_title: Scotty and the Secret History of Hollywood (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Both social drama and thriller, Most Beautiful Island is a breathtaking study in how expendable the vast hordes of humanity appear to certain segments of the ultra-rich population.
Whether in the past or the present, Jane Goodall has never looked better.
There is a light touch to the mise-en-scène that lends the story a jaunty feel, however off-beat the plot. I love the peculiarity of it all, even as I balk at some of the tonal inconsistencies.
There are only so many words in the language one can use to describe excellence ... but rest assured ... that when I call Easy Living a perfect gem of a movie, I mean it.
It may not be particularly original, but the details are well-realized, and the film moves along at a brisk pace. A minor King adaptation, perhaps, but a good one.
Things happen - some severe, some less so - and life goes on. And always there is Olshefski, a one-man film crew who captures it all and distills it for our narrative pleasure.
Despite it's problems, It is a lot of fun until it forgets to be interesting.
It is not just the fact that Sonia suffered ... Rather, it's those details plus the delightfully ordinary quality of who she is today that makes her trajectory so extraordinary.
Kudos to Lipitz and her team, and kudos, especially, to Blessin, Cori, Tayla, Gari, Paula and the rest for their incredible journey.
This movie tells us to beware and to be afraid, lest these magnificent creatures go the way of the Dodo.
With a solid cast and a mostly strong script, Crown Heights delivers the dramatic goods in this riveting tale of a man imprisoned for a crime he did not commit.
Slow, subtle, yet ultimately mesmerizing, Cameraperson is a very personal testament to one exceptional filmmaker's love affair with her profession.
The food looks good. How could anyone resist?
Bleak stuff, but riveting.
'Everyone is a suspect,' as the tagline reads. Too bad no one cares.
Beautifully shot and edited, the movie does justice to its subjects. Still, it has [a] promo-video quality, at times ... that detracts from its perfection.
At least the ultimate message is a positive one, and the villains get their comeuppance, but this is rough stuff, indeed.
Whatever its occasional flaws ... Human Flow must be seen, reminding us of our common, if fractured, humanity.
I just wish it were enjoyable, rather than merely disgusting.
Strad Style, a new documentary from director Stefan Avalos ... tells a remarkable true-life story about one man and a seemingly impossible dream.
It's ethnographic filmmaking with a culinary twist, both informative and enticing.
It's an odd movie, for sure, but that's Kaurismäki for you. Sui generis, he imbues every frame of the film with his own particular quirky sensibility.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beloved and admired, Turner has led a full life, and Dealt is a fitting tribute to his many accomplishments.
In addition to the great camerawork, I loved the filmmakers' dry, sardonic method of storytelling.
Told in a purely observational style, without talking-head interviews (though with some voiceover), the movie is remarkable for the deliberate patience of its camera aesthetics.
Depressing as the subject can be, the film, itself, is a beautiful work of art.
Brilliant and tragic, This Is Congo will break your heart.
If you like David Bowie, you will like David Bowie: The Last Five Years.
movie_title: David Bowie: The Last Five Years (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully photographed and edited, Island Soldier offers a fitting tribute to its subjects.
Bombshell is a much-needed corrective to the historical record, updating Lamarr's biography so that we fully understand her contributions to our world past and present.
By the end ... Kohn cracks the façade of surface bonhomie, and is able to probe the depths of Bolletieri's regret. It's a remarkable achievement, and a damn fine movie.
Cocaine Prison speaks documentary truth to power as sharply as any work of investigative journalism. That's quite the cinematic rush; who needs actual drugs?
It's the end of the world, and we sure do know it, but in this umpteenth version of the apocalypse, I am dying from ennui.
As he demonstrated in Tangerine, Baker has a fine way with actors. Here, he is especially good with children. Brooklynn Prince, as the six-year-old Moonee, is astonishing.
Sohn proves an extremely able documentarian, inserting herself among participants on all sides of the debate, from the police to activists and beyond.
The Big Sick stars Nanjiani as himself (or a version thereof), joined by Zoe Kazan (Ruby Sparks) as Emily. Together they have a genuinely sweet chemistry.
At over two hours, the movie drags a bit towards its finish, but still remains a strong tribute to Jackman as Logan, bidding him a fond farewell as he exits the series.
The Franco brothers bring the same creative energy to their project that motivated Wiseau in his own endeavor. The difference is, they have talent.
Much to my surprise, given my initial reaction to the story, I found myself crying at the end.
Movies need a script, first and foremost, and this one ... never quite comes together, though there is nevertheless a lot to admire in the attempt.
An alternately delightful and heartbreaking mockumentary romp of a biopic, I, Tonya features a mesmerizing performance by Margot Robbie.
Like, love or hate his movies, Paul Thomas Anderson is a filmmaker of uncompromising vision.
Mixed tones can, and do, work, but a mixed bag is a problem.
It's a truly fascinating film ... that will make you scratch your head in wonder that this was the only prosecutorial response to the financial misdeeds of the last decade.
See it for a lesson in what freedom of the press entails, and a call to action to change the world of today. Make America great again, indeed!
All in all, this is one of the most life-affirming documentaries I saw in 2017.
There's so much good here that, by the end, I forgave the faults and just had the good time I was meant to have.
With writing and direction this smart, Lady Bird is a joy to watch.
This is truly a remarkable work of documentary storytelling, raw, intimate and subsequently quite profound.
As The Blood Is at the Doorstep demonstrates, real people - and by extension, all of us - suffer when we accept the status quo. We can't walk away.
movie_title: The Blood Is at the Doorstep (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With a script that subtly explores the realm of emotional conflict, and powerful performances from its ensemble of actors, the movie is a gentle tour-de-force about trauma and healing.
For most of the film, Radcliff and Wolkstein manage their combination of elliptical narrative and shrewd revelation of secrets with great skill.
While the movie's dramatic arc is small, at the end of its 88 minutes we emerge refreshed, as if from an engaging dinner party spent with beloved (if cranky) old friends.
As a portrait of an eccentric, wealthy clan that struggles to remain on top as their world crumbles, Happy End is another strong entry in the Haneke canon.
Linklater's deft touch seems to have left him for this project.
Treat yourself to a delightful experience of less than 80 minutes by immediately watching this film in whatever manner suits you best (I'm going to buy it on Blu-ray).
The total is very much the sum of its terrific parts, although the film could, in all honesty, be a little shorter.
The characters more than hold our interest, and their ghoulish pas-de-deux makes good viewing.
I was unfamiliar with Ovidie's other work prior to watching Pornocracy, but based on her skills as a documentarian, I look forward to seeing what she does next in this new career.
movie_title: Pornocracy: The New Sex Multinationals (Pornocratie, les nouvelles multinationales du sexe) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One of the best aspects of the movie is Barker's close access to his subjects.
Their Finest is that thing you didn't think you needed - yet another World War II story - yet are so happy to have found.
Everyone is good ... and the ensemble, together with Volpe's fine script and expert direction, make this vital tale soar.
Wang packs a lot of information - three years! - into this brief, but sharply observed little jewel, and all of it of consequence to the world today.
I usually love Payne, but his bloated Downsizing (all 135 minutes of it) needs trimming all around.
The topper for me is the ending, however, which blatantly states everyone's intentions to make a sequel, and more. Really? I, for one, have already had enough.
Both a personal documentary and a profound meditation on race in America, Strong Island ... takes the viewer on a harrowing journey through crime and lack of punishment.
Though at times nakedly exploitative, Below Her Mouth is nonetheless a powerful drama about two people falling deeply in love; beautiful erotica doesn't get much better.
Moonlight is a powerful film, exquisitely made, that tells a story of how love can heal all wounds, especially if that love comes from an unexpected place.
Wonder Woman is a solid piece of work, well worth watching, and hopefully a harbinger of better things to come from DC in the near future.
Right from the start, Thor: Ragnarok feels different than its predecessors (Thor and Thor: The Dark World), more comedic in tone and lighter in palette.
Anachronistic as all get-out, though often in the overt cause of racial justice and equality, the movie strains narrative credulity at every turn
The missteps pile up, the tone descends into middlebrow pablum.
Rat Film offers a mesmerizing mix of straightforward documentary storytelling and experimental elements.
While there are a number of things to recommend within this live-action retelling of 'a tale as old as time' ... the movie, as a whole, feels strangely inert.
There is just enough good material embedded in the excessive padding to appeal to our cravings for more Star Wars.
This is a movie, above all, about loneliness, as well as the particular challenges that women face as they seek personal agency, or even just some form of identity for themselves.
Filled with striking images, excitingly disorienting action sequences and strong performances, Good Times ... is in many ways a marvel of ... low-budget filmmaking.
The result is a poignant profile of a woman who will not go gentle into that good night of rage against the dying light.
It's a great cast ... and there are many fine moments of genuine, moving rapport between them. I just wish the film did them greater justice.
It has its pleasures, but they are guilty, indeed.
Pearlstein asks the big questions, and sometimes the answer is a tear, sometimes a laugh, and always profound.
If you can forget the story, and focus on the action and the leads, however, you may still have a good time. Good luck!
Divided into three chapters ... the movie is a compelling hybrid of personal reflection and observational filmmaking.
Leaving the actors aside, however, the real problem with the film is the way it is shot.
As a declarative statement of the power of self-expression, Burlesque: Heart of the Glitter Tribe is a resounding success.
movie_title: Burlesque: Heart Of The Glitter Tribe (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The story is a typical quest journey ... Along the way, our heroes learn moral lessons while cracking jokes and singing songs. Predictably, all gets worked out at the end.
Bearing witness to the torture and/or killing of ... animals is a particularly oppressive task, yet must be done.
Every scene is both light on its feet and weighted with potential import; we never know what is leading where until we're at our destination.
The joy of this movie is how Craig breathes new life into a cinematically commonplace narrative.
What makes The Last Animals especially powerful is the manner in which Brooks examines the human cost of the killings.
Disney has given us a wonderful Thanksgiving present, to be savored by all. I'll take seconds (and maybe thirds), please!
New Zealand Director Annie Goldson ... constructs a brilliant procedural thriller, filled with sharp commentary from a slew of talking-head experts.
movie_title: Kim Dotcom: Caught in the Web (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Everyone here is capable of more than this (maybe not the directors, however), though I can't imagine it hurts a lot to earn a paycheck this way, and maybe that's the appeal.
The film truly fascinates, but it's a bit of a train wreck ... Perhaps that's its appeal. Whatever the reason, I found myself glued to the screen, unable to look away.
Dismaying, disquieting, distressing, Mommy Dead and Dearest is above all profoundly cinematic.
When the film slows down enough for the dialogue to sink in, we realize that the story, such as it is, has been cobbled together from all previousStar Wars films combined.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the surface inaction ... there are currents of deep emotional distress that roil just below, like a deadly iceberg about to strike.
If it stumbles a bit from a burden of overly expositional passages ... it nevertheless packs a powerful enough dramatic punch that resonates long afterwards.
From its exuberant opening musical number, set atop a traffic-jammed Los Angeles freeway overpass, La La Land announces its intention to win your heart through whimsy.
At 85 minutes, Diverge never overstays its welcome, and proves, time and again (remember: time travel), that low-budget science fiction can more than deliver.
It is a film to be watched and discussed, now and until we achieve real peace.
With its fractured, elliptical narrative, Kissing Candice uses its form to perfectly illustrate its content.
Most of the time Black Panther delivers a masterful new take on the superhero origin story, fresh in its perspective and energetic in its plotting. I highly recommend.
As a paean to the power of self-will and the tolerance of difference, A Fantastic Woman is fantastic, indeed.
[Flaws] aside, this is an otherwise assured debut that is part social-drama, part corporate thriller, and very watchable as both.
Like the mythical Diana (and as the title promises), our heroine is good with a bow, so expect much shooting of arrows and piercing of flesh. In other words, a good time.
Turner can keep his story to himself. Bening and Bell deserve better. Heck, even Grahame deserves better.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beautiful, tragic, but not without joy, Spettacolo is a great film about the search for meaning. Did I dream it? I hope not.
There is serious work being done in The Work, and much good comes of it.
It could feel gimmicky, but doesn't; instead, it is cinematically innovative and deft, and a lovely work of art.
We've seen many "hookers with a heart of gold" stories before, but none like this.
The film is not without its strengths in this early part ... but before long ... whatever originality remained after the borrowed premise is completely discarded.
Captain Sullenberger may not have sought the limelight, but he more than deserved it, and Sully is a fitting testament to his humble courage.
It's good fun ... and if it doesn't reinvent the genre, at least, at 89 minutes, it quits just as it's getting old.
As a meditation on the mechanics of male bonding, Goat ... has a lot to recommend, filled with sensitive performances from its two leads.
Let's call it "The Adequate Seven," then, since it gets the job done, yet is ultimately far short of magnificent.
Call this by whatever name you choose - hybrid documentary, scripted reality, narrative nonfiction, etc. - it's endlessly fascinating, regardless.
Beautifully photographed and perfectly edited, The Islands and the Whales is a powerful, if challenging, documentary that needs to be seen.
If you like your stories obvious, where everything is spelled out for you, then The Girl on the Train might just work. If not ... well, you have been warned.
If calculated catharsis does not annoy you, then The Light Between Oceans could be the late summer movie for you.
Although parts of the film seem almost too clever by half, Moorehead and Benson do a marvelous job sustaining an atmosphere of eerie dread.
The film spans over seven years in the lives of its participants. It's an especially remarkable achievement, given our level of intimacy with the subjects.
Here, we right an historical wrong, looking back at the important ... contributions that a group of three African-American women made to our nation's space program.
Schrader has done the world of cinephiles a real service by bringing these good folks together into one movie; we are privileged to learn from them.
Cammisa and her crew interview many of the dynamic ... folks who fight back ... Theirs are ... the stories in this heartbreaking movie designed to provoke outrage and activism.
Heineman has crafted a film about the barbarism of war, in which ideology blinds its adherents from recognizing the common humanity of others.
Michell knows his way around a camera, and has a fine sense of location ... The entire affair needs a little more energy, however, to raise it above the obviousness of its conceit.
An Insignificant Man ... is a truly exciting work of direct cinema, profiling a mass protest movement that ... has a major impact on the future of India.
ACORN and the Firestorm ... brings us the often sordid tale of the takedown of this once-proud-and-successful agency.
To be brief: there is nothing wrong with The Book of Henry that a good script could not fix.
A pleasant enough diversion, The Hero ... nevertheless sinks into a mire of clichés from which it never quite escapes.
I admired An Inconvenient Truth and find its sequel even more powerful (and necessary).
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fortunately, this is not just a hard-nosed dissection of hardliners. Everyone here is a human being capable of change and growth.
Perhaps the film is not harmless, since if you go, we may then get a Despicable Me 4 (set up, of course, at the end of this one), and that is a sobering thought, indeed.
The good news is that Spider Man: Homecoming is actually a lot of fun ... And at least this is not a pure origin story, yet again.
Even if I found the script, itself, lacking, there is genuine power in the mise-en-scène, and strong visuals that remain with me days after watching the film.
First a pioneer and now an icon, Dolores Huerta is above all a woman committed, as ever, to the many causes she has championed throughout her life.
When it sticks to being a pulpy action homage to the powers of Charlize Theron ... it almost always shoots straight.
Not without aesthetic interest, the movie is still a complete mess, weighed down by an expositional script and extremely mannered performances.
[Director] Amman Abbasi ... pulls no punches in his evocation of hopelessness and despair amongst this particular African-American community in the Deep South.
It's a powerful story, though one cannot help but feel sad at the end, post-decision, to see then-President Obama speak so eloquently about the event.
The key is to not think too much. Remember that.
Fortunately, typecasting or not, Plaza's skills of both comedy and awkwardness are used quite well in Ingrid Goes West a new social dramedy from ... Matt Spicer.
The Wall ... tries very hard to achieve that seriousness of purpose that shouts importance with every spoken word.
Thanks to the talented cast ... and well-choreographed action sequences, there is still great entertainment value here. There's also a lot of wasted opportunity.
Though at first the emotional stakes may seem low, the more one thinks about the movie the more its profound truths resonate beyond its narrative limits.
Cone ... fashions a moving drama that hits all the right - though never predictable - beats on its journey towards an extremely satisfying conclusion.
Whatever issues I may have with the mise-en-scène, I was still deeply affected by the drama, and I expect others to be, as well.
Both Driver and Farahani draw us into this world of small stakes writ large, theirs a moving portrait of a living marriage, quirks and all.
Slowly, through the poignancy of its writing and brilliance of its two leads, Toni Erdmann wins you over, worming its way into your mind and heart both, in equal measure.
There are clear plans for a John Wick: Chapter 3, but unless they refocus on meaningful characters and dramatic conflict beyond slaughter, I will not be there to watch it.
A minor trifle, Table 19 nevertheless manages to be quite entertaining when it sticks to comedy.
Ultimate misfire though it may be, at least it's an artistically ambitious one, almost deserving of another half-star rating. Almost ...
This is a worthy tribute to the folks in Boston who helped solve the case, and well worth watching.
It mostly succeeds ... in advancing the characters' dramatic arcs in interesting ways. I mean, who wouldn't want to watch old friends build a whorehouse together?
As the film progresses ... the inanity of the proceedings begins to take over the comedy, and no amount of performance magic can rescue the conclusion, enjoyably madcap as it may be.
It's a mostly affecting and harrowing thriller that makes up for lack of subtlety with seriousness of intent.
Isn't that the point of these movies? Fast ... and furious? More like boring and irritating.
There's nothing wrong with Poitras wanting to delve further into what makes Assange tick; it's just a half-hearted attempt, diffusing the primary through line.
Mungiu delivers yet another profound, cinematic exploration of ordinary iniquity, brilliantly executed and well deserving of the Best Director Award received at Cannes in 2016.
There is no doubt that Spirit Game: Pride of a Nation is a solidly engaging and informative work of cinema.
movie_title: Spirit Game: Pride of a Nation (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Facts alone do not compelling drama make. When the most moving scenes in a Holocaust drama are when the animals are shot, you have a problem.
The footage is beautifully shot ... The New Siberian Islands, with their stark landscapes and almost unearthly rock formations, are a character unto themselves.
A charming computer animated tale about a little mouse who travels through the woods, rendered beautifully and in rhyme.
What happens when smart people set out to make a dumb movie. They made the movie they wanted to watch, rather than the one anyone else might want to.
What's most interesting about Paper Moon is that it has the tone and timbre of a comedy, but the setting and style of the film are somber and more reminiscent of a European art film.
Epic is a word that suits Hoop Dreams well: The film seems to encompass not just a few individuals' stories, but draw archetypes out of them to personify the larger world around.
Sally Hawkins is eminently watchable, but it's too bad Made in Dagenham feels like it rolled off another kind of assembly line.

Credit this action flick with self-awareness: It doesn't try to dazzle with deep meditations on aging assassins filled with regret. This is a movie devoted to celebrating mayhem, which it does with straightforward flair.
It's hard to think of another movie where so many young performers have so forcefully announced themselves to the world.
Lyrical, poetic and heartbreaking, "Biutiful" is not for everyone. It's a troubling, exquisite vision of human contradictions.

A searing portrait of a corporate culture utterly lacking in human values and the people who are rolled over by it. It's an effective drama, even if writer/director John Wells is occasionally a bit heavy-handed with his us-versus-them shtick.

"Night of the Living Dead" became a seminal film without being a particularly good one. It nudged horror movies away from creepy-but-family-friendly into adult films featuring gruesome violence and nihilistic overtones.
The real reason little ones might not enjoy The Illusionist is that it's simply not intended for them. It's a poignant tale about regret, generosity and ungratefulness.
Part biology lesson, and part slick CGI adventure, Sea Rex 3D makes education cool.
movie_title: Sea Rex: Journey To A Prehistoric World 3D (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Tolerable but forgettable, Gnomeo & Juliet is a halfway clever idea executed with minimal effort and ingenuity. It continuously reaches for the lowest-hanging fruit -- in its jokes, in its animation style and its brazen, narrow appeal to tykes.
The result is a film of wonderful performances but few happenings. It's less pure storytelling than a peek inside a small circle of people who feel authentic and three-dimensional.
Ostensibly a comedy, this movie can't quite decide what it wants to be when it grows up.
It's a good, engaging movie - great-looking, too, with top-notch photography and production design - but it tends to fall apart when you start kicking the tires and peek under the hood.
A film that's steeped in sorrow, but watching it is a joyful experience - at least for those who appreciate finely drawn characters from fabulous actors who invest them with heft and heart.
This mush-brained psychological thriller is Ingmar Bergman's Persona as interpreted via Fight Club, pressed through the sieve of a high school drama class festering with personality conflicts.
It succeeds as a comedy of manners and observation, though it errs in presenting us with a wide array of interesting characters, and then selecting the least compelling among them to drive the story.
This touching and quirky Australian short is about the things that just don't fit. The imagination and animation, especially in the finale, are dazzling.

This movie is like a fancy sundae, a concoction of sweet thrills and empty calories. We shouldn't take too long admiring it, because it'll melt if we do. Just scoop it up, enjoy the sugary rush and smile.

Tron is at once a supremely silly movie and a groundbreaking one. It's best seen as the maiden voyage of an expedition that has led us to wonders like Gollum from the Lord of the Rings movies and Avatar.
The Fighter is a true anomaly: A moving drama about two brothers in which boxing is merely a backdrop for their familial tussles.

Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling give tender, nuanced performances in the most authentic portrayal of romance we've seen in a long time - its hopeful, giddy beginning and its stagnant, fracturing end.
Occasionally self-indulgent and silly, the sequel is an undeniably entertaining flick, a cornucopia of eye candy and family-friendly violence.
An aggressively awful movie that's much, much dumber than the average kiddie flick.
Remake, re-imagining, call it what you will - True Grit is the Coen brothers' best movie in a decade.
Straight from the school of Inspirational Tales from History, what it lacks in novelty it makes up for in executing this type of movie-making about as well as it can be done.

I can't say I really enjoyed myself watching Hiroshima mon amour. Resnais' style is deliberately off-putting - the thought of entertaining an audience seems repugnant to him - but I respect the film for its audacious storytelling.
It's a jokey, flirty pile of wink-wink to let the audience know these two heterosexual actors are pretending to be in love just to get a laugh.
Nowadays, we would call this the purview of a low-rent TV sitcom. Watching it play out 70 years earlier with top-flight stars doesn't make it any more palatable.

It feels less like a coherent narrative than a series of vignettes in which the characters say improbably witty things and act in ways that aren't tethered to rational behavior. We sense them performing for the camera.
That's why I keep coming back to My Bodyguard: It continually reveals new layers of truth about what it's really like to be a teenager, whether an outcast, a bully or the bullied.
An exquisitely acted slice of cinematic comfort food, Driving Miss Daisy marked the coda of one great acting career and the rise of another.
Ed Helms and company seem like they're mocking middle-America vanilla-ness, which is ripe for mocking, but they also want to embrace it with a cuddly ending.
No Highway in the Sky is notable for its depiction of airline travel and disaster-film dynamics, each then in emerging stages. Unfortunately, it's not very skilled at either one.

Wants to be epic in scope but ends up feeling like ham-fisted CliffsNotes version of a man's life. The film loiters way, way too long on Frank Wead's early days as a hell-raising test pilot, then skips ahead through long sections of his life.
These movies are sheer silliness, improbable roadway mayhem interspersed with obligatory fistfights and gunplay, all coated with a noxious layer of adolescent macho posturing.
An uncompromising look at alcoholism at a time when addiction was considered a personal failing to be swept under the rug of polite society.

Like Thor himself, the movie is overly puffed up and self-serious. But the character experiences a satisfying arc of change, turning into a genuinely heroic figure whose magic hammer does some serious smiting.
After an overly mushy first half, the movie redeems itself with a second act that is decidedly dark and dreary and an extended air combat sequence that's still amazing nearly 70 years later.

A competently-made animated film crafted specifically for the toddler set, who may enjoy the bright colors and boingy action. Older kids and parents will find themselves, if not quite bored, then only modestly engaged.
The comedy is broad and predictable enough that I pretty much always saw it coming - and yet I still found myself laughing when the jokes arrived right on target.
In an era when Hollywood loved cut-and-dry endings, Tokyo Joe is notable for the way Humphrey Bogart's character never steps fully into the light, or out of it.
Stranger Tides at least has a story that is relatively comprehensible and keeps its roster of main characters trimmed to a manageable level.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Flawed, but in an era of safe filmmaking with stories and characters tied in uniformly neat bows, The Beaver operates outside the box ... and then it kicks the box down the street.
Alec Guinness' sharp bird nose and watery eyes helped him play characters who were misfits on the margins of society. He made for a kindly but stubborn rebel in the Ealing comedies.
movie_title: The Man in the White Suit (1951)

movie_review_blurb: Lacks the novelty of the original, which found a sweet spot in between martial arts and goofy animated critters, and milked it for every last laugh. This one feels like leftovers that have curdled.
The natural state of humanity is to be kind to each other, Steinbeck says - holding George and Lennie up as an imperfect example.

An engaging character study, solidly handled by rookie writer/director Dan Rush, that gives a little insight into the sort of career Ferrell might have had if he hadn't made his bones playing nincompoops and running around bare-assed.

A shallow, cynical bit of movie-making, certainly never boring but rarely engaging on either an intellectual or visceral level. The cast of mostly twentysomethings posing as teenagers does an awful lot of pouting and strutting.

Russell Brand creates a distinctive character based on his own persona, rather than trying to mimic Dudley Moore. He is by turns hilarious and touching, with an inner core of sweetness we haven't seen from him before.
Some nice performances, but the sad, harsh truth is that two hours spent inside a Trappist monastery turns out to be achingly dull.

It's a rather uncharacteristic role for Gregory Peck, in that there's not a trace of cuddliness or Atticus Finch-esque nobility to Frank Savage. He's a man with a job that needs to get done, and everything in his existence is subservient to that goal.

A simple two-act story: Prelude to war, and the war. The former is concerned with a lot of British derring-do and priggish behavior. The latter consists of battle scenes with a lot of kinetic energy but not as much emotional punch as they should have.
Less a rumination on free will than a potboiler with some intellectual pretensions, The Adjustment Bureau is a pleasant enough middlebrow mind trip.

A neon-colored, sun-baked fantasia that's part Western spoof and part surrealist jag through the desert with Johnny Depp as our theatrically unhinged, reptilian tour guide, Rango is anything but your standard kiddie animated flick.

Tony Curtis' acting is borderline awful. His famous Bronx accent bleeds through his faux Southern one like a bloody shirt, and he continually grits his teeth in a failed attempt to show the character's self-loathing.
Feels like an amalgamation of other animated films' styles and storylines, assembled by a marketing department bent on hitting a demographic sweet spot rather than artists following their muse.
A sword-and-sorcery spoof from the Pineapple Express crew that, like that ode to inhaling, isn't nearly as funny as it seems to think it is.
A strange, dreary and stubbornly un-entertaining reboot of the fairy tale, where ancient forebodings about creatures of the night are used as grist for the mill of angsty teenage lust.
The humor is generally in well-traveled terrain with a generous helping of penis jokes, but somehow having it coming out of the mouth of a little green man makes it fresh and ironic.
More a daffy comedy than a true newspaper movie.
Murphy's War has the bones of a great movie but forgets to add the flesh.
The rare thriller that engages us with its protagonist and his plight, even if the sci-fi part of the story never really seems to add up.
Less a plot-driven movie than a meandering look at the nomadic men who make their lives on the high seas for various reasons.
A wonderfully acted little drama about a tight-knit group of ordinary people whom we get to know and like despite their quirks and flaws.

While recognizing that it's not any sort of great piece of acting by Robert Mitchum or a searing portrait of war, if one accepts The Enemy Below as an action-filled war movie, it's thoroughly entertaining stuff.

The story sounds ridiculous -- hokey, even. But James Gandolfini, Melissa Leo and Kristen Stewart inhabit their roles with such an unstudied validity that we don't for a moment think of them as movie characters behaving for the camera.
Affleck gives such a confident, authentic performance - both in front of and behind the camera - that the crime genre's familiar tropes take on a lively, at times electric quality.
The cinematography by Henri Alekan is simply astonishing in its spare yet lyrical quality.
Ed O'Bannon and John Russo may have intended The Return of the Living Dead as a comedy, but it's just too damn gory, too scary and too good to be dismissed as a zom com.
movie_title: The Return of the Living Dead (1985)

movie_review_blurb: The revelation the whole thing was a sham cannot repair the damage Joaquin Phoenix has done to a once-promising career. I'm Still Here is a practical joke, and not a very good one, either in conception or execution.
I didn't really buy the words coming out of the mouth of a precocious 17-year-old, I still enjoyed knowing somebody uttered them.
The Seventh Seal is a film not about the end of time, but the silence between man and God.

Writer/director David Michôd constructs a slippery narrative that consistently fools the audience about where the movie is heading. The result is part Donnie Brasco, part Godfather and more than a little bit Ma Barker.
This is the movie version of comfort food from your grandmother: Familiar, wholesome and rather bland.
An after-school special on steroids, Legendary is the story of a fake wrestler teaching his kid brother how to be a real wrestler.
It's fascinating to note that Richard is almost always portrayed by middle-aged actors - Olivier was 48, and actually comes in at the low end. In reality, Richard was only 32 when he died.
The 1958 film, made six years after publication of the book, is a faithful adaptation - virtually a word-for-word copy of Hemingway's dialogue and prose - that is not without its faults.
movie_title: The Old Man and the Sea (1958)

movie_review_blurb: James Mason's portrayal of Captain Nemo is a hard-edged, dramatic performance, with no winking nods or cartoonish layers. You could transport Mason whole into a much darker movie with R-rated violence, and he would fit like a glove.
To put it bluntly, Mystic Pizza is more or less a movie version of a soap opera, layered in with some quirky humor and gigantic '80s hair.

Limelight seems stuck in time, even for 1952. The un-ironic pathos and sentimental humanism seems almost quaint in the post-Hitler world. But that's Chaplin for you - a man who lived by, and wrote, his own rules.

This 1972 German film eschews narrative for hallucinatory images and long takes that plunge you into the whirlpool of the main character's madness. It's less storytelling than a visually disturbing fever dream.
movie_title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God (Aguirre, der Zorn Gottes) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: Becket is a terrific example of the historical play or novel turned into a cinematic drama crackling with whip-smart dialogue. I imagine actors must go mad with delight when they read a script that has page after page of dialogue this good.
The tone in many ways reminded me of Top Gun, which would come out three decades later: Callow young pilots learn to rely on their fellow fighter jocks and act as a team.
movie_title: Men of the Fighting Lady (Panther Squadron) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: The Sugarland Express is not terribly original - Bonnie and Clyde, Badlands and The Getaway are indelibly marked in its DNA - but shows an already dazzling young filmmaker honing his skills and vision.
I really enjoyed the dark atmospheric cinematography, and a wonderful, large cast. The movie kind of wanders away from itself in the second half, but I mostly enjoyed the places where it rambled.

Despite a few slow patches, it is loaded with gut-busting laughs. After its much brainier predecessor, though, it feels like a well-meaning kid forced to follow in the footsteps of his genius older sibling.
Robert Duvall got his start in movies nearly a half-century ago playing a lonely, misunderstood recluse, Boo Radley, in To Kill a Mockingbird, and Get Low completes the circle.
The American is a spare, tightly-wound thriller that is less the story of a man who kills for a living, than what that life has extracted from his soul.
Nanny McPhee Returns may not be the most original material, but compared to so much of the dim-bulb rubbish churned out for tots, it practically qualifies as enchanted.

This movie is like the entirety of American youth culture crammed into a single package: It's about love, alienation, video games, comic books, chord-grinding indie/punk rock, texting, dead-end jobs and evil ex-boyfriends.
I admired Julia Roberts' grasping for something meatier, but this film sticks her with an unrelatable character that even her coltish smile can't beautify.
Like the rest of Stone's oeuvre, it's about as subtle as a sledgehammer. But his filmmaking style is like heavy metal: When he hits the right chords, nobody plays with as much power or brash energy.

It's interesting that the film, a sequel to Ridley Scott's 1979 atmospheric horror-film-in-space, is generally regarded as an action movie. Go through it, and you'll realize the character and dialogue scenes far outweigh the kablooey stuff.
