It is hard to imagine a better tribute to this victory of survival than Nolan's spare, stunning, extraordinarily ambitious film.
Even for fans of McDonagh-and I am certainly one-Three Billboards is a revelation, and among the very best films of 2017.

Does Coco rise to the heights of Pixar's very best work? No. But it is a generous, heartfelt film, full of color and music, one that offers a timely Thanksgiving tribute to the intergenerational importance of family.
Eggs, water, and-yes-sex all play crucial and overlapping roles in director Guillermo del Toro's The Shape of Water, an adult fairy tale that is at once deeply familiar and utterly original.
The Last Jedi probably does the best job of any Star Wars film of capturing the allure of the Dark Side and the spiritual turmoil that would lead to-and also result from-its embrace.
The Post is so on the nose for the political moment that at times it almost seems it might have been produced not by Spielberg, but by some high-end marketing firm.

Until the final 15 minutes of its deceptively short hour-and-a-half running time, Hero is a marvel, one of the best films to be released in the United States this year. It concludes, however, on a note both emotionally unsatisfying and morally idiotic.
Cuarón's Prisoner of Azkaban, while a touch less faithful to the details of Rowling's oeuvre, captures far better its mood, the constant sense of wondrous discovery and lurking danger.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Where KB1 had the pace of an ADHD six-year-old on a sugar high, KB2 has been Ritalinized, its tempo slowed to a crawl in self-conscious, and self-defeating, imitation of Sergio Leone. It's two hours that feel like five.
Reynolds is the perfect role for Day-Lewis, who is likewise famous both for his obsessive meticulousness and for the lengthy sabbaticals he has used to recharge between films.
A sequel so awful it needs to be described in detail to be believed. Therefore, a spoilereview.
Branagh's retelling of the classic Agatha Christie tale is visually sumptuous yet otherwise inert, a series of what are essentially cameos by performers far too gifted to waste their time like this.
Put in your metaphorical earbuds, turn the key in the ignition, and enjoy the cinematic highlight of the summer so far.
Michael Bay has promised that this is the last Transformers movie he will direct, which is no small relief. It will not, alas, be the last Transformers movie.
Corporate synergy, as they say, is a cruel mistress.
Scorsese's abiding passion and respect for his source material are everywhere in evidence. For once, perhaps, they are a little too great.
Despite its generally genial, boys-will-be-boys air, there are a few scenes and storylines that lodge in the mind unpleasantly.
To all of the shocking developments of the last 12 months, we may now add yet one more: M. Night Shyamalan has made a good movie.
A movie this bad deserves to have its flaws enunciated clearly...
Beautiful, evocative, and ultimately heartbreaking.
It's not a film you'll soon forget.
It is an intimate tale of triumphs and setbacks, but also a story of tremendous consequence.
It is witty, charming, and by the end surprisingly moving.
As a referendum on gentrification in Brooklyn, the movie can occasionally be a bit tedious. But the entire cast is strong, especially Michael Barbieri.
A small but likable film.
In its latter half the film... gradually runs out of ideas, and out of steam.
The film is nicely structured, gently witty, and it boasts an excellent cast
Kong: Skull Island is just good enough-the sharp allusions, the moments of wit and warmth supplied by Reilly's long-abandoned airman-to make one wish it were better.
A film nowhere near as revelatory as the original, but in some ways more satisfying, the proper closing of a tale that had been left open-ended.
As Baby Groot's companions battle the tentacular horror in the background, we're treated to the delightful spectacle of the mini-veggie juking his way through "Mr. Blue Sky" in the opening credits.
Among the less-noted cardinal rules of cinema is that any movie that takes the title Unforgettable will prove to be anything but.
This may not be a movie that reinvents the wheel. But it's one that knows how to make it roll.
The subtitle of the new Pirates of the Caribbean movie is "Dead Men Tell No Tales." The moral of the movie, alas, is that the same cannot be said of dead franchises.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The final big action sequence, as now seems always to be the case, is a messy and overwrought CGI extravaganza. But at least the movie that precedes it involves actual characters-likeable ones, even!-exhibiting recognizable human emotions.
Did she? Didn't she? Much as I enjoyed My Cousin Rachel at times, by the end I was no longer sure that I particularly cared.
An utter gas, a fast and very funny superflick that inserts Spidey into the larger Marvel Cinematic Universe without ever losing sight of what makes him unique and beloved.
Chazelle has reinvigorated the big-screen musical by embracing the present while paying tribute to the past, by balancing irony and innocence, novelty and nostalgia.
Welcome back, Pixar. You were sorely missed.

Zhang's moments of visual splendor-a battalion of hot-air balloonists, the queen-monster and her royal guard of fan-frilled monstrosities-are weighed down by a script and performances almost dutiful in their dullness.
Until its final act, Tomorrowland plays as a lighthearted techno-conspiracy thriller, Men in Black by way of Nancy Drew with the occasional whiff of Philip K. Dick paranoia and Pixarian high concept.
Though Elysium is a testament to Blomkamp's extraordinary skill as a visual filmmaker, it does not speak nearly so well for his gifts as a writer.

The only participant to emerge with its reputation intact--though not its paint job--is the Shelby Mustang muscle car, which also delivers the film's most nuanced and psychologically complex performance.
A compact masterpiece of storytelling that brims equally with ambition and humility. It is, by a wide margin, the best film I have seen so far this year.
A genial, knowing throwback-a reminder of that stylish, half-imaginary era that thrived in Hollywood before Mad Men came along and pickled it in gin.
A movie with a PG brain and a NC-17 body count, unsuitable for audiences of any age.
Ethical exploration or exploitation? In the end, I come down reservedly on the former side: the work done here by Jackman, Gyllenhaal, and especially Villeneuve is simply too powerful to ignore.

Rush is not a particularly deep film. But more importantly, it is not a film that mistakes itself for deep. And this self-knowledge makes Rush, in some ways, a wiser film than many that aspire to loftier goals.
Unfolding as a series of terrifying object lessons in Newtonian physics, the movie lends new meaning to the phrase "spatial geometry."
Whether or not you find it an inadvertent parable of the political moment (I do), Captain Phillips is a terrific film.
Yes, this is the point in the summer when I outsource my critical judgment to my kids.

12 Years a Slave is likely the most painful, clear-eyed feature ever made about American slavery. In that light, it almost seems faint praise to add that it will also likely prove to be the best film of the year.
And so another awards season brings another film (adapted from another international bestseller) offering up the unrelated and uncontroversial lessons that reading is good and Nazis are bad.

Now the violence is not merely physical, but existential. Far from having won her freedom as promised, Katniss is now imprisoned in a false public narrative-supporter of the Capitol, lover of Peeta-from which she may never escape.
Be forewarned: Whether through ego, avarice, or unchecked enthusiasm, Jackson has wandered deep into the realm of fan fiction.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Wolf of Wall Street is a magnificent black comedy: fast, funny, and remarkably filthy.
Her is a remarkably ingenious film but, more important, it is a film that transcends its own ingenuity to achieve something akin to wisdom.
The story unfolds with an earnestness so implacable that on the rare occasions when a bit of humor sneaks into the proceedings it feels like an uninvited party guest.
A total gas--even if its message is that we should do as Lego says, not as Lego does.

Surveying the peculiar array of 1980s retreads clustered into release this week, I'm reminded of Marty McFly in Back to the Future Part II, traveling forward in time 30 years to discover that everything is still the same, only worse.
The comedy in The Grand Budapest Hotel is among the broadest yet undertaken by Anderson. But amid the frenzied hubbub, there are intimations of a darker, sadder history unfolding.

Though hardly a must-see, Thor: The Dark World is better than the original: a looser, loopier hybrid of science fiction and fantasy powered by a pair of magnetic performances and leavened with a number of truly witty moments.
Yes, this is the point in the summer when I outsource my critical judgment to my kids.
Allen is a famously hands-off director, and while this method succeeds on occasion, too many scenes in Blue Jasmine betray a directorial negligence.
An unexpected yet irresistible cross between Meatballs and The Ice Storm, The Way Way Back just may be the best movie of the summer.

If you limit your expectations for Jurassic World to "more teeth," it will deliver on that promise. If you dare to hope for anything more-relatable characters, narrative coherence-you'll only set yourself up for disappointment.
A powerful, morally complicated work on an urgent subject. It is a film that deserves-that almost demands-to be seen and argued over.
Committed fans of the musical are likely to have their affections reaffirmed. The less devout, however, may conclude that in this case more is less, and fidelity not always a virtue.
What follows is not a review; it's an autopsy...one long (illustrated!) spoiler.

Though R's mind is nimble in (very witty) voiceover, out loud he can only express himself in a series of groans and grumbles--as touching a metaphor for love-struck adolescence as we may see at the movies this year.
A crafty teaser that presents itself as one kind of film before gradually evolving into another kind altogether. I, for one, enjoyed both enormously.
Stoker is a cunning exercise in transgression. But one can't help but wonder what kind of film Park might have made if he'd had the full creative control to which he's accustomed in Korea.
The animation is first-rate, with moments of genuine visual imagination, and the story, while unremarkable, is entirely adequate.
What is most distressing about Admission is that it serves as further evidence that Tina Fey, despite her dominance of the small screen, has not yet mastered the big one.

A stylish and worthy homage: inventive even as it is derivative, never quite jokey but never taking itself too seriously, and clocking in at an entirely appropriate 91 minutes. Any longer would be unmerciful; any shorter, ungenerous.
Trance is to Danny Boyle more or less as Side Effects was to Steven Soderbergh: an arty spin on a trashy B-movie, engineered to showcase the director's particular gifts.
Shane Black excels at writing witty, self-referential, pop-infused banter, and there is no actor working today who is better suited to delivering it than Robert Downey Jr.
The central problem with Luhrmann's film is that when it's entertaining it's not Gatsby, and when it's Gatsby it's not entertaining.

For all its chasing and falling and fighting-and the movie supplies a great deal of each-Star Trek Into Darkness is at its best when the Enterprise crew are merely bickering and bantering among themselves: less space opera than soap opera.

A film in which the text and subtext-an effortlessly gifted father presses his less-talented son to follow in his footsteps-are in perfect alignment. Alas, only in one of the two does the story end happily.
Crass, flimsily plotted, and self-referential to the point of narcissistic personality disorder. For those willing to tolerate such defects, however, it is also very, very funny.

There's plenty to like in Snyder's hectic, rowdy film. But by the time we reach the bludgeoning excesses of the last half-hour it's hard to shake the sense that this was an opportunity at least partially missed.

Essentially a louder, sillier version of Die Hard, with John Cale standing in for John McClane, a precocious daughter standing in for the plucky wife, and, alas, no one even much trying to stand in for Alan Rickman's deliciously wicked Hans Gruber.
Somewhere, around the hour-and-a-half mark, The Lone Ranger makes the fateful decision not to end. Worse, the movie keeps not-ending for another full hour.

Its visual achievements notwithstanding, Pacific Rim's greatest breakthrough may be that it's the first Hollywood blockbuster to sport a title less descriptive of its plot than of its intended market.
Willis is self-evidently capable of kicking the asses of men considerably younger than himself. But at some point shouldn't he consider an alternative pastime?
The Life Aquatic drifts along at a lazy pace, the occasional encounter with pirates notwithstanding.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Kids will enjoy it, and there are more than enough clever gags to keep parents amused. But the film lacks the tenderness and rich nostalgia that made The Muppets such an improbable delight.
Robert Frost famously mused 'Some say the world will end in fire/Some say in ice.' I prefer Edgar Wright's vision: It will end in a pub.
A movie that is, in the best sense of the word, a Marvel.
Cuarón brought to the Potter franchise a quality curiously missing from the two previous films: magic.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Might it have been better if they'd squeezed the whole book into one movie? Probably. Nonetheless, Mockingjay Part 1 is a fine entertainment, shot through with moments of surprising emotional impact.

Thanksgiving is a time for family and for shirking work, and out of respect for both traditions-and in recognition that I am surely not in the movie's demographic sweet spot-I'm handing the heavy lifting over to my kids, Tom (11) and Alexandra (9).
This is the first portrayal of God I've ever encountered who looked like he could use a good spanking.
The plot of the film is almost willfully convoluted. But it's also largely beside the point, an excuse for quite a few good scenes, most of them equal parts homage and subversion.
What is perhaps most depressing about Jackson's swollen Hobbit enterprise is the way it retrospectively diminishes his Lord of the Rings trilogy.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A stately, sober film, at times uplifting and at others agonizing.
Oscar Isaac has been extremely good in previous roles, but he is an utter revelation as Abel, the quiet power of his performance recalling early Pacino.

The movie's most depressing feature is its naked pandering for overseas box office. If there's one thing worse than appealing to the lowest common American denominator, it's appealing to the lowest common global denominator.
Not only is The Departed not among the best of Scorsese's films; it's not even the best version of this film.
Foxcatcher is among the best movies of the year, but ultimately it seems one better suited for awards than for audiences.

By no means a masterpiece, but a solid genre offering, a portrait of desperate men crammed together and surrounded on all sides by what one describes as "dark, cold death." What better way to escape the midwinter doldrums?
Frequently reactionary, bordering on retrograde, bordering on reprobate. But it's also a tremendous amount of fun.
It's been said that the movie contains 20 minutes of sex; if this is the case, it must contain at least 40 minutes of Ana biting her lip or putting a pencil in her mouth.
The movie is simultaneously conventional and subversive, broad and nuanced, shamelessly manipulative and genuinely moving, a cheap sucker punch and a work of real moral weight.

Whether or not it succeeds will depend on how individual viewers weigh the movie's narrative flaws against the profound appeal of its stars and setting. For my part, it was a reminder that sometimes second best is good enough.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Like its source material, the movie is stylish, profane, intelligent, and eminently diverting. But as much as it is a delight that Dominik has disinterred Higgins's work, it is a mild disappointment that the result is not more substantial.

A dull, generic retread, made far worse by Penn's self-seriousness as an actor, by the banal political pieties he's grafted on as producer and co-writer, and by the presence of a pitifully retrograde female lead role.
Ferrell has stuck to the formulaic farce that made him a star, even as his roles have been shifting from antic instigator to bewildered straight man.

Despite its flamboyant, and at times goofy, fantasy trappings, Noah is firmly anchored by the fierce moral intensity of Aronofsky's vision, which is, if anything, more Old Testament than the Old Testament itself.
The sharp, interpersonal dramedy that made the first movie such a delight is again present in flashes, but not infrequently it is drowned out by the noisy, inevitable need to Save the World.
An A-plus B-movie that at times feels almost like a tone poem to early-'80s excess, a cross between a monster-truck rally and a Plasmatics concert.
Don't even get me started on the aliens, many of whom would have been turned away from the cantina door in Mos Eisley.
Interstellar may be a preposterous epic, but it is an epic nonetheless.
Children of Men founders in its latter moments -- not a lot, but enough. Its failure is less one of plot than of something deeper, a composing idea to undergird the plot.

Whether or not Riggan is in fact possessed of divine abilities-Iñárritu offers contradictory clues along the way-Birdman puts on clear display the indisputable superpowers of its cinematographer, Emmanuel Lubezki.

Godzilla handles everything the military hurls at him: ships, guns, planes, rockets, even a squadron of HALO paratroopers. The only thing that can cut him down to size is being relegated to a supporting role in his very own movie.
I would be remiss not to note that tucked away amid all the existential melodrama is perhaps the most hilarious set piece ever to grace a superhero film.

As a cameo, Jolie's performance might have proven spectacular; but as a protagonist, she doesn't give us enough to hold onto. For all her efforts, she remains yet another special effect, however spectacular.
The result is a cinematic vagueness that makes the film less aesthetic yet more persuasive. This is how dreams really look: like reality, only less so.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The conceit may sound constricting, but Liman (like Harold Ramis before him) gets exceptional mileage out of it, presenting his ever-revolving tale with visual style, narrative velocity, and a wonderful dose of dark humor.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Self-referential irony is hardly a new gimmick, having served as the underlying premise for such franchises as Scream and Austin Powers, but rarely has it been indulged with such fervor.
If it truly takes this long to save the world from the depredations of robots that turn into muscle cars, it may be that the world is no longer worth saving.

The movie is moderately obsessed with the ideal of authenticity, which is a rather awkward position to champion given that it is a calculatedly more-commercial, less-authentic variation of a film, Once, that Carney had already made.
For the next installment, it might be wisest to forgo our own species altogether and make it all-ape. It is, after all, the logical next step in this particular cinematic evolution.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: I can't help but think there may have been a better movie still lurking in his accumulated footage, one that with a mild shift in emphasis might have been titled, more ambitiously, Adulthood.

Now 33 years old, Gyllenhaal is the same age that De Niro was in Taxi Driver and, like him, he is learning to channel an eerie, inner charisma, offering it up in glimpses and glimmers rather than all at once.
Besson has made very, very bad films in the past, but this is the first time he has presented one so idiotic that the only way to properly convey its flaws is to enumerate them.

It may be a mess, but it's an extremely good-natured mess, full of humor and warmth. More surprising still, the very elements that seemed most likely to ruin the movie-the tree-man, the talking raccoon-account for much of its improbable charm.
There are a handful of ways in which A Dame to Kill For actually improves on the first movie. Alas, none are enough to prevent it from being a substantial disappointment.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An amiable diversion, though not a terribly memorable one. Elmore Leonard aficionados longing for a truly worthy sendoff of the master crime writer will have to look ahead toward the upcoming final season of Justified, and cross their fingers.
Fincher is as Fincher does. And what Fincher does better than almost anyone is create moody, meticulously crafted thrillers that straddle the divide between genre and art.
These interwoven tales of suburban parents and high-schoolers--united by the common themes of sex, alienation, and the Internet--amount to a kind of techno-misanthropic Love Actually.
In a sense, it succeeds too well in conjuring its own subject matter: heavy, mechanical, claustrophobic, and unrelenting.
Wearing a beard and a Welsh accent that fits him as comfortably as a well-worn glove, Hardy offers a subtle yet riveting portrait in noble obstinacy.
It's Apatow without the Apatow, all ornaments and no tree.

About the best thing one can say about this fiasco is that Webb has taken only two films to reach the same exhausted, exhausting endpoint that Raimi required three to achieve. It's progress, of a sort.
Never did top that first stunt.
If this movie were a big-band arrangement, it would be a duet for a sax man and a girl singer, but with the soloists in a different key from the band.
Where the film truly excels though is in its sound design. The Babadook is truly a film to see in a well equipped cinema.
Geostorm in a nutshell: a bunch of supposedly connected scenes that don't seem to even know each other and were maybe shot years apart.
Never has watching an on-screen teen trying to lose "it" seemed so empty.
It might be time for Johnny Depp and Tim Burton to start thinking about seeing other people.
Constantly screws up even its own mid-sized ambitions.
Some scripts can be saved by a good cast that delivers the material with as much chutzpah as possible. And then there are some that are simply unsalvageably dreadful.
The film is certainly funny, but the laughs aren't as constant as you'd hope from a film like this.
Sweet without being saccharine and wrenching without being devastating. Frances Ha is a film of many small surprises, but they contain big, satisfying rewards.
A horror movie can be many things, but one thing it should never, ever be is tedious.
An astoundingly sweet, lovable, immensely enjoyable little film that hits all the right notes as you're watching it thanks to its excellent cast.
Fruitvale Station does work, but it's marred by problematic writing and direction.
The key to The Spectacular Now's success is in its insight, empathy, and fantastic performances.
Gives children a legitimately hopeful and enduring lesson about doing the right thing in times of crisis.
movie_title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (Kaze no tani no Naushika) (1985)

movie_review_blurb: You're Next might be one of the most audience-gratifying horror films I've seen in quite a long time, rewarding the viewers as much as it likes to screw with them.
A mixed bag of gorgeous images and sounds trapped in an only partially-developed narrative.
A deceptively slight film, imbuing into its simplistic animation style and sly humor an astounding level of philosophy
Short Term 12 is cinema at its most compassionate, vulnerable, and human.
Continually surprises and engages the viewer even when it's falling apart.
Could've been an inoffensive enough 90 minute feature, but the film insists on garbling the narrative with useless subplots that...bloat the movie beyond the breaking point.
Something must be said for a film that's three hours long and remains this consistently engaging.
Too clinical to have an emotional impact, not romantic enough to engage a standard audience, and not smart enough for viewers looking for an intellectual experience.
One of the most immediately involving science-fiction films in recent memory.
No amount of concentrated analysis can really explain the level of deep emotion that Upstream Color effortlessly evokes.
The seeds of a truly great horror film are here, but they aren't quite developed enough to leave you with something truly memorable.
Instead of searching through the mysteries of the universe, Terrence Malick cuts open his heart for all to look inside.
If any film in [Studio Ghibli]'s filmography has inspired the works of Pixar, it's surely this one.
A startling, beguiling rumination on the slipperiness of mortality and the methods we create to escape the inescapable.
Goodbye World feigns intelligence from the very first frame...hoping that snappy dialogue and charming performances can allow us to forgive its utter lack of ambition or thought
The more Escape From Tomorrow lingers in the mind, the more disturbing and fascinating its implications on modern American culture become.
To watch Spirited Away feels like a special gift. It is a film of such startling imagination, originality, intelligence, and emotion that I feel inexplicable joy when the opening title card fades in.
What's meant to be a triumphant true story about succeeding under impossible odds ends up feeling more like a Lifetime TV movie.
Pi accomplishes so much more with...its micro-budget than a Hollywood production could.
As uncompromising a work of art as you can ever view.
Perhaps in twenty more years or so, [The Fountain] will be recognized for the utterly gorgeous masterpiece that it is.
Darren Aronofsky's filmmaking in The Wrestler is the most subtle and nuanced he's ever done.
Cate Shortland infuses a fresh perspective and a haunting moral quandary to the WWII genre, bringing a little seen part of human history to chilling life.
Pretentious in some of the worst possible ways. Needlessly opaque, grim without being provocatively so, & just downright ugly to look at, the film has nothing of value to say.
Dark Skies may not be a revelatory experience, but as a pure exercise in genre filmmaking, it excels.
Not a single aspect of this film suggests that anyone involved in the production cared.
There are some good shorts in The ABCs of Death, and yet they're all overshadowed by some of the most awful, idiotic, infantile material I've ever seen in any film.
Endlessly compelling and thought-provoking throughout its entire running time, even when it plunges the darkest, bleakest depths of human nature.
A powerful, towering, yet intimately-told epic with excellent performances, a unique structure, and a story told with as much passion and angst as the myriad sons in the film.
It goes off the rails, but in a way that's exciting and reinvigorating.
A film that crosses generations and cultural barriers: watching it, it's hard not to feel like a kid again.
It's nice to get a horror film whose horrors are so intrinsically rooted to very human fears and follies that they become one and the same. Oculus is that movie.
[Miyazaki] revitalizes conventional tropes, using elegant imagery to say something substantial about growing up, and he even subverts gender stereotypes along the way.
A masterpiece of animation and filmmaking.
movie_title: Neon Genesis Evangelion - Movie: The End of Evangelion (1997)

movie_review_blurb: The Cat Returns...is all fluff, but it's cute and enjoyable fluff at the very least.
The Rocket won't change anyone's world, but as a pleasantly sweet piece of world cinema, it's still worth seeing and being charmed by.
Bethlehem never really comes together as a revelatory experience until an incredible, wince-inducingly savage finale that leaves a strong aftertaste.
Despite the muddy narrative... It's the more intimate character relationships that ultimately make Howl's Moving Castle work as a whole.
We can't help but refuse to ignore the experience, digging deeper and deeper into the horrors that await us.
Dares us to reconcile our spiritual and physical selves.
Go ahead and take away my credibility badge...The film is one of the most emotionally affecting and profound experiences of my life, regardless of how recent it is.
Not as profound as Miyazaki's other works, but the fact that an animated children's film actually has the brains to go for larger, resonant themes is worth congratulation.
A rather mediocre film...And yet, even with all of its faults, I still find myself oddly swept up in its familial drama.
Maybe some restraint would have improved Snowpiercer in the traditional sense, but I wouldn't want to live in that world.
Sachs finds drama in silence, and makes the mundane rich with humanity.
No, it's not the tightest spoof movie around, but you'll laugh a lot.
The kind of serviceable yet lovingly crafted indie genre picture you wish was made more often.
Reveals itself to be not just a drama about love, romance, aircraft, or war, but a drama of the very essence of humanity: why do we try to live?
Isao Takahata's masterpiece is one of the most profound anti-war statements ever brought to cinema
movie_title: Grave of the Fireflies (Hotaru no haka) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: There are undeniable signs of this being a first-feature from an "unproven" director, but there's also a confidence in Yonebayashi that elevates the material a great deal.
Malick manages to do something I never thought possible, and that's make America seem like a New World to begin with.
An overly stoic, pretentious, boring, unimaginative trainwreck that just happens to have been made by some of the greatest animators in the history of Japanese anime.
Ethereal, gorgeous, and evocative.
Clunky thematic exposition isn't enough to break an otherwise lovely film
One of the most harrowing of anti-war statements, and the most beautiful too.
Funny and delightful throughout, even with very serious themes bubbling underneath the surface.
A stunningly beautiful, unabashedly sentimental, and surprisingly complex story that works as both a coming-of-age film and a study of the trials of being a single mother.
movie_title: Okami kodomo no ame to yuki (The Wolf Children Ame and Yuki) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: By no means a particularly good film...But as a cultural curiosity and a showcase for stunningly bizarre animation, there's nothing else quite like it.
movie_title: Pom Poko (Heisei tanuki gassen pompoko) (The Raccoon War) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Like its characters, the film's horizons expand further as it progresses, creating an all-encompassing portrait of childhood dreams & the sacrifices we make to commit to them.
movie_title: Whisper of the Heart (Mimi wo sumaseba) (If You Listen Closely) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A terrifying nightmare to lose yourself in.
A perfect marriage of classically composed storytelling and disturbing surrealism. But perhaps more importantly, its influence in storytelling still resonates to this day.
One of Lynch's darkest, most disturbing films precisely because it is able to delve into the places that the show simply wasn't allowed to explore on national television.
movie_title: Twin Peaks - Fire Walk with Me (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Princess Mononoke's greatest feat is in crafting a story that could've been so easily simple, but manages to be more morally complex than even the most epic live-action films.
Beyond subversive and downright ahead of its time.
The movie is just as free, experimental, and unsure of itself as its main characters are, and thus fits like a glove.
Lynch shows a weakness in this film that isn't present in just about any of his others: Sentimentality.
The most terrifying film ever made.
An incoherent, strange, plotless, poorly structured mess that has to be seen to really be believed.
We go to Mulholland Dr. not merely for explanations, but for the euphoric sense that there is something beyond our understanding affecting us as we view it.
Is The Straight Story one of my favorite Lynch films? Hard to say. Is it one of his most meticulously, and perfectly constructed? Well, I just can't disagree on that one.
A perverse, violent, nutso depiction of romance that even Bonnie and Clyde would shrug off as too hardcore for them.
Crime thriller or offbeat family drama? Darkly funny or way too dreary? Trespass has all of these elements, and ultimately, this thick stew is unsatisfying.
Will children be satisfied? It's more than likely that they will. But The Secret Life of Pets is unlikely to earn repeat viewings, and in the crowded kid-pic marketplace, that's rather disappointing.
One of the most memorable political documentaries ever made.
Lights Out does not break new ground. But you're going to jump, you're going to smile, and you'll undoubtedly enjoy the ride. What more do you want from summer cinema?

It is free of cynicism; devoid of pop songs, sassy kids or fart jokes; and centered around concepts of real-life magic and wonderment. This makes Pete's Dragon stand out in the 2016 kid-flick landscape.
While it's not particularly original, The Student and Mister Henri understand that good casting can make even a tired plot seem delicious.
The "true story" inspiration does not help, either. The more one reads about the real case, the nastier it seems. It makes Godeau's version look deeply vapid.
It's a fascinating, insightful experience with just a few notable failings... But who can quibble (or Tribble) when the interviews and footage are so strong?
Anchored by two exhilarating performances from Rooney Mara and Ben Mendelsohn, the film is also harsh, moving, and extraordinarily riveting.
For Field, Doris may just herald a career rebirth.
Disaster done right can be entertaining, and Deepwater is a solid example.
It didn't last long, but it was one helluva ride. Above all else, Supersonic captures that feeling.
Rarely has a film so successfully highlighted the inner lives of the type of female characters so often ignored in movies.
Mitchell and Dohrn keep Trolls funny and light, and the 93-minute result is sure to be every 4- to 10-year-old's favorite film of the fall.

The Japanese animated drama Miss Hokusai is a unique, fascinating oddity. It's a strong historical drama, and a serious one. Yet it's occasionally joke-y, often uneven, and occasionally difficult to follow.
On the basis of Bad Words -- a film destined to be a cult classic -- and The Family Fang, Jason Bateman is undoubtedly a real-deal director.
It's undoubtedly a masterpiece.
The acting and setting, as well as Audiard's mastery, make Dheepan essential viewing.
My goodness, Storks is a strange movie. It's also a bad one, and a reminder that not all children's films are created equally.
Warcraft is far from a disaster. In fact, it's a (mostly) fun, wonderfully imaginative, surprisingly emotional beast of a film that should please its core audience of gaming vets.
For this audience, Ron Maxwell's film will prove entertaining and though-provoking, at the very least. For the rest, it is unlikely to provide much dramatic sustenance.
Question: Is the exhausting, utterly uninvolving Alice Through the Looking Glass somehow worse than Tim Burton's execrable Alice in Wonderland? Answer: Probably.

Comparatively, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them ranks as the weakest Potter film, and probably one of the least kid-friendly. But the teenagers who grew up on Rowling's stories will adore it, and what comes next should be fascinating.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that Bert and Arnie has a few laughs, some nice performances and does not beat the viewer over the head with a slapstick-lead-pipe means it is a film worthy of respect.
movie_title: Bert and Arnie's Guide to Friendship (2013)

movie_review_blurb: ...I Am Breathing is not a documentary intended to induce sobbing. It is, instead, a film about dying that is stunningly alive, wildly optimistic, and always insightful and entertaining.
You Are Here is a shockingly inept comedy, a project with the look and style of a mid-'90s Ivan Reitman or Harold Ramis comedy, not the first film from one of our finest TV writers.
Reggio's film is an artistic and aesthetic achievement unlikely to be equaled in 2013, and perhaps the only film in recent memory which can proudly claim to be unlike anything else we have ever seen.
If making Abuse of Weakness was a necessary step in Catherine Breillat's recovery, then it surely ranks as one of the most important-if not the most important-projects of her career.
From the acting...to the music (especially Strauss's "Four Last Songs), it is remarkably full of life.
...it is hard to walk away too disappointed when the stories are this fascinating-and when the music is this triumphant.
Davidson's movie aims for Polanski dread, but instead feels jumbled and weak-kneed - half made-for-Lifetime, half horror-wannabe.
movie_title: I Will Follow You Into The Dark (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Roman Polanski: A Film Memoir is a rare opportunity to hear a master filmmaker speak about his life. Both his haters and fans will agree, it is a highly watchable documentary. But don't expect either group to feel they have heard the whole story.
Watch Cusack and you will see the face of an actor who knows how bad this is, and who must be aware of how far he has fallen. If only he could see the face of the viewer.
Sasha and the girls of FEMEN may be black-and-blue, but they are most certainly not defeated.
Should he direct again, it is possible he will create a film worthy of his talent, and worth watching. Don Peyote, however, is as big a bust as the apocalypse of December 2012.
While the politics and film as a whole are not entirely successful, there is much to admire in Wolf Creek 2, not the least if which is director Greg McLean's chutzpah.
As the moving, sad, riotously humorous documentary "The Dog" explains, the film only captures traces of Wojtowicz's personality, and only tells bits of his story.
There is nothing particularly fresh about "Anna," from its script to its direction to its cast.
The concept of "The New Girlfriend" could have been played several different ways, from farce to high-drama to Hitchcock-ian thriller. Ozon decides to try it all, but in the end doesn't pull off any.
"Northern Soul" feels driven by youthful energy.

Elstree 1976 is a must-see for Star Wars fanatics, and coming shortly after the much-hyped franchise adrenaline shot that is The Force Awakens, it's almost shocking to hear firsthand accounts of the first film's way-under-the-radar status.

High-Rise is not a backward-facing period piece, nor a glimpse into the future; it is a sobering look into a recognizable present, and that's what makes the film a worthy adaptation of a literary master.
In its attempt to please both children and adults equally, Zootopia is a failure.

There are no surprises here, and the whole affair is a bit too modest. But Elliott's voice and his face have a lived-in quality that is unforgettable. The actor makes The Hero an enjoyable, worthy drama.
Norwegian disaster film The Wave is a reminder that cliché-ridden, unexceptional, effects-driven cinema is not purely the domain of Hollywood studios.
Molly's Game is slick, flashy, highly entertaining, and hugely forgettable.
There's never been a Denzel Washington performance like this one, and there's never been a protagonist quite like Roman J. Israel.
"Mademoiselle Paradis" is the fifth film from director Barbara Albert, and for both she and star Maria Dragus, it is a stunning success.
If "Sleeping Giant" was a shout, "Porcupine Lake" is a whisper. Told with style, warmth, and restraint, this knowing, delicate film from director Ingrid Veninger should be a modest crowd-pleaser.
Columbus is the debut from Kogonda, and it marks him as a filmmaker to watch closely.
With just about 15 minutes or so left in its 120-minute running time, Mary Shelley comes alive.
Dawson City: Frozen Time is a truly important effort. It is also genuinely haunting.

The storytelling is often over-adrenalized and the visuals eye-popping, but the humor and sweetness make The Lego Ninjago Movie a winner. And if you're a 7-year-old, it might even be the best movie ever made.

Lady Bird will surely go down as one of the year's best films, but Greta Gerwig's feature is also a contender for having some of the strongest insightabout the winding path of adolescence this decade.
Mauréry makes the film worth watching.
The performances are uniformly excellent.
More Fifth Element than Avengers, more John Carpenter than Jon Favreau, Thor: Ragnarok is an often riotously entertaining interplanetary romp.
If there's any justice in the world of cinema, Wonderstruck will prove the type of unexpected, unhyped film for young adults that becomes a generational touchstone.
Euphoria is undeniably a missed opportunity at creating a drama of frayed sisterhood that feels fresh and unique.
Calling it a "kids film" is a disservice; Paul King has directed an of-the-moment family comedy that rivals any in recent memory.
Sweet Country is many things - a stark western, a gripping chase story, a tale of slavery and self-defense, and a searing drama in which the stakes are horrifically high.
Basmati Blues is an inoffensive trifle. It does not warrant outrage; it's not bold enough to risk it. Yet there is some heart, and undoubtedly, some ambition.
Keating's film does not come close to reaching the heights of Repulsion, but this loving homage is nevertheless a gruesome winner.
Faces Places is truly a joyous documentary, and qualifies as a must-see for any lover of cinema. If it is indeed Varda's final film, it's hard to think of a more effective goodbye.
While I Do ... Until I Don't is fiercely unmemorable, it does not diminish the success of Bell's career. There's no doubt she'll be back with a far better creation than this one, and soon.

Like Tim Burton's classic "Ed Wood," "The Disaster Artist" is a testament to the communal joy of movie-making. But more than that, it's an unforgettable appreciation of the pleasures of movie-watching.
When the credits roll, it's nearly impossible not to be smiling.
What resonates most from Mifune are the film clips, of course. Watching him on screen remains an exhilarating experience. As many state in the film, there was no one quite like him.
The reason to see Ingrid Goes West, ... is for the performances.
More enjoyable than Finding Dory, more clever than the overrated Zootopia, and more memorable than Moana, Sing is a real holiday treat.
Director Øvredal lets the tension and claustrophobia build, and the end result is chilling.
This mini-Dark Knight might not be the Batman we deserve, but he's certainly the one we need right now.
XX is a horror film that should inspire real discussion and real scares, and that's an accomplishment.
These visual flourishes are not always matched by the story. Ocean Waves is slight, and there's no getting around that. Still, the film never loses its innate likability, and is a brisk 76 minutes.

Yes, it's an odd title, one that sounds much better in its native language ("Ma vie de Courgette"). It's also a wonderful tremendously moving film about an emotionally wounded little boy, and the family unit that develops at a foster home for orphans.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While The Zookeeper's Wife never lands an emotional knockout punch, there's a decency in the actions of Antonina Żabińska and Jan Żabiński that's downright heartwarming.
The film is a grueling, often painful experience. But this is essential cinema, and for Scorsese, a story he needed to tell.
With its bold premise, it's designed to provoke discussion, and should make a greater impact in homes than on the big screen.
Thanks to some noteworthy visual flare from the directors, enjoyably creepy effects, and a game cast (especially Welsh), The Void warrants a recommendation. But just barely.
The Art Life is a must-see for Lynch obsessives, but it's also worth watching for anyone with an interest in the creation process.
It Comes at Night is very close to a masterpiece. Enveloped in dread and oozing with tension, it's one of the great recent studies of the fear that comes from a desire for survival.

With quirky characters, a somewhat meandering plot, quick jumps between humor and shocking violence, the Netflix release brings to mind past festival favorites like Joel and Ethan Coen's Blood Simple.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's one of the year's essential releases - maybe its most essential.
It depends on who you ask. But make no mistake, a film with a climactic "dance fight" set to Madonna's "Into the Groove" can't be all bad.
The Dark Tower is a crushing disappointment for Stephen King fans.
It's one of those overused lines in film criticism: "You've never seen anything like NAME OF MOVIE!" But in the case of Polish horror-fantasy musical The Lure, it's accurate.
Bloated.
Violence, especially violence at the expense of the black community, has seldom been more candidly dissected and critiqued in American film as it is in Across 110th Street.
Moodysson both trivializes a vital human impulse to re-envision and remake society on one's own terms, and flattens out the political complexities of a specific historical context.
Noémie Lvovsky's heartfelt work has plenty of potential but keeps coming up short.
movie_title: Tomorrow and Thereafter (Demain et tous les autres jours) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing in the first two thirds of All the Money in the World that isn't pure plot transmission. It's based on the most literal-minded kind of narrative expediency and is a total chore to sit through.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Exactly what you expect--a slick, slight, energetic video game of a movie that is far better than most will admit.
Sci-fi via the deep. The effects are cheap, but the writing is good.
More like 'Running with Scissors.' A terrible, awful, hilarious misfire. Folks, a new camp classic is born.
So bad they should have called it Scary Movie 4.
If it weren't for "Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit," "Howl's Moving Castle" would be your winner for this year's Academy Award for Best Animated Picture.
The cautionary new thriller 'V for Vendetta,' finds director James McTeigue envisioning some rather difficult times ahead for the year 2020.
The new Harrison Ford movie, 'Firewall,' doesn't just sentence its audience to a dull time at the movies. It also sentences its talented cast with 100 minutes of mediocrity.
As much fun as tracing patterns in a carpet.
A punchy movie, with Pierce Brosnan happily trashing his 007 persona.
The film's best element is the inspired casting of Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson; their easy repartee helps to grease over the film's shortcomings.
Disagreeable, unlikable, unwatchable.
'Empire' scores in that it does get to the ever timely corruption of power--just look around you--but it faints in the presence of HBO's superior 'Rome.'
Before the movie leaches into sentiment toward the end, Judi Dench's good time is infectious.
A marvelous movie, with Bill Murray scoring again in the realm of drama.
Steven Segal--still chopping (it's a struggle), still kicking (it's exhausting), still in a career slump (it's over, cookie).
The movie understands what Polanski himself knew upon surviving the Holocaust--you take your kindness where you can find it, weighing its price along the way.
Overly celebrated, but the gun fights are among the best ever in a Western.
A timely, daring movie that skillfully weaves the corruption of big government and drugs--the pharmaceutical sort--deep into its equation.
Hallelujah for the hymns! They save "The Gospel."
No classic, this series. The show has become gratingly cute, particularly in the episodes "Doogiesomething," "Double Doogie with Cheese," and "Lonesome Doog." Doog, I'm Doogied out.
Beyond kitsch. Hell, beyond belief.
You could call her desperate. She might even agree.
Its appeal likely will be for the youngest in the household. All others might wish that this nanny had recalled a bit of Bette Davis' nanny in 1965's "The Nanny."
Evolution? Not quite.
As played by Murphy in what is an excellent performance, Kitten is sort of like a transvestite superhero--able to overcome impossible situations and look fabulous while doing it.
A riff on the "Little Red Riding Hood" tale, literally reimagining our innocent, skipping little sweet tart as a street-smart, butt-kicking, take-no-prisoners hard-lass from the 'hood.
To help suspend disbelief, here's a tip--try watching it through gauze.

Where is the fun in a movie like this? There are no jolts, no flashes of humor, no camp aspect, no winking at the audience--just bloodletting that crosses the line. Those who want this sort of thing can have it.
Mullett mediocrity.
This game is so over.
If Vince Papale was the heart and soul of Philadelphia during the mid-1970s, Wahlberg brings those same qualities to "Invincible," a movie served considerably by them.
Rotten, risible, rubbish. One of the year's worst films.
An instant cult classic. Pure, hardcore moviemaking backed by an inane plot, unrelenting action and zero pretensions.
Between us, let's just forget the movie.
Smoothly sends up romantic comedies and the superhero genre with such panache, it leaps into mid-summer as one of its best diversions.

Raunch only works well if there is an undercurrent of substance at hand to lift the bottom feeding. "Clerks II" has no problem plunging into its messy depths while also, somehow, generating a groundswell of affection for its messy characters.
Confident and engrossing, a smashing return from Woody Allen, who hasn't been this spot-on in years.
The new computer-animated movie, "The Ant Bully," knows a few things about bullies, most of which we already know--all of which bear repeating.

The first third is the movie at its best--it has the looseness of improvisation. The second half is a struggle, but McKay recovers nicely toward the end, where so many stereotypes are eventually run down by the script.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In "The Descent," look beyond the stalagmites. Leaping amid them and eager for fresh meat are an amphibious race of blood-sucking beasts who appear to have been poached beyond the boiling point.

Perhaps Stone's greatest triumph is in his seamless recreation of Ground Zero. Stone rises to the occasion, achieving greatness by creating the illusion of reality within the most surreal of environments.
One day, should the American Film Institute loosen up and offer a list of the 100 Greatest B Horror Movies ever made, David R. Ellis' "Snakes on a Plane" deserves a spot on that list.
Filled with compelling, old-school thrills.

How do you replace the heroic sight of Shelley Winters--breath held longer than David Blaine could fathom--skimming through a watery deep in an effort to save the remaining passengers of 1972's "The Poseidon Adventure"? You don't even try.
This time, the balance has been tipped, and it isn't in Tom Cruise's favor.
More like "An American Hanging." It slips a big noose of banality around its audience's necks and then tightens the rope until unconsciousness sets in.

As with so many zombie movies, table manners have no place here--why should they when fresh intestines are on the menu? Gluttony, however, does bloom in Slither, and what it builds to is one savage little garden.
A stiff shows up with gruesome repetition in The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada, and some will be surprised to learn that it isn't Tommy Lee Jones' former college roommate, Al Gore.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: What style--and what a lack of substance.

Liz Friedlander's "Take the Lead" is a fine example of how all the good intentions in the world can't make a poorly conceived movie good, though a good central performance can at least make it bearable.
There's so much to admire about Thank You for Smoking, you savor it for the rare satire that it is.
Paul Weitz's American Dreamz assembles a sumptuous buffet for the viewer, but since Weitz isn't hungry, he just stares at the spread, dumbly refusing to eat when really he should gorge.
This time out, what's scary is how boring and unimaginative the series has become.

What the movie gets exactly right is its knowledge that for some, realizing their first major accomplishment has nothing to do with throwing a touchdown or getting on base. For someone like Akeelah, correctly spelling a difficult world can prove the earl

Evict them.
Shock cinema? Yes, but with a story and with a point.
Touching and fearless.
A great movie, a funny movie, an important movie.
One story, two versions, each from Woody Allen, so you know you're in for it.
A tense, satisfying thriller.
Financed by the mafia, always there when you need them most.
Pure formula, but nevertheless an enjoyable triple klutz.
Vadim Perelman's "House of Sand and Fog" is one of the low points of the current movie season. But then it's meant to be.

The best way to tell when things are getting bleak is to check Dakota Fanning's face. When she starts to look like a poached egg, that's when you better hide.
When it comes to war, Robert S. McNamara wants us to know that our history with war has taught us plenty. Not that we've learned much from it.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Clap your hands for a better script.
If you dig this sort of gross-out throwback to the horror movies of the '70s, by all means, accept "The Devil's Rejects."
The biggest screen orgasm of the year.
No shame here.
High style and noirish overtones about mind control and brainwashing in corporate America. Nothing new there, so nothing new here.

Austen goes to Bollywood.
Wide awake amid the smoke and mirrors.
The film's emotional ending is deeply felt and powerful, examining the pain and the humor of life without pathos or melodrama. As such, the film resonates and lingers.
"Goblet of Fire" is the first film in the series to mark a turning point in terms of quality of direction and storytelling.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The childlike whimsy of the previous Potters is dead, replaced by an encroaching loss of innocence and a foreboding sense of darkness. A new punch of life for the series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A spectacular franchise takes flight.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Smart and engaging, Zathura is one big "Check Mate" to Jumanji, a movie it trumps in every way.
A swell twist and fine performances in an otherwise average thriller.
This bizarre movie is many things--a celebration of Christian values, a drag act, a drug plunge, a soap opera, a sitcom revenge fantasy.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Fresh off the failure of "Duck Soup," this was the Marx Brothers' comeback movie. The effort shows.
Plays like a live-action version of the "Dilbert" comic strip. A smart, funny satire.
"Open Water" works on many levels, chief among them as an examination of isolation, worry, terror, and the dread that can accompany the unknown.
Apparently, Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is the book whose influence just won't die.
Begins in a picturesque nowhere of tall mountains and big skies, where the only stone wall here is the real thing, with nothing political muddying the mortar.
Slumming with Jim and Tea.
Cheaper by the gross.
Says to hell with subtlety--but with a pretty face.
More like Night of the Living Dead.
Go ahead--throw the first stone. Throw it right at the screen. Take aim, wind up and let the rocks rip.
After a slow start, produces some of the year's biggest laughs.
'Twas overkill killed the beast.

Their, theirs, theirs. They can keep it.
A surprise. The movie is fantastic, with a depth of storytelling and character development that might just leave our Harry looking over his shoulder with a trace of concern.

movie_review_blurb: One of 2005's best movies, with a performance by Philip Seymour Hoffman as Capote that right now is the one to beat in the pending awards season.

Personally, after her amazing performance in Monster, I prefer the ugly Charlize Theron.

A harrowing, powerful and often disturbing movie about three seemingly unrelated stories that collide after one horrific car accident in Mexico City.
A terrific film that follows several interrelated New York stories and the people barely existing within them.
As a mystery, "Lantana" is memorable. But as a study in human relationships and the human condition, it's unforgettable.
If this movie is about how some choose not to live, it's also just as much about why others choose to go on.

We've walked this line before, so it's good news for Mangold that his excellent cast makes us forget it.
Beat your chest for this one.
The cast is a who's who, a who's not, and a who might one day be; they're the best part of a picture that is unnecessarily complex.

For "Sahara," the problem is that we have the Indiana Jones movies to compare it to, and I'm afraid there's no comparison. It's never more than a likable poseur.
Flaccid.

Puts another monkey on Jack Black's back, but this time it isn't several stories tall, it doesn't have a thing for blondes and it doesn't famously destroy New York real estate. In this case, it's the script.

Irresponsible? Sure. But for the most part, also funny--and that's the point.

From 1997, a movie that explores whether a woman has the grit, the strength and the nerve to survive Navy SEAL training, with a bald Demi Moore sweating, swearing, smoking cigars and fighting in head-to-head combat to prove that she can.
There always is the sense that this dream world in which they live could be taken away from them in an instant. "Entourage" builds a foundation of fear on that, and it uses it to its benefit.

Some of the five films selected here find Fields at his best, while others favor schmaltz over the actor's acerbic wit. We want the former, but this set also gives us the latter. The result is a surprise.

Sweet and good-natured, but ultimately it's as unremarkable as its animation.
An iconic movie, thoroughly New York, with Pacino in top form.
Entertaining in parts, but there's no denying that this is the weakest of the three.
Hokey title, but sometimes movie is good.
Mullet mediocrity.

movie_review_blurb: Marketing for the sake of marketing. Still, the movie is a winner.

A brash departure from the legend that retains the round table, but that's about it. Still, the contemporary echoes make the Dark Ages relevant again and the movie, while longwinded in parts, overcomes its shortcomings.
Presents a powerful, kinetic ballet by a martial arts master at the peak of his form--just try looking away from him.
One of those movies in which you ask yourself, "So, who isn't in this movie?" The answer? Not many.

One dizzying musical time capsule.

movie_review_blurb: Sicko shows that, at the very least, our health care system is a productive system. After all, it tirelessly defeats plenty.

movie_review_blurb: A horror movie that eschews today's penchant for torture porn and gets back to the basics.
Spit-and-paste bilge.

So, here's a surprise. The summer's first blockbuster action film worthy of its hype has nothing to do with pirates, Spider-Man or the Fantastic Four. Instead, it comes down to Michael Bay's "Transformers."
Expertly conceived, fun and infectious.

A terrific movie -- and an early contender for the Academy Award. With Ratatouille, Disney and Pixar not only capture the culinary heart of Paris -- itself a feat -- but also the hearts of audiences through one adorable little rat.
A damn good movie pie.
A slight, forgettable film, not without energy or humor, with an inexhaustible taste for sending up B-movie trash.
Failure to Launch? The same can be said for the movie.

Not Norman Lear's best show, but in 1975, it nevertheless gave Nielsen viewers something they hadn't seen before on network television--the story of a divorced single mother galvanizing herself against the world.

Stars Judi Dench in one of the cruelest, most isolating roles of her career. She's Barbara Covett, a British school teacher of a certain age who wields a poisonous wit that's so cutting, it tends to draw its share of blood.
Call it a comeback, but this is the best "Rocky" film since the 1976 original.

The new Darren Aronofsky film, "The Fountain," is high-concept, metaphysical trash that shoots for the heavens--literally--but which likely will leave some wondering how they paid eight bucks to walk through the doors of hell.

One of the key problems with the new Robert Kennedy biopic, "Bobby," is that it never is as compelling, necessary or as thought-provoking as RFK's ideas, nor is it as interesting or as tumultuous as the time it depicts.

Pedro Almodovar's "Volver" stars Penelope Cruz in a comeback performance that's so good, it recalls the film's title itself. In Spanish, "volver" means "to return," and that's exactly what Cruz has done here. She's fantastic.
There is no escaping the banality of it all.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Its rushed ending aside, there is plenty to recommend in the otherwise excellent computer-animated movie "Happy Feet."
Bling-bang.

If movies are among our greatest, most enduring vehicles for illusion, then a movie about dueling illusionists should, in theory, offer that same sleight of hand--only amplified. In this case, it does.

Clint Eastwood's new World War II movie, "Flags of Our Fathers," is what the recent World War I drama "Fly Boys" should have been. It nixes cheap sensationalism to cut to the core of war's grisly realities.
Good breeding, that queen--but poor manners.

movie_review_blurb: Given the groundswell of hype surrounding the new Bill Condon musical "Dreamgirls," there's every reason to expect it to be on par with "Chicago," which was based on Condon's script. The reality, though, is somewhat different.

One of the worst movies thus far this year.
Buzz kill.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: By virtue of its title alone, is it too much to expect "Employee of the Month" to be something special, perhaps a cut above your everyday comedy? Shouldn't the jokes make that extra effort, as well as the cast?
Finally, the race is on. The battle for Best Picture begins with Martin Scorsese's The Departed, an outstanding return to form that will be nominated across the board in several major categories.

These days, spinach is scarier than anything that unfolds in "The Grudge 2." The film is such a waste, it could have benefited from the inspired and truthful title found in the recent "Jackass" movie. "The Grudge Number Two" comes closer to the mark.
Like the best, most hypnotic magic trick, "The Illusionist" seamlessly draws you in, wows you and then tricks you, though you're delighted by the trick even if you saw it coming.

It's convention and cliches that drive the new computer-animated movie "Open Season," an overly familiar yet nevertheless likable film that could have been exceptional had it attempted something fresh within the genre.

Stars Gretchen Mol in a terrific comeback performance as Page, the God-fearing woman from Tennessee who left Nashville for New York, where her aspirations of becoming an actress were interrupted, you might say, by a whip and a ball gag.
Watching "Hollywoodland" unwind, it becomes clear that this is the movie Coulter and Bernbaum should have made in the twilight of their careers, after Hollywood had had its way with them.

With fall and its promise of better movies on the horizon, this movie, like "Hollywoodland," could have been among the most exciting of the new season. That neither is true for either movie isn't exactly encouraging.
With the ongoing gloss, the tin dialogue and the broad echoes of "Star Wars," "Fly Boys" is about as far removed from the best examples of the genre--"Wings" and "Hell's Angels"--as it could get.
Achieves a controlled sense of arcane looseness on its way to becoming one of the year's better animated efforts.
Some movie.
Welcome to the new year, folks, and welcome to Alfonso Cuaron's superb "Children of Men," which is one of 2006's best.
We are not impressed.
Like "Seinfeld" and "Sex and the City," you watch this ingenious show wishing they would just bring it back.
movie_title: Not Just the Best of the Larry Sanders Show (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A James Cagney collection without "Yankee Doodle Dandy," "White Heat" and "Public Enemy" is an oversight, to say the least, but this otherwise solid boxed set from Warner does include five noteworthy Cagney films.
With the writing way above board and insights fueling the story forward with heart and bawdy comedy, "The History Boys" is amiably off-center, sure, but it finds its core and leaves its mark.
In spite of its title, few will want to hit rewind to visit the movie again.
Just as she did in the dark, sadomasochistic comedy "Secretary," Gyllenhaal raises her share of eyebrows here, though for a whole host of different reasons.
Some of the laughs are inspired and big, and while you wish the movie was as cruel as you know the figure skating world really is, at least it isn't afraid of being silly.
The 11th Biblical plague.
Designed for those who want to rock on schlock.

Although the movie makes a case for its ending, taking you by the hand and walking you through the stink of all its red herrings, the effort is wasted. Ro sounds like roe for a reason, and the logic behind this film was fishy from the start.
Snuffed.
Asks what a teenage boy is to do when he's been placed under house arrest for assaulting a teacher. The answer? Take a cue from Alfred Hitchcock's "Rear Window" and start spying on the neighbors.
With the exception of its ending, which offers a passable twist, very little about this courtroom suspense thriller is remarkable or reproachable.
Watching it, the amateur, institutionalized filmmaker might think, "Well, there it is--the movie to which I aspire." For the rest of us, however, things are predictably bleak.

There's such a crushing rush of testosterone on display in "300," those who turn out to see it might leave the theater with an unexpected surprise--male pattern baldness. But don't fret. It's such a lightweight, the effects will be gone by morning.

The lot of it is pseudonoir.
The movie refuses to pander.
Since the movie is about mending class differences, Minghella manufactures a hopeful ending that wants to have it all--just as he wants his London to have it all--but which instead only rings false.
A movie that recognizes that in old age, our minds might remain bright with humor and mischief, but our bodies nevertheless betray us. Coming to terms with that gives "Venus" its emotional final act.

Some will make compelling arguments that Eastwood doesn't give us a complete picture of the Japanese or their atrocities, but the director still is betting that right now, perhaps the world could benefit from another perspective.

Guillermo del Toro's excellent new film, "Pan's Labyrinth," is a violent, enthralling children's movie made for adults.

An origins movie that follows the serial killer's early years. As you might expect, those years didn't involve much time in a sandbox, unless of course Hannibal's spade was used as an instrument of death.

I think I love it, but why am I afraid to say so?
"Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines" is pure meat-and-potatoes summer fare, offering audiences precisely the sort of wrecking-ball entertainment they didn't find in the high-minded "Hulk."
Plays to Burton's strengths as an auteur of fantasy colliding with reality.
A ho-hum piece of junk.
"Twisted" is a train wreck, with Ashley Judd stuck in the caboose.
Comedy is difficult. Good comedies are rare. "Starsky & Hutch" has three noteworthy moments, one of which involves a horse mistakenly gunned down at a bat mitzvah. Hilarious.
"The Passion" is big, physical, violent and unflinching. It's unlike any biblical film ever made and it's impossible to watch it with a trace of passivity.

Right up there with the "Faces of Death" series in the punch of nausea it likely will generate in some viewers.

Exhilarating and suspenseful.

One of summer's better surprises.

A numbing, end-of-summer stinker from David Zucker.

A less violent, less successful movie that would have balanced the first film's kinetic energy had it been shown as Tarantino originally intended: as an uninterrupted whole.

For all of its easy jokes about poop and flatulence, the one stinking here is the movie itself.
Laced with crude racial stereotypes and a rash of homophobia that's akin to a minstrel show, "The Longest Yard" makes Sandler's "The Waterboy" look like an oasis.
The new Ron Howard movie, "Cinderella Man," begins precisely where pop culture is currently at its happiest--smack in the middle of a boxing ring.
That a movie about pants features a story that skirts formula is an irony worth savoring.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: "Batman Begins" is Christopher Nolan at his best. It's his movie all the way.
Watching it, you realize that Lucas has created his own coup. He has stolen this trilogy back from the brink of disappointment and ended it with an intergalactic bang.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: In "Monster-in-Law," Jane Fonda emerges from her recent tobacco bath to take on her first movie role in 15 years. The good news? At 67, she's still smoking.
Alive with more wit and mischief than any movie to hit theaters so far this year.
Is it a compliment to say that "Guess Who" is better than "Booty Call?" More compelling than "Texas Rangers?" Superior to "B*A*P*S?" Guess not.
With great panache and a broad wink at its audience, "Sin City" cranks up the heat and dices up the double-talk.
Has the stink of a bad perm all over it.
Funny. One of the Farrellys' best.
A high-concept, high-minded piece of pseudointellectual trash, "I Heart Huckabees" is one of those stink bombs the intelligentsia like to champion.
All of this could have been loose, kitschy fun, but "Cursed" is too self-conscious to get off the ground.
An uneasy, sometimes difficult film to watch - rare at the movies these days. But as a study in pedophilia, there is plenty to be said for the conversation it ignites.
A technically fine looking yet dull-as-drill-bits movie whose busy animation creates 90 minutes of chaos onscreen.
In "The Ring 2," bathtubs overflow, ceilings drip, walls weep, wells vomit, characters nearly drown, yet ironically, the movie suffers from the lows of a creative drought.
Sure, "Armed and Fabulous" would like to be considered absolutely fabulous, but "Armed with a Few Laughs" comes closer to the mark. "Amputated by a Weak Script" nails it.
Dating is difficult. Relationships can be tough. "Hitch" wants to be the Band-Aid that heals the wound.
"Constantine" isn't a movie, per se; it's a stunt with eye-catching effects that work to lure in audiences, those who, after seeing this beauty, will be the real lost souls.
Who knew that marionettes could be so tender, crude and aggressive in the bedroom?
This smart, entertaining show continues to stand alone.
An uneven, overly stylized mess that wants to recall Quentin Tarantino, but which only mines the glitz, not the depth or the sharpness of Tarantino's dialogue.
Laced with pseudoserious undertones, the movie makes "Anaconda" look like a modern-day classic.
Poor Guido. Poor Marshall. Poor audiences, who likely were eager to see this movie (given the hype, who wasn't?), but who likely will leave it knowing they deserved better.

It doesn't tread much new ground, but that's beside the point. The lack of a black princess in Disney's repertoire was as appalling as it was glaring. This otherwise excellent film makes a solid effort to remedy that.
"Hair balls are prettier than what's coughed up here."
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: On paper, the movie's plot sounds clichéd and forced, and while the film is tainted with elements of each, the good news is that it's overwhelmed by neither.
Depp's performance overcomes every flaw in the film. He ends up playing Dillinger exactly as he should be--suave, mysterious, romantic, but with obvious elements of cruelty and unbridled violence.
The gag-inducing melodrama "Everybody's Fine" hails from Kirk Jones, whose phone calls, kisses and hugs no longer will be returned the moment this baby hits theaters.

"Old Dogs" also wants to entertain the adults in the audience. Frankly, any adult who finds this film humorous may be at the same level of intelligence as their child and someone should call child services immediately.
It's a wild mess, and it commits the worst crime a messy film can make--it completely lacks entertainment. It's an overly violent, unintelligible bore.

Had the audience at my screening heaving and sighing so often, here's a recommendation: Bring an oxygen tank. You'll need it and a mask, particularly in the presence of so much heaving and sighing and busy shirtlessness.
It should be put under citizen's arrest as it's one colossal disappointment.
The message of the movie seems to be that Americans can solve guilt by paying the right person.
It's cute, it's passable, the animation is fine--but the major problem with the film is its predictability.

By avoiding excessive cliche and maintaining a simple and optimistic attitude throughout, and with a healthy dose of comedy, "The Blind Side" ends up being one of the best sports films of recent years.
Begins with the subtitle: "More of this is true than you would believe." It's the perfect beginning to a film that deftly combines truth and fiction.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Though the sum isn't quite as good as the parts, the film does succeed due to its phenomenal cast, which consists of some of the best British actors working today. Philip Seymour Hoffman gives one of his most entertaining performances.

What's curious about the movie is that you can tart it up all you want, but Dickens' words still resonate, his characters still infuriate, frighten and touch, and there's still satisfaction to be had in his tale.
Amelia is a film that could have been great, but instead is an average film about an extraordinary person.
The film doesn't deliver any frights or creepiness. The so-called shocking parts are revealed in the trailer. The rest feels as if moments have been stitched together to make a whole.
Anyone going into "The Box" expecting a simple everyday thriller surely will be surprised with what they get--a dismal, morally complicated piece of sci-fi surrealism.

What "This is It" accomplishes is key to not only preserving Jackson's memory, but also to galvanizing his myth. Onstage, he still moonwalks, but there are new moves to be had here and a voice that is still strong.
Proves that in a horror movie, often the less you see, the more intense the story.

Director Billingsley, who once played Ralphie in 1983's "A Christmas Story," should have picked up that old BB gun of his and blown the hell out of the script before he ever signed on to make a movie out of it.
This spoof on the zombie genre literally and figuratively is killer. It's laugh-out-loud funny, the gore is beautifully over-the-top, and the wicked script is laced with a cutting wit.
Jonze has, in a sense, deepened the work that came before it.

The problem with the movie is that while the action is swift, the set design is polished and the running time is enjoyably lean, the film leaves behind too many unanswered questions in its quest to drive the action forward.
Good movies happen, too. Just not this time around.

What's so frustrating about "2012" is that it could have been a great action movie. If the special effects team can do their jobs, certainly better writers could have been hired. But no. Just try finding a surprise.
Thing is, to live forever would mean the eventual re-remake of Fame. And that won't do.
Yes, it's probably a good film for children. But when films far more sophisticated and enjoyable like "Up" or "Where the Wild Things Are" come out, a film like this merely seems trivial.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One 2009's best films.
For people who haven't seen any of Kevin Smith's films, this shouldn't be their foray into his work--his earlier movies are much better.

The thread-bare plot mostly serves as a means to get these people in an isolated area so they may be attacked by the undead. While the characters are likable, they are flat--you're given just enough information to care about them.
The new Benicio Del Toro movie, "Hirsute and Hatin' It" (okay, "The Wolfman"), is so ripe with the stink of fouled fromage, it should have taken place in France instead of Victorian England.

"John Travolta is obviously having a ball playing the obnoxious tough guy, but I took him less for tough and more simply for obnoxious. Sometimes his performance works, but often, it's just excessive."
"The year's most ambitious film is so breathtaking, it detracts you from the fact that Cameron's characters are caricatures, and too much of the dialogue is stock. The good news? None of it matters."

"It's like a Valentine's Day card put on screen--it's vaguely quotable, sweet, occasionally clever--and totally vanilla. Which basically means it'll make the perfect date movie for this Valentine's Day."

The plot is a pretty blatant rehash of the typical "coming-of-age hero" tropes. Still, while "Percy Jackson" may not end up being the next huge and successful franchise, at the very least, it was an honest and amusing two hours.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: While the writing isn't as sharp or as funny as it is in Almodovar's best movies, so be it--it's a hell of a lot sharper and more interesting than most of the mass-produced movies coming out of Hollywood.
