In the film, John says he compares himself to the fine pressing of a coin. It's a sad state of affairs when you have to compare yourself to a collectible coin to express your individuality.
This might be Jeff Bridges' best performance. And he might, in fact, just take home the Academy Award for Best Actor.
Last time I checked, films had plot, characters (and character development) and, if nothing else, some semblance of a purpose other than to make money. Such is not the case here. At all.
A flawed, middle-of-the-road, mildly enjoyable thriller.
Watching "Precious," you have to wonder--does it offer this year's inconvenient truth?
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: One of the problems with Christian films is that they can come off as very preachy. "To Save a Life" doesn't necessarily tone down its religious overtones, but it does try to make the religious aspects as organic as possible.
Legion is hellishly bad.
Follows every cliche and family-film formula so painstakingly that each moment is unbelievably boring. Almost from the moment the film starts, you know where it's heading every step of the way.

Gilliam has had a rough 10 years, but he's ended the decade with what is easily one of his seminal works. He has shown what imagination and storytelling means to him, and he's made one of his best films in the process.

Denzel Washington does the best he can with the material, but "The Book of Eli" is so ingrained with over-stylization, self-indulgence and ridiculous thematic material that it had no chance of succeeding from frame one.

The film's presence on the scene punctuates the ongoing issues surrounding the move toward equality for gay couples. The movie doesn't define the debate so much as it adds to it. Colin Firth's performance is a beautiful example of restraint.
The new Peter Jackson movie, "The Lovely Bones," is a head trip for audiences, a trip to hell for the family featured, and a plunge into purgatory for another.
As a whole, "Youth in Revolt" is simply an overwhelming success--as a comedy, a romance, and as a new career-high for Michael Cera. A dark, stylish and incredibly funny triumph.
A bloody, fun start to the new year.
Both of the leads do well in their roles, but since the movie is so predictable and some of the attempts at humor go south, most of it just leave you smacking your palm against your forehead.

It should have been titled, "Well, It's All Just Sort of Manufactured." The film is pat, it's predictable, we've seen revisions of its story countless times before--but that doesn't mean it isn't enjoyable, which it is.

For all its dialogue and relative lack of action, "44 Inch Chest" is lively and vibrant, no doubt due to the pitch-perfect performances. The movie relies on substance over style and flash, and manages to impress all the same.
In the end, "Bronson" is a beautiful, intense film about a man that may or may not be insane, based on events that might actually have occurred in his life.

True, the general audiences doesn't need hours of complex biochemistry talk they won't understand, but surely there's a better way of getting around it than showing Ford sitting in a lab coat writing on a dry erase board to rock music.
One of the year's better animated movies.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie--well, you know the movie. You know how great Judy Garland is as Dorothy, how memorable the rest of the cast is, how terrific Victor Fleming's direction is, and that the film's themes of the importance of home have helped it to resonate througho
The understatement of the year. Essentially, ax-wielding rednecks unite in a slasher flick that drives itself into a brick wall of no return.
It's a beautiful, heartfelt movie about people overcoming their own difficulties to make a positive impact on the lives of others.
One of the best, most satisfying teen-oriented coming-of-age comedies to come along in awhile.
Some movies you want to hang for their contrivances, others you're able to overlook in spite of them. Joel Hopkins' "Last Chance Harvey," from his own script, is the latter.
All the great animation and swell 3D effects in the world can't save a movie with a dull, uninspired storyline.

Stars Nicolas Cage in one of the actor's better commercial efforts, which is good news for Cage, since he needed a movie that was an improvement over the dreck he's been shucking to audiences for far too long.

Gilroy's movie does have its moments, most of which come down to the pleasures of its A-list cast, which possess enough talent and presence to stand down a plot so unnecessarily cluttered, it's a gimmick.
Back to Broke Mountain.
Philippe Claudel's "I've Loved You So Long" finds Kristen Scott Thomas giving one of last year's best performances in one of last year's better films.
A pretentious, over-long, pseudointellectual mess. Self-indulgent and boring, this overhyped dud is one major waste of time.
Well, they got the Number 2 right.
Some of the more annoying people you'll meet in sometime onscreen.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Isla Fisher is terrific, but the movie ultimately mirrors a shopping experience itself. It's a mixed bag of elements you either want to exchange or keep.

"Wolverine" has zip for depth, but since it never sold itself as such, who cares? This is the action movie the advertising campaign promised, and Hood comes through with plenty of scenes that satisfy on a visceral level.
This beautifully rendered stop-animated movie is so masterfully realized, it already has staked its claim as one of the animated films to beat at next year's Academy Awards.
Slumdog.

Digs into India's gritty depths, where it juxtaposes squalor, exploitation and corruption with humanity's fight to overcome it. Elements are predictable, but the movie never is slight, in large part due to its superb cast.

While the story itself is a mixed-bag at best, you have to give it up for the technology, which uses the 3-D platform to such a successful extent, it takes a mediocre movie and turns it into a reasonably fun, camp contender.
Initially, the new Mike Leigh film, "Happy-Go-Lucky," is so overbearing, it's a turn-off. But b the end of it, you might be calling it "Up with Poppy."

You've heard the buzz--and in this case, it's safe to believe it. Fresh from the flames of whatever hell he's been lost to for so many years is Mickey Rourke, who is back in a major way in Darren Aronofsky's "The Wrestler."
Mall cops everywhere should sue. The movie is trash.
"Defiance" sometimes is so subtle and well done, you admire Zwick for his reserve and tact. Unfortunately, at other times the movie is so heavy-handed, it can leach into parody.
Stillborn.

It tries so hard to construct something profound, the effort competes with the performances, stealing away some of the rawness of the emotions. But not all of them. Winslet and Kross are especially terrific.
For Eastwood, the movie is a slight, easy breeze to the end. But he's terrific in the role, the supporting cast is just as good, and as a result, the movie is well worth seeing.
Smith is a good actor, but he's lost it here. The film can be nauseating in its overbearing use of unbridled sentiment.
The movie is filled with canned situations, sure, but there's heart in this tale, and strong performances by Wilson and Anniston that give the film unexpected weight at the end.
Brisk and intense, with Howard and company rising to the challenge of recreating the infamous 1977 television interview David Frost scored with disgraced former U.S. president, Richard M. Nixon.

In Abrams' capable hands, the film is hugely satisfying. Smart, jaunty and savvy, it takes Orci and Kurtzman's script and races with it, boldly opening a new chapter in the series while giving it a fresh shot of life in the process.

The new Ron Howard movie, "Chaos & Disorder"--sorry, "Angels & Demons"--is a sequel to 2006's "The Da Vinci Code," and like that latter film, the news surrounding it is as dull as the luster on Miss California's crown.
Bale is good--solid amid the ongoing storm--but don't expect much of him. This is Sam Worthington's movie, and he steals it.
Director Rob Reiner creates an atmosphere of tense horror wrapped around rich dialogue ("Cockadoodie dirty birdie!"), and in the process, he gets sterling performances from Caan and Bates.
A deluge of dim jokes and rote romantic interludes between Matthew McConaughey and Jennifer Garner that are intended to recall Charle's Dickens' "A Christmas Carol." God help us all.
Here's an observation--Jody Hill's bum comedy fails to live up to the potential of its two talented stars, Seth Rogen and Anna Farris. As for the story, here's the report. It's stupid.
You admire it for the care that went into fleshing out its characters, the camaraderie that grows between them, and the thrill of watching a few harrowing turns around a skating rink.
"Jennifer's Body" has issues.
It's disappointing to report that the movie--while terrific to look at and rousing in parts--is not the movie it could have been.
Smart and affable, but not laugh-out-loud funny. A comedy shouldn't be as grounded as this. Since it's coming from Mike Judge, you expect it to fly.
Widely considered a terrible movie, but if you enjoy the camp genre, it's a must-see. It is, in fact, camp on a catnip high.
My open letter to Rob Zombie on his *cough* brilliant execution of Halloween II.
A fine show that follows a band of outlaw bikers through all sorts of dramatic hell.
Remains a highlight. It's smart, well-balanced lunacy with an undercurrent of romantic and dramatic tension that cuts through the laughs.
Beefcake! Blood! Body slams! Boring! Boring? Well, not quite, but at 150 minutes, "Gladiator" isn't entirely the thrilling, action-packed Roman epic some fans of the genre were expecting.

In this season of the show, Wisteria Lane and the "ladies" who lunch there remains a place where friendship and neighborly love don't exactly go down like spoonfuls of sugar. Saccharine, yes, but rarely sugar.

Tarantino's best movie to date turns out to be his latest movie, which clashes together history and fantasy, intentionally echoes back to many of the World War II movies that came before it, and uses them to inform it.

This low-budget film with its unknown cast is recommended because it ultimately is thought-provoking and smart. This isn't a sci-fi thriller so much as it is a sci-fi drama. It poses several serious questions about the state of humanity.
Nora Ephron's winning new movie is a tonic for those seeking something different from the usual summer fare of explosions, aliens and all things gone berserk. And what a swell departure it is.
The script has unexpected jolts of substance and drama, so much so that too often there are long stretches between the laughs, all of which fuel the film's bloated 2.5-hour running time.

Everybody loves a good romantic comedy. Unfortunately, nobody gets one in "The Ugly Truth," a crude movie that won't be a surprise for anyone who sees where the genre is going, which essentially is down a dark hole of no return.
The movie satisfies with new revelations and twists, one of which is so dire, it left many at my screening in their seats long after fate revealed its cruel hand and the credits started to roll.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The new Sacha Baron Cohen movie, "Bruno," really isn't a movie at all. Calling it one is sort of like calling mutton the new white meat.
Its refusal to sugarcoat death and loneliness deepens its appeal, with Carl's longing for Ellie so palpable, few won't be moved as the film wends along its harrowing way.
Sign the pre-nup so you can get a refund at the box office. "I Love You, Beth Cooper" has a few moments, but mostly it fails to show us the love.
Easily, one of summer's more outrageous, funny comedies.
A crowning achievement--the first English-language film that needs subtitles in order to understand it. It's a shoo-in for the Razzies--Worst Foreign Language Movie in a Non Foreign Language.

With his goatee and fake tattoos, it's safe to say you've never seen Travolta quite like this before. He's hardcore, and it works. As for Washington, he infuses this fine thriller with the kind of humanity it needs to ground it.
Saying it's slop is sort of like saying that entering a dank subway restroom at the height of the lunch rush hour is like wandering into a French perfumery. This baby stinks from start to finish.
A solid horror movie that features such big laughs, you come away wishing that most comedies were consistently as funny and as bright.
For those who like their movies wrapped in a tight bow, you're not going to get it here.
Another reason to see the original. In this disappointing remake, it's time that stands still.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An insignificant film that desperately wants to be significant. Still, thanks to a decent cast and mostly solid direction, it manages to be at least moderately entertaining through its running time.
For such a potentially great concept to result in such a thoroughly mediocre product is baffling, especially given the talent involved.
Their joyous return to Narnia washes away as their comfort in the face of the fantastic sets in. Nothing appears new to them, and likewise, nothing enchants us.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Yogi's picnic gag is funny in small doses but, much like his Chipmunk brethren, inflating these simple pleasures into a feature-length movie is disastrous.
This neurotic comedy tiptoes from one boring setback to the next, bottling its issues in schmaltz, and thus, costing the film its heart.
Most of the drama takes place outside of the ring, where lives are on the line, a family is divided and one of the year's best movies is found.
A mapped minefield of bad jokes.

Jack Black's abridged version of Jonathan Swift's famed epic fairs slightly better than other recent family adaptations. It's silly and occasionally funny -- not bad for a movie starring a guy who saves an entire city with his urine.

With so many tricky undercurrents to manage, "Rabbit Hole" could have caved beneath their weight and gone into safe, predictable directions that would have been easier to navigate. But it doesn't. It's more complex than that.
Because this is the first release of 2011, it would too be easy to crown "Season of the Witch" the worst film of the year, but I'm sure it will live up to that title for weeks to come.
Like the original movie, "Tron: Legacy" was made to push the boundaries of technology in cinema. It succeeds. The film is a special effects spectacle to behold.
If distilled, there are enough stories here to make for at least one interesting movie. "Love & Other Drugs" just needs a dose of Ritalin to figure out what that movie is.

This is a testament to the power of 3D when mastered--and not rushed. "Tangled" is animation at its best and it's this season's biggest surprise--it treats its audience with intelligence while giving them a jolt of fun.

The actors possess their best chemistry yet (as well they should--they've practically shared each other's Pablum), and the chemistry shows. You now can fully feel just how high the stakes have become.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You've never seen a movie quite like "Black Swan" before. It's brazen, it's ridiculous, it's magnificent, it's human, it's unique, it's the world at its worst, it's the worst at its best - and this is why it's so weirdly compelling.
What begins as one witty, unstoppable blast eventually succumbs to a flat story elevated by its consistently terrific animation.
Good performances, but where the film falters is in its inability to deliver the laughs.

The film should end a half-hour earlier than it does, but I guess we needed another film in which someone brings their disruptive kid to work or another scene where a desperate lover rushes through an airport.
In the film's far-reaching goals, "Hereafter" fails to connect its meticulous plotting together, leaving the second hour unnecessarily tedious and overtly detached from the audience.
This excellent prequel once again proves that in a horror movie, often the less you see, the more intense the story.
With all the money this series has behind it, couldn't the studio have hired a director and writers who had the ability to set a little mood? Make at least something of an effort? Obviously, not.
Gathers a great cast that makes "The Expendables" look, well, expendable. This is an extremely funny, action-packed movie in which gimmicks such as Helen Mirren blasting guns don't grow old.
It's gross--and it's fantastic.
An inspirational true story that oozes with so much inspiration, its overwhelming optimism becomes annoying and embarrassing.
"My Soul to Take" is one of the worst films I’ve seen this year and easily the most irritating.
"The Social Network" has an unusually difficult task to pull off--it has to make computer programming exciting--and it does so with aplomb.

Besides the performances, which are uniformly strong, what's so terrific about "The Exorcist" is how it's in no hurry to get to the meat of its horror. Unlike today's horror movies, it isn't exploitative. It's about its characters.
movie_title: Exorcist: The Version You've Never Seen (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The film fails not necessarily because of a lack of effort, but because there's very little heart in this film, and with such a dull plot, that's really what it needed.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Once again, favoring melodrama over reality, Perry overextends his bounds and delivers a poorly filmed series of worst-case scenarios elevated to tolerable heights by a fantastic cast.
Affleck brings this base, disturbing slice of Boston into focus.

"The Rite" aims for authenticity but is nothing more than a cartoon. The film is rife with poorly executed genre clichés and bad acting, alienating the viewer from the picture--and putting them into a coma.
Rife with uncertainty and realism, Weir's film is a stunning testament to human fortitude and to the power of Mother Nature.
"Bridesmaids" is a great first step for Apatow in finding his feminine voice, and an even better launching pad for the hilarious Kristin Wiig.

If you have an action movie that doesn't have enough loud, wham-bam, explosive fun to wake a sleeping baby, which was the case at my screening, then you, my friend, have an action movie not worth seeing.

The film relies on a singular idea-deciding whether to hurt a friend for the sake of true happiness. It's a premise that runs out of steam halfway through, but not before repeating its point over and over. More like "Something to Throw Away."
With a director this interested in making every shot exciting, it should come as no surprise that his film is just that.
The very nature of animation is to appear lively, and if that's the case, "Hoodwinked Too" fails at almost every turn.

The film's plot rarely makes sense and the script is lackluster, but who cares when each chase is composed of the right amount of speed and clarity? Lin never puts his foot on the break until the last possible second.
There is a scene in the movie that is so visceral, it will make you forget about the high-flying silliness. That's the Donnie Yen I was waiting to see.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Madea's Big Happy Family" is an assault on the senses. I'm still trying to figure out how "Afternoont" and a pancreatic tumor equate in humor, but, hey, maybe Perry's a pioneer of comedy, too.
The director puts on a beautiful spectacle. However, while the film looks fantastic, its stars lack the connection needed to make this circus a true marvel.

Move beyond the lame title, and you'll find an unexpectedly good movie, with the inspired casting of Drew Berry and Hugh Grant possessing the necessary chemistry to lift this rote, manufactured story into something appealing.

Like the colorful candies of Easter, "Hop" is a pastel distraction lacking any kind nutritional value. Inside its foil wrapping exists an endless array of predictable jokes, aimless subplots and obnoxious characters. It's a disaster.
A well-paced and structured sci-fi thriller that's as complex as it is clear-headed.
Check your brain at the door and enjoy.
"Beastly" is a poor representation of its source material and creates a monster out of it its inherent themes.
Damon and Blunt are great--it's just a shame they don't have a stronger adversary for their love.

Against the phony sets and effects, Valerie's world seems more like a cheap stage rather than a realistic fantasy world, making the film's own flaws and missed opportunities clear as day even in the dark of night.

"Rango" has everything going for it -- strong characters, complex plotting, and a knowledge of the genre it parodies without excluding newcomers to it. It's smart without being alienating and exciting without being mindless.
If the recent slew of apocalyptic invasion pictures teaches us one thing, it's that they make better trailers than movies. This is a case in point.

McConaughey's confidence fits like a glove--it's the role he's been waiting for, and coupled against Philippe's easy-to-hate playboy and a great supporting cast, the film turns out to be one of this season's better movies.

"Limitless" delivers the goods in terms of fun, suspense, and an above-average story. The twists and turns never appear without reason, and Cooper delivers an assured, charismatic performance that lifts the film.

"Paul" might not connect with everyone, but it's certainly funny and heartfelt enough to please those brave enough to see it. It seems destined for a cult following rather than a legion of converted geeks.
If all is right in the universe, the only good that will come out of "The Resident" is the murder of its director's career before it even starts.

James Cameron produced "Sanctum" to create a similar experience to "Avatar." But where as the world of Pandora benefitted from the immersive qualities of Imax 3-D, "Sanctum" only occasionally uses the screen's size properly.
It explores that roommates can be, you know, like a total drag sometimes.
The hilarious supporting players keep things moving when the director stumbles, but "No Strings Attached" lacks the emotional core that would have made it memorable.

In the wrong hands, "The Company Men" could have slipped into a slop of sentiment, but the movie doesn't go there. This is, first and foremost, a movie about "men," and what, in Wells' eyes, it means to be a man in these difficult times.
"Mars Needs Moms" is only consistent in that it's a mess.

The lot of it is pure melodrama, but as any fan of melodrama knows, if you have a talented cast willing to throw themselves headfirst into the cinematic blender, that melodrama can be as captivating as it is cheap.
Reeves has done the impossible and made a foreign film for a mainstream American audience.
The new Paul W. S. Anderson movie, "Resident Evil: Afterlife," features one scene that's memorable, if only because it's so comical. You were looking for more than one memorable scene? Wrong movie.

Hill is great, but he's just like the last five main characters in these sort of films. Thankfully, Brand's excellent and wildly original performance makes up for this for the most part, so it's not much of a problem.
Nice cinematography and set design aside, "Robin Hood" fails at its most basic level--it's not particularly entertaining, and as such, it's not particularly worth your time.

It's impossible to get excited about such cardboard roles from writers Jose Rivera and Tim Sullivan. These two need to write to Juliet ASAP to rediscover their love for writing %u2014 if they ever had it.
It's not the best the genre has to offer, but if studios insist on making video games into movies, they could do worse.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Better than the last film, but the latest in this disappointing franchise is "Shrek" out of luck.
"Memaws on Mid-Life Support." To see this movie again, you'd have to grab me by the Barneys and push me hard through the Dior.
"MacGruber" is so consistently laugh-out-loud funny and silly that at its worst, you hardly notice any of its flaws.
The over-hyped Jon Favreau movie, "Iron Man 2," is a downer and a disappointment, especially when compared to the entertaining first movie that came before it.

This is not a film you will enjoy. I promise. Of course, there's always the chance that there's someone out there will like it, but that's a risk I'm willing to take. The odds are pretty great in my favor.
There are a few things you should expect a slight romantic comedy to deliver, and "The Back-Up Plan" delivers every one of them.

Let's start by naming a few things scarier than the new "A Nightmare on Elm Street" %u2013 golden retriever puppies, rainbows, chocolate chip cookies, "Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs," and flower gardens.
"The Losers" is a lot of fun, especially when it understands it's an over-the-top action comedy, and not some kind of super-serious revenge story.
Overall, "Killers" makes for good quick, date-movie-ish entertainment, but it's hard to hold it against anyone who would find the whole thing an unbearable mess.
In the end, the film is something of a gift. If ever there was a movie needed right now to underscore the importance of preserving our world and its life-giving waters, this is it.
The chemistry between Carell and Fey is pure fire--they feed off each other, and thus feed audiences several big laughs in the process.

The film delivers exactly what you expect %u2014 well-done action pieces blended with jolts of camp that are so over-the-top, you half expect Mount Olympus to be made from one of Joan Crawford's shoulder pads.
Another Perry film that is certainly flawed but well-worth the watch.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: "The Last Song" hits the big bong of banality early on, and it never recovers.
It's a mood piece that moves. The film clocks in at just over two hours, but it's so enticing in its cold, rain-swept way, the sponge absorbing it is you.

There isn't a surprise to be had. There isn't a moment that isn't telegraphed. There isn't a time when you couldn't toss some tea leaves and, regardless of your skills in that specialized area, know exactly what's coming next.
For the most part, this is a really goofy and fun piece of work, and Cusack hasn't been this good in years.
With breathtaking animation (about the best I've seen in recent years, certainly on par with "Up") and a very sweet tale, "How to Train Your Dragon" is one of the best films of the year thus far.
Well done, if not amazing, "Green Zone" is an entertaining war thriller that delivers more often than not.
The direction is especially impressive, but the film really starts to take a nosedive in the last third. The plot begins to drag, the tone jumps, and the last few scenes are ridiculous.

Though not particularly groundbreaking or memorable, "Diary of a Wimpy Kid" definitely exceeds the standards for a modern family film and it's almost guaranteed to entertain any kid who goes to see it.
There is mold all over this "Alice," and while some of it features the brightest of greens, a lot of it is predictably grim, but not in the way that Burton fans have come to savor.
For a remake, "Death" isn't bad at all. The jokes that really worked in the British film are still quite funny here, and the actors chosen for each respective role are pretty perfect counterparts.

As far as remakes go, it's not the best out there, but it's definitely a worthy effort and a fine display of Chan and Smith's skills, both as dramatic actors and action ones. They're beyond impressive.
"Jonah Hex" is a movie missing every element of what makes a movie. It's a gritty comic book adaptation without the grit. It has characters without character in a story without storytelling.
How about if we just call it what it is: "The C- Team."

Unbelievably sharp writing, excellent performances and a fine mix of lower-brow humor with clever dialogue and mature storytelling make it one of the most entertaining comedies of this year, as well as the past few.
Shockingly, the whole thing probably would've been better off if Shyamalan himself had been involved beyond conception and producing.

I loved this movie. I loved it for giving the finger to what so many American thrillers have become. Instead of coming off an assembly line, here is a thriller that's fresh and different, focused and smart. It has a European sensibility.

Sometimes it's sweet, sometimes it's sappy, sometimes it's unbelievably raunchy and occasionally it's rather witty, but none of it melds together particularly well. Often, it's like watching five different movies crammed into one.
One of the best action movies in a long time.
Perhaps the best exploration of American journalism this past decade has seen.

Though many movies have explored Eastern culture and juxtaposed it against the American experience, there still is something to learn here, especially because it repeatedly questions what's important in life.
What Friedberg and Seltzer need to know is that in order to create a successful spoof, you have to understand the genre's more mature older brother, satire. And they don't.
Who would've thought the best use of 3-D yet in film would be a "Step Up" movie?

This isn't the summer's best comedy, but at this point in the season, when movies typically take a turn for the worse before better fare appears in the fall, it comes through with enough laughs to make it worth a look.
In a world where pop culture shields us from the truth, this movie is something of a novelty. It isn't afraid to tell it.
A film that is a true gamechanger in every way, something so visually spellbinding and inventive that it really proves there is room out there for flat-out originality in mainstream cinema.

Despite some surprisingly decent performances, it just isn't as fun as it should be. But Stallone does prove there's still some room left in the action genre for these titans, so let's why not? Let's have another round.
As far as these kind of movies go, it's fairly good. Better yet, you don't just feel as if you're watching a sad sap story on the back of a postcard like "Dear John" or "The Last Song."
A horrible movie that likely will entertain (very young) children. But when movies like "Toy Story 3" and "Despicable Me" are still in theaters, it feels irresponsible to force them to see this.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: When you see Jolie leap from bridges onto moving semis or when you see how she ingeniously gets a cop to drive with the help of a stun gun, you're essentially looking at the female version of James Bond. Jolie knows it, and she owns it.
If you think "Lost" was complicated, let's just say it's kitten chow when compared to this.

You can feel the French sensibility ringing throughout "Despicable Me." There is a cool aloofness to the proceedings that gives the film an edge and helps to make its dark humor something unique and unexpected.

"The Sorcerer's Apprentice" is more frustrating than it is bad--there's a lot of potential here, and if the writing had been more inspired, this could have been a strong comeback for both Cage and for Disney.
Cruise and Cruz are a well-paired team, here to have fun, and that fun translates in a movie that features moments that are intentionally and deliriously absurd.

Shyamalan has been working in cinema for more than a decade now, but none of his films are nearly as disastrous as this. It's his final plea to get his name back in Hollywood, and I don't think anyone will hear it.
Manages to transcend the soapiness of its predecessors and work quite well as an engaging story about sacrifice, romance and, interestingly, the inner conflicts of the undead.
A startlingly good comeback for a franchise nearly spoiled for good with the horrendous "Alien vs. Predator" films.
Once again, you're left with a groundswell of admiration for the skilled people at Pixar, who have an uncanny way of balancing emotional weight with outrageous moments of comedy and action.
It's hard to take slapstick and gross-out stuff seriously coming from a bunch of 40-year-olds.
Be forewarned--after watching it, some might feel dirty upon leaving the theater. And I'm pretty sure that's the point. So, um, good for the fimmmakers!
Previously, director Tom Dey made "Failure to Launch" and "Showtime," the latter of which was one of the worst movies of 2002. Congratulations Tom, you've done it again in 2010 with "Marmaduke."
It's not particularly funny, it runs a bit long, and it certainly uses its fair share of cliches, but it somehow manages to be charming and likable for most of its runtime.

At nearly three hours, it's too long by a third...and that's where the quibbles end. The film is rich and intelligent, beautifully shot and just as well acted. Not the year's best movie, but among them.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For scares alone, "Insidious" deserves an "A." It may not be very original, but for a fun trip through a haunted house, it works exceedingly well.
Apparently, their hearts did go on--and how. Easily, one of the year's best films. It's fantastic, with two amazing performances by Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio.

If this film underscores anything, it's just how deeply we still misunderstand the Middle East and how our culture--in this case, pop culture--completely misses complexities it can't even begin to understand.
In the new Russell Mulcahy movie, "Resident Evil: Extinction," one scene is effective. You wanted more than one? Wrong movie.

It's for those who remember the days when the bad guy at school wasn't just the bully in the next seat, but an ex-jock whose life peaked when they were 17 and who now possesses the authority that comes with age, position and a whistle.
Out of focus.
The rats multiply at a rate that suggests Willard's basement is the city's red light district.
Between them, young love and bacteria bloom. Between us, bacteria consumes the movie.
High-strung, melodramatic hogwash steeped in a measure of scientific fact. Emmerich takes it as seriously as he can and his movie, as a result, delivers more provocative fun than you might expect.
Kidman and Law share almost no screen time together, which harms the film. Still, there are moments that are sufficiently ablaze, and make "Cold Mountain" a worthwhile diversion.
The story is bland and workmanlike--week-old catnip that's lost its bite. What saves it is the animation, which is set amid a live-action world and which is extremely well done.
Casting a stain.
After just 30 minutes of "Whipped," you either want to hose down the screen with Lysol or dip yourself in bleach. It's that offensive, that rotten, and it easily stands as the worst film in years.
All the world can blow up around Lara Croft--and it does here--but who cares when there's no reason to fear for her life?
A fresh blast of toxic air that lingers.
Strangled with formula.
About as subtle as an amplified death rattle--only not quite as fun to listen to.
Cruz smolders with sexuality.
Memorable, with a terrific performance by Presley Chweneyagae as Tsotsi that burns in its contained rage.
Armed with good performances--and contrivances.
Nude and loving it.

Free speech and its ramifications are at the heart of "Shut Up & Sing," which recognizes that for the celebrity, engaging in a public exchange of ideas and opinions isn't always without its costs. The price can be dire.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For the movie--and audiences--the good news is that both Tatum and Dewan are just enough to best the bum script. They are likeable and their dance talent is undeniable.
Thank God for Fat Bastard.

Directly charging him with mass murder, the film colors Kissinger as a secretive, paranoid, duplicitous megalomaniac who rose to political superstardom while literally--the movie claims--getting away with decisions that left hundreds of thousands dead.
Ruthlessly dumb people--but funny, too.
"Snow Dogs" doesn't offer much, but to be fair, it had the youngest viewers at my screening cheering and laughing until the end.
When compared to Disney's best animated films, "Atlantis: The Lost Empire" doesn't compare.
Comes off like a flamboyant cartoon, another film about the deglamorization of glamorous people living it up in the glamorous world of drugs.
A terrific movie with excellent performances from Crowe and Bale. If it doesn't find itself on the short list of Academy Award contenders, the film itself has been robbed.
Will the Farrellys mine enough gross-out scenes to generate a box-office buzz? The idea that they won't is the air of desperation that hangs over the movie and which, too often, suffocates it.
The bum execution ironically sheds light on just how dim this film about light and dark really is.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Somebody needs to tell the director to get his head out of the computer and back into humanity, because "Beowulf," while exciting at the end, is sorely lacking in humanity throughout.
If "Margot at the Wedding" had come to the fore with something interesting to say about corrupt families and sibling rivalry, which is the movie it wants to be, we might have had something here.
Excellent performances mark "The Savages," with Linney and Hoffman each navigating characters who could have become unlikable had they not been shaded with nuance.
There's no sinking into "Atonement," no losing yourself to it, no moment when the screen fades away and the story and the characters come to the fore to overcome you.
An undeniably great-looking movie that loses its way.
A necessary throwback, a movie focused on building character, atmosphere and chills rather than on being merely a gory gross-out.
The film, which initially seems as if it might only exist to serve its splendid dialogue, comes to serve its characters, who resonate long after Reitman and Cody deliver their final twist.
It's bloody -- and it's bloody excellent.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Reindeer roadkill.
The new Robert Redford movie, "Lions for Lambs," is nothing if not nostalgic and well-intentioned, and that's part of its problem.
The big monster in this movie isn't the human race, but those humans who failed to make a compelling film.
Apparently, they took the title seriously. It feels so false, you sense it was written, directed and conceived by martians.

Somebody should put Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson in a remake of "The Miracle Worker," because when it comes to a working actor whose personality can override even the dreariest of cinematic drivel, he's right near the top.
The screen burns with talent.
As you'd expect from Kubrick, this is a cerebral film that works on several levels--the illusory, the real, the ethereal and everything that falls in between.
"Saw IV" should be tossed into the business end of 1988's "Woodchipper Massacre."
Clooney delivers a performance that demands what only a few in the industry can deliver--a critical, grounded turn that allows the film to savor its well-earned commercial overtones.

After seeing Ben Affleck's solid directorial debut in "Gone Baby Gone," maybe it's time to suggest that the actor give up his day job and turn to writing and directing full time. If this movie of his is any indication, he could have a serious go of it.
So, a rabbi and a priest fall in love...
The film seems manufactured to furrow a cynic's brow before bringing up their lunch.

Hurley is great fun to watch, a Faustian powerhouse of curves, smoky eyes and big hair who sounds exactly like Jackie Collins doing an imitation of Madonna's pan-European accent. It's creepy, but effective.

Sex, lies and politics--they all boil together beautifully in "The Contender," a strong political drama that understands Washington, knows its dirty secrets, and uses its excellent cast to fine effect.
The director wants his film to be as smooth and as infectious as the funkadelic music he highlights throughout, but a string of bad decisions prevents that from happening.
Toys are us.
I couldn't have karaoked less about it.

The main difference between the first film and its new sequel is this: In "Elizabeth," Cate Blanchett emerged as one staunch, formidable queen. In "Elizabeth: The Golden Age," she's been reduced to a drag queen.
Real Life? Nah--but the emotions are real.
This swift, rank, enjoyably dark movie presses against so many limits, it achieves the threshold of a new limit.
Costner finds in the Western something grand, familiar and new within a genre that clearly has some life in it yet.
Chokes the life out of a classic--and then runs it hard into the business end of a butcher knife.
Zellweger and McGregor have only their dimpled cuteness to get them through this movie, which you sense, at least from their mugging, that they believe is enough. It isn't.
Designed only for the youngest of children, who might be roused by the silly action, or perhaps for John Hughes, who might delight in the fact that his influence continues to color the landscape.
Cowabungled.
A romantic zombie comedy that tips its hat to George Romero and mines one very funny spoof that doesn't ignore the rules of the zombie horror genre--though it does tamper with them.
The show remains as fresh and as laugh-out-loud funny today as it did when it first premiered in 1976. Who knew that one of pop culture's most enduring love affairs would be between a frog and a pig?
Time to remodel.
We're finished.

It's a tragedy, a romantic comedy and a drama, with its charismatic cast navigating the manufactured highs and lows with enough skill to deepen what otherwise might have been a movie sorely lacking in depth.
Good performances and solid writing mark the series.
Such episodes as "Ladies on the Ropes" and "The Meek Shall Inherit Rhonda" suggest that the pleasure it once evoked seems better suited for the time in which it was conceived.
The film's cheat ending aside, this arch, ridiculous movie heaves, sweats and steams, and for the most part, it delivers what its title promises.
Matricide.
Joyless dreck, another dumbed-down teen comedy fired out of Hollywood with all the crudeness of a spitball.
From the BBC, a lively retelling of the tale that once again makes it hip to steal from the rich and give to the poor.
A champion of imagination.
Camp isn't just an undercurrent here--it's the grindhouse force that drives the movie, with Bruce Campbell clearly happy behind the wheel.

His name might sound like a pair of designer jeans from the '70s, but few directors are better. He was as important to the emerging shape of the Western as Francis Ford Coppolla was to reimagining the gangster movie.
Tom Skerritt's Sherrif Brock and Kathy Baker as his wife were pivotal to the show's Emmy-winning success. They were something real and recognizable within Kelley's button-pushing absurdity.
A big-budget epic of the American Revolution, with Mel Gibson, of all people, leading the charge.

Some shows hold up up. Others don't. Viewed now, the fifth season of Michael Mann's "Miami Vice" feels more like "Miami Blight." Who knew the show would be among the first to champion the metrosexual?
For those who love bad movies--really, really bad movies--this terrific set is like taking a one-two punch to the head. And yet you cry out for more.
Highlights include "The Antowuk Horror," "Vendetta Road" and "Alice in Disco Land." Seriously.
If there's a criticism of the set, it's of Schama himself, who favors a heavy pen. Still, sift through the wordplay and the padding, and what you find is a mind bright with insight.
movie_title: Simon Schama's The Power of Art (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though the fourth season marks a more family-friendly shift in tone--and thus neuters the duo's racy wit, which is unfortunate--the collection nevertheless is very good.

It's all just enough--just enough for most fans and just enough for the casually curious, who now might be tempted to do what Fox really wants them to do--buy all those boxed sets of the television series awaiting them on DVD.
As charming as the film's title sounds, here is a movie, distinctly French in its clipped rhythms and melodramatic arc, that's anything but charming. It is, in fact, a jumbled, caustic tour-de-force.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A coming-of-age film of the toughest sort. Far from Wayne's best, but nevertheless a movie whose ending ignites a heated discussion.

Singer and his screenwriters know the value of a surprise and they deliver their share without dipping into the absurd. The result is a movie that surpasses expectations, a superhero flick that can rightfully take its place alongside the best.
An overpraised thriller that's really as superficial as a bruise.
Dull blades. Saddles audiences with a buckets-of-blood mentality that deadens the spirit and drowns the film.
In spite of what's its title suggests, "Balls of Fury" isn't a sex comedy. The balls of fury here are ping-pong balls, and they disappoint.
For those who appreciate the power of Bean in brevity, this 'Bean' leads to too much bad gas.
TV material. Kelly Rippa should have played the nanny, Kathie Lee Gifford should have played the Laura Linney role, Verne Troyer should have played the kid--and a mutt should have played that dog.
In spite of the film's startling deluge of dirty dialogue and sight gags, tender notes are struck.
It's a paradox--it's at once exhilarating yet exhausting, thrilling yet boring, masterful yet banal.

Has two things going for it--its spectacular, Academy Award-nominated special effects and the fact that it ends. Everything else about this ridiculous, three-hanky film sends it sharply into nightmare.
Throughout, the plots become almost secondary to the chemistry blistering between Powell and Loy. Theirs was one of the great screen romances.
A beautifully mounted movie that's difficult to shake.

This terrific box set from the BBC features 10 productions of Ibsen's most famous plays, including Ingrid Bergman and Michael Redgrave in "Hedda Gabler," Judi Dench and Michael Gambon in "Ghosts," Anthony Hopkins in "Little Eyolf," among others.
A tightly paced, involving movie that underscores the timeless appeal of Finney's tale.
This cloying, fractured slop of uninspired swill is content to swim among summer's worst.

Has a strong enough cast to cast you way above its unnecessary complications. The actors are, in fact, having such a grand time of it here, you might find yourself enjoying the movie purely for their performances.
Oh, there's reason to fear. 'Underdog' the movie is here.
A rousing travelogue of espionage.

There isn't enough dry ice in the world to conceal the rot of stupidity hovering over "13 Ghosts." With Embeth Davidtz and Matthew Lillard both overacting to a lower power in supporting roles, there apparently also aren't enough acting coaches.
Good, occasionally powerful noir that's been overhyped.
It's a film at war with itself. Worse, it's a mixed bag of carefully packaged entertainment, with little room for spontaneity or surprise.

With the exception of a few memorable moments between Eddie Murphy and Owen Wilson, the film is mostly a drag, a second-rate effort with top-rate talent whose biggest risk seems to be a reversal of race.
Terrible. A substitute for sleep medication that's so self-indulgent and plodding, it drove four people out of my screening midway through.
Robin Williams creates a character who earns our revulsion--and somehow also our sympathy.
Welcome--now get out.
Village idiot.
In a blood-thirsty, dead-three-centuries sort of way, it's perfectly charming.
Drowns the Aegean in hair products.
Crap circles.
Much of it is good, but other moments feel uninspired, as if Sleeping Beauty had a hand in writing the script.

A crude, funny satire that tackles local television anchors and their newscasts. Those are easy targets to skewer, but the movie mines more truth from its subject than some in the biz will want to admit.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While you sometimes feel its length, stick with it--its in its layers that the movie comes alive.
It is an excellent, first-rate account of a story that, depending on your perspective, did or didn't end so well for Christopher Johnson McCandless (a terrific Emile Hirsch).
If there's a disappointment, it's that Aunt Clara (Marion Lorne) is missing from the entire season.
The emphasis on this war is personalized, and what Charlie Wilson learns from it could change the world now.
Sidney Toler continues on as Chan, the smooth Chinese sleuth you could have over for dinner or a murder, preferably the latter, though his manners certainly are good enough for the former.
One of last year's better new television shows.

The eighth and final season of "Will & Grace" finds Debra Messing, Eric McCormack, Megan Mullally and Sean Hayes having a final go of it in a series that came to mean plenty to plenty for good reason.
From the BBC, a sci-fi spin-off of the network's "Doctor Who" franchise, with a solid dose of sex meant to spice up the proceedings. Often, it does.
Take the cannoli--and if you're a fan of these movies, definitely take this set.
Igor? No. More like Ibore.
It's a fine movie--spare and moving--and, in its way, also kind of daring.
Some moments are satisfying and they linger, and then it all becomes so ridiculous, the film falls apart.
It takes ovaries the size of Alaska to update a classic like George Cukor's 1939 catfight "The Women," but that's just what Diane English has done--and nobody should thank her for it.
A mixed bag of tricks that sometimes works, and sometimes doesn't.
Righteous? Not exactly--though with these two, it certainly should have been.
It's a lovely, moving film, marked by memorable performances throughout.

The photography is rich, stunning. You watch each show in admiration for the effort, and come away grateful for having experienced something new about the world you likely wouldn't have seen otherwise.
Here's a note to Nicolas Cage: Your stylist hates you. Your director and screenwriters? Not so far behind.
The movie pits Arnold Schwarzenegger against the devil (Gabriel Byrne), with director Peter Hyams delivering tense moments of action amid not-so-subtle choices for character development.
Very funny. Even though his hands are nowhere on it, you can feel the presence of John Waters everywhere.
Blade Slummer.
Here's what they got right: The name of the movie. Disaster, indeed.

The unstoppable Anna Faris has perk in her pipes and a pep in her step, but a bum script working at every turn to tear her down. That's a shame, because with the right material, Faris could do very well, indeed.
It's exactly what you expect...and that's part of its problem. There isn't one surprise in this movie, not one, which is a good reason why it feels so hammered out and routine.
Ice Cube is good, but the story has been done so many times in so many better movies, there's little here to recommend.
Riff out? Please. This is about as hardcore as a wrestling match between Clay Aiken and Barry Manilow.
A daring, politically incorrect satire on the movie industry that turns out to be one of summer's loosest, funniest comedies.
Let's just say the DNA of this Clone is not the same as what came before it.
There's no denying it has its moments. There's also no denying it doesn't have enough of them.
A smart, satisfying movie. Once again, Allen removes himself from Manhattan, and finds his muse in Europe.
Entre nous, the show--often called "Sex and the City" for men--only has gotten better.
Jason Statham sports enough stubble to scrape the metal off a gun. Not that he'd want to do so in this slight, silly heist movie, which turns out to be plenty of fun.
Oh, look--a good movie.

It's a terrible movie. You could go into any supermarket, pluck two reasonably attractive people from the check-out line, put them in this movie, and nothing would change. Shia LaBeouf and Michelle Monaghan are lost amid the dumb, uninvolving chaos.

Good, highly entertaining performances lift Doubt into the stratosphere, where it often courts camp with the mere twist of Streep's mouth, but even they can't help the movie from ultimately feeling oddly hollow.

It's about finding the courage to raise your voice in the face of great hatred, opposition and fear. That it comes by coincidence in the wake of the assassination of Benazir Bhutto gives it an immediacy and a power it otherwise might have lacked.
About as entertaining as being slapped by a stranger.
This is a movie that doesn't just want to take over the cineplex--it wants to own it. For better and worse, it has a hell of a time doing so, though not without belching and hicupping along the way.
A fabulous, important and timely movie with a core performance by Sean Penn that, at the very least, will lead to an Academy Award nomination for Best Actor.
What a horrible little movie.
Bolt? More like Sparky. The movie is nowhere near as good as this year's best animated film, "Wall-E," but it does zip with energy, the story escalates nicely and, in the end, it's a good time.
Sloppy, overheated, sometimes involving, ultimately shallow. Read the book--skip the movie.
It's an action movie, it does a fine job updating Bond for the present, and it doesn't dumb him down in the process. The movie rocks. Loved it.
"It's strictly for tots, who should enjoy it. As for those adults in attendance, there are worse ways to spend your time at the movies."
Just bizarre enough to work--and when it does, it can be a howler.
A muddled effort that strains to come together.

When it comes right down to it, the less said about the movie the better. But in lieu of that, let's just tackle it, vilify it, screw it to the wall, and send it back into the sewer from which it came.
A beautifully measured, well-acted period piece, with a fine performance by Angelina Jolie.
The movie is best viewed as a rushed, modest starting point to understanding how Bush got into office, why he got into office, and why he never should have gotten into office.
Well, it certainly is enthusiastic.
Pop a blue pill if you see it. In this case, a few funny moments don't make for an especially funny movie.
Not great by any stretch of the imagination, but Secret Life of Bees is better than most family fare currently available to audiences. Latifah and Hudson, in particular, and memorable.
No. Just...no.
The new Ridley Scott thriller, "Body of Lies," is a misfire, but not an embarrassment. So, that's positive, I guess.
And here we thought Diana was dead.

Every voting adult concerned about the damages created by the Bush administration in the wake of 9/11 should watch it. So should those who steadfastly believe that no real or lasting damages have been made by that administration.
Why?

Sure, it's a familiar tale, but it's a familiar tale told well. Anyone who remembers that time in their lives when running around the city until all hours of the night could lead to romance will likely view it with fondness.
Features moments so light, they alone could lift the economy.
Nice performances can't save this dull movie from its bum script.
The film is trash, and it's fittingly shot in the hues of a corpse.
Uses its sly brand of humor to say plenty about the state of race relations in the U.S. (really).
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's insane, it's ridiculous, it's way over the top, and while it might not be the best in the franchise, it mostly delivers what its target audience wants.
Strong performances mark this movie, with Penelope Cruz, in particular, rarely quite so good.
Look. Let's just toss some pig's blood on this baby and call it a day.
What a lovely movie.
In the wake of "Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day," we have yet another screwball comedy. And this one, while it has its problems, isn't so bad, either.

Right from the start, it's easy to think, 'Well, poor Miss Pettigrew. She may have lived for a day, but let's hope that she and everyone with her passes by nightfall. Certainly, they will have worn themselves out by then.' And then there's a shift.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Apparently, they really do hate us abroad. Just look at this jewel inspired by Asian fare. Risible doesn't even begin to describe it. Lost in translation? No. Lost from the get-go.

Haven't these children been bullied enough!? Okay, seriously, while yes, we've seen all this before in better (Apatow) movies, some of the writing is very clever, the jokes do hit--and the young actors are very good.

A cross between "The Karate Kid" and "Fight Club," though without the A-list cast. That's right, the A-list cast. When compared to the D-listers assembled in "Back Down," Pat Morita and Ralph Macchio might as well be A-list.
Seuss' genius, updated for the masses. It's a curious mix, and it isn't always successful, but there's no doubt that this jumbled tale is the best mass-market adaptation yet of one of Seuss' works.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A film that at once embraces formula and, in critical scenes, dismisses it all together.
A complicated mess that doesn't offer audiences a single challenge beyond the very real challenge of getting through it.

All of this feverish bending, twirling, twisting and snapping of the body is so infused with attitude, in fact, that it allows the film and its characters to live and breathe in ways that run counter to the movie's otherwise rhythmless script.

If you're going to compete in an arena already owned by the "Harry Potter" and "Narnia" franchises, you'd better enter that fray determined to show you can compete favorably with them. And that's where "Spiderwick" runs into trouble.
This is actually a movie you forget while watching it.
So far, this is the worst movie of the year.
The president of the United States gets shot--and then behold! The movie also is down for the count.
About as charming as being slapped by a stranger.
Moments feel disappointingly scripted, so it's especially good news that many of its characters do not.

So self-aware and dull, you wonder what's the point of Haynes being experimental if his experiment doesn't yield something that's compelling or, at the very least, entertaining. Insight might have been a goal, but there's no insight here.

In spite of the rawness the film's subject, Schnabel wisely didn't create a weepy--far from it. This is a film about a flawed womanizer with little time for his children who comes to face himself by the vehicle of his own memoir.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The best movie of Daniel Day-Lewis' career turns out to be in the best movie of Paul Thomas Anderson's career.
A flawed movie that nevertheless offers scenes of gripping terror--and a few moments of genuine surprise.
Terminal cancer can wait.
After this bomb, McConaughey's next project should be a reality show called "Pimp My Abs."
A superb film, in which the enemy isn't just time.
A national embarrassment.
Everyone involved should have known when to fold 'em. The movie is about as interesting as counting cards.
Creepy time down south.
Not great--but not forgettable, either. Offers enough laughs, male-frontal nudity and charm to offer a swell time at the movies.
Essentially, it's 88 distracting minutes of watching Al Pacino work the hell out of his formidable fright wig.
No Country for Young Women.
In this case, audiences are deceived.

Nothing special, nothing risible, nothing memorable, nothing that's going to last long at the cineplex. It just sort of evaporates on screen. And that's almost worse than being a bomb. At least you'll remember the bomb.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: "So here it is: The best superhero movie ever. The Dark Knight deftly accomplishes all one could hope for, and then it surpasses it, and then it continues to surprise. The movie isn't just a triumph, it is that rare pop-culture oddity: A masterpiece."
Long live Brennan and Dale. A funny, raunchy comedy that likely will transport grown men back to their childhoods while watching it.
Similac should be so good.

The return of Scully and Mulder turns out to be a welcome return. While the movie has nothing on the popular television show that inspired it, it does have its moments, and a nice little undercurrent of evil that's appealingly dark.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You could spend all week eating bacon at a pig farm and still find more ham in "Mamma Mia!," an irrepressible, unstoppable kaleidoscope of karaoke camp gone berserk that features a cast happily mainlining ABBA's songbook.
After seeing this superior movie, Hancock likely is back in rehab.

The movie respects its young audience, it has a keen appreciation for what it means to be a child in a troubled world, and it knows that there's plenty to be said for the optimism that comes with innocence.
There are more problems afoot than just its misleading rating, beginning with the story itself.
So far, the quintessential summer movie, so absurd, slick and entertaining, it's an outright blast. Scarylina Jolie has never been quite so intimidating--or fun.
A terrific movie, easily one of Pixar's best. The animation is startling and the story follows suit. So far, this is the animated film to beat at next year's Academy Awards.
Far from the MENSA candidate it should have been. In spite of its appealing leads, "Get Smart" is consistently led down by a bum script.
Now, this is how you go green.
With this sort of junk, Myers obviously is all out of love, and one day he'll be so lost without us.
Not a complete return to form (by far), but also not a failure. Let's be fair--this is the best film Shyamalan has put out in years.
Don't mess with audiences, Sandler. Yet another bum movie from the actor that so steeped in stereotypes, it's nauseating.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie easily karate chops the weekend competition. A fine, fun film, filled with excellent animation and well-drawn characters.
A fine throwback, and one filled with moments of real suspense. In spite of its rushed, awkward ending, I'd take this any day over the Saw movies, and all that came in their wake.

It's nice to see the girls again, but this "City" seems oddly smaller than it did when it ran on HBO. In the end, a more accurate title would have been "Strife in the City." These women, after all, aren't having much sex.
A swell throwback, and one that was worth the wait.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: LOVED the first movie. This one? Not so much, but not that bad.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It would be little without its superb martial arts sequences, so its good to report that the movie isn't just filled with them, but that each fight was choreographed by Yuen Wo Ping.
Not the sin some claim it to be.
No, Speed Racer. No.

THIS is the way to begin the summer movie season. A smart, well-written movie that never condescends to the genre or to audiences. Robert Downey Jr. is wry and exciting as Iron Man, perfectly suiting the suit.
It's a big story, one filled with enough life lessons and tears to come apart at the seams, but the good news is that it doesn't.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As appealing as the actors are--and as much as I rooted for the movie to come through--too often it didn't. This isn't a bad movie; it just could have been a lot better.

It skirted around George's chronic drugs problems, and made no mention of the circumstances surrounding his death. But it also neglected to mention that he was an endlessly generous man, who gave away millions without asking for recognition.
Writer Julian Fellowes's tendency to shove pompous, verbose dialogue into his characters' mouths suited this adaptation perfectly.
Compared with the adaptation earlier this year by Ian La Frenais and Dick Clement of the book by Alan Furst, Spies Of Warsaw, this was insipid.
At one point, Paul describes his music as "somewhere between euphoria and melancholy," which is also an apt description of Eden itself.
An engaging, scenically spectacular documentary about one of the world's most extraordinary eccentrics.
A grotesque squandering of time, talent and a great idea.
Any director who can make a film that dares to be this expressionistic is a talent to watch.
A trip to the innermost circle of comedy hell.

Pixar's tenth film is one of the most uplifting ever made. It's an instant classic and one of those rare movies which will appeal to all ages and intellects. It has heart and intelligence, beauty and excitement, plus loads and loads of imagination.
It might make a passable video game. Despite expensive production design, as a movie it is pretty much unwatchable.
It's like Mamma Mia! without the songs, wit and charm, or Shirley Valentine after a full frontal lobotomy.

The reason this wildly improbable, socially clueless drivel is easily the most entertaining film of the week is that it contains three of the most exciting action sequences I've seen in the past ten years.
The Invention Of Lying deserves high marks for cleverness, but low ones for humanity and warmth.
Foxx is an Oscar-winner thanks to his uncanny impersonation of Ray Charles in Ray, but he plays Ayers as a multitude of tics and non sequiturs. He is hampered by Susannah Grant's muddled screenplay.
Much of it seems suitable only for adults or sophisticated children who have been taught about survival of the fittest, but the narration becomes childishly anthropomorphic.
Creation is an elephantine, but forgettable biopic.
It's exactly like Final Destination 1, 2 and 3, but in 3D. Unfortunately, three-dimensional images do little more than show up the one-dimensional characters.
The beauty of Surrogates lies not so much in the somewhat conventional thriller plot, though it is efficiently crafted and keeps the audience guessing up to the end.

It is harmless, entertaining fun for under-12s, and a worthy follow-up to Surf's Up from Sony Pictures Animation. It's not challenging Pixar just yet, or even Warner Brothers, but at least it's heading in the right direction.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A redundant compendium of blokeish cliches.
At its best, the film reminded me of another road movie about alternative lifestyles, Flirting With Disaster, but this isn't nearly as sharp or funny.
The dialogue is so painfully naive that it seems to have been written by a 15-year-old who has read nothing but Alistair MacLean novels.
movie_title: 31 North 62 East (Too Close to the Truth) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Julie & Julia is among the most heart-warming, feelgood films of the year, and so joyously obsessed with food that it might be described as a feed-good movie.
Dreary and unoriginal, like hundreds of its sub-Ken Loach predecessors, this is how Billy Elliott might have turned out had it been made by a collective of depressive Essex girls.
A little charmer.

This is not Wilde. It's tame and dreary, with no energy, suspense or horror. When the picture of Dorian's demonic soul is finally uncovered, it resembles not so much evil incarnate as the late Max Wall.
A lot of fun, highly original and the most entertaining action sci-fi to hit our screens for many years.
By a wide margin the outstanding romantic comedy of 2009.
Virtually everything about Allison Burnett's screenplay is blander, dumber and less daring than the original.
An underwhelming screenplay and weak acting mean this is unlikely to spawn one sequel, let alone many.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As a director of child actors, Poliakoff is hopeless. Worst of all, he seems not to have seen many movie thrillers in the past 20 years, for the pacing is pedestrian and the camerawork static, more redolent of bad episodes of Midsomer Murders.
A hit movie that's small in scale, but big in heart - the most charming British film of the year.
Marshall does his best to disguise the cast's lack of terpsichorean talent with fast editing, but doesn't entirely succeed.

Is Avatar worth seeing? Yes, on a big screen in 3D because it really is spectacular. The Na'vi are more expressive than any previous examples of motioncapture technology, except Gollum in The Lord Of The Rings.
St Trinians 2 achieves the near-impossible, by being even cruder, messier and more amateurish than the first outing.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Precious, pointless and tediously self-aggrandising.

The plot is frequently incomprehensible, and Rachel McAdams's poorly photographed femme fatale could be edited out of the picture without making much difference. Most of the time, I hadn't a clue what she was doing, and she didn't seem to either.

Jonze has created one of the most offbeat, original and interesting films of the year. It's just a pity he didn't make it more accessible for children - and remove it a lot farther from the therapist's couch.
It's strong on claustrophobia, but extremely weak on characterisation, so it's not terribly involving.
Zac Efron proves again that he's more than a pretty face in this period charmer, but the performance you'll remember to the end of your days is from an unknown British actor called Christian McKay.
An extremely dull and unfunny comedy with pop-culture references where the gags should be, and humdrum voicings.

People start wandering about in a zomboid fashion but no one notices. The acting deteriorates into overwrought melodramatics. The plot gets sillier and sillier, and makes less and less sense. The Box should be taken away in one, and speedily buried.
It has a lyricism, passion and beauty unmatched in cinema this year.
So deliriously corny that I can imagine it becoming the unlikeliest hit of the year.
Arguably the most preposterous picture of the year.
The film is adequately acted by its two young leads, but for this to be terrifying it would need an already hyped-up, excited audience, ready to jump at the smallest thing.
To me, and I suspect the mass of the cinema-going public, it feels nasty and pointlessly vindictive. There's a hole in the middle of this movie, where a modicum of empathy and humanity ought to be.
There's no denying it's well crafted, but it's Haneke's silliest and least interesting film.
Undermining the entire snooze-fest is Lee and Schamus's sentimental, clichéd view of Woodstock as the last flowering of hippie innocence.
For a movie that desperately wants to be inspirational, Mira Nair's Amelia is a disappointingly earthbound hagiography.
Writer-director Sophie Barthes can't decide whether to take the idea seriously or comedically, with the result that it works neither as comedy nor drama.
If you want massive spectacle, an orgy of disaster-movie clichés and schadenfreude run riot, you won't be disappointed. Cinematic popcorn doesn't come poppier, cornier (or cheesier) than this.
Harry Brown is not a great film, but it is an important one, with messages we ignore at our peril.
There's a fine line between fragile sensitivity and wimpishness, and Ben Whishaw tramples all over it. He is the drippiest British actor since the Merchant Ivory heyday of James Wilby.
If you want an entertaining period piece, you could do a lot worse than attend Robert Zemeckis' A Christmas Carol.
About as entertaining as a goalless draw at Accrington Stanley.
A more chaotic mixture of good and bad. Its faults include a tiresomely hectoring narrator and an approach that tries to cram far too many disparate thoughts into 100 minutes.

Whereas Dahl kept his foxes and other animals relatively true to their wild selves, Anderson humanises and Americanises without bothering to establish a coherent set of rules for his far too self-consciously quirky universe.
At 89 minutes, even though the story is repetitive and the humour childish, there's no time to get bored. Five to ten year-olds will find it cool. Adults, less so.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A script this lousy should never have gone into production, and should have been abandoned as soon as anyone with any influence witnessed the rushes. The final result is a disgrace to everyone involved. Please God, let there be no Year Two.
A depressingly stupid parody of movies such as Save The Last Dance and Step Up, this relies even more than their previous films on toilet humour.
Like Meek's music, it's not much good and definitely not sophisticated, but I enjoyed it.
Welcome and much needed proof that great action movies don't have to be meaningless and moronic.
This is an important film that packs a powerful emotional punch almost 60 years after the main events.
By the end, I was thoroughly alienated by the movie's twee, self-satisfied empty-headedness and rooting for the homeless man to do his worst.
A bloodthirsty costume epic directed for maximum gruesomeness.
Looking For Eric is not so much a game of two halves as a chaotic kickabout, in which the rules of the game keep changing. It will score with some people but, I confess, I was looking for more.
It has none of the underlying humanity of that other revenge thriller Eden Lake, and by the end I found the experience repulsive and deeply exploitative of its audience's worst instincts.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Rude, crude and defiantly male, it's the ultimate phallocentric antidote to Sex And The City, and easily the funniest American comedy of the year.
It's meticulously researched as regards period detail, and the whole thing is full of excitement and suspense.
Great cinema can extend our own experience by making us understand how it must feel to be somebody else - and this is, in its gentle and unpretentious way, great cinema.
It fails to be as likeable, despite being beautifully acted by Dustin Hoffman and Emma Thompson.
It's brainless, it's soulless, and it gave me a headache.
Horrid, hackneyed and half-witted.
The film is sufficiently tense, economical and fast-moving to warrant a Hollywood remake, but lacks the lethal menace or twisted ingenuity of the original Saw.
Bad taste? Undoubtedly. And the slim storyline only just sustains itself to feature length. But if you're in the mood for this kind of impishness, it's extremely jolly entertainment.

The lack of new ideas might not matter if the puzzles were fresh or entertaining, but they aren't. Director Renny Harlin has made enjoyably daft movies before, including Cliffhanger and The Long Kiss Goodnight, but here he fails to set our pulses racing.
This is a curious and unusual film, but unfortunately more admirable than enjoyable.
movie_title: L'Empreinte de l'ange (Mark of an Angel) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's pacily directed by Jon Wright, but Stephen Prentice's script is clichéd and unsophisticated, with characters too young to have seen Scream and probably too dumb to understand it.

Most people won't care enough about these people or believe in their relationships to sit out all 115 minutes of this icily mannered film that continually hints at darker, more subversive themes of sado-masochism than it dares to explore.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An art-house collector's item that will reward the patient and the sensitive.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A comedy adventure that the whole family can enjoy, right down to the age of five.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: His film is about the way life transmutes into art, but the art he creates is so lifeless as to be alienating. It's a piece poking fun at morbid self-indulgence that becomes morbid and self-indulgent itself.
Nowhere Boy does offer insights into what made The Beatles great, and it's an unpretentious, well-paced first feature.
The actors give their all, but there's not enough here that's fresh. French Film is plodding and predictable - frightfully English, and not in a good way.
The talented cast deserved better than turgid direction and a cliched script.
Even if it were a more tolerable 90 minutes, it would still sum up everything that is most tedious, crass and despicable about modern Hollywood.

The movie is cringe-worthy when trying to be humorous, and laughable when it attempts belatedly to make us care about these characters with the depth and humanity of wet cardboard. I hate you, pathetic high school movie.

Mann dedicates himself to making Dillinger look cool, and that's the problem with the whole movie. It looks the business, but has no depth, nothing to say, no new angle. It just feels like a homage to older, better films.
With direction this leaden and scripting this ham-fisted, my suspicion is that there will be far too many dry eyes in the house.
Inglourious Basterds is sporadically enjoyable, but it's also a dismal squandering of a once-promising talent.

It could have been thought-provoking drama, but settles for being a novelette-ish tear-jerker. I hate the dismissive phrase 'chick flick' but that's what this is, and it could have been a whole lot more.
There is enough freshness in the documentary-style observation to make up for any lack of imagination in the storyline.
The film plays pretty skilfully with audience expectations, the scenery is lovely, and the performances are above average for this sort of B-movie nonsense.
Bizarrely charmless and misconceived from start to finish, it represents yet another nail hammered into the coffin of Eddie Murphy's career.
Children below the age of ten may be amused... Older people, by which I mean everyone from 11 upwards, may notice that the movie runs out of ideas within 20 minutes.
The movie is too sophisticated in its first hour for preteens, and much too tragically unhip in its second hour for the older teenage audience that might appreciate its pithier wisecracks.
There hasn't been be a more loathsome, depressing or woman-hating movie this year. This is a new low in romantic comedy.
Orphan is nasty but enjoyable, and the whole film is so competently crafted and superbly acted, especially by the three central females, that I was gripped and entertained throughout.

I'm unconvinced that Mesrine was worthy of a four-hour biopic. He's just not that interesting, and though he may have the killer instinct, this movie sags too frequently to have the thriller instinct.
Overlong, boringly vacuous and pointlessly noisy, but I am not this movie's target audience. At least it isn't as pretentious as Watchmen.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)
