movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Max Mayer's film has good intentions, but a weak narrative. This grinds to a halt far too often to make way for maudlin, soft-rock interludes.
The Taking Of Pelham 123 may not be up there with his best, but it's professional, fast-moving and holds the interest. It will pay a few bills, which is the only reason it exists.

The funniest aspect of this turkey is that it cost more than $100 million to make, yet it still looks like something assembled by idiots. It's one of the most abject family films ever to have slithered out of Hollywood's nether regions.
This is not a movie for Hamstered intellectuals. Just imagine how Alvin And the Chipmunks might have turned out if it had been directed by Michael Bay.

Writer-director Wayne Kramer insists on trying to tell us all the way through what we should feel. Yet, by the end, it's not clear what he's trying to say: are U.S. immigration laws unfair, unnecessary or badly enforced?
It's too bad that so photogenic a star is saddled with such a stodgy biopic, which crams about half an hour's worth of incident into 110 minutes.
It's a Hitchcock-style thriller involving mistaken identity, mid-life crisis and adulterous romance. It gets very far-fetched towards the end, but it's enjoyably suspenseful and extremely well acted.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As a fish-out-of-water comedy, it's so lousy that you keep wishing someone would put the poor fish out of its misery.

Antichrist is a horrible combination of extraordinarily unpleasant elements. It's offensively misogynistic. It's needlessly graphic in its use of violence. And its maker almost certainly needs psychiatric help.
Pitched at the other end of the sci-fi market from Transformers 2, this is too quirky and cerebral to be a hit, but it's more than a space oddity.
This film is bad - really, really bad.
As a quiet celebration of ordinary women's resourcefulness, the film is well-crafted, sensitively acted and modestly affecting.
This is the least involving of the series so far, with an unclear storyline and action set-pieces that fail to convey the excitement of the book.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There is no braver satirist than Sacha Baron Cohen today, working in any medium, and I salute him. This movie is going to be as big as Borat, and deservedly so.
The film has poor commercial prospects, as its plot is too slender, its tone too blandly upbeat.
The world's most irritatingly high-pitched rodents are back and noisier than ever, in this lobotomised rip-off of the High School Musical franchise.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Where Date Night never lets us down is in the core believability of the Fosters, who love each other and are credibly bewildered as they find themselves catapulted into a dangerous alien world.
Grant's familiar, pained and rueful expressions start to look like an actor's commentary on the film, not a character's response to events within it.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Letters From Juliet is far from a great movie. But if you're female or -- like me -- a man with a taste for romance and a fairer deal for our senior citizens, this is one of the year's guiltiest pleasures.
It didn't always work for me,but this is one of Winterbottom's most ambitious films, and it's good to see that he's continuing to stretch himself.
Here is yet another American comedy in which a beautiful woman falls head over high heels in love with a worthless geek.
An undistinguished remake of a crude black comedy.
It's junk -- and remarkably soporific when people aren't fighting or shooting each other -- but the action sequences are stylishly directed by Sylvain White. you'll be hearing more of him.
No, it's definitely a zero.

The film is most likeable when it remembers that it is meant to be more than an exercise in middle-aged, middle-class smugness and self-absorption. Its principal strength remains its celebration of female friendship.

It is a hackneyed girl-meets-boy story, adequately performed by Nichola Burley and Richard Winsor. The good news for the film-makers is that Streetdance's likely audience will be much less critical than I am.
A fast-moving swashbuckler with an Arabian Nights flavour and the kind of athleticism that made Douglas Fairbanks a star in the silent era.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This thriller is among the cleverest, most innovative films of the year. It proves that even a mediocre, B-movie script can be made memorable by a strong director and brave leading actor.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is essentially Das Boot in a tank, with four frightened, under-prepared Israeli soldiers reluctantly involved in the 1982 invasion of Lebanon.

Dario Poloni's script pays tribute to Werner Herzog's Aguirre, Wrath Of God, and British cult films such as The Wicker Man, but fails to bind the ingredients into anything like a plausible or satisfactory narrative.
Director Haim Tabakman avoids sensationalism so assiduously that his film has slightly less eroticism than the average party political broadcast.
This is a cracking good yarn, and you shouldn't miss it. It lifted my spirits in these troubling times, and should do the same for yours.
As the various teenagers fight to stay awake, you may find yourself doing exactly the same.
The film is ugly, gross and obnoxious, with all the vulgarity and vomiting you might expect.
In the end, Morris's attempts to explore the boundaries of humour is exploded by a lethal combination of furtive political correctness and transparently terrible taste.
Jennifer Lopez has never looked better or acted worse than in The Back-Up plan, a formulaic chick flick that conveys a deep distrust, if not downright hatred, of child-bearing women.
The film is hectoring enough to put the green movement back 100 years, and you end up wondering how many trees have been felled and air-miles flown to make this abject excuse for slapstick comedy.
A gripping little thriller, with one or two original ideas and a trio of accomplished performances.
Disney starlet Miley Cyrus becomes an early contender for worst actress of the decade in this painful attempt at a romantic tear-jerker.
It will be a hit. But it should have been a whole lot better.
The film is never funny enough, and comes across as dispiritingly mean.
Any anti-materialistic movie from Hollywood - spiritual home of furtive product placement and dodgy role-models - deserves commendation for at least pretending to have its heart in the right place.
Audiences are unlikely to feel sufficiently involved to cope with all the emotional agony.
This is the kind of low-budget movie that attracts respectful reviews, but tiny audiences. That's because there's virtually no story or character development and the main character's an idiot.
What have moviegoers done to deserve releases like these?

Will Forte, who hasn't starred in a movie before and looks extremely unlikely to do so again, lacks the slightest vestige of credibility or charm as MacGruber. He also cowrote the script. Let's just say comedy is not Forte's forte.
Another cheap horror film dressed up like a documentary.
This is a terrible movie with barely concealed contempt for its audience. Please don't go to see it - or another of these calamities may be along next summer.
Almost everything is wrong with it.
Somewhere during the transition to a live-action movie, screenwriters Jackie and Jeff Filgo have turned Greg from endearingly weedy into annoyingly insufferable.
The murky lighting, dull camerawork and slack editing (especially obvious during the action scenes) aren't of the quality you'd expect in a Hollywood film.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's the old romcom story - boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy fights to win back girl. But it's steeped in pop culture, especially video games, rock and comic strips.
Stallone, never a clear speaker, spends most of his time grunting like a Gloucester Old Spot or barking like a sea lion with a sore throat.
I must confess that I have a sneaking admiration for knowingly humorous movies that exploit the worst instincts of their target audience.
The lovely Edinburgh backdrops, shot with marvellous attention to light and weather conditions, only partially compensate for a story that's sluggish and uninvolving.
The incoherent, moralising script demeans a number of actors, including William H. Macy, Judy Greer and David Walliams, reduced by a kindly editor to an ineffective cameo.
A thriller jam-packed with ridiculous stunts and a plot that's arguably the most barking-mad of all this summer's blockbusters.
Writer-director Juan Jose Campanella is a master of camerawork and editing. He is also wonderful with actors. There isn't a false performance here.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Please let it be the last Shyamalan.
No one is likely to mistake it for art, but this is one of the better summer blockbusters, thanks to special effects, adequate acting and welcome flashes of wit.
Even by the rock-bottom standards of dance movies, the script is abysmal: formulaic and dumb.
The miracle is that Patrick O'Neill was able to pitch his screenplay for Knight And Day and not get carted off to a home for the criminally insane.
Even committed action fans may acknowledge the editing is so frenetic that it's often impossible to know what is going on -- or why.
One of the year's most unusual, imaginative and daring films.
This primitive effort needed much more work on the screenplay, a director with some grasp of pace, and a budget that could have done justice to its ideas.
Duris is an engaging mixture of clown, matinee idol and working-class boy made good, while Paradis has a lovely, gap-toothed smile and a radiant intelligence.
Shrek Forever After is an amiable but underpowered conclusion to a franchise that ran out of comic ideas six years ago. It is time to lay this ogre to rest.
Whatever Works is a welcome return to Allen's New York roots and enjoyable insofar as it is far wittier than most modern comedies, but it lacks anything fresh to say.
Just a succession of gross-out gags and sketches that fail to deliver.
All you need to know about When In Rome is that it was written by David Diamond and David Weissman, who perpetrated the atrocity that was the Robin Williams-John Travolta 'comedy' Old Dogs.
Do you recall a racial culture-clash comedy from 1967 called Guess Who's Coming To Dinner? This is an appalling, crass, 21st-century rehash of the same idea.
Centurion is a curious mixture of Gladiator, Braveheart and Apocalypto, but not nearly as good as any of them.
It relies on an unusual premise, intriguing characters and expertly generated tension to involve us; and that's just what it does.

It deliberately sells a perniciously sexualised view of children and glorifies violence, especially knife and gun crime, in a way that makes it one of the most deeply cynical, shamelessly irresponsible films ever.

Pattinson's young female fans are likely to find this film less unbearable than anyone else. But even they may find the big emotional climax, which exploits a major terrorist disaster, cheap and pretentious.
Maybe if you're aged between eight and 12, or exceptionally dim-witted, you may not notice that this is a tenth-rate rip-off of Harry Potter, with Greek mythology taking the place of magic.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Utterly uninvolving and never remotely scary.
It would be churlish to deny that this is by far the classiest, most skilfully crafted film of the week, with two extraordinary performances.
As so often with recent Hollywood rom-coms, the script smacks of mechanical contrivance, as glib life-lessons are handed out to all and sundry.
The film is fast, colourful and weird enough not to be dull. But that still doesn't mean it is good.

Eastwood's biopic is unconventional only in that it wisely does not attempt to tell Mandela's whole life story. Instead, it seizes on his rarest qualities, thus creating a moving tribute to a genuinely great humanitarian.
This is yet another of those Hollywood coming-of-age movies where no one grows up. I've seen worse, but that's my problem.
Subtitled 'An Arousing Comedy', the only emotions it's likely to arouse in most people are boredom and contempt, with a dash of pity.
Simon Fellows and screenwriter Jayson Rothwell have come up with one of the worst ever ideas for a movie and created a cinematic abomination devoid of point, humour and entertainment value.

There is a thin line between compassion and voyeurism; soul-searing drama and overwrought melodrama; opera and Oprah. This film tramples all over it.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Princess And The Frog isn't perfect, but it is highly entertaining. Its charming, feelgood escapism will amuse young and old alike. It has a witty take on the old fairy tale, lively characters and colourful visuals.

Some of the story-telling is muddled, and no attempt is made to imbue the proceedings with any kind of morality. We are presumably meant to admire the leading man's opportunism, resilience and ability to cast off and reassume his Muslim identity at will.

For a film about silent assassins, it's phenomenally noisy. But if you're into swearing, decapitation and sliced-off limbs, and your brain has been reduced to mush by sitting in front of violent video games, this is the movie for you.
The plot is mundane and relatively dull... The result is an experience that's amiable but underwhelming.
George Clooney revels in the role of his life in this unique and often brilliant mixture of topical drama, romantic comedy and corporate satire.
Ponderously paced and surely the final nail in the coffin of its once-promising directors, Albert and Allen Hughes, this is an extremely dumb film with absurd pretensions to spiritual significance.
This weirdly unfunny comedy is like Clint Eastwood's Play Misty For Me seen through the eyes of the stalker, and played unsuccessfully for laughs.

The set-up's better than OK, but the black comedy premise never develops into anything remotely interesting. The piece staggers along like a third-rate fringe play, with increasingly pointless fantasy sequences.
Splendidly and often lyrically shot, with a marvellously sympathetic, dread-inducing score by Jonny Pilcher, this is one of the most powerful documentaries I have ever seen.

What it does have is a barnstorming performance from Andy Serkis as the raucous, engagingly barmy Dury, and a quietly effective contribution from young Bill Milner as his understandably troubled son, Baxter.

The movie suffers from thin characters, uneven performances and a denouement that begs more questions than it answers.
Drab, virtually plot-free and aridly pointless, this road doesn't get anywhere.
A heartfelt condemnation of mass-produced, chemically treated food, though it covers so many areas of concern in 94 minutes that it is necessarily superficial.
I admired the way the movie avoided the usual romantic comedy happy ending, but the film's bleakness is unlikely to win it many friends at the box office.
Though Ponyo contains images so haunting that it's hard to dismiss altogether, this is one of Miyazaki's feeblest efforts.

Bridges can play this kind of role in his sleep, and at times appears to be doing so. If he wins the Best Actor Oscar for this, it will be as a long-service medal, not a reflection of excellence in a demanding role.
Dreamworks' latest venture into animation is thrilling for children (though too scary for under-sixes) and extremely tolerable for adults.
Disappointment of the week is this expensive but ponderous remake of the 1981 epic, which wasn't much good either.
Here is a movie that honours a downtrodden financial, racial and political minority: rich, white southern Republicans who carry guns and aren't afraid to threaten black people with them.
As rock musicals go, it's exceptionally hard on the ears. I haven't heard singing this bad since Pete Doherty was in his prime.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It keeps lumbering to a halt, in an attempt to make us care about the central relationships, but the writing never delivers characters who are anything more than unsympathetic caricatures.
Hardly any films are made that can be enjoyed whether you're three or 93. Sequels superior to the original are another rarity.
At the screening I attended I didn't hear one person laugh, though I did hear plenty of involuntary sighs and groans, some of them emanating from myself.
I like Jennifer Aniston, but heaven knows what attracted her to this junk.
It's one of those depressing, unconsciously patronising British movies about downmarket characters in which everyone has such a low IQ that it's difficult to drum up much empathy for any of them.
The miracle is not that this guy lost five girlfriends, but that he ever attracted them in the first place.
Imagine a bad Ken Loach film invaded by monsters from a George A. Romero movie that's run out of cash, and you've already visualised a movie better than this one.

Jaw-droppingly unfunny and morally despicable, it doesn't work on any level.

It looks like a cerebral director and hard-working cast trying to treat a piece of trash much more seriously than it deserves.

Here I am giving Banksy the ultimate in undesired praise, a favourable review in the Left's most routinely reviled newspaper.
A heart-on-sleeve weepie which takes extraordinary liberties with the truth to fashion a conventional Hollywood narrative.

Though it aspires to be like Chaplin or Tati, it's more like a bunch of terribly earnest clowns from the Cirque du Soleil performing a self-consciously cutesy, politicised version of Mission Impossible.

Is this a satire on amoral violence or a celebration of it? Regrettably, it's the latter, which should give you some idea of just how despicable this film is.

The Lovely Bones marks a new low in cinematic adaptations. Back in 1989, Peter Jackson made a trashy horror film called Bad Taste. Even that was in better taste than this banal monstrosity.
Beautifully crafted, and sensationally well acted, it overflows with romance, heart and intelligence.
It must rank as the outstanding prequel of all time.
This is one of those churn-'em-out Disney comedies in which every performer seems to be competing to give the most annoying performance in cinematic history.
Cheri radiates quality in every department, and - whether it's popular or not - this splendid achievement establishes him as one of Britain's very best film producers.
Interview is a decently acted two-hander fringe play that doesn't deserve to be on film.
The film is just about worth seeing for the wigs and costumes. But Elizabeth: The Golden Age sank without trace in American cinemas, and I fear it will do the same here.

Good idea, boring execution.
Bland remake of tasty German romcom.

Boring and pointless.
Top-class direction lifts ho-hum script.

A comedic disaster of biblical proportions.

movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's lost its X-factor. I wanted to leave.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

A strong early candidate for the most agonisingly tedious film of 2009.

Romcom of the year.

This has to be the dumbest and most implausible action movie of the year.
Cleverly plotted and brilliantly acted, this is up there with Fargo and Raising Arizona as the Coens' finest comedic work.
This is a gruesome film, even by modern standards. It is also utterly devoid of a point, or interesting ideas.

Easily the finest of the week's films, though it's unlikely to be showing anywhere near you, is Gomorrah, a warts-and-all Italian drama about the threat posed to civilisation by organised crime in Naples and beyond.
The script fails to come up with a convincing reason for the mirrors behaving as nastily as they do, and the final twist is effective only if you don't, as it were, reflect upon it.
Depressingly for a film written by two women, it's relentlessly sexist in its insistence that, in order to attract men, women must appear brainless and dress like a hooker.
The only reason to see City Of Ember is to enjoy the sight of Bill Murray trying to look scared as he is attacked by a giant, man-eating mole.
Won't win many friends and will alienate some old ones.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It isn't at all emotionally involving. Charles Ryder remains a cold fish, and Goode endows him with good looks instead of personality.

Seeing a personification of America exterminate pesky foreigners as if they're so many cockroaches does have entertainment value, despite its worrying overtones. It's just weird that it's been made, with no apparent irony, by a couple of Frenchmen.
The remake illustrates only how low modern action movies can stoop. Necks are broken, guts eviscerated. Fans of impaling and decapitation will not be disappointed.
If a western is going to be this slow, it needs to have a lot more tension, and deeper meaning, than this one.
The whole thing feels as tired and over-familiar as its leading men. Really, only three words need saying to Pacino and De Niro: you're too old.
Unendurable American middle-aged whingeing.
When a film strives this hard to be non-controversial and fashionably non-judgmental, it takes a lot of the sting out of its social comment. It just ends up as defeatist, liberal hand-wringing.
Admittedly, I am a man, but I am partial to a good chick flick. This one made me feel as if I had been trapped in the perfume hall at Selfridges.
Though there are funny one-liners early on, the script becomes increasingly lazy, while the violence which takes over the second half feels as if it belongs to a different picture.

It doesn't fight shy of a truly frightening final twist, which makes it not only bleaker but also more truthful than virtually every other movie in this genre, which all too often is over-populated and under-humanised.

Despite the 12A certificate, I would regard this as most suitable for intelligent children aged ten to 12, who will be more prepared than adults to ignore its major implausibility - that security at concentration camps was ever this inefficient.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This is Guy Ritchie's third turkey in a row, after Swept Away and Revolver. It is a pitiful attempt to recapture the success of his first two movies, Lock Stock And Two Smoking Barrels and Snatch.
The Duchess lacks the high romance of Pride And Prejudice and the tragic depth of Atonement, it is a decent example of English heritage cinema.
Some of the stunts remain impressive, and this picture will do well because of its predecessors. But it's a huge disappointment.
Director Catherine Hardwicke (who made Thirteen) captures perfectly the breathless thrill, fear and fascination of first love.
More pro-terrorist propaganda.
It is poorly shot, indifferently acted camp, based on a rightly forgotten Noel Coward comedy.
The film is content to laugh affectionately at Thompson's bad boy exploits, giggle at the impatience of a man who went hunting boar with a sub machine-gun.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It will find an enthusiastic audience among those sympathetic to the Palestinian cause, who will find it a revealing analysis as opposed to one-sided agit-prop.

Inkheart the novel is intended to be the first of a trilogy, but - like The Golden Compass, but even more so - it falls well short of convincing me that the next two films would be a worthwhile investment, financially or emotionally.
I don't know of any film quite like Dean Spanley, and I mean that as a compliment. It will stay with me long after 99 per cent of this year's films have been forgotten.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Christmas turkey has landed, in the form of 20th Century Fox's worst blockbuster ever.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Transporter 3 is going to make an awful lot of money. It has in abundance the ingredient that was missing from the last Bond film: a sense of its own idiocy.
The whole thing is coated in a golden hue, as though the lens has been dunked in syrup. Males - or females with a horror of smug, sugary sentiment - should run a mile.
It's for children, rather than families. Adults can safely avoid.
The kindest adjectives to describe Weaver's performance would be 'overwrought' and 'unsympathetic'.
As a satire on Tinseltown, it's toothless.
They don't make thrillers like this any more, and for good reason.

Witherspoon and Vaughn are physically ill-matched. She has never looked tinier, while the always gigantic Vaughn has put on so much weight that I half-expected the big plot revelation to be that he'd eaten her twin sister.
I'm always wary of that overused word 'masterpiece', but this is one film that deserves the accolade.
It's undeniably distinctive, and anyone interested in the unconventional end of animation should take a look.
The downside is that for the final half-hour the camera shakes so badly I started suffering from motion sickness.
This is one of those films that would be enormously improved by the arrival of 100 crazy Somali pirates who would proceed to take the entire cast hostage.
It's hard to know what aspect is the most offensive: the glib, cynical approach to mental illness; the sleazy sexism; the infantile attempts at blasphemy; or Rockwell's smug, boorish performance.
Body Of Lies lacks the epic sweep of Gladiator and the emotional pull of Thelma And Louise. But it's enormously competent, with a couple of fine supporting performances from Crowe and Strong.

The picture ends on a note of hope, but most of it is extremely ugly, pictorially and spiritually. It's full of symbols and metaphors instead of believable people - but I have no idea what, if anything, it is trying to say.

The only 21st-century aspects of it are the unfunnily vulgar references to sexual and bodily functions along with several hundred uses of the F-word, which those who adore Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross may find a thousand times less wearisome than I did
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Director John Moore is clearly more interested in hot babes, body tattoos and slo-mo shootings than he is in story or characterisation. Max Payne offers Min Pleasure.
They don't add up to much; and he's just too passive to make us care even slightly about whether he gets the girl or ends up taking a meat-cleaver to his rival.

The film crams a vast amount of information into two-and-a-half hours, and makes an honest, intelligent attempt to portray terrorism from every angle, including the victims' and authorities' viewpoints.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: But is this an illuminating portrait of George W. Bush, or a searching examination of the Republican failures which led to the election of Barack Obama? It is, undeniably, not.
Here's an excruciatingly dated and derivative New York cop movie.

Ironically, Davies' own, sadly minor, talent is for being uniquely dismal, which means that this film is unlikely to appeal to many non critics, inside or outside Liverpool. Ken Dodd might have done this a whole lot better.
Dinner For Schmucks is easily the most obnoxious film of the year, and ranks high among the least intelligent remakes of all time.
A silly, at times despicable film that never remotely deserved an Oscar nomination. Compared with this, Team America: World Police was a think piece.
It's rescued by the warmth of the two central performances. It also makes a pleasant change to see a woman of generous proportions land a handsome guy.
Diaz's smile lights up the screen, though her role struggles to be as much as one-dimensional.
The first Nativity was a corny, amateurish shambles, but it had that hard-to-define quality of likeability. Its sequel has none.
There are times when it does something new with the genre - and it does make you care about the protagonists.

It becomes a winning mixture of Bullet Boy and My Beautiful Laundrette, and not nearly as dreary or dispiriting as you may fear.
Ben Affleck's movie tells an amazing but true story set against the context of the Iranian hostage crisis.
If you're in the mood for a sentimental feel-good movie with affection for its music and characters, The Sapphires offers solid entertainment.
I went in with rock-bottom expectations and came out pleasantly surprised. It isn't completely awful.
Kurtzman directs with a heavy hand and huge earnestness, but it boils down to trite platitudes about fatherhood and family.
The special-effects are amazingly realistic, as is the leading lady's luminous, anguished and extremely moving performance.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film keeps trying to be filthy and outrageous, but is actually rather timid.
This is a good-looking production. However, too much of it feels bland and flat. There have been so many previous versions that a new one has to justify itself.
Eye-popping and bounding with energy, this is fun for audiences of all ages.
You'll be expecting a much better film than the one on offer.
A return to form for Tim Burton and his most entertaining venture yet into stop-motion animation.
Sandler's second venture into animation is almost as unfunny as his horrendous Eight Crazy Nights, ten years ago.
It misses out the one thing that makes Jack Kerouac's 1957 novel worth reading - his voice - and has no insights into sex, drugs, music or beatniks.
Though recognisably a variation on Pygmalion and My Fair Lady, it's a daringly unconventional idea, and Ms Kazan has written endearing roles for herself and her real-life boyfriend, Mr Dano.

Sinister does everything right.
All the film-makers do is show us things that raised a laugh in other movies - a bride with diarrhoea, lads vomiting, a little girl emitting obscenities.
Dumbing down doesn't come much dumber than this.
This is an amiable, literate but prosaic U.S. indie movie.
It deserves to be regarded as a modern classic.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

A family film full of wonder, originality and good-heartedness.
To have worked, this story needed a super-professional story-telling genius such as Alfred Hitchcock. Instead, it gets an arty novice who apparently wants to be the new Andrei Tarkovsky.
Too much is so clever-clever that it borders on the stupid.
It staggers on for almost three hours and calls into question the sanity of some of the world's best-known actors.
It is abysmal, dealing in outdated stereotypes that will leave you in a state of appalled amazement.
A boring, preposterous mess.
On any serious level, it's deplorable, but it's so macho a vision of old age that it becomes quaintly enjoyable.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There isn't enough story to float a TV sitcom; it simply consists of people bickering.

Warm Bodies has enjoyable moments, some funny lines and a central idea that works for about 20 minutes.

Spielberg is always a professional, and the film is never less than well-crafted.
The movie becomes a touching, often funny portrayal of sex as a form of kindness and human contact.
This is Quentin Tarantino's most entertaining film since Pulp Fiction, and its first hour is brilliantly funny.

It's an accomplished film that draws strong performances from very fine actors.
A realistic, well-acted vision of the 2004 tsunami that led to more than 230,000 deaths.
It may not make you walk out, but it certainly left me unsatisfied.
It's not quite funny enough and I could have done without the lavatory humour, but it's so warm and fuzzy that it's hard to dislike.
It's like a superior, wittier double-episode of Glee.
Life Of Pi must be the most beautiful film of the year, a technical marvel, and magic realism at its most magical.
This is an ingeniously plotted film, and the two superb performances at its centre compensate for any implausibilities.
It's not as good as I hoped, but it's also a lot better than I feared.
This is a wonderful film, an all-time-great musical, guaranteed -- despite its title -- to raise your spirits, as well as make you cry.
A turkey that may serve a useful function in being the last nail in the coffin of Miley Cyrus's acting career.

The film's strong points are its noble intentions and the nuanced performances by Streep and Lee Jones. But I'm not sure who will actually enjoy this movie.

This is not so much a film as an insufferably aggressive exercise in product placement.

The guys are back and attending a high-school reunion, but not much has changed. That is not a good thing.
Flicks don't come chickier than this.

Director Whit Stillman shows with this film why he has found it so hard to find funding for the past 13 years.

Battleship is trash.

Cut away the flab, and there's probably an adorable hour-long movie in there.

It's conventional, dull and unconsciously nasty.
One of the most original films of the year.
Fast, furious and infuriating.
Beneath the stylish flippancy, it's a fascistic bore.
In some inner circle of Hell, this movie will be for ever playing.

Keira Knightley when lit like this, is a screen goddess.
Most of it looks rather too much like Ridley Scott's classic, Blade Runner.
Some are hailing it as a masterpiece. I'd say it's a missed opportunity.
Comic timing livens the picture up no end. In fact, you could say it's the one thing that stops it from being hackneyed.
A thriller needs to thrill, and this one doesn't.
The Watch is unwatchable - a punishingly long, aggressively crude, laugh-free American comedy about neighbourhood vigilantes in suburban Ohio.
They're just as hopelessly violent, bad-tempered and stupid at the end as they were at the beginning. These days, that's refreshingly anarchic.

movie_review_blurb: You'd think this might be a shocking, even paranoid scenario, but instead it comes across as too ridiculous to be even slightly believable.

This is, I can say without fear of exaggerating, one of the great films of all time.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Chamber Of Secrets is funnier and more exciting than the first Harry Potter movie, and adorned with some of the most stunning special effects ever.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: I have no serious criticisms. The film does full justice to Tolkien, who has often -- and erroneously -- been accused of escapism.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This is a tricky film to award a star rating, for it starts out as five-star and ends up a turkey. I've compromised on three stars.
I was hoping to be thrilled, and I wasn't. All the film delivers is a somewhat inhuman pastiche.

Hokey, but a hit.

This is an over-the-top gangster flick that starts with the volume turned up to 11 and stays that way. It's never boring, but revels in the bad behaviour it pretends to condemn, and is too much on one note to be much good.

It is director David Fincher's equivalent of Orson Welles' Citizen Kane: the story of a capitalist who is awe-inspiring in some ways, but tragic in others; enviably clever and driven, but also repellently ruthless and treacherous.
Pointless, puerile and a shameful shambles.
A little goes a very long way, and even at 75 minutes it ends up feeling silly and self-indulgent.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's so unsubtle in its characterisation and so plodding in its narrative that it's unlikely to reach much of an audience.

movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

Here is the best of the superhero films to have emerged from Hollywood.

In which a bunch of drugged or drunk superstars, played by themselves, use the end of the world as a pretext for projectile vomiting, bodily fluids and every kind of grossness.
If Snitch ultimately perishes from over-ambition, at least it's an honourable death.
This is one of the few sequels for which the cliche 'eagerly awaited' is truly applicable.
Brad Pitt's hero lacks personality. All we know is that he loves his family, but no one has given him or his relations any exceptional qualities.
I can't recommend it highly enough.
A plodding, sub-Merchant Ivory costume drama, not terribly convincing even though it's based on a true story, about a romantic triangle in Edwardian Cornwall.
It is ... perilously short on laughs, and the few that do come are generated by Lily Tomlin as the heroine's ferociously feminist mother.
It's a triumph of spectacle over content.
Made for TV usually means 'not good enough for the cinema'. Here's the exception.
The dialogue is platitudinous and delivered in stilted accents. The structure is that of a very dull video game made by someone who once watched The Lord Of The Rings.
Unfortunately, the movie runs out of things to say about its monosyllabic hero within a half-hour, after which the killings become repetitive.
Not since The Artist has there been a French film as delightful or commercial as Populaire. If you're looking for a happy, feelgood romantic comedy, here it is.

It's clever in the way it takes some disagreeable elements from our own time - fear of racial minorities, envy of wealth, needless aggression and gun crime - slightly exaggerates them and projects them into the near future.
Byzantium doesn't add enough that's new to the genre. I was never bored by it, but I wasn't excited, either.
At the screening I attended, not one person laughed.
The quality of the animation is exceptional, and will open many eyes - young and old - to the beauty of natural woodland.
Involves four Academy Award winners, all cruelly wasted on roles unworthy of them.
Luhrmann lovingly titivates the fake and superficial, and never gets round to serving the meat of the novel, which involves cutting into sham and heartlessness.
Resembles Fargo in its geography and atmosphere, but fatally lacks its sense of humour.
Abrams approaches the subject-matter with the zest, imagination and humour of Steven Spielberg on top form.
Director Michael Winterbottom has achieved the impossible: he has made a biopic of Paul Raymond, Britain's most colourful porn baron, that's unobservant, unerotic and dull.
I didn't find it very entertaining, but it is at least trying something different.
Comic-strip superhero movies are not exactly noted for intelligence, wit or humour. Iron Man 3 is the welcome exception.
Overlook the abysmal acting, unattractive nudity, awful dialogue, laughable effects and diabolical direction, and there are a few memorable shocks and images.
There's no suspense, and it isn't scary.
Some will find it ridiculously entertaining. I found it entertainingly ridiculous. Either way, it's a guilty pleasure.
Its emotional impact lies in the fact it makes even the most blasé of us feel what it must have been like to be on the sinking ship. And the film's underlying themes still have potency.
The Moo Man is a very old-fashioned documentary, a gentle, bucolic account of a man at peace with himself and his environment.
As it dragged on and on, I found myself wondering if a more accurate title might not have been another of Byrne's songs, Road To Nowhere.
A flawed but entertaining sci-fi thriller...
This is a cheesy soap opera that dearly wants to be a country and western All About Eve. The songs aren't too bad; the dialogue is.

There's nothing here that couldn't be covered adequately in 40 minutes. The other 50 minutes consist of director Werner Herzog's spiritual musings, which are uninteresting, verbose and not terribly coherent.
Route Irish is a didactic thriller about the Iraq war, with wearisomely predictable villains and a profoundly unsympathetic hero.
First-time writer-director Richard Ayoade is a talent to watch, and his film is always amiable.
The distinguished actors are as strong as you would expect, the narrative structure is well-crafted, and there's something curiously bracing about Allen's misanthropy.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A fiendishly twisty crime-thriller...
A fluffy little romcom that could have been better, but will do nicely until something more daring comes along.
It's the kind of exercise in mildly salacious voyeurism that has been attempted many times before, in movies such as Sliver and Hider In The House. This is the least thrilling version yet.
Battle: Los Angeles is for American teenagers who found G.I. Joe: The Rise Of Cobra too cerebral.
This movie was fun when it was made 56 years ago and called The Seven Year Itch.
This looks like Ancient Rome as reinterpreted by the makers of Brokeback Mountain but with all the explicit gay sex taken out.

There are so many distortions within the movie, but space does not allow me to recount them here. Suffice to say, whenever the Hollywood Left tries to sell you a conspiracy theory, it is a good idea to check the facts out yourself.
Misjudged, un-poetic and tedious - like a pompous production of Mamma Mia, without the Abba songs.
A possible cult hit, it's too self-indulgent to find a mass audience.
Ironclad desperately wants to be a historical blockbuster along the lines of Braveheart. Sadly, it has more in common with Monty Python And The Holy Grail.
Collet-Serra generates plenty of suspense and keeps the action flowing. There is even, of all things, an imaginative car chase.
A romantic drama that presents us with one of the most likeable couples in recent cinema.
Though more professionally made than its predecessors, it is just as lazily plotted, formulaic and insultingly stupid.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It depicts with admirable clarity the insanity of the boom that led to bust. If you have ever wanted to understand derivatives, hedge funds and collateralised debt obligation, this movie is for you.
The encouraging aspect of this musical documentary is that it proves the 16-year-old Canadian does have the talent to go with his precocious self-confidence.
A diabolical romcom in which the hero is a sexist plastic surgeon who preys on younger women and enjoys hitting small children. Have you guessed yet that he's played by Adam Sandler?
The Coens are nothing if not film buffs, and their framings lovingly copy earlier movies, most noticeably John Ford's The Searchers and Charles Laughton's Night Of The Hunter.
The piece comes across as uneventful, devoid of tension and disappointingly superficial in its view of a parallel dystopia.
A decent, earnest, well-intentioned picture about white-collar unemployment.
Though Nick Hamm directs with zest, the script by Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais, adapting rock critic Neil McCormick's autobiography, is low on laughs.
All you really need to know about Hop - a godforsaken mixture of live action humans with animated rabbits - is that it's brought to you by the same geniuses who gave us Alvin And The Chipmunks.
It's a pleasure to welcome one movie that won't damage your brain cells and actually has a story worth telling.
This is a harmless way to squander two hours of your life, but it's impossible to imagine the green-clad central character becoming a serious rival to Batman.
This may not be the most innovative documentary, nor the most probing (it fails to mention Senna's marriage or ex-fiancee), but it is intelligently assembled and avoids hagiography.

It lacks the crossover appeal of the best in its genre, such as Superman, Spiderman 2 or Batman Begins. All the same, this is the classiest of the series and one of the better summer blockbusters so far.
The main reason to see this is a charismatic leading performance by Kim Rossi Stuart. Even so, it makes two hours feel like four.
The Hangover Part II is the worst sequel of all time.
Not every sequel is a cynical rip-off of innocent moviegoers, and here's the welcome proof.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It defies criticism, since quality is clearly irrelevant to its success or otherwise. It is loud, bombastic - and extravagantly boring.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are enough laughs to qualify as black comedy, but it's also scary enough to be thrilling.
This is high romantic melodrama: Titanic on dry land, with the doomed liner turned into a Thirties travelling circus careering towards catastrophe.
It suffers from an inordinately protracted middle section that should have been half an hour shorter, but turns into the kind of bloodbath you would expect from Tarantino.
Once the lights have come up you realise that behind the beautifully choreographed frights, there was very little going on.
Not many movies manage to be filthy but sweet. This one brings it off.
Steve Gordon's 1981 screenplay won an Oscar nomination, but there's no danger of Peter Baynham's rewrite doing the same.
With belief soundly suspended and your senses of sight and sound reeling under full frontal assault, this hybrid of action, chase movie sets the bar low - and clears it with ease.
Little White Lies sets out to be a Gallic Big Chill and ends up like a less comedic Grown Ups.
Some will respond to the film's mumbling minimalism and there is something mildly heart-warming in seeing aimless individuals gaining a sense of purpose.
There is no sexual or romantic chemistry.
The pity is that Disney hasn't returned to basics in the voiceovers.
I went in hoping for a more inventive Princess Bride, or a less uneven Monty Python And The Holy Grail. I came out wondering what drugs the cast had been ingesting.
It's quite tedious for much of its length, but it certainly captures the boredom of waiting around and sharing an uncomfortable lifestyle with people you'd rather not spend time with.
You could spend the entire movie texting your friends and not miss a thing, which I suppose its target audience may consider an asset.
The incoherent, over-complicated storyline is played with much too much gravity, and the few jokes aren't funny.
Rio is a joyful celebration of the great city and the glorious plumage of parrots. It is also the most enjoyable animated film since Toy Story 3D.
It seems to have been made for 15-year-old boys by a sad middle-aged man whose only experience of life is from violent comics, shoot-'em-up video games and online pornography.
Source Code isn't without entertaining moments, but it's a waste of its intriguing set-up, a bright director and a superior cast.
The film is sparky and offbeat, but the script - credited to seven people, not including the Bard of Avon - isn't consistently funny or imaginative and too much of it seems camp rather than amusing.
Although there are laughs along the way and Pegg and Frost have an easy on-screen camaraderie, there's a smugness that prevents them from achieving their potential.
Although it's sad, it avoids miserabilism, because it is leavened by touches of humour and a refusal to wallow. The reason to see it is Kidman.
Bale steals the movie with a mesmerisingly goofy performance.
Machete is a supremely violent exploitation movie that's nowhere near as enjoyable as its trailer.
The most memorable sequences in the film are not, for once, the action scenes but the acting ones.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The worst example of torture-by-chick-flick since Bride Wars.
It's schlock, but on such a grand scale that it's quite fun to allow yourself to be carried along on its tsunami of emotion.
While it's never going to set the box office alight, it was a pleasure to watch this charmer from France.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Their third and worst film will appeal most to the evolutionally challenged and anyone who retains an infantile obsession with bodily waste.
I'm surprised Let Me In has received mostly enthusiastic reviews, for it is a dim-witted Hollywood remake of the acclaimed 2008 Swedish film Let The Right One In.
Mike Leigh's improvisational methods often result in fine acting with profound explorations of character, and that's the case here.
It appears to have been put together by social workers eager to bombard children with Aids awareness and the importance of condoms.
Films about the stresses and strains of marriage don't come any better -- or more entertaining -- than this.
Easy A is easily the most entertaining high school comedy since 1999's Ten Things I Hate About You, and the first great teen movie of the 21st century.
Its silliness becomes wearisome the longer it continues, but I found it as entertaining as, say, Clint Eastwood's Space Cowboys, and could happily sit through it again.
Why spend vast amounts of money on fine animation when the script is a baffling abomination? It's an owling shame.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing here that Disney hasn't done much better decades ago, and the script is a lame mixture of slapstick and sentiment.
The imagery could hardly be more heavy-handed or banal -- dominoes topple and bubbles burst but, paradoxically, the plot is hard to follow in any detail.
Cynics will find the film mawkish, but the story-telling is clear and involving.

Rhys Ifans is simply too charmless to play Marks, and director Bernard Rose's plodding screenplay is torn between making this an Ealing-style romp (but it isn't funny) and a human interest story with a sympathetic hero (except he isn't).
The plot goes through motions that will be tiresomely familiar to anyone who saw Baby Boom, Three Men And A Baby, Raising Waylon or dozens of other movies about unplanned parenthood.
This is a film that should lift your heart, whatever your politics.

This is a tough urban thriller that ranks with the best recent efforts in the genre. It lacks the originality of Michael Mann's Heat, but it's at least on a level with Eastwood's Mystic River and Scorsese's The Departed.
What's the worst foreign journey you've ever experienced? Mine is this movie.
It's the most daring black comedy of the year, and I admire its willingness to be not only vicious, but downright un-American.
It will wow anyone who thinks grimness equals profundity.
It's so gripping you won't mind the subtitles.
The English countryside is pretty, and it's good to see a splendid cast of mainly British actors so happily and productively employed.
The third and worst of Stieg Larsson's trilogy is poorly directed, under-energised and unthrilling.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The acting is uniformly on the button, but the script is patchier.
You've heard of action movies. The American is an inaction movie...
The action is poorly handled, the pace is leaden, and the camerawork tediously static.

Riseborough is one of our most talented young actresses, and she tries hard to be sweetly innocent. But because of the underwritten script and Riley's performance, her waitress comes across as borderline retarded.
About as morbid and schlocky a romcom as you can imagine.
Art-house cinema doesn't come more long-winded. It's pointless and the worst kind of liberal hand-wringing.
Never have I seen 3D used so poorly.
Despite computer animation, the movie looks lovingly hand-drawn and is somewhat indebted to the French artist Fragonard.
Acclaimed writer-director James L. Brooks has turned out one of the most unbearable romcoms ever in How Do You Know.
This is a bewilderingly pointless drama, weaving together three dreary stories about mortality and the afterlife.
Needed the gentler pacing of television to win us over to the central anti-hero, and make the supporting characters feel less like caricatures.
Presumably, we are meant to find this cute, rather than intensely depressing.
This is acting of extraordinary power, all the more astonishing from an actress whose performances in the Star Wars movies were ridiculed for their woodenness.
A long, slow-moving, unthrilling thriller about a teacher who decides to help his wife, unjustly convicted of murder, escape from prison.
I ended up wondering how a screenplay this messy had ever gone into production, let alone attracted two actors of this quality.
It's a bravura piece of film-making that captures the resilience of the human spirit better than any movie since the Oscar-winning documentary Touching The Void, but it's uneasy viewing.
The rumours are completely true. The superlatives are completely justified. Colin Firth really does give the performance of his life as the Queen's father, George VI.
It's a patchy, unambitious comedy with five or six laughs, and will be passably amusing when it comes on television.

A feeble rip-off of Jonathan Swift's 18th-century satire, reduced to a succession of lame jokes and a drearily unfunny star vehicle for Jack Black. Dumbing down doesn't come more dispiriting than this.
Colin Farrell as an amoral Russian gangster, Ed Harris as an enigmatic American and Saoirse Ronan as a vulnerable young woman all make enough of an impression to make us wish we knew more about them.
It works initially as a suspenseful mystery and then turns into . . . something else.
So bad it's moderately entertaining, Burlesque is a lesson in how not to put on a musical.
This comes across as the same kind of pompous drivel that eventually made the Matrix films unbearable.
The really good news is that if you're looking for a thoroughly enjoyable family outing this Christmas, you need look no further. This is a delight.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like Bad Santa and Silent Night, Bloody Night, it's a Christmas movie that isn't for children. Quite whom it is for, I'm not totally sure.
Others may respond more readily than I did to this ambitious attempt to blend kitchen-sink realism, heartwarming sitcom and raunchy sex comedy. For me, they didn't gel at all.
movie_title: The Be All and End All (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 'You're so predictable,' Roxanne tells Megamind early in the movie, and I'm afraid it's fair criticism.
I think this is one of the year's most enjoyable family films.
The narrative is devoid of any conventional structure, and the pace is punishingly slow.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Love's Kitchen is a rural British romcom that appears to have been assembled by a committee of village idiots.
Due Date is not so much a road movie as a cultural car-crash.
Ann Peacock's didactic screenplay may be based on a true story, but it's hopelessly unconvincing in the way it manufactures and resolves conflicts.
Jaw-droppingly misconceived.
Film of the year and a joy forever.
I wish I admired this film as much as I do its leading character, the Burmese politician Aung San Suu Kyi, played with reverential sweetness by Michelle Yeoh.
The master of the thriller genre, Alfred Hitchcock, knew that even the nastiest stories need light as well as shade. Fincher's too busy darkening his garish source material to care.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I'm happy to admit I cried. I'm willing to bet that you will, too.
Brad Bird made his name with two brilliant animated films, The Incredibles and Ratatouille. Mission Impossible 4 is his first live-action film, and it confirms that he is a first-rate director.
The message of the picture, delivered with the sincerity of an unsolicited email from Nigeria, is that everyone deserves a second chance and forgiveness - even, presumably, Ashton Kutcher.
Both long-winded and profoundly unsatisfying.
Though Puss was an entertaining subsidiary character in Shrek 2, he fails to convince as a leading character.
The man responsible for Raging Bull, Taxi Driver and GoodFellas has tackled his first family film. Not only that: it's in 3-D, and a must-see for anyone who loves cinema.
It's an enchanting tragi-comedy, a hugely enjoyable trifle, and may prove an eye-opener to generations too young to remember the allure of Marilyn Monroe.
To those unfortunate enough to have a potentially terminal illness, it could be inspirational.
Nichols has nothing positive to say, and spends more than two hours saying it. It's a superficial movie pretending to be deep.
Donaldson's skilful at orchestrating the action sequences, and there are two plot twists that should take you by surprise. At least you won't be bored.
Despite the emotional hurt on display, there's not much grandeur.
There have been several 'what if' movies about what Britain might have been like had the Nazis occupied us. This is one of the worst.
A rather good original idea has dwindled into self-parody.
This is an undemanding children's movie, with just about enough humour and excitement to keep adults entertained.
Winter and Christmas are traditionally times for ghost stories, and The Awakening is a classy one.
Trespass is a crime, and so is this movie.
This is a rambling comedy with enough good moments and witty lines to compensate for its messiness.
A would-be sophisticated but actually naive attempt to turn Emily Bronte's fascinating, emotionally involving romantic melodrama into the most alienating kind of brutalism.
Doesn't Greece have enough problems?
In Time is The Adjustment Bureau without the charm and sexual chemistry.
Lurie's film has nothing in its head beyond the desire to make money.
There's an awful lot of dreary and incomprehensible exposition to get through, and Gina Carano is not a charismatic leading lady.
It offers a ludicrously reductionist view of England's greatest writer, William Shakespeare, and a grotesquely offensive portrait of its most celebrated monarch, Elizabeth I.
Coriolanus is such a proud, cold-hearted swine that spending more than two hours with him is a long, hard slog.
There's no way to overlook the ineptitude of the screenplay by Madonna and long-time collaborator Alex Keshishian.
Lieberson's direction lacks any sense of geography or light and shade. Nor does he endow the film with the slightest sense of reality.
The world's most tedious zombie movie...
movie_title: World of the Dead: The Zombie Diaries 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a science-fiction action-adventure for girls, faithful to its source novel, with a fiery teenage huntress battling to overcome a corrupt, male-dominated system.
Directors Max Giwa and Dania Pasquini use too much flashy editing, which detracts from the dancing. The final showdown is particularly disappointing.
While texture and local atmosphere are all very well, I wish Winterbottom had speeded up the plot and delved deeper into the characters.
An utterly dreadful attempt at a costume thriller by the flashy, heavy-handed, vacuous director James McTeigue, whose previous crimes against cinema have been V For Vendetta and Ninja Assassin.

Stanton's screenwriting skills are, on this evidence, slightly below those of George Lucas, so there's plenty of clunky exposition and such inadvertent laugh-lines as: 'I would lay down my life for Helium.'
Georges is nowhere near likeable enough to make us enjoy his successes, and by the end he's no more corrupt than he was at the start.
Neither perceptive nor funny, it's just a mass of unbelievable characters in a demeaning search for a feelgood finale.
Writer Laurence Coriat fails to come up with any fresh ideas for developing characters or storylines, and the film never has enough sense of pace or direction.
It's a treat to see a feelgood movie in which elderly heroes triumph over adversity - and their own pessimistic expectations.
This can only be recommended to connoisseurs of terrible acting.
Director Julie Anne Robinson never finds a convincing tone and ruins everything with over-emphatic comedy reaction shots and a music track that keeps telling us how funny everything is (it isn't).
This isn't so much a movie as a list of cliches.
Harrelson does everything but beg for an Oscar in a film that does little else but delve deeper and deeper into a character that has no depth.
I hope this movie will bring these talented artistes back to the forefront of the entertainment industry. It deserves to.
This is an unexpected treat: an intelligent, unsettling view of what could happen if three ordinary teenagers developed super powers.
This turns out to be an excuse for outlandish special effects, including Michael Caine (right) riding bareback on an oversized bee.
Amazingly, Jack And Jill is even lousier than I feared it would be.
Every successful film-maker has one flop in him, and Young Adult is Jason Reitman's.
Most audience members will be rolling their eyes in disbelief. That's if they haven't already leapt from their seats and left the cinema.
At its best it's a gripping action movie about the thin line between death and survival, reminiscent of Walter Hill's Southern Comfort.
You'd think fun could be had with the idea of fleeing a flea, but gags are few and far between.
Worth seeing for a luminous performance by Felicity Jones, who's even more impressive than she was in Chalet Girl.
It's an uninspired compendium of haunted house clichés, with a twist that barely deserves to be called one.
Hoover has been portrayed for so long by the Left as a monster that it's refreshing to see Eastwood illuminate his achievements...
Steven Soderbergh's well-researched, convincing, courageously bleak drama about how a lethal virus could decimate the human race.
21 Jump Street is another re-hash of a largely forgotten Eighties television series - but it's surprisingly enjoyable.
A grown-up, perceptive, funny film about family and responsibility, subjects rarely covered in movies except in cliched, romantic terms.
A frustrating mixture of promising and atrocious.
As usual with Almodovar, there is no one to care for; it's detached, smug, empty camp.
This is the first film about medieval barbarians that appears actually to have been made by them.
I found the film insufferable.
The reasons it's worth seeing are Gleeson's impish performance and the sparkling dialogue, which marries Irish blarney to Tarantino-lite philiosophising.
Why has there never been a film about cowboys beating up extra-terrestrials? This movie will give you a pretty good idea.
A handsome costume drama graced with sensitive performances and a strong central idea.
Rise Of The Planet Of The Apes is an impressive action movie - providing excellent, and far from mindless, entertainment - and a technological marvel.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The writers have created the painfully unfunny Daddy Day Camp, National Security and Norbit. So what do you expect? Entertainment?
Remember Adam Sandler in Click? Robin Williams in Hook? Eddie Murphy in The Haunted Mansion? Then congratulations, you've already seen this movie.
Super 8 is not just the most entertaining family film of the summer, it's up there with the classics of its various genres.
It is entertaining, thanks to superior CGI effects and, most of all, Farrell's knowing and understated performance.
It is saved from dour didacticism by the power of the central child's performance.
No one is going to pretend that this is art, psychologically profound or anything other than preposterous. It is a popcorn movie, but much better than most of its kind.
The skilled comedian Bateman has the best moments, underplaying when all about him are going over the top.
It's funny, entertaining, and visually witty. I could happily watch it again, just for the ingenuity of the background detail.
The acting is abysmal, and the gloating depiction of violence is hard to take, unless you're extremely thick and perverted.
Decently acted but so uneventful and underpowered that it will stretch the patience of mainstream audiences.
Its portrait of an unconventional, curiously needy friendship developing in an inhuman environment does hold the attention.
The film-makers wisely resist the temptation to make Juan a classically upright Hollywood hero. In taking a more pessimistic direction, the film comes across as infinitely more realistic.
Like most of its kind, it's just so bad it's bad.
This is a very good, thoughtful film and an important one.
It's a rare film that manages to be both spectacular and sweet.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tilda Swinton's performance is towering, but the story around her doesn't convince.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Three decades fewer on the clock would doubtless lighten my perspective, but the slapstick here seems gauche, while the script fails to provide the game young cast with much in the way of character or comedy.
Writer-director Gavin Wiesen piles on the coming-of-age clichés, and it doesn't help that his leading character has oddly middle-aged tastes.
A corrective to all those family films and documentaries, many of them by Disney, that sentimentalise - and patronise - wild animals by trying to turn them into quirky, mentally subnormal humans.
A charmless re-tread of a well-worn storyline about two yuppie friends trying to embark on a sexual relationship free of commitment.
The least watchable movie ever to star Tom Hanks...
Carnage is one of the funniest and most intelligent films of the year.
Anyone hoping to gain insight into an exotic, erotic culture is likely to be disappointed, as is anyone in search of a cheap thrill.
A corny grown-up's vision of teenage wish-fulfilment, like a sexless Sex And The City 2.
[A] long, earnest tract about men objectifying women, directed by first-timer Julia Leigh, who shows no flair for story or characterisation.
It's too well acted to be a turkey, but it completely lacks the vibrancy or excitement of City Of God or the craftsmanship that has distinguished Morgan's best work.

Anderson's previous offences against cinema include films such as Mortal Kombat, Resident Evil and Death Race. In view of the classic source material that this vandalises, The Three Musketeers is his most regrettable atrocity yet.
Too insubstantial to be a full-length feature.
Predictable and too much like Wish You Were Here, My Summer Of Love and An Education, all of which were stronger; but the performances are modestly engaging.
There are no big surprises in this movie, other than the fact that it's done with conviction, skill and special effects that are all the more spectacular for being presented in a matter-of-fact way.
All in all, this is a film I attended with rock-bottom expectations, and came out of feeling elated.
The film's big weakness is its screenplay.
You'll never think of the Tooth Fairy in the same way again after seeing this.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While Shame has style to spare, it isn't as well-written, entertaining, or as socially and sexually aware as it pretends to be.
Classic cartoon musical.
The film is decently acted, well photographed and sumptuously costumed - but dry, drab and a little dull.
There's nothing to hate about this film, but it is just not interesting enough to warrant its 104-minute running time.
Was anyone really clamouring for a sequel to the first Johnny English?
It made me laugh more than most movies this year, and confirms my belief that Anna Faris could be a big star if she ever gets offered a script worthy of her talents.
[A] pretentious, spiritually unattractive piece of grandiose self-indulgence...
Gosling gives a laconic, sexy, quietly charming performance evocative of Steve McQueen, as a Hollywood stuntman who moonlights as a getaway driver.
It's blessed with one of the most adroit comedy scripts since Richard Curtis burst upon the romcom scene with Four Weddings And A Funeral.
[An] exceptionally classy adaptation of John le Carre's 1974 novel, starring an impressive collection of British actors.
Universal Pictures brings you more vile rubbish from the writers of Four Christmases and The Ghosts Of Girlfriends Past, and the director of Fred Claus.
Already there are plans for a Hollywood remake, and it's easy to see how it could improve on the original.
Just when Woody Allen seemed to have written and directed himself out, he comes up with his biggest hit.
A wonderfully acted, finely-crafted project that deserves our attention.
Best known as a gritty wiseass, Denis Leary creates a fine dramatic performance as Bill, as does his co-star Hope Davis whose screen presence is glacial and entirely believable.
Call it old-fashioned or old Hollywood fluff, Holiday Inn is a sweet, pleasant slice of another time in pop entertainment.
The film is more interesting as a video time capsule reflecting what some saw as a threat to America's moral fiber.

Impresses on most every conceivable level: as a pure film, as wild, speculative storytelling, and, like Murnau's own Nosferatu, a benchmark ranking among the most ingenious vampire movies ever crafted.
The most polished work that Del Toro has created in some time.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: In today's glut of so-called "effects films" featuring all CGI and no story, Dragonslayer is a reminder that a balance between the two is indeed possible.
A fine example of American film noir via Paris, France.

movie_review_blurb: Warm, funny and delightfully nostalgic, this is a must-watch this Christmas for the whole family.

An enterprising but ultimately unsatisfying exercise that promises quite a lot, but delivers very little.

movie_review_blurb: Smart, empathetic, fun loving and, best of all, a delight for all audiences.

[Cruise is] distractingly bad in this, the iconography of his celebrity so strongly overshadowing his performance. He's just too powerfully contemporary.

Overlong and self-indulgent.

[James] plays yet another misfit, but one who's so two-dimensional, needy (and frankly annoying) that it's difficult to root for him.

Nim's Island is a movie for kids who like to think and read and use their imagination, and for parents who may be tired of family fare that's nothing but a litany of cutesy pop-culture references.

The cliches and laughably hammy dialogue are scattered about just as liberally as the spent bullet casings in Street Kings.

So curious, and such a disappointment.

Beneath the requisite spectacle is an issue-laden storyline with heart to go along with its brains.

One of the year's best films, one that will surely get even better upon repeated viewings.

What is surprising and worth noting, though, is the quality of talent that's sadly squandered in comedian Larry the Cable Guy's feature film debut.
movie_title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is a cool/potentially creepy idea only if you're in high school and goofing around with your friends at the movie theater. For everyone else, this isn't just a preposterous premise for a horror movie, it's a source of unintentional hilarity.
If you didn't know you were watching Vin Diesel in Find Me Guilty, you wouldn't know you were watching Vin Diesel. And that's a compliment.
Really, ATL -- like last year's Roll Bounce -- is about roller skating.
Rothemund and screenwriter Fred Breinersdorfer have locked themselves into an episodic structure that offers virtually no nuance.
Tyler Perry's heart is in the right place, but he still has a tin ear.
All those Star Wars geeks, who've been waiting for weeks outside movie theaters with their Yoda sleeping bags and their homemade lightsabers, finally have a film that's worthy of their perseverance.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

Quote not available.

Harry Potter is 13 now, an awkward age for anyone -- even a boy wizard armed with magical powers. But Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, the third film in the series, couldn't be more self-assured.
