movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Richard Linklater is channeling Robert Altman -- or at least it seems he's trying to channel Altman -- with his meandering, intertwined plot lines.
Whether you love or hate the outspoken Maines, you've got to give her this much: She's never boring.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Whether or not you get that nagging sensation that you've seen Deja Vu before, your brain will seriously hurt trying to figure out whether its central gimmick works. (It doesn't.)
It's as if Aronofsky was so consumed with the film's elaborately contrived aesthetics that he took no time for a little thing called character development.
Director Brett Ratner, who built a career on this buddy cop franchise, has cobbled together a lazy and formulaic action comedy that is neither thrilling nor particularly funny.
Based on the novel by Neil Gaiman, Stardust definitely has more than enough imagination and whimsy to keep you engaged.

Forget everything you think you know about the movie musical, one of the more predictable genres. With Once, writer-director John Carney deconstructs it and reinvents it as something wholly new, inspired and alive.
Becoming Jane becomes a rather ordinary, though sporadically entertaining, game of dress-up.
No End in Sight will leave you floored, agape and enraged anew.
We'll just say that McLovin turns out to be the baddest mutha by far.

Dying is easy, comedy is hard, as the saying goes. A comedy about dying, especially a British farce, requires a specifically light, deft touch, which director Frank Oz achieves only about half the time in Death at a Funeral.
Wow, is this movie mind-numblingly vapid and shrill.
A film that feels truncated, rushed, unfocused and -- worst of all -- not the slightest bit scary or suspenseful.
The real letdown comes from knowing that the film is from Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini, the husband-and-wife writing-directing team behind the thrillingly inventive American Splendor.
It's helpful if you walk in with the expectation that it is a genre picture -- not a parody, not camp, but a loving homage to gangster movies of the 1980s like Scarface.

2 Days in Paris may seem familiar, with its manic, walking-and-talking rhythms reminiscent of Woody Allen and Diane Keaton in the 1970s. But you never know where it's going, which is one of the film's greatest pleasures.
It's like sitting through a college lecture and knowing with gripping dread that you're going to be quizzed on all of this afterward.
Confusing? Yes, and intentionally so. But it's never boring.

It's a wonderful surprise to discover that this new version, starring Russell Crowe and Christian Bale and directed by James Mangold, not only remains true to its roots but expands on them in ways that are thrilling and thoroughly entertaining.

Fierce People is based on a forced premise: the idea that a family of super-rich New Jersey eccentrics is like a tribe to be studied anthropologically. None of the characters resembles any creature you'd discover in nature, however.
It's actually not as maudlin as it sounds.
Blitz continues to make a case for himself as a filmmaker with rich, realistic stories to tell.
Anytime you compile a series of vignettes and call it a feature film, you're going to have hits and misses. It's the nature of the structure.
It's so expertly crafted and the cast is so superb that The Bourne Ultimatum exceeds all expectations of the genre.

The immensely likable Roberts... happens to be the best part of the film from director and co-writer Andrew Fleming, which offers a few laughs here and there but is otherwise contrived, cliched and stiff.
A STRIKINGLY shot tale of Sicilian villagers seeking a better life in America, Golden Door is so minimalist, it's practically a silent film.
It's the acting that elevates the story beyond its biopic trappings.
At times the visuals can be impressive, but the climactic flood -- the ark's raison d'etre -- looks surprisingly cheesy and fake.
For a big chunk in the middle it feels like a standard crime drama -- though it's a strikingly crafted and stirring one.
It is quintessential Moore: expertly crafted, eminently entertaining, one-sided and overly simplistic.
Ratatouille is free of the kind of gratuitous pop-culture references that plague so many movies of the genre; it tells a story, it's very much of our world but it never goes for the cheap, easy gag.

Ultimately, El Cantante, which is also the title of Hector's signature song, leaves you feeling like you've watched yet another cliche, a shortened life in the same polluted vein as Jim Morrison or Edith Piaf.
Mostly Evening feels draggy and repetitive as it wallows self-consciously in its own sense of emotional and cultural significance.
At once familiar and yet startlingly inventive and thrilling.
No winking, no mugging -- just earnest, wholesome, knock-your-socks-off fun.
It might seem offensive if it weren't so lame.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Everyone involved is so pedigreed, so capable, they make the experience go down easier that it ordinarily might.
Despite the film's undeniable technical achievements, it's hard to walk out of the theater without sensing that you've witnessed a bit of a cheat.
There's nothing lovely, however, about the movie's bombastic ending, but there are enough small moments until then to make this mixed-up experience vaguely worthwhile.
It makes you wonder what Lohan was thinking when she said yes to this project.
Eagle vs. Shark might have seemed amusingly original, albeit in a self-consciously quirky, indie-movie kind of way, if Napoleon Dynamite didn't already exist.
The Brave One seems to be implicitly saying that only men are capable of forceful action, only men are interesting at the centre of a moral quandary -- or at least, women who resemble men.
[Director] Shepard strikes just the right absurd, satirical tone until near the end, when he allows the film to wrap up a bit too conveniently.

Penn depicts this flawed figure with all the richness and complexity you'd find in the unforgiving Alaskan terrain, presenting McCandless in both his selflessness and selfishness without once judging him or turning him into a martyr.
Maybe it's not a whole new world, but it's one you already know and love quite well.
Kiss Kiss, Bang Bang is as much fun as the title suggests, and packed with banter that rolls off the tongue just as easily.

Despite its dark humor, The Savages tackles the tough topics of aging, frailty, humiliation and death. All depressing stuff, to be sure, but Jenkins handles it with a delicate, relatable touch, and without being maudlin.
Astonishingly beautiful and self-consciously so.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Juno is the kind of movie all indie comedies wish they could be: light and lovable, perhaps a bit too pleased with the cleverness of its dialogue, but a small charmer nonetheless.

A documentary about sex trafficking might have been more powerful. Dramatizing the subject in this fashion, with a race-against-time road trip, breathless online bidding and a couple of different happy endings, simply cheapens it.
Tickle Me Elmo is more subversive.

Yes, something is in the mist. Lots of things are in the mist. They're gorgeous and frightening and strange and elaborately detailed, and the effects used to create them allow them to blend in seamlessly with the live action.
It's just exceptionally well-crafted.
If nothing else, though, The Kite Runner does succeed in providing a vibrant window into a region of the world we might not have known and might have felt daunted to seek out.
An incomprehensible, pretentious, meandering mess -- so self-serious, it's laughable.

Charlie Wilson's War, a crisp, biting satire that confidently mixes sex and politics, glides along so smartly and smoothly, it makes you wonder how it's possible that director Mike Nichols and writer Aaron Sorkin have never teamed up before.

It's strangely beautiful and beautifully strange, with horrific subject matter that produces plenty of wicked humor and characters who initially seem ghoulish but ultimately reveal themselves as sympathetic and deeply sad.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Judd Apatow can do no wrong, apparently.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: P.S. I Love You is as treacly as the title would suggest.
In an era when pop-culture onslaughts are more fashionable, family movies of this quality are hard to find.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I Am Legend turns from a quiet meditation on the nature of humanity into a B-movie schlockfest.
Wake me when the wackiness is over.

Redacted might have been more compelling if De Palma had redacted himself a bit -- if he hadn't been so overt, if he'd given us enough credit to think for ourselves and come to our own conclusions about these men and the choices they made.
It's the actors themselves who all too often feel out of place.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's like Friends without the funny. Oh, wait -- that's redundant.
Shot in the 115-degree heat of Arizona and on location in Abu Dhabi, it has a visual intensity and intimacy reminiscent of Michael Mann.
This is Jones' show and he makes you feel a father's fear and loss in ways that are subtly heartbreaking, never melodramatic.
...sharp writing from Tony Gilroy and an intelligent, subtly powerful performance from George Clooney.

Through small gestures and bold choices, [Gosling's] created a character you begin feeling sorry for and end up rooting for and almost envying, simply because he's found something (someone?) that makes him feel whole and alive.
Despite its lofty aspirations and late 16th century setting, this one belongs right up there with Showgirls in the high-camp section of your local video store.

The Darjeeling Limited, the latest self-satisfied exercise in style over substance from writer-director Wes Anderson, will amuse his cult followers -- as well as Anderson himself and his pals, of course -- but probably nobody else.
Everything is black and white here, a tremendous disservice considering the complexity of the issue.
In his directing debut, Affleck has found his calling, an avenue for using his obvious intelligence while getting out of the way of his own celebrity.
Bier, in her American debut, mostly keeps things simple and intimate, though, by using hand-held cameras, extreme close-ups and flooding the proceedings with spare, natural light.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Washington, as real-life heroin kingpin Frank Lucas, and Crowe, as detective Richie Roberts, are on a collision course with one another that's bursting with the gritty period atmosphere of 1970s Harlem.
Yet another animated flick with a starry cast in which a creature that ordinarily would seem pesky is rendered as not just harmless but even lovable and idiosyncratically human. Enough already.

Demme doesn't insert himself, there's no structured interview format, we never see him or even hear his voice. He simply, easily immerses us. It's the opposite of Fahrenheit 9/11. And that's refreshing.
Veers awkwardly from shrill, slapsticky physical humour to diabolical meanness (courtesy of Spacey as an efficiency expert) to reheated, snuggly sentiments about the importance of love and family.
It's their best work in a while and it's probably going to end up being the year's best movie.
Carnahan's script is thoughtful, but its ideal venue may be a college debate class, not your local multiplex.
Beowulf bellows 'I am Beowulf!' so many times, it could be a drinking game; it certainly rivals 'This is Sparta!' as the year's preferred macho catch phrase.
The fact that LaBeouf can read a line like, 'Winners find a way no matter what' -- and not sound corny -- is emblematic of what makes Surf's Up such an enjoyable ride.
It's hard to get over the implausibility of the premise in Micky Levy's script, even though the characters themselves acknowledge that they're in a ridiculous situation.
Roth is good at what he does. Trouble is, he keeps making the same kind of movie over and over, and with his talent and imagination you'd like to see what other weapons he has in his arsenal.
Except for being a bit on the long side -- which you won't mind because you'll be having too much fun -- it's pretty close to perfect.
Feels more lightweight than it should and simultaneously not magical enough.
There are some jokes here, and any of these situations could have been funny as skits. Taken together, they're incoherent.
The idea may sound melodramatic but the result has realistic bite.
The rhythmic step dancing is infectious in the otherwise formulaic underdog flick Stomp the Yard -- so much so, you'll want to see more of it and less of a plot.
There are several good jumps and scares, and it's surprisingly tense the whole way through, not just gory and cheesy.
Carnahan veers wildly between dark comedy and over-the-top violence but never quite finds the right tone.
This fish-themed romance flops wildly all over the place, from heavy poignant moments to slapsticky comedy, with a healthy dose of soapy melodrama in between.
It's bad in a sickening, disturbing way, with its gratuitous mixture of sex and violence.
... technically solid but dramatically unremarkable ...
Sienna Miller remains an actress in search of a movie worthy of her talent.
It isn't until the end that things spin out of control. No one says 'Gimme the bat, Wendy' or 'Here's Johnny!' But they come close.

Hopefully the awards and acclaim Murphy has received for his work in Dreamgirls will inspire him to think twice from now on about puerile pictures like Norbit. The combination of the two speaks to his versatility, if not his pride.
A weird little hybrid of a romantic comedy that's simultaneously too fluffy and not whimsical enough.
Effortless performances from the two young stars ultimately make this movie worthwhile, regardless of the age of the kids watching.
Sitcommy, forced and forgettable.
Zodiac certainly has its moments, but it's no masterpiece.
Everything about Because I Said So screams out generic chick flick -- and we do mean scream, literally -- from the forgettable title to the excruciatingly corny ending.
White noise is intended to help you fall asleep. White Noise would never let you do that, though. It's far too interested in a cacophony of cheap scares.
It wouldn't seem possible, but this is yet another fractured fairy tale in which the characters subvert their own genre in self-conscious, smart-alecky fashion.
Crass and joyless.
In their silken robes, the wise men -- like everyone else in The Nativity Story -- feel like participants in an elaborate high school production, one that looks authentic but has no soul.
...Because we never had a strong handle on who all these people were at the beginning, it's difficult to care about whether they're capable of redemption in the end.
It can also be undeniably charming, so you may as well just check your cynicism at the door and surrender.

Inland Empire might be David Lynch's masterpiece -- or it might just be a total mess. Either way it's vintage Lynch and designed exclusively, it seems, for hardcore fans -- or perhaps solely for the director himself.
It has an intensity that's just spellbinding, with surprises around every corner -- many of them horrifying.
This is Hudson's movie all the way.

Corny? Overly simplistic? Perhaps. But those were grown-ups snuffling and wiping away tears at a recent screening -- not kids -- as the story reaches its heart-tugging conclusion. And there's no shame in that.
Except for a couple of Cedric's ad-libs, which are funnier in the closing-credit outtakes than in the movie itself, the whole thing is just lame and inane.

At its core The Pursuit of Happyness is a good story -- one that's literally rags to riches, and didn't need the many tweaks and embellishments that Italian director Gabriele Muccino and writer Steven Conrad have added.
This second picture is so different from the first, and such a rare, remarkable achievement in itself, it could have stood squarely on its own.
Rocky Balboa, the sixth (and hopefully last) installment in the underdog saga of the Italian Stallion, straddles the line between nostalgia and self-parody and frequently teeters toward the latter.
It's the story of the season: Trim about a half-hour and you could turn a good movie into a great one.
The movie certainly has its heart in the right place, but that alone just isn't enough.
Even though Perfume is primarily about how things (and more importantly, people) smell, it manages to be a feast for all the senses.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: George is just so darn cute with his big eyes and bright smile and perpetually sunny disposition, he's pretty much impossible to resist.
Whether or not this kind of horror movie is your cup of tea, you have to at least admire Roth for the daring and creativity with which he illustrates that concept.
Rips off Doc Hollywood, almost note for note.
Love lost and found, faith lost and found -- Brewer takes these tried-and-true themes and breathes bold, fresh life into them.
Moncrieff never gets melodramatic with subject matter that easily could have been; she won't make you feel good, but she will make you feel.
No one says, "Gimme the bat, Wendy," or, "Here's Johnny!" But they come close.
It's a highfalutin hodgepodge of biblical mumbo jumbo, more likely to inspire laughter than fear.
You have to give these guys this much: They remained true to their twisted vision, and that's exciting to see.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What could have been a feel-good performance from Molly Shannon is instead delicate, poignant, and an unexpected display of dramatic mastery from an actress who's made her name with comedy.
Perfect Stranger is one of those movies in which nothing and no one turns out the way they originally seemed. And, maddeningly, that's true of the movie itself, as well.
The way in which it gets off on the violence -- and, ostensibly, hopes the audience does the same -- is especially distasteful and, frankly, misogynistic.
Fracture is suspenseful and darkly stylish, but it also has an unexpectedly dry sense of humor. It's actually a lot funnier and a lot less stiff and self-serious than such a thriller might look.
It feels like Kasdan has piled one event on top of another on top of another, as opposed to building a believable story arc.
If you've got a taste for blood and three hours to kill, Grindhouse is for you.
[A] small charmer.
Its heart is absolutely in the right place, and it strikes some real emotional truths. It will make you laugh, it might even make you cry, but it definitely will make you hungry.
Spidey the Third feels like an even greater letdown following Spidey Part Deux, which was the rare sequel that surpassed the original.
In the end, it's just another concoction of unbelievable characters doing unbelievable things, and telling us nothing we haven't heard before.
It simultaneously feels truncated and interminable, and it grossly wastes the comic talents of Amy Poehler, Paul Rudd, Donal Logue and Charles Grodin, making his first movie in 13 years.

It's not sexy or stylish or glamorous or any of the things you might assume Paris would be before going there. But of all the segments that comprise the film, it comes the closest to depicting honestly what it feels like to fall in love.
Whatever unexpected ability [Judd] shows in the early scenes of this paranoid thriller go utterly to waste as the film spirals ridiculously out of control by the end.
With 18 pieces in all, there should be something here to tantalize everyone's tastes, or at least prompt you to contact your travel agent to book a vacation.
It has the audacity to serve as a self-righteous indictment of graphic, gratuitous violence, even though that's exactly what it's peddling.

Here, the effects spring organically from the story. You feel like you're immersed in a complete universe, the way the ground slopes toward you or objects seem to come from behind you and enter the screen.
The Lookout may look like just another bank heist caper, but it's actually a beautifully drawn character drama, and the rare film that manages to balance subtlety with suspense.
Then come the plot holes, the cartoonish performances (especially from Ned Beatty as a crudely drawn, corrupt Montana senator) and -- oh, yes -- the stuff that gets blowed up real good.

Surprisingly, for a movie about music, the sound is lousy. Some of the songs sound distorted because they have so much bass. In other moments, the dialogue is so low, it's hard to understand what the characters are saying.
Everything comes back to Garner, though -- and even when the movie takes itself too seriously, thankfully she never does.

The best parts of this dud are the ones in which she's singing. This is what she does best. This is what she should stick to. Save your money and watch her videos for free on cable music-television networks.

Snyder's depiction of the ancient Battle of Thermopylae, in which 300 Spartans fought off a much larger Persian army, is so over-the-top it's laughable -- so self-serious, it's hard to take seriously.
It works as a portrait of a father-son relationship that's awkward, volatile, uneven and always painfully real.

Undiscovered feels more like a pilot for a glossy nighttime soap on Fox -- probably one that would be canceled midseason -- than a feature film with even a modicum of discernible originality or depth.
The impossible plot and laugh-out-loud dialogue would have been tolerable if the tricks were impressive.
The Host begins with a dry, frequently absurd comic sensibility, but steadily grows darker, more intense and truly thrilling.
Every bit the cinematic shipwreck you'd imagine it to be.
It's boring. It's flat. It's ugly. Worst of all for a comedy, it's not even remotely funny.
This straight-up slasher flick probably should have gone straight to video for the cheesy-looking, computer-generated snakes alone.
A documentary on baseball's Texas Rangers and their last-place season would have been more interesting.
You could see the same thing for free -- with higher production values and snappier dialogue -- watching X Games coverage on ESPN.

The script from first-timers Paul Kimatian and Christopher Gambale requires Dillon to say corny things like: 'Bricks don't fall outta the sky in this neighborhood unless I'm throwin' 'em.' Tony Soprano, he ain't.
Snoop, Dre and their buddies take it all in stride -- if they were any more laid-back, they'd be napping in their trailers.
Rock is still too stiff and clunky as a filmmaker.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You certainly have to appreciate that Sandler wants to stretch in such a fashion, but you also want material that allows him to do so more convincingly.
If you competed in high school athletics, you might be able to overlook that Gracie is just another formulaic, if well-intentioned, sports movie.
Red Riding Hood does trot out the classic what-big-eyes-you-have routine. It's a pretty amusing moment, and it makes you wish the rest of the film had that same sort of knowing sense of humor.
Even if the visually similar Cloverfield and the thematically similar District 9 didn't already exist, this would still seem painfully hackneyed and obvious.
Schnabel's attempt at depicting this longtime, bloody friction from the Palestinian point of view -- and with a conciliatory tone -- is admirable; if only it had been more compelling.

You never feel like you're watching a play on film: The way Morgan has opened up the proceedings in his screenplay feels organic under the direction of Ron Howard, who has crafted his finest film yet, and one of the year's best.
Radcliffe, through his sheer presence and the piercing honesty of those big, blue eyes, makes this mixed-up material watchable.
Crashes and crime scenes are his bread and butter. He is driven. He is innovative. He is happy. He is also a monster - a fiend who preys on people at their weakest and worst moments.
Even calling "Actress" a documentary doesn't feel entirely accurate.
A strongly acted, handsomely crafted film that nonetheless feels bland and unsatisfying.
It's a film I didn't exactly enjoy and can't say I would recommend. And yet as an event, as a singular movie-watching opportunity, it's undoubtedly worthwhile.
What a tortured path "The King and the Mockingbird" has taken to reach theaters in the United States, and what a treat it is for us to be able to experience it now.

Writer-director Justin Simien takes a sledgehammer to the rosy notion that we've achieved a post-racial utopia - but he does it with great wit, bite and flair - in his debut feature, Dear White People.
It is The Room of Christmas movies. Actually, The Room is more enjoyable. But you get the idea.
The pacing is so zany, the jokes are so rapid-fire and the sight gags are so inspired that it's impossible not to get caught up in the infectious energy of it all.
With a combination of power and grace, Julianne Moore elevates "Still Alice" above its made-for-cable-television trappings, and delivers one of the more memorable performances of her career.
A numbing and soulless spectacle of 3-D, computer-generated imagery run amok, Ridley Scott's "Exodus: Gods and Kings" presents an enduring tale by pummeling us over the head with it.
In Bruges is a wildly imperfect feature debut, but it does make you curious to see what else McDonagh has to offer.
Even when "Two Days, One Night" drags a bit, Cotillard's performance remains compelling.
This is what all the fuss was about?

It manages to be both old-fashioned and high-tech. It remains faithful to the character's roots while also placing him firmly within a contemporary setting. It's charmingly funny and shamelessly punny.
It's an elaborate game of hurry-up-and-wait. And it's the most shameless example yet of splitting the final book in a hugely popular series into two film adaptations.

If you're at the multiplex in the middle of the afternoon, and "The Wedding Ringer" is the only movie playing at a time that's convenient, you won't be completely miserable. This is not exactly a ringing endorsement, I realize.
While the body count grows numbing and repetitive, "John Wick" actually is more compelling in the aesthetically heightened, specifically detailed world it depicts.
It's one of the most disturbing entertaining movies I've seen in a long while.
It's essentially a Transformers movie - a Michael Bay production complete with mass destruction, urban panic, white-hot lighting, inane quips, product placement, explosions and, well, Megan Fox.
"Life After Beth" gets into the well-tread zombie-comedy territory in a clever and inspired way. Then it doesn't get out of it nearly so skillfully.
This notion might have worked perfectly well in sketch form, but stretched out to feature length - in a film that's overlong at nearly two hours - it grows thin, repetitive and wearying.
[Moretz's] grounded, naturalistic presence goes a long way toward making mushy material palatable.
"Rocks in my Pockets" is a bold, rough-hewn combination of papier-mâché, stop-motion animation and hand-drawn images.
"Frontera" is a well-cast, well-made, well-acted drama that you will probably forget about soon after you've seen it.
As we enter this season of big, important awards contenders that "matter," "The Skeleton Twins" is a small, intimate gem that might truly matter.
The result is one of the best times you'll have at the movies this year-which might even be the best movie this year.

No Good Deed practically fetishizes the brutality Idris Elba's character inflicts on a number of women. It sexualizes him as a killing machine. It wants us to salivate over him and tremble before him simultaneously.
Mawkish, self-satisfied and false, This Is Where I Leave You strenuously attempts to wring poignancy from its familial clashes and catharsis. More often, it's cringe-inducing.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a risky approach that's bound to frustrate many folks, but it's also quite illuminating in its own way.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: We also find ourselves wondering about the real Chelsea, but Grey plays her as such a chic, chameleonlike enigma, she remains beyond our grasp. It's all part of the game: enticing but frustrating, the ultimate tease.
It should have more smoldering panic bursting into full-blown freak-outs. It should have more passion, more intensity. It should have more bees.
This is the most elegant, exquisitely made trash.
This may look like a wacky spoof of 1970s sci-fi, but Jack Plotnick's beautifully designed comedy-drama actually has a lot more on its mind.
The goose bumps are undeniable. You may as well just give in.

What's intriguing about "The Maze Runner"-for a long time, at least-is the way it tells us a story we think we've heard countless times before but with a refreshingly different tone and degree of detail.
Even by the standards of this franchise-and this genre in general-"Step Up All In" is pretty laughable.
Let's start with the fact that Hemsworth stars as the world's most brilliant hacker. Let that sink in for a moment.
The cheese is thick and it smothers everything in "The Boy Next Door," but it's never quite gooey or spicy enough.
Truly, there is not a single redeeming moment in director Andy Fickman's film. A general flatness and lethargy permeates these reheated proceedings.
If you can give yourself over to the idea of Unfriended,you'll find it's surprisingly engrossing and really quite clever.

It's meant to be a tale of uplift for faith-based audiences, but instead wears viewers down with a heavy-handed narrative, an overbearing score and voiceover that spells out everything in cringe-inducing, folksy tones.
Ex Machina is the best movie I've seen all year.
More does not necessarily equal better; here, more is just ... meh.
What begins as a sweetly sentimental story ends up being cloyingly melodramatic.
It's actually, actively worse than you think it's going to be.
You're likely to laugh and learn in equal measure-and so will your little ones.
Believe all the hype: This movie will melt your face off.
"Aloha" feels like several films at once, crammed together and sped up, with results that are emotionally hollow and narratively confusing.
It's like Planes, Trains & Automobiles, only with a catastrophic body count.
I leapt out of my seat and grabbed the arm of the critic sitting next to me so often (and he did the same, although he shall remain nameless) that you'd think we'd never seen a horror movie before.
These guys learn nothing, they don't change, they have no arc and they are never truly challenged.
There's little tension as her romantic and financial calamities collide, only mere traces of tragedy. Even at nearly two hours, much-needed character development is sorely lacking.
So basically, Jurassic World is a big-budget indictment of corporate greed, jammed with product placement for Samsung and Mercedes-Benz and Beats by Dre and Coca-Cola.
Deft and delicate and exquisitely uncomfortable, but it also offers revelations that are joyful, sad and true.
Stop me if you think you've heard this one before.
Pacino gives a refreshingly quiet and understated performance with poignant moments of vulnerability. It is the most consistent factor in a film that is frustratingly inconsistent.
The Longest Ride is pretty darn tolerable - and sometimes even enjoyable - not just for fans but also for regular people who are, you know, cynical.
While he doesn't really uncover much that's new in "Going Clear," the way he's collected and assembled testimonials, documents and archival footage creates a cumulative effect that's chilling.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Show 'Em What You're Made Of is the title of a song on their new album, but you also get a sense that they feel liberated in finally showing the world what they're made of through this film.
movie_title: Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water" remains true to the surrealism of its animated television roots. But it also tries to force a live-action element which isn't as comfortable a fit as a certain pair of symmetrical trousers.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Love, Rosie" is one of those annoying movies in which everything would be just fine if the two central characters had a simple conversation that cleared up all their misunderstandings.
A lot of people spent a lot of time and a lot of money making a lot of movie, but there's not much there.
It realizes this story is ridiculous in ways the book itself never could. It has an actual sense of humor.

Whitman displays flawless comic timing and consistently makes inspiring choices in terms of delivery, reaction, even the slightest facial expression. She shines confidently in a self-deprecating role, and it's irresistible.
Co-stars Will Smith and Margot Robbie remain consistently charismatic, even once the script for this heist caper collapses in a punishing pile of its own twists and double-crosses.

"Dior and I" intimately demonstrates the tricky balance between art and commerce, between perpetuating a mythology while attending to the bottom line, and doing it with the pressure of a ticking clock.

Madden's movie is crammed with so many characters that we never spend enough quality time with any of them for their stories to resonate. While the many attempts at poignancy feel forced and false, the effort as a whole feels like it will never end.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It'll make you listen to "Good Vibrations," a song you've heard a million times, with fresh ears.
The colors - good lord. They're like nothing you could experience in the real world. Cinderella's behemoth of a ball gown alone is 50 shades of blue.
Mitchell's skills in crafting mood and building tension result in one of the most mesmerizing and suspenseful horror movies to come along in a long time.

The observant and mocking humor that makes the film's first two-thirds so breezy and enjoyable gives way to shattering realizations, but Baumbach ultimately tempers that instinct somewhat by exhibiting genuine sympathy for Stiller's character.
Heartwarming and harmless? Sure, why not. But it's also numbing in its simplicity and often rather annoying.

It's hard not to admire the intentions of a movie that depicts two exceptional women living exactly the way they wanted, together, outside the expected societal norms of the time. But the tone of the film itself feels unfortunately conventional.
"Last Knights" is so thoroughly mediocre, so dully empty, that it's difficult to summon the enthusiasm to trash it. And yet, duty calls.
While the visual effects are spectacularly seamless, they're in the service of a movie which devolves from vaguely funny to just-plain silly to numbingly gory.
Despite being handsomely crafted, well acted and even sufficiently enjoyable, "The Hundred-Foot Journey" is also conventional and predictable.
In Boseman's hands - and his feet, and his entire body, for that matter - he demands and earns our attention.
Director and co-writer James Gunn brings a giddiness and a wondrous, endless sense of why-the-hell-not? possibility that's reminiscent of Star Wars.
"Better Living Through Chemistry" as a whole feels rather superficial and safe.
Like the film's fake fish, The Life Aquatic is endlessly fascinating to watch but, if you look closer, there's not much there.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Veronica herself is such a breath of fresh air as a strong female character: smart, secure, resourceful, loyal, funny and not the slightest bit chickish.

Wicker Park is one of those maddening movies in which the characters do incredibly stupid things simply for the sake of plot contrivance, and everyone's problems would be solved if they simply picked up their cell phones.
In quiet, intimate ways, it is one of the most startling, haunting films you'll see all year.
As an examination of memory and experience and how they shape us, "The Missing Picture" is meaningful beyond its specific subject matter.
This is supposed to be a thriller, by the way. It's more of a slog, not so much a whodunit as a whydunit-and by the end, it's: Who cares?
Once we understand what's driving Guy, the revelation is airless: It feels like too little, too late. Now we're supposed to care about whether he has feelings?
The performances -- namely from stars Shailene Woodley and Theo James and Kate Winslet in a juicy supporting role -- always make the movie watchable and often quite engaging.
In some ways, Noah resembles one of those Kirk Cameron movies about the apocalypse, only with a better cast and more dazzling special effects.
Haynes' loving homage to the Technicolor female-driven melodramas of the 1950s looks and feels so authentic, it will make you forget you are watching a new movie.

"Island of Lemurs: Madagascar" accomplishes a great deal in its 40-minute running time, entertaining and educating us while delivering a message about preservation that's clear without being heavy-handed.
Pondering the questions, reveling in the mysteries - that's what matters. And I haven't even said the words naked Scarlett Johansson yet.

Despite the predictable formula, screenwriter Scott Silver wisely avoids taking the easy route every time; there are several small twists you may not expect, and the ending isn't entirely a happy one.
The Lars von Trier you know and love (or love to hate) is back: cynical, misanthropic, punishing.
Underlying the directorial derring-do is an enduring truth: Love really can conquer all.
Lars von Trier is funny. Who knew? That's certainly the most startling revelation to come from Nymphomaniac: Vol. 1 .

Throughout his career, Firth repeatedly has proven himself to be a master at steadily revealing his characters, and the way his Lomax eventually reclaims his identity before enjoying some redemption is gently stirring.

Solid performances-especially from star Cuba Gooding Jr.-elevate the film slightly above the familiar trappings of its genre.
A film with a message of inspiration, to be sure, but not much in terms of innovation.
Ride Along  has the dubious distinction of being simultaneously shoddy and straining, lazy and desperate.
"Run & Jump" is surprisingly alive, full of jolts and unexpected bursts of humor and earned emotion.
A movie that's not just accessible but fun, with a surprisingly emotional payoff at the end.
An after-school special blown up on the big screen, it stridently aims to inspire you. More likely, it'll make you cringe.
A Beautiful Mind is Howard's best movie, and easily one of the best movies of the year.
Zoe Kazan breathes fresh, exciting life into a tried-and-true high concept, playing opposite herself as twentysomething identical twins in "The Pretty One."

The Lego Movie: Merely a great film, or the greatest film ever in the history of cinema?
Cherish is one of those movies in which the soundtrack is better than the movie itself.
"Endless Love" isn't so much a remake of the 1981 Franco Zeffirelli film as it is an extended ad for the idyllic Abercrombie & Fitch lifestyle.
Is it wrong to root for the volcano?
It's hard to tell what Reitman-who also wrote the script, based on the novel by Joyce Maynard-intended here.

Darkly funny and deeply twisted, "13 Sins" grabs you from its startling opening sequence and doesn't let go.

Everything about this film smacks of laziness.

A tasteful and formulaic biopic, visually lush but emotionally shallow.
Simply recreating what we know to be hackneyed and safe doesn't suddenly make it hilarious and surprising. There has to be a spin to it; there has to be some innovation.

Long before Optimus Prime hoists his hulking metal frame onto the back of a giant robot dinosaur, wields his mighty sword and rides valiantly away to save the planet once more, Transformers: Age of Extinction plays like a parody ...

The wholesome, hopeful, let's-put-on-a-show enthusiasm may sound hokey but it's actually infectiously joyful. At the same time, Carney roughs up the edges just enough to make this fairy tale seem somewhat accessible and realistic.
It's a one-joke movie that feels like a one-joke movie.
A heavy-handed and didactic drama which also manages to be totally mushy in terms of the message it's trying to convey.
It's so hard to describe how amazing Snowpiercer is without giving away everything that makes it amazing.

It is pummeling. It is punishing. It is nauseating and headache-inducing.
The musical elements of the film aren't even the most compelling parts. They're actually surprisingly cheesy.
A movie that's as empty and unlikable as the characters themselves.
Easily a contender for the worst movie of the year.
Husson captures the restless rhythms of adolescence-the push-pull of angst and boredom, of self-consciousness and the yearning to lose oneself completely.

Typical Adam Sandler fare in every way, from the raunchy humor to the inclusion of his buddies to the deplorable view of women to the vacation disguised as a movie shoot to the forced sentimentality in the final act.
It's just dull and hollow-a massive waste of time and money.
It's gorgeous. It's lively. It's got terrific performances from a strong voice cast. It's emotionally affecting without being heavy-handed.
Veteran French director Anne Fontaine approaches a spiritually and emotionally complex real-life slice of history with deftness and understated drama in "The Innocents."
Even as events turn more than a tad preposterous with twists that seem not just predictable but inevitable, Farr keeps a handle on the tension and tone, which keeps us hooked.
The movie as a whole is such an incompetent train wreck, you can't look away, just to see how much worse it can get.
Everyone is horrible all the time-so when they do horrible things to each other, the result is a chuckle rather than a vicious bite. The music business is cutthroat, we get it.

Gags get piled upon gags with relentless frenzy and results that are overbearing rather than uproarious. You can rely on every character to behave the exactly the same way every time, regardless of the situation, and that way is usually obnoxious.

While you may think you've seen "Sisters" countless times before, it often feels refreshing and even pleasingly subversive through the sheer force of nature that is Fey and Poehler's well-established bond.
Right away, we know we're in the hands of a director who wants to tell the story of the Holocaust from a different perspective than we've seen before in films: a more personal, intimate one.

That's what's so impressive about the tricky balancing act Abrams has pulled off with The Force Awakens: He's made a movie that's simultaneously gripping and a huge release. We are in good hands, at last.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Garrel may not be saying anything new about the capricious whims of the heart, but he does so with a purity of narrative and tone, and with thoroughly convincing performances from his stars.
It's awkward and strange but never shamelessly over-the-top enough to serve as a guilty pleasure.

The 5th Wave plays like a Wayans-brothers spoof of movies based on dystopian Young Adult novels. Seriously, it could have been called YA Movie the way it wallows in all the overly familiar tropes of the genre.
Mostly, "Fifty Shades of Black" is exactly what you expect it will be.
Maybe someone else can crack the code to the ultimate Austen mash-up when the inevitable "Sense and Sensibility and Sea Monsters" adaption comes along.
Think of "How to Be Single" as a cinematic Whitman's Sampler: There are enough pieces that work to offset the pieces that don't.

So vividly immersive is Kung Fu Panda 3 - so vibrant, so tactile - it will make you feel as if you've stepped into a fully realized world. And then once you've stepped out, you'll be craving dumplings.
Their latest, Hail, Caesar!, is their giddiest comedy to date, but it's also hit-and-miss within itself.

It's a shame that a movie about a man with zero athletic ability, who had the fearlessness to attempt a perilous 90-meter ski jump for the first time ever in front of a rapt Olympic audience, takes no chances.
It might be trying to make a point. If so, it sure is hard to hear it over the noisy screeches and cheap jump scares.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: We know how the story ends, so there's little in the way of tension.
London Has Fallen is Donald Trump in film form.
Bring tissues.
A nightmarish landscape that's meant to be frightening - or at least unsettling - ends up being hilariously cheesy instead.
It is an incredibly simple yet irresistible idea for a movie. It's also exactly what you think it's going to be - no more, no less.
Where the story leads is so disappointing-and hackneyed-it makes the entire journey feel like an enormous waste of time.
Just try to stop yourself from swooning.
The erotic thriller "Trap for Cinderella" is neither erotic nor thrilling, but rather reliant on cheap nudity and multiple mistaken-identity switcheroos in hopes of keeping us on edge.
A solid genre picture that knows exactly what it is, has no delusions of grandeur and carries out its task in entertaining and occasionally even suspenseful fashion.
Gerardo Naranjo may have made the least-glamorous movie ever about a pageant queen with "Miss Bala."
"Haywire" feels like minor Soderbergh: zippy, hugely entertaining and well-crafted as always, but not one of his more important films in the broad scheme of things.
"Albert Nobbs" is clearly Close's show - for better and for worse.
"Man on a Ledge" is so cliched and reheated, it almost feels like a parody of a generic action picture -- only no one seems to be in on the joke.
You may look back at the end and wonder, how did we get here? Pay attention: There are small clues along the way.
Like a whale itself, "Big Miracle" is large and unwieldy -- but it also has its moments of splendor.
If some incarnation of "Glee" were to be developed for the Christian Broadcasting Network, it would probably look a lot like "Joyful Noise."
This is an auspicious beginning for a couple of exciting, young filmmaking voices.
Ultimately, "Safe House" reveals itself to be more interested in bombastic, bloody thrills than provocative, analytical thought.

"The Vow" serves as a series of precise if obvious moments and emotional cues we must endure en route to the inevitable reconciliation, complete with an intrusively heart-tugging score and too much explanatory voiceover from Tatum.
Having great-looking stars who have the added bonus of actually being able to act makes the noisy romp "This Means War" more tolerable than it ought to be.
Bring tissues. You've been warned. And you don't even have to be a sports fan to be moved.
Eventually it reveals itself to be a character drama about the way the past shapes us and our inability to escape it, no matter how convincingly we believe we've transformed ourselves.

Some jokes get hammered into the ground repeatedly; others go on well past the point of cringe-inducing awkwardness, which is the point. But some do reach the levels of brilliant, unfettered lunacy to which they aspire.
An inspiring must-see for anyone who feels the urgent need to create something beautiful and meaningful, no matter the cost.
The trappings may look familiar, but "The Innkeepers" is a new twist on the good, old-fashioned ghost story: It's the bored-slacker horror movie.
Ultimately, being either Flynn doesn't seem terribly appealing.
Movies with this kind of moral complexity are rare, so not only is it worth seeking out, it's one you need to see with friends because it invites -- or rather demands -- debate afterward.
Even the greatest actress of our time can only do so much when the figure she's playing just isn't on the page.

As the initial whiff of scandal eventually gives way to great, repetitive blubbering about the brilliance and significance of Shakespeare's works, "Anonymous" ultimately feels like much ado about nothing.
if you can get past the plot holes and the copious time puns, In Time is actually rather brisk, enjoyable entertainment.
When Murphy's on screen in his classic comic mode, it's hard to focus on anyone or anything else. It's as if we've turned back time and erased all those family-friendly duds and lame laughers...
This third film in the Harold & Kumar franchise is inordinately jacked up with visual effects and peppy holiday music, but nothing can disguise the fact that this series has run out of steam.

Regardless of your own stance on the death penalty, it's impossible not to be shaken by the senseless loss depicted in "Into the Abyss," the overwhelming sadness, but also the possibility of spiritual redemption.

Depression finally seems to have brought out the best in Lars von Trier: "Melancholia" is his strongest work in a while, a devastatingly beautiful, operatic mixture of all his signature themes and visual schemes.
The story keeps you guessing as to where it will go, and it features some piercing moments of emotional truth.
Being a hardcore cinephile (like Scorsese) might add a layer of enjoyment, but it certainly isn't a prerequisite for walking in the door. A sense of wonder, however, is.

The dialogue is, of course, ridiculous and the acting ranges from stiff to mopey. But moments that should be pulsating with tension are usually hilarious because the special effects are still just so distractingly cheesy.
Fassbender's performance here is riveting, haunting. He immerses himself and makes you feel as if you're truly watching a man hell-bent on exorcising his demons through compulsive self-destruction.
Precisely staged but maddeningly obtuse, "Sleeping Beauty" is an artful exercise in pointlessness.
In the vein of Alexander Payne, Reitman finds just the right affectionately mocking tone in taking some jabs at small-town Midwestern life.
This is a grim, methodical world ruled by drab, mistrustful geeks who have come to relish their power, but Alfredson navigates it fluidly and keeps the many complicated pieces moving with quiet ease.

What seemed clever and novel the first time around now feels stale and tired; a lot of that has to do with the grimy, gray color scheme, which smothers everything in a dreary, suffocating sameness and saps the film of any real tension or thrills.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is the first feature from Crowe since the heavy-handed, overly quirky "Elizabethtown," and while it's not a complete return to form, it's close enough.
It's overlong, painfully earnest and sometimes even hokey.
Spitting and stammering, clawing and convulsing, her jaw jutting forward and her eyes popping out of her head, Keira Knightley is a frightening force of nature in A Dangerous Method.
"Project X" grows repetitive and starts running out of steam, and you begin to wonder what could possibly occur over the remaining 30 minutes or so.
Westfeldt takes a topic full of complex emotional shadings and turns it into something that is, for the most part, reductive, cliched and even sitcommy.

Olsen continues to reveal a startling comfort and maturity in front of the camera for someone so young and relatively inexperienced. But the film's dexterous cinematographer, Igor Martinovic, is just as much of a star behind the lens.
This is being marketed as an ideal film for moms and daughters to see together on Mother's Day weekend. A long, awkward brunch sounds more fun -- and more truthful.
"God Bless America" has a whole lotta "Taxi Driver" in it, and some "Network," and some "Heathers" (with Barr functioning as Christian Slater in the equation), and even some "Kick-Ass."
Clearly, Baron Cohen is a smart, gifted and versatile actor; it's time for him to stretch his abilities and dictate to himself a new kind of challenge.
A good-looking cast of popular actors can only do so much with material that's superficial and sitcommy.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Battleship" is big, dumb fun that knows it's big, dumb fun and enthusiastically embraces its big, dumb, fun nature.
Sure, you've seen this sort of material before -- comparisons to HBO's "The Wire" are frequent and obvious -- but when it's done right, as it is here, it's gripping.
If you love Wes Anderson, you'll love this: The best of what he can do is vibrantly on display.

The film itself takes awhile to get going as it establishes all those characters and back stories. Once there, it seems to have nowhere to go -- out of the shadows or into the light, it doesn't really matter either way.
When even the most charismatic actor on the planet can't fake excitement, you know you're in trouble.
Astonishingly beautiful and breathtaking in its brutal imagery, Snow White & the Huntsman is thrilling and frightening in equal measure, yet as bereft of satisfying substance as a poisoned apple.
The paranoia becomes palpable, and a lot of its impact comes from how dramatic and dazzlingly seamless the special effects are.
You have to admire the fact that, rather than turning to the safety of snark, this little movie sticks to its big idea: All you gotta do is believe.
Squanders the abilities of these usually fearless, formidable actresses with material that's entirely predictable and a high sap factor that belongs in a made-for-cable production.
It's a defiant, uncompromising statement in every way.
Even when things get a little crazy and maybe even too soapy, "Your Sister's Sister" always feels like it's rooted in a tangible reality, a place of unpredictability and abiding humanity.
If this era was a formative time in your life and you're feeling a yearning for kitschy nostalgia, "Rock of Ages" provides a sufficiently fun little escape.
Cluzet has the daunting task of trying to strike a powerful contrast while acting only from the neck up, and he pulls it off with stoic, bemused grace.
Mostly, "Marigold Hotel" is old-fashioned, safe and resistant to stray from its comfort zone -- like visiting a foreign country and only eating the foods you already know you like.
Notable for a chilling lead performance from Rebecca De Mornay and not much else.

Halfway through you want to yell at the screen for them to run off to Las Vegas and just get it over with already; then again, it becomes increasingly difficult to root for them to stay together when they seem to be headed down such divergent paths.
Yes, there is life on Mars in "John Carter," and it's deadly dull.

All of these comic actors find different sorts of laughs -- sadder, truer ones -- by toning down some of their usual tendencies. They're no less effective this way, but the shift does provide an unexpected tone.
Cute, but not much more. But maybe it's better if you've had a couple margaritas with friends beforehand.

"The Hunger Games" runs nearly two and a half hours in length but is the rare film that never drags and doesn't overstay its welcome. It could keep running as long as Katniss does, and we'd want to be right there every heart-pounding step of the way.
Rather than crafting a movie that's so bad it's good, writer-director brothers Jason and Brandon Trost have come up with something that's just plain bad -- and boring, and repetitive.
"Bully" is essential to see, whether you're a parent or a kid, whether you've been on the giving or receiving end of such increasingly pervasive cruelty.
For a movie about ragged, trash-talking thugs beating the crap out of each other on the ice, Goon is surprisingly sweet.
The dialogue and the action are, for the most part, rather dull and weirdly devoid of energy.
You won't appreciate the film fully unless you're already a member of the choir to which it's preaching.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: If any film should be redone in 3-D, it's "Titanic." And if any filmmaker should be the one doing the redoing, it's James Cameron.
"American Reunion" relies on clichés about nostalgia, forced tension over strained friendships and melodrama about the rekindling of first loves.
As Goddard and Whedon jump back and forth, the pieces snap into place; then just when you think you've got it all figured out, they throw something else at you.
A little nyuk-nyuk-nyuk goes a long way in "The Three Stooges," Peter and Bobby Farrelly's feature-length homage to the classic slapstick comedy trio.

You have to give "Think Like a Man" credit for not only trying to serve as an alternative to Tyler Perry-style date-night fare, but for even going so far as to make fun of those movies for their soapy conventions.
You can roll your eyes, or you can give in.

The dialogue sparkles as brightly as the special effects; these people may be wearing ridiculous costumes but they're well fleshed-out underneath. And so in every regard, this movie truly fulfills its hype.
"Sound of My Voice" may seem like an extended episode of "The Twilight Zone," but within its clever structure it digs into the notions of identity, loyalty and the need to belong.

It makes you squirm in your seat - not because the angst of the young love depicted on screen is so vivid and relatable, but because these two people are so incredibly annoying together, you'd much rather see them apart.
Pixar is long overdue for a feature with a strong female character at its center. Now that she's arrived, it's clear that she deserves better.
For quick, lively, family friendly entertainment, "Puss in Boots" works just fine, even in 3-D, which is integrated thoughtfully into the narrative and doesn't just feel like a gimmick.
Johnny English isn't reborn so much as reheated, and his aim hasn't improved after all these years.
Strong performances and a stripped-down visual aesthetic help mitigate some of the movie's potential mawkishness.

Giving the people what they want is one thing. Making nearly the exact same movie a second time, but shifting the setting to Thailand, is just ... what, lazy? Arrogant? Maybe a combination of the two.
If you're open to letting the imagery wash over you, to allowing yourself to get sucked into the film's rhythms and fluidly undulating tones, you'll be wowed.
The freshness and novelty that made the original film such a kick back in 2008 has been, well, kicked to bits.
The Blind Swordsman: Zatoichi begins life as a straight-up samurai movie, evolves into a slapstick comedy and ends as a rousing, tap-dancing musical.
To describe Love, Wedding, Marriage as sitcommy would be an insult to sitcoms, which can and do succeed in inspiring genuine laughter.

On paper, it all could have been too cloying or self-conscious, but writer-director Mike Mills finds just the right tone every time. He also draws lovely, natural performances from Christopher Plummer and Ewan McGregor.
[It] is the shortest in the series. But it still feels overlong and overstuffed: needlessly convoluted yet, at the same time, phoned-in.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: All you're left with is ... story. And strong performances. And well-developed characters. And a believable emotional arc. And genuine thrills.
This is going to sound corny, but here goes: "Buck" will make you want to be a better person.
A joyless amalgamation of expository dialogue and special effects that aren't especially special.
Cars 2 is such a mess, it makes the original look like it ought to rank among Pixar's masterpieces by comparison.
"Bad Teacher" is exactly the one-joke movie that you probably expect it to be, but there are enough variations and shadings of that one joke to sustain its brief running time -- just barely.
"Larry Crowne" serves as a reminder that you can have two of the most likable, bankable stars on the planet together, but strong writing is crucial to making them shine.
All three young performers are strong here, but Wysocki especially never seems like he's "acting" during these scenes of adolescent drama. He just is.
The kills aren't terribly suspenseful or dramatically staged and they quickly grow repetitive. Worst of all, they're not particularly scary.
A shrill, shallow cacophony of individual wacky moments without much narrative momentum.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film that's wildly, brazenly stupid -- but also, you know, fun.
No film has asked [Ferrell] to delve into the kinds of deep, dark places required of him in "Everything Must Go." And he more than rises to the challenge.
Bowen is likable and has strong-enough timing to make these moments less cringe-inducing than they might sound. It's the rest of the movie that'll probably make you cringe.
There's no great narrative momentum to Win Win, and that's fine, because it's such an enjoyable little slice of life.
It has nothing to do with the capital of Nebraska or the former president. While you're watching it, though, you'll wish it did.
You could pick the script apart for impossibilities. But why bother? It's much more enjoyable to shut your brain off and have a good time.
It'll make your brain hurt (in a good way) trying to determine whether it all makes sense -- until it quite obviously and frustratingly doesn't make sense anymore.
Insidious is the kind of movie you could watch with your eyes closed and still feel engrossed by it.

It may sound like Super is trying too hard to shock, trying too hard to be edgy or weird. But it has such a low-budget charm, it's pretty hard to resist. Besides, if you don't, you risk incurring the wrath of The Crimson Bolt. And you don't want that.
The fact that Ronan is this good at this young age is what's truly frightening here.

Bridesmaids surely doesn't mark the end of conventional female-centric comedies, but it works on so many levels, it'll hopefully make future filmmakers stop and think twice before approaching this kind of project and realize it can be done [better].
Soul Surfer takes that story of complex emotions, determination and faith and turns it into overly simplistic mush.
Nothing deep or heavy here -- just a good time and a pleasurable escape.
Reichardt trusts her audience, encourages her viewers to feel comfortable in the stillness and the quiet, and to draw their own conclusions from an ending that's as profound as it is enigmatic.

Spurlock's folksy affability creates the sensation that he's truly going on a journey, that he doesn't necessarily know all the answers to the questions he's posing, and he'd like nothing more for us than to go along for the ride.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The whole thing goes down like a second, giant tumbler of scotchy scotch scotch: familiar, comforting and, ultimately, numbing.

Werner Herzog has such obvious enthusiasm for the discoveries he depicts in Cave of Forgotten Dreams, it's as if you're listening to a giddy little kid who learned the coolest thing at school today and can't wait to tell you all about it.
Prom means well -- and it grows on you. And it's much less of a hassle than schlepping to the real thing.

Many melodramatic revelations come to light in the film's third act, then they're just as quickly resolved. But don't feel daunted: You'll probably have checked out mentally and emotionally long before any of this anyway.
It should be tense and thrilling, full of rich, powerful performances; instead, it'll make you feel like you should be taking notes in preparation for a high-school exam.
While "Deathly Hallows: Part 2" offers long-promised answers, it also dares to pose some eternal questions, and it'll stay with you after the final chapter has closed.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is just 68 minutes of pure, hunny-covered satisfaction.
Morris' spirited pacing and the jaunty score from John Kusiak help maintain a tone that's part mocking, part suspenseful.
Soderbergh takes us from suburban living rooms to labs at the Centers for Disease Control to remote Asian villages with equally clear-eyed realism.

Gosling's masculine, minimalist approach makes him mysteriously compelling. Yes, there's the fact that he's gorgeous. But he also does so much with just a subtle glance, by just holding a moment a beat or two longer than you might expect.
"I Don't Know How She Does It" suggests what might have happened to Carrie if she had two kids with Mr. Big to worry about, and less time to obsess over her wardrobe.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like the A's themselves at this time, "Moneyball" has enough unlikely pieces that do work -- and it generates enough underdog goodwill -- to make you want to stick around for the final out.
When Statham and Owen finally meet in the showdown you've been waiting for, it's rendered in such dizzying, adrenalized style that it's hard to tell who's doing what to whom.
The real-life Sam Childers, who's still working in Sudan, is probably more complicated than this.
Levine has accomplished a tricky bit of juggling here: He's made a film about cancer that's effortlessly affecting.
As it jumps back and forth in time, "The Debt" explores the conflict between expectations and reality, intellect and emotions, truth and regret.
Daring thematically and striking aesthetically, even as it pierces at the heart of the most relatable, everyday anxieties we all experience.
It's hard to tell whether [Six] made "The Human Centipede 2" to titillate his audience or to mock it. And after a while, it is hard to care.
Gosling radiates charisma, schmoozing and charming reporters and staffers with equal ease. But beneath that slick exterior, his character is a true believer.

Yes, this comedy about a sad-sack, has-been boxer is painfully predictable and manages to include every cliche of the genre, but executive producer and star Adam Carolla keeps it rolling along with his trademark, deadpan rants.
The heavy eye shadow, cheesy clothes and stiffly flipped-out hair feel almost too mocking ... rather than serving as stylistic choices that make the characters feel like real people.
This feels almost like a parody of Almodovar, with its melodramatic tone and themes of gender, identity, sex and revenge.
"The Big Year" flaps its wings awfully hard but never truly takes flight.
Spacey does some of the best work we've seen from him in a while as a once-confident man who's now questioning everything upon which he built his cushy life.
It's juicy stuff but not very informative.
For the most part, it's all big and silly, but at least it's enjoyably staged and crafted.
The film as a whole often feels like an exercise in style over substance, especially as it becomes clear just how many times we've seen these kinds of characters in this kind of story before.
"Higher Ground" probably sounds rather somber, but Farmiga also deftly conveys the absurdity of Corinne's predicament. Every once in a while she'll let out a cackle that's just pure joy.
A pervasive feeling of the unknown is what provides the film with its gripping suspense.

Like the experiment itself, "Project Nim" morphs from something inspiring and often humorous to a pointed and disturbing portrait of arrogance run amok. Greed and glory end up overriding decency and altruism, and it's heartbreaking to watch.
Mitchell finds a balance that's just right in juggling all these emotions and presenting them believably in screen. His little movie is pretty much perfect in depicting youthful imperfection.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You are not in for a giddy, winking, high-flying summer fling. And that's OK -- there's something appealing about such an old-fashioned approach.
It never gets crazy or stupid enough to make you truly fall in love with it.
A low-budget adventure with propulsive energy and plenty of laughs.
"Life in a Day" is so intimate and ultimately optimistic, it'll leave you with the inescapable feeling that you've just made hundreds of new friends you've never actually met.
It offers hope that original storytelling is still out there, lurking in the darkness, just waiting for a massive flamethrower to light it up.
[It's] all over the place in tone, veering awkwardly from some daring comic moments to feel-good sappiness and back again in hopes of redeeming some semblance of edginess.
This seventh film in the Planet of the Apes series rises to such ridiculous heights, it's impossible not to laugh out loud -- in a good way, in appreciation.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You don't have to know a thing about Formula 1 racing to become engrossed by "Senna."
None of this crackles with the kind of breezy, madcap hilarity that it should; it's actually rather tortured and convoluted.
Is it calculated? For sure. But it does what it needs to do to please its target audience. Everyone else may as well surrender to the juggernaut.
It didn't seem possible for there to be even less characterization than there was in the original "Conan," but voila.
Hathaway and Sturgess lack the chemistry to make us yearn to see them together. They're all wrong for each other physically, tonally, logically, which only makes "One Day" feel a whole lot longer.
At least this new version stays true to its origins by having a bit of cheeky fun, and the way it contemporizes the story is really rather clever.
There's a gap of logic and emotion that's hard to overcome.
Rodriguez seems to be trying too hard to cram in too much - more gadgets, more characters, more noise, more color. But bigger, brighter and faster isn't necessarily better.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Buoyed by individual moments, and by some of the inspired casting that's revealed at each stop along the way.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Far too often, African Cats feels episodic in its structure. Rather than featuring a driving, compelling narrative, it's: cheetah vs. gazelle. And then: hyena vs. cheetah. And then: lion vs. crocodile. Who will win???

Much of the material works because the bear has someone to bounce off of; Wahlberg does his best work in situations like this, where he's playing it totally straight in a setting that's totally silly.
It is essentially Revenge of the Nerds, with fur. And scales. And whatever gooey, gelatinous substance comprises the outer coating of various other oddball creatures in this crazy parallel world.
The sense of detachment that is a signature of Sofia Coppola's work -- the coolly distant, stylishly dreamlike way she regards her characters -- works to her detriment in  The Bling Ring.
Similar to Eddie Murphy's hard right turn from daring and profane comedy to family-friendly romps, Vaughn and Wilson have gone all soft and gooey here.

Co-directors Michael Palmieri and Donal Mosher try to encompass so many people and so many angles in such a short amount of time, they end up breezing through them and providing glimpses that feel rushed and unsatisfying.
Stays mean and maintains a bit of an edge even when it threatens to go all soft and gooey.
The unloaded gun is also unfortunately a rather apt metaphor for the movie itself. Kick-Ass 2 may look powerful, but doesn't have much real pop.
A muted but always engrossing tale of young, doomed love.
Despite the film's playfulness, it's still quite clear that we're in the hands of a master who takes the work seriously, if not the material or his characters.
The irony is that a man who treasured innovation and sleek, stylish design should be the subject of a film that's so bland and bloated.
"Short Term 12" comes from a place of delicate and truthful understatement, which allows the humanity and decency of its characters-and, yes, the lessons-to shine through naturally.
Scenes are dramatic without a hint of melodrama, so when a flash of intensity does occur, it does so out of nowhere and registers even more powerfully.
Drinking Buddies  is a crackling screwball comedy refracted through a low-key, mumblecore prism.
Getaway might have been enjoyable as a mindless bit of dumb, late-summer entertainment if it had been vaguely coherent.
The moral of the story appears to be: Don't invite a stripper to come live with you in your home. Suggestion noted.
This Is Us does what it needs to do for its target audience. But anyone looking for actual substance or insight will be disappointed and maybe even a little bored with its repetitive nature.
It feels overstuffed and overlong, getting bogged down as it does in the minutiae of certain segments of Salinger's life without conveying a big-picture sense of what his actual writing was like.
The World's End might be the best time you'll have at the movies all year. It is a complete blast: urgently paced, hilariously clever and blisteringly profane.
Adore is, as my late mother would say in describing Sidney Sheldon novels, good trash.
As both thrilling spectacle and escapist summer entertainment, World War Z is enormously effective, with Brad Pitt at the center hopscotching the globe in search of the origin of a zombie apocalypse.

French director Luc Jacquet and a team of incredibly brave (and heavily bundled) documentary filmmakers captured this complicated mating ritual with strikingly crisp photography that's both grand and intimate.
The approach is oddly riveting, though, because the tension builds slowly, and you know what's going to happen at the end of the day.
[Luhrmann's] "Great Gatsby" is all about the glitter but it has no soul - and the fact that he's directed it in 3-D only magnifies the feeling of artificiality.
Nothing really happens in ''Frances Ha'' and yet the film takes us on an emotional journey.

Even calling ''Stories We Tell'' a documentary seems rather limiting and not entirely accurate; it's also a deadpan comedy, a juicy melodrama and a gripping mystery, all cleverly blended together with great focus.
It dares to alienate the very audience that made ''The Hangover'' the highest-grossing R-rated comedy of all time because, well, it isn't exactly a comedy.
Just when it seems All About Steve couldn't grow any more insufferable, it turns strangely sentimental.
Such a sad irony that Dana Carvey, who's made his name bringing celebrities to life with uncanny impersonations, should make such a lifeless movie based on characters of his own creation.
Director Paul Feig, whose Bridesmaids upended notions of what a raunchy ensemble comedy could be, does it again here with another genre.
Every bit as unwatchable as the deafening negative chatter would suggest.
Consists of little more than tired racial jokes and fish-out-of-water gags.
The ending sneaks up on you with a surprising bit of emotional catharsis, thanks largely to a brave, complex performance from former child star Gaby Hoffmann.
Wiig finds herself sadly outmatched in this comedy crammed with wacky and tacky characters-types, all of them-in which she's stuck functioning as the uptight, frustrated straight woman in the middle.

Director James Mangold's film features some breathtakingly suspenseful action sequences, exquisite production and costume design and colorful characters, some of whom register more powerfully than others.
Paxton steals the show. And O'Leary more than holds his own again here. Too bad it's in a movie that fails to live up to its potential.
Working from Philip Gelatt's script, Cordero keeps things consistent, elegant and streamlined. "Europa Report" actually may be understated to a fault, but that's preferable to gratuitous melodrama.
For its stunning visuals and standout performances, Minority Report -- or at least the first three-fourths of it -- might just be the best movie so far this year.
It's exactly what it looks like from the commercials -- a one-joke movie, and that one joke isn't even funny to begin with.
The film's stars ... are hugely charismatic individually and have chemistry with each other. But the soapy melodrama and ferocious, on-the-nose poems threaten to overpower their budding romance.
Roitfeld seems constantly inspired by the prospect of pushing boundaries and expectations, and that, in turn, is inspiring to watch.

French director and co-writer Gilles Legrand shows great mastery of tone and pacing in his third feature, which begins life as a domestic drama set at a family-owned vineyard and slowly morphs into a tense thriller.
You may as well check your cynicism at the door, because Curtis & Co. are going to find a way to trample all over it - adorably.
As with any kind of episodic or sketch comedy, some gags land more effectively than others, although you'll likely find a line or a beat or an image that makes you laugh from start to finish.
That's a lot of stuff going on at once, all of which feels rather familiar but none of which the film ever truly gets right.
Dern makes Woody as cantankerous as he is clueless, bobbing and weaving to avoid his inevitable mortality, but there's a purity about him that'll break your heart.
The schlubby, aw-shucks look on Vaughn's face in the omnipresent Delivery Man ads tells you everything you need to know about the ooey-gooey direction in which the film is headed.
Goblet of Fire is more effective in these smaller, more intimate moments than in the bloated bombast of its larger set pieces.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Director Francis Lawrence's film runs nearly two-and-a-half hours but it concludes so abruptly and tantalizingly, it leaves you wanting more.
The famously left-leaning Costa-Gavras is preaching to the choir in his indignation, but he does so in slick, brisk fashion.
After a 90-minute onslaught of in-jokes, here's the real punch line: Shrek strives to have a heart. Supposedly there's a message about beauty coming from within, but somehow it rings hollow.
While the journey may seem overly familiar, the destination has some surprises in store.
Sure, Elf feels a little too feel-good at the end, but what do you expect? It's a Christmas movie! Anything else would be the cinematic equivalent of finding coal in your stocking.
Yes, it's all as clunky and tasteless as the description suggests, and the awkward casting doesn't improve this overlong drama.
A down-and-dirty revenge picture whose classy cast elevates it above its gritty, grimy trappings.
Ridiculously entertaining in all the best ways.
It represents a return to the kind of writing and filmmaking with which Neil LaBute made his name.
What ideally might have been playful and knowing is instead uptight and dreary, with a visual scheme that's so fake and cartoony, it depletes the film of any sense of danger.
A rare example of a sequel that's better than the original.
Everything about "Free Birds" feels perfunctory, from its generic title and holiday setting to its starry voice cast and undistinguished use of 3-D.
