It is a timeless thing for all of us, the ritual of high-school expectation and heartache. Once again, as it did nearly 40 years ago, Carrie turns it into an experience of biblical proportions.
A sort of Muppet Babies version of the Beat poets ...
It feels so inauthentic at every turn, it's as if the film itself is unsure of what it's supposed to be.
Blue Caprice takes a true story of violence and panic and tells it in the most artful, understated manner imaginable - which makes its events even more powerful.
An odd mix of beautifully bleak atmosphere and hammily mannered performances, "A Single Shot" is simultaneously understated and overpowering.
"After Tiller" takes the politically divisive, emotionally charged issue of late-term abortions and portrays it with grace, understatement and humanity.
It's got lofty aspirations but it also wants to wallow in the muck - to thrill you and sicken you in equal measure while also being About Something.
"Baggage Claim" is so archaic in its depiction of feminine self-worth-and, frankly, so insulting-it's amazing that it's coming out in 2013, not 1963.

Yoo finds room for all of the obligatory bad first dates and fantasy sequences, montages and misunderstandings, a wisecracking best friend and overbearing parents. It doesn't appear that she means any of this ironically, or as parody.
It might have functioned even better as an hour-long TV documentary. But with such great music coming, one hit after after another, it's always a joy to watch.
Joseph Gordon-Levitt turns the gym-tan-laundry routine into an art form with Don Jon, his vibrant and viciously profane directorial debut.
Pacing can be painfully languid, to the point of being nap-inducing.
movie_title: Running Wild: The Life of Dayton O. Hyde (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Believe the hype: Gravity is as jaw-droppingly spectacular as you've heard - magnificent from a technical perspective but also a marvel of controlled acting and precise tone.
The pasty, scruffy Pegg shows a surprising amount of range for the unlikely hero of a zombie flick.
What also makes 28 Days Later effective, and sets it apart from other thrillers, is that it makes you care about the characters.
While some of the kills are sufficiently clever and gnarly, "Mandy Lane" is never particularly frightening. And the twist at the end raises the wee issue of character motivation-or lack thereof.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "CBGB" ain't no party, it ain't no disco, it ain't no foolin' around.
The entire performance is one of the greatest in Hanks' prolific, varied career - a role that gives him a massive arc and the opportunity to show great range.
"The Fifth Estate" feels unfortunately small and safe.
The less you know about this movie before seeing it -- and you really should see it -- the better.

Nolan takes an admirable stab at developing a character-driven drama, only to give in to generic action-movie conventions with a blinding, deafening, explosion-laden finale that could have capped off any number of interchangeable Jerry Bruckheimer flicks.
Even when the film threatens to turn feel-good, it thankfully resists the urge.
The artistry on display is indisputable, and thrilling.
"The Words" leaves nothing to the imagination, smothering all these storylines in narration that spells out the actions we're seeing or emotions we could infer for ourselves.
Both funnier and deeper than you might expect at the outset.
In his first film since the 2010 performance-art stunt of "I'm Still Here," Phoenix once again digs deep to mine his character's inner torment and comes up with a mix of haunting quirks and tics.
Gere is so charming, so irresistible when he's on top of the world - when he's got all those plates humming in unison - that he kind of makes you root for his character to get away with it all.
From the brutal daily violence to the dramatic final act, "End of Watch" itself remains thrilling and uncompromising.
A wickedly dark comic streak breaks up the vivid violence and relentless bleakness of "Dredd 3D."
"The Perks of Being a Wallflower," may not do anything groundbreaking, but it tells a familiar story in small, thoughtful ways.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Travis keeps things moving so briskly, you find yourself not minding how by-the-numbers the story is. And then within that by-the-numbers story, there end up being enough surprises and subversive twists that you find yourself unexpectedly charmed.
Johnson establishes the machinery of the time-travel concept, then steadily pushes it into the background in favor of exploring his characters and the difficult questions they face.
Revisiting the past - his own, and that of the masters who came before him - seems to have brought this filmmaker's boyish enthusiasm back to life, as well.
While steeped in the trends and filmmaking style of the decade, "Argo" still feels immediate and relevant. Affleck's best film yet is also one of the best films of the year.

The bottom isn't low enough, the struggle isn't difficult enough, and the characters (especially the supporting ones) don't feel developed enough to provide necessary context for our heroine's journey.

It has some difficult and heartfelt performances as well as moments of uncomfortable honesty, but ultimately writer-director Ben Lewin's film feels too slight, too pat, and too wildly overhyped out of its festival showings.
Artfully constructed but hollow at its core, "Nobody Walks" makes it impossible to stop watching while simultaneously making it impossible to care about what's happening.
A bloated, pseudo-intellectual, self-indulgent slog through some notions that are really rather facile.
For the most part, "Flight" manages to achieve the tricky balance of functioning as a serious, adult drama that's also crowd-pleasing.
It's ridiculous and predictable but also just a ton of fun, so you may as well give up and give in to your inner musical theater geek.
It's a frustrating movie in its inconsistency.
Hillcoat's ultra-violent drama plays like a hot, sweaty, delusional fever dream and is similarly fitful. It can be visceral and operatic, beautiful and brutal but also slow and overlong.
The film is gorgeous, dripping with texture and sensuality and, well, mood.
Garfield plays Peter as more of a misunderstood outsider, a rebel with a chip on his shoulder, a guy who wasn't afraid to stand up to the class bully even before he underwent his transformation.
If Over the Hedge aims solely to entertain, it does so in a way that's mildly amusing but mostly hackneyed. If it aims to instruct, it weakens its own argument with the plethora of product tie-ins.
"Savages" is an enjoyably gratuitous romp, but with something to say.

The web-slinging sequences are bigger-better-brighter-faster than the already spectacular ones in 2002's Spider-Man, and at the same time, the film's smaller emotional moments are denser, richer and more resonant than those in the first.
Director Bart Layton takes a story that was already fascinatingly weird to begin with and makes it even more compelling by structuring it as a shadowy film noir.
Red Lights culminates with a twist ending that doesn't just change everything that came previously, it actually negates the entirety of the film.
Polley (who's been an actress herself) never judges these people she's created. Instead, she depicts the giddy, fleeting and illusory nature of new love, and lets us get caught up in it, too.
If Kill Bill - Vol. 1 was like a roundhouse kick to the head, Vol. 2 is practically a warm hug.
This is the problem when you're an exceptional, visionary filmmaker. When you give people something extraordinary, they expect it every time. Anything short of that feels like a letdown.
Maybe it'll give you something to think about as you Facebook stalk that cute girl you just met for coffee.
Like a deep-fried Twinkie at the State Fair of Texas, ''Killer Joe'' is gooey, flavorful and bad for you. Dig in.
"Celeste and Jesse Forever" is by no means a parody of romantic comedy cliches, but rather an acknowledgement of them en route to an exploration of greater emotional truths.
Farrell is confident and competent regardless of the situation; there never seems to be any real threat of him coming out alive.
It will make you want to go home and have sex with your spouse afterward. Or at least share a longer hug or a more passionate kiss.

It's a lovely, beguiling little film a rare treat during this overheated season of blockbusters. It's also an unusual example of a follow-up that doesn't seem forced, but expands effortlessly on the original.
Structurally, yes, it's loaded with all the lies, schemes and high-tech trickery that are staples of the espionage genre. But a deeper, more individualistic source of tension propels the film along.
These are not horrible people, just ones who flung themselves enthusiastically toward the American dream as so many do.
Simultaneously thrilling and meaty, this is easily one of the best entries ever in the 50-year, 23-film series, led once again by an actor who's the best Bond yet in Daniel Craig.
[Tatum is] just mesmerizing: confident, creative, acrobatic and, above all, seductive. `Cause that's the whole point.
Wondrous as all this artifice is, it's also a huge distraction. The self-consciousness of the structure keeps us at arm's length emotionally.
A strong cast of likable and, yes, beautiful actors can only do so much with the formula in which they're forced to work.
A Good Day to Die Hard is pointless and joyless, a barrage of noise and chaos, an onslaught of destruction without the slightest mention of consequence.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Haggis moves seamlessly between all these stories and has structured them in such a way that his characters reach a crisis point simultaneously, followed by melancholy clarity.

''The Place Beyond the Pines'' aims admirably for an epic sense of Greek tragedy, and it does have some powerful individual moments, but the characters are all so underdeveloped that the whole effort feels like studied posturing.
Boyle takes his wildly high-energy visual aesthetic and applies it to a story that, at its core, is rather sweet and traditionally crowdpleasing.
A mostly gentle and tastefully photographed depiction of a young boy's coming of age in rural 1940s New Mexico.
''Jack the Giant Slayer'' ends up being smart, thrilling and a whole lot of fun.
''Identity Thief'' strands these two ordinarily enjoyable comics in the middle of nowhere with no help for miles.
While comparisons to ''The Hangover'' are inevitable, ''21 & Over'' is actually reminiscent of a different and specific kind of movie: the early Vince Vaughn-Jon Favreau romp.
After it's over, poof! You'll forget you ever watched it in the first place.
We're all screwed, Korine seems to be saying. It's very sad - but also kinda sexy.
This is a movie that's easier to admire than love; it's impressive but not exactly moving.
"The Croods" is both brisk and beautiful, and should be sufficiently entertaining for family audiences for whom few such options exist these days.
What should be a hilarious, long-overdue pairing of two hugely likable, superstar comedians ends up being a major disappointment with "Admission."
To tell you what happens to him from here would be a tremendous disservice. We'll just say that, refreshingly, nothing about it is sickly sweet.
That's not to say that this G.I. Joe is good, aside from a couple of dazzling action set pieces, but at least it's efficient in its muscular mindlessness.

Oz the Great and Powerful aims for nostalgia in older viewers who grew up on The Wizard of Oz and still hold the classic dear while simultaneously enchanting a newer, younger audience. It never really accomplishes either successfully.
There's enough humor and tenderness in Fisher Stevens' film to make it a passably enjoyable experience for the most part.
The complexity of emotion, confusion and loss at the film's start gives way to some acrobatic trickery by the end, but "Side Effects" is never less than gripping or entertaining.
It will surely strike a chord with anyone who's watched a loved one slip away in this manner, whether it's a parent or a spouse.
David O. Russell has pulled off a tricky feat here, finding just the right tone in crafting a romantic comedy whose sweethearts suffer from bipolar disorder and depression.
These are people who never would have connected under ordinary circumstances; they end up needing each other desperately. Only in the movies.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Even as "The Central Park Five" seeks satisfactory answers, it stirs outrage and discouragement all over again.
An incredibly stylish genre exercise set in the world of mobsters, junkies and lowlifes, but it's also trying incredibly hard to be About Something.

It is truly baffling that all the talented, acclaimed actors involved actually read this script and then agreed to devote their time to this movie, especially given its uncomfortably flagrant misogynistic streak.
It is enormous and sprawling and not the slightest bit subtle. But at the same time it's hard not to admire the ambition that drives such an approach ...
Statham is stepping into a well-known persona. But he's not exactly pushing himself outside his comfort zone; he's on auto-pilot here, despite the obvious physical demands of the part.
Finally -- finally! -- the Twilight franchise embraces its own innate absurdity with the gleefully over-the-top conclusion, The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Besides being a mind teaser, "Jack Reacher" offers the muscular thrills of a `70s action flick ...
It's the feel-bad comedy of the holiday season - and that's what makes it good.
"Promised Land" offers an experience that's alternately amusing and frustrating, full of impassioned earnestness as well as saggy sections.
Beasts of the Southern Wild is sheer poetry on screen: an explosion of joy in the midst of startling squalor and one of the most visceral, original films to come along in a while.
Bigelow's extensive staging of the May 1, 2011, raid is a prime example of virtuoso action filmmaking.
It's all just noise disguised as entertainment.
Kim keeps things moving briskly and the members of the strong supporting cast don't seem to mind that they're playing flimsy types. Everyone's just here for a mindless good time.
Everything is simultaneously too complicated and overly spelled out.
''The Impossible'' is about as subtle as a wall of water.
Isn't it encouraging to see that a big summer flick can be tethered to something other than a sweaty male action hero?
That it works is testament to an astounding, Emmy-worthy performance by Moore, who plays Palin with nuance, and without a trace of parody.
A mostly lightweight endeavor that never builds any genuine emotional traction. And you have to wonder if it's just a little too 'inside' to resonate with a sizable audience.

Odds are you won't be able to take your eyes off director Steven Soderbergh's luridly entertaining peek into the relationship between legendary pianist Liberace and his much younger lover, Scott Thorson.
An ambitious, exuberant and eye-boggling adaptation of Grease.
Bell, as charming and witty as ever, smoothly steps back into the role she was made to play.

As Confirmation winds down, the frustrated Hill camp is a picture of weary resignation, looking as if their efforts were all for naught. But somewhere out there, an angry feminist storm was gathering, and you can feel the changes coming in Confirmation.
Pacino and Mirren make for a dynamic pair.
Asghar Farhadi navigates his complicated narrative thicket with an apparent ease, but he isn't able to blend the brushstrokes as he has in prior films.
Frontloaded with a surprising amount of plot, the film takes forever to get going, but it's the filmmakers' hypocrisy that really grates.
Several reels' worth of ugly, unshaped footage that wouldn't have been deemed fit for a movie's end-credit outtakes not so long ago.
You may feel as if you're watching two or three abbreviated episodes of Law & Order in quick succession rather than a fully realized movie.
Throughout, Joe Swanberg connects Generation Y's fetish for past pop-cultural kitsch to its attending sexual insecurities.
An almost offensively "tasteful" dud that remains irritatingly on the surface, more alive to the set design than the characters' motivations.
By the end, audiences will most likely feel as if they've been locked out of the drama that's presumably unfolding right in front of them.
The film is a quiet, tender triumph that leaves you feeling as if you've been embraced without you feeling had.
There's ultimately little in the way of authentically resonant drama underneath the film's self-conscious busy-ness.
Felony reveals itself to be a profoundly cynical movie posing as a work of idealism.
Based on the evidence offered here, West would appear to believe that all cultists come to their way of life by an inherent lunacy or stupidity and nothing more.
It's one of a kind.
The premise might make sense, if only hypocritically, but the film abandons this already flimsy parody of macho pride disastrously at the last minute.
To watch teh film is to wonder once again why Neil LaBute was ever taken seriously as a so-called dramatist of the gulf between the sexes.
It derives its tension from its almost pointed meaninglessness, which would appear to be a subterfuge for a personal expression that's never quite achieved.
Eliza Hittman's film captures the exclusive properties of sex with a degree of intimacy and empathy that, at times, feels authentically revelatory.
The problem with the film isn't the contrivance of its premise, it's that writer-director Jessica Goldberg doesn't know it's contrived.
It compellingly captures a family wrestling mightily with the riddles and contradictions of a culture that promotes achievement at all costs with little thought as to what that actually means.
Marc Bauder's documentary quietly detonates the conservative notion that our largest corporations should be allowed to duke it out in metaphorical no-holds-barred cage matches.
Greatly cognizant of the revenge genre's penchant for hypocritical demagoguery, director Arnaud des Pallières unsettles the audience's usual feelings of vicarious blood lust.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The film ultimately leaves you feeling as if you're stuck watching your cousin's boring slideshow of his trip to Palookaville.
We're simply presented a person in trouble, and we're allowed to recognize his problems as extreme embodiments of universal issues of terror, confusion, and loneliness.
movie_title: Stand Clear Of The Closing Doors (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With The Sacrament, director Ti West has bitten off more of a premise than his classically modest barebones approach to horror movies can presently chew.
A sexily chaotic parody of entitlement becomes just another tale of a white dude learning that there are worse things in life than essentially having no problems.
There are cheap shocks in the film, but there are also terrifying moments that poetically command our empathy.
Like a number of cult directors to emerge in the 1970s, Henry Jaglom values a party atmosphere at the expense of narrative cohesion.
A potential barroom joke blossoms into a surprisingly poignant portrait of three aging men wrestling with how to shed their mortal coil.
It transforms itself from a meek lo-fi indie stalker thriller in the key of May to a hysterically sexist and homophobic revenge film.
It ultimately offers little more than another opportunity for famous actors to indulge their fetishistic, inadvertently condescending impressions of "everyday" people.
The art is the reason to see the enjoyable but egregiously slight Remembering the Artist: Robert De Niro, Sr.
movie_title: Remembering The Artist Robert De Niro, Sr. (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The sex in Nymphomaniac is inhuman, mechanical, boring, and predictably viewed through the (male) scrim of someone who characterizes women solely as withholders.
Atom Egoyan is a much better director when he drops the art-film fanciness and wrestles directly with his inner voyeuristic weirdo.
The film's method of admitting its own hypocrisy so as to enable it to further indulge said hypocrisy grows more grating than if it were merely indifferently conceived junk like Falling Down.
The film is a singularly huge, relentless, all-encompassing set piece that mutates and spasms with terrifying lack of foresight. It's all business, business, business.
Paolo Sorrentino's film is really just a huge turn-on that has the bad manners to go sour, succumbing to its own self-delusions of moral/political grandeur.
It's the rare coming-of-age narrative that manages to respect the tricky ambiguities of shifting perceptions.
Wayne Kramer thankfully refuses to cloak his excessiveness in hedge-betting self-consciousness and the result is a gratifyingly disreputable B-movie blow out.
The film is in part an exceedingly black comedy that parodies proper society's eager, self-righteous naïveté on the subject of its children.
The tension almost immediately leaks out of the narrative once we realize we're watching a found-footage horror movie.
One sees a film called 100 Bloody Acres expecting the requisite allusions to The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, but an homage to the best scene in Melvin and Howard comes as something of a shock.
It takes cojones for a filmmaker to chase Fassbinder's ghost, but it takes heart and talent to damn near catch up with it.
After a while, it's hard to escape the fact that the audience is watching a potential monster movie in which most of the fun stuff--i.e. the monster--has been pared away.
Yet another ghost story that insists there's nothing more chilling than a professional woman charged with raising a child on her own.

On the surface an amusing black comedy that parodies the horror movie's continual status as the cultural black sheep of the cinematic landscape, but it's most prominently concerned with painting a sonic portrait of alienation.
Sadly, Douglas Tirola's documentary doesn't follow its subjects' advice regarding the refinement of technique.
A trim and exciting beach-read of a movie.
Álex de la Iglesia has a real flair for wild action sequences that remain exhilaratingly coherent and sensical.
The film's most striking quality, and it's not insignificant, is director Margarethe von Trotta's refusal to fossilize the controversies she dramatizes.
The film is an ultra-violent parody of unearned self-entitlement, of people who feel tricked into a lifestyle they refuse to challenge for the comforts it still offers.
As one incoherent action scene follows another, one's left staring at a film with nothing to respond to, waiting for it all to be over.
Paul Schrader and Brett Easton Ellis don't have the sense of play this kind of narrative of one-upmanship requires, as we're never allowed to enjoy the characters' misdeeds.
The film, more likely to invite comparisons to the writings of Marcel Proust than the previous Ip Man films, is a gorgeous folly that never entirely emerges from its creator's head.
Taste and good intentions are only going to get one so far with a script this tone deaf and direction this ugly and monotonous.
The film is unavoidably slight, but there's a certain pleasure in watching talented people wax passionate about a common source of inspiration.
There are a few effectively disquieting sequences early on, but the film never recovers from director Kevin Macdonald's indifferent staging of a pivotal moment.
The only truly graspable notion the film can be said to put forth is one of increasingly tedious sci-fi-romantic genre busy-ness.
The film ultimately doesn't live up to this early potential, as Keanu Reeves loses his way in the third act with too many false climaxes.
Toback's frequent gasbaggery is often forgivable. Underneath his party-boy hubris beats the heart of an occasionally major artist.
Director Jason banker finds the ironic beauty that arises from his characters' self-contemptuous and misplaced acts of destruction.

Vincenzo Natali emphasizes technically impressive shots in the service of predictable, boring expository beats, at the expense of elaborating on his main character's growing feelings of isolation and torment.
The film is just a stunt or, more specifically, a calling card, but that might be enough for anyone who's ever wanted to kick Mickey Mouse square in his padded, pious balls.
There's possibly no other living director as in sync with the politics of touch as Claire Denis.
It's fair to say that a filmmaker is thinking outside of the box when he or she stages a scene in which an ambulatory hemorrhoid tears a guy's cock off with its teeth and swallows it.
The film is dispiriting because there's virtually no sign of Dario Argento in it, nor of any novel motivation to mount yet another version of an oft-told tale.
Jim Mickle plays the scenario deadly straight and unintentionally exposes all of its attendant absurdities, leaving the cast stranded.

It ambitiously parodies and mourns the implications of the one coherent message that mass media manages to convey to all of its consumers in all its endlessly proliferating, ever-shifting permutations.
The filmmakers satirize the often obscenely meaningless ways in which people of a certain socioeconomic strata attempt to launder their white guilt.
A rich and heady cocktail of the various things swimming around in Jean-Luc Godard's mind at the time of its production.
A confident and exciting genre film, and that's certainly not nothing, but it has a slight impersonality that marks it as either a calling card or a work for hire.
There's considerable talent on display in Exhibition, but it's the kind of thing people mean when they use the term "art film" as a pejorative.
Any pretense of satire collapses by the film's midpoint, leaving only the contempt.
There's a sense throughout of Steve James rushing and dutifully covering all his bases to evade accusations of creating a puff piece.
The source material, which is convoluted even by Shakespeare's narratively dexterous standards, is admittedly a tough nut for a filmmaker to crack.
The film ultimately understands poverty as a profound and often irreversible desolation of terra firma.
Yet another boring ode to heavy breathing that's offered under the hypocritical pretense of celebrating female empowerment.
Cannily approximates a channel-surfing quality with its propulsive alternation of clips and interviews.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The images gorgeously embody both the fear and the beauty of James's exploratory experiments with socialization.

Each of the six vignettes that make up this unusually energetic anthology pertains to the methods of calculated mass dehumanization that are (barely) hidden beneath the practices of social institutions.
Thomas McCarthy evinces no interest in the people who come into Max's store and wind up as fodder for his increasingly violent and self-absorbed escapades. Not a shred.
The film's skillfulness renders its eventual slide into the routine all the more irritating.
For most of the film's running time, one mistakes the main character's callousness for the filmmakers'.
Jody Lee Lipes shapes the footage into an intimate symphony of poetically shaped bodies that contrast poignantly with uncertain faces.

Peter Strickland charges full-tilt into the objectifying whims of his fantasies in order to somehow reach the other end of perception, which acknowledges the ultimate empathetic limitations of said fantasies.
It's a comedy concerned with myopia that doesn't succumb to the self-obsessed pitfalls of that subject.
The film effectively underlines the one undertaking that time-travel fantasies can never truly allow: escape from ourselves.
The actors play off one another beautifully, but the film bottoms out just as it's getting warmed up.
A dizzying hall-of-mirrors stunt, a horror remake as autobiographical X-ray, and a work of fantasy that serves as a decadently cleansing creative exorcism.
Andrey Zvyagintsev never loses sight of the humans, who're allowed to display improvisatory behavior that deepens the majesty of the rigorously orchestrated tableaus.
So flimsily constructed that it resembles a middle-school play that's been hastily filmed on an antique camcorder.
After a surprising development, the film grows slack and sentimental, reverting to the survival-movie platitude about hardship making you a better human.
Like other Andrew Niccol films, Good Kill is about an essential innocent who dreams of release from a highly structured, classist, and hypocritical environment.
Pauline Chan's film is a jumbled mixture of redemptive uplift and genre hijinks.
The film often suggests a less defiant cover of The Defiant Ones, yet it's a must-see for Viggo Mortensen's characteristically wonderful performance.
A sluggish, obvious fusion of a disease-of-the-week tearjerker with a comedic family crime romp that abounds in stiflingly over-emphasized Boston-crime-movie details.
Chris Messina is eventually a little too indifferent to the machinations of the plot, but the film, however inescapably sentimental, is a romantic daydream that casts a lovely spell.
Director John McNaughton, once an agile orchestrator of seemingly incompatible tones, has retained his talent for teasing insinuation.
It bridges the cautionary elements of a horror film with the wish-fulfilling platitudes of a touristy romance.
The film is so unusually moving and penetrating because it refuses to cloud its emotions in distancing irony, anger, or nihilism.
A fawning tribute to the cult legend, enriched by a subtle current of sadness that prevents the documentary from turning into a glorified DVD supplement.
Another macho celebration of fighting for "freedom" because someone else told you to, devoid of any acknowledgement of the inherent irony of that ideology.
It evolves into an intimate reverie on family and aesthetics, while remaining sporadically attuned to the reflexive and ethical dimensions of ethnographic discovery.
The film's peculiarly exhilarating effect can be attributed to a sense of social outrage that's transcended for the sake of metaphoric social clarity.
The film can't reconcile Ron Rash's apocalyptic tenderness with its own eagerness to revel in romantic star allure.
The politics of the boat as it reaches calamity are mostly reduced to a singular urge to kill one character.
Asghar Farhadi's sensibility embodies a combination of empathy and paranoia that's striking considering that the latter is normally driven by self-absorption.
The film has the plot of an intensely lurid thriller, but Atom Egoyan can't bring himself to face that and actively tend to the story; instead, he trades in barely coherent, high-brow euphemisms.
Director Chuck Workman's simply compiles Welles's greatest moments, offering little in the way of an authorial point of view.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Clint Eastwood startlingly grips the audience with his sense of hypnotic silence, which carries suggestions of what might be termed politically apolitical pragmatism.

Alain Resnais's overpoweringly beautiful final film dares to push through the ghosts that inhabit the present, standing between the pessimism of an ill-spent past and the optimism of an undefined future.

The film's so preoccupied with being "inspirational" that it disastrously fails to evoke the allure of rock n' roll, particularly in America in the 1950s, when it represented an erosion of racial and sexual barriers.
As executed by writer-director Ari Folman, the concept is tidy, superficially clever, and almost defiantly irrelevant.
Lost in this barely coherent and clichéd hugger-mugger is the initial killer-website conceit and the attending erotic dread, which is retrospectively revealed to be an illusory siren call.
Michael Winterbottom and his gifted actors still haven't quite solved the riddle of portraying social disconnection in a manner that's anything other than sporadically involving.
Leo Carax's first film seizes on a particular element of intellectualized youthful ennui with uncommon clarity and ferocity.
The film abounds in guilt and grief, reveling in a general sense of hopelessly broken social connection.
It's informed with a subtle but disquieting subtext that insists on the pitfalls of allowing ideology to steer you away from common sense.
This is less a movie than a dutiful renewal of a recognizable title's licensing rights.
Jonathan Demme makes loving sport of the trust his actors have clearly placed in him, erecting for them a monument to the joys and terrors of walking an emotional high wire.
The film is impersonal and populated with wisps of characters who spend most of the running time wandering around in the dark yelling at one another.
The director diligently keeps her heroine's ego in check, and that's awfully principled of her, but her audience may feel as if they've inadvertently booked a trip with no destination.
Aarón Fernández captures one of the most heartening elements of sex: that it doesn't always oblige our rules or expectations.
An inept trifle, A Long Way Down reduces Nick Hornby's novel of the same name to a series of smug self-help gestures.
Joe Swanberg's films have grown into a reliable relief from the competitive, dehumanizing freneticism of much of American culture, marked as they are by an affirming and understated sense of decency.
It waffles between dramatizing youthful self-absorption and succumbing to it, and this tonal instability comes to mirror the domestic discord that's revealed to be its real subject.
Terry Gilliam has imposed a mix tape of his greatest hits, whose greatness was debatable to begin with, on a whiff of a story that might've flourished under the maxim "less is more."
Wiktor Ericsson emphasizes one of the strongest and most distinctive features of Joseph Sarno's aesthetic: his concentration on female pleasure.
Paul Schrader's personality reveals itself in the film's joylessness, which is meaningless without the director's accompanying and occasionally poignant existentialism.
Benicio Del Toro's performance is showy, a great actor's parade of indulgences that occasionally sets the deranged camp tone that should have been the narrative's starting point.
The film soon settles into a confident, well-staged groove, primarily because of two unambiguously terrific performances.
A confident work that smashingly updates the Southern gothic for contemporary generations.
A reminder that crime movies pointedly inspired by other, better genre films can still be enjoyable, if they wear their influences lightly and cleverly connect them to something tangibly human.
Timidity and perhaps fear, of visual confinement, of lingering emotional engagement, closes Nacho Vigalondo's most promising windows.
The film is ultimately, and disappointingly, revealed to be a contraption that's less concerned with mental portraiture than with getting all of its expository ducks in a row.
Gregg Araki's film suggests a hothouse melodrama that's been drained of the hothouse, the melodrama, and any other discernably dramatic stakes.
Like Better Luck Tomorrow, it tries to cut cool-movie poses under the pretense of providing an alternative racial viewpoint to typical genre tropes.
This is, to put it mildly, a lot of information for one documentary, which inevitably devolves to resemble not so much an anthology as a slideshow of genocide's greatest hits.
You grow to feel as if you're arbitrarily changing the channel back and forth from a diverting horror film to a promising odd-couple comedy.
It reveals itself to be a profoundly cynical movie posing as a work of idealism, and it's all the more insidious because it's otherwise so bland and forgettable.
Drive Hard is the action-film equivalent of one of those folks who relentlessly speak of having it tough all over as they plan their third yearly vacation.
The 50 Year Argument is a fawning testimonial to the legacy of a cultural giant.
movie_title: The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Lilting doesn't have any momentum or any sense of ambiguity, once the setup has been established.
The film preaches resolutely to the choir, and cinephiles in sync with the film's politics may still blanch at how snugly their interests are courted.
A middling genre movie, but it's oddly likable for its conflicted, unresolved tension.
So poorly acted and ineptly written and directed that it wouldn't pass muster as the pilot for a particularly asinine soap on the WB station.

Writer-director Ron Morales conjures an atmosphere of unpredictable live-wire dread throughout, which is an impressive accomplishment in these media-savvy days in which everyone has seemingly seen everything.
Peter Stormare is a limited actor who only manages to exude the resolute nothingness of the role.
Raw Faith is as pared as Sewell's sermons, as there doesn't seem to be a misplaced or gratuitous moment in the entire film.
Road to Nowhere is one of those films with several stories-within-stories that could all be true, or false, or some previously unconsidered combination of the two.
Mr. Nice lacks the unifying thematic rage, or drive, that might have tied the good moments into a coherent, satisfying whole.
Hello Lonesome isn't really that much of a movie, but it has something that a number of more polished pictures in the same vein don't: human decency. Sadly, that's noteworthy.
Hey, Boo is so appealing because it's obviously and undeniably a work of commitment and passion.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film lingers on prolonged moments of foreshadowing that offer little apart from the studied weirdness with which many low-budget wannabe oddities traffic.
An enormously overheated yet oddly affecting movie gets an appropriately earnest DVD treatment.
Arbeláe doesn't let anger cloud his humanity though, and he never sacrifices the ambiguity of his images to score points.
We Go Way Back is another tale of a twentysomething struggling to get a grip on their life.
Earthwork turns a potentially fascinating, infuriating story of failure into a dull, naïve civics lesson.
Dumbstruck actually pays more convincing tribute to those willing to honor their interior calling regardless of the hardship.
The film isn't very good for reasons common to a low-budget work early in a director's career.
The Family Jams is an edited home video, not a movie, and it's an especially annoying home video with delusions of artistic grandeur.
Under the Boardwalk is affectionate and inoffensive, but unavoidably disposable.
movie_title: Under The Boardwalk: The Monopoly Story (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Circo has the succinct haunting contradiction of a good Steinbeck story, perhaps something out of Tortilla Flat.
Lucky, unfortunately, is terrible: overbearing, obnoxious, and boring.
A wonderful, must-own transfer by the Criterion Collection of one of last year's best films.
No moment in the film seems to directly connect to another; they stand apart as isolated little atoms of numbing inanity.
My Reincarnation, at its simplest, is another illustration of the idea that people of most walks of life have essentially the same problems.
This is still the kind of film that's probably most necessary if movies hope to play any kind of part in our cultural rehab.
The ironies of the white man having to face potential extinction in a country infamous for racially tinged violence is too neat.

The Nine Muses could've been a bravura and rigorous display of erudition and editorial showmanship that's all structure and portent, but this film, which Akomfrah has said he's wanted to make for 20 years, has an obsessive power.
Journey from Zanskar maintains a level-headed matter-of-fact tone that humanizes the Zanskaris without stooping to crass exploitation.
Filmmaker Susan Streitfeld takes all of the mysticism at face value, shutting the audience out of pleasures that are discussed but rarely shown.
The film quickly becomes redundant, and there's a self-congratulatory smugness to it that's off-putting.
I can say with only a little irony that Triple H acts Parker Posey off the screen.
Watching people land on the moon isn't all that interesting or photogenic, especially when we know it's pretend.
The Burnett clan manages to encompass virtually every cliché of any dramedy made in the last decade that has garnered or hoped to garner Oscar buzz.
Born and Bred bungles a promising subject with an overreliance on suspiciously on-the-nose, thesis-spouting talking heads.
For about 20 minutes, Bad Posture is agonizing in all the ways we've come to dread from a low-budget film about troubled, rootless misfits.
A competent barebones transfer of a horror film that deserves to win a wider audience among the Netflix crowd.
Sloppiness doesn't suit Granito, which should be concise, complicated, and elegant.
Laredoans Speak is bad in a special kind of way that inspires the obviously piteous description of "well-intentioned."
movie_title: Laredoans Speak: Voices of a South Texas Border City (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You want to tell the filmmakers to get on with it, and to more eloquently detail the rest of Tracy and Larry's story beyond their occupation.
The film is so laughably Freudian it could play as a parody of certain acclaimed horror film studies such as Men, Women and Chainsaws: Gender in the Horror Film.
It's about equal parts brilliant, baffling, ridiculous, and unwatchable.
The Nature of Existence was bound to fall short of its deliberately and ridiculously broad title anyway, but one still wishes for more.
Burzynski is the kind of should've-been-important picture that you damn with the faintest praise: It means well.
As it stands, the film is a notable misfire.
The Lightkeepers is bafflingly lame in execution: A number of cuts don't match, and the entire film has a herky-jerky stop-and-start lack of momentum.
Ocean of Pearls is, underneath the gross sentimentality, racist and shameless, and it might be dangerous if it weren't so forgettable and on-the-nose.
Make-Out with Violence is a horror movie given the generic low-budget art-movie treatment.
A teensy, unoriginal young love triangle with a hint of subversion.
Stop Making Sense is a concert film with a narrative, bursting at the seams with bits of invention and passion.
A big, galloping party movie in which the party in question is a clear metaphor for the world.
The passages in the mysterious factory, which should be Charlie's and our release from the oppression of the earlier scenes, are just as ugly as everything that's come before, so there's no contrast.
movie_title: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory (1971)

movie_review_blurb: Another serial killer movie...and this one's so bad it reaffirms how often we take even mediocre pictures for granted.
Gigante isn't a great movie, but it's likeably humble and scruffy around the edges.
Albert Maysles's portrait of Iris Apfel gradually emerges with cathartic clarity without compromising her inherent mystery.
Garbage Dreams's images have the unsettling primal power of a dystopian sci-fi movie come to life.
Conor Horgan has a nice eye and ear for disturbingly intimate little incidents that tell us more than any series of expository speeches could ever hope to.
Sequestro is terrifying and clear-headed.
S&Man is interested in the horror film in general as a perverse bridge between the genders.
A Good Man has devastating moments, but its good intentions ultimately shortchange Chris and Rachel, diminishing, not to mention patronizing, them.
Immigration Tango is the kind of surreally terrible comedy you'd come across on HBO at three in the morning...in the 1980s.
American Grindhouse seems to miss the irony of what the recent proliferation of faux-exploitation films actually partially represents.
Satan Hates You is self-conscious trash with occasional bite.
An okay presentation of an okay picture featuring a characteristically appealing Jeff Bridges performance.

There's a larger issue nagging many of these no-budget films about struggling young adults: They assume that all aspiring, rootless artistes are incapable of even rudimentary thought when the opposite is normally the case.
The awkward title pretty much covers it.
movie_title: El Superstar: The Unlikely Rise of Juan Frances (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Grapes of Wrath is flawed, but it captures that shiver of panic that grips anyone for whom the money for the next meal is unknown.
Eichmann could be just another bland program you flip through on the way to the History Channel as you crack open your third beer.
Punching the Clown can be too cute, but it's a quietly sad portrait of just barely getting by.
Bitter Feast could have packed a satirical punch.
The company behind The Two Escobars is ESPN Films, and the influence, coincidentally or not, is tangible.
Budrus is passionately, more-than-competently made, but it's a civics lesson that doesn't quite shake you to your core.
These pictures explore the limitations and constrictions of a mass culture, no matter what the nature of said culture may be.
It can be exhilarating to watch as clearly intelligent/talented people hold forth on the true objects of their obsessions.
The Story of Lovers Rock, an unapologetically single-minded appeal for the legacy of this music, is amateurish but appealingly shaggy.
Director Mahmoud Kaabour is Fatima's grandson, and she instantly seizes on--lightly, in her way--the guilt and panic that's inspired him to make this film.
Seducing Charlie Barker is a big so-what, but you leave wanting more Heather Gordon, who might be something in a more original movie.
Lawless is a compellingly nutty and uneven gangster film.
The romantic quest that's meant to drive the film is meaningless because Alexander Poe has extended empathy to no one besides himself
Shundell Prasad's self-consciousness also has an ugly side that's unusually insidious for films this preachy and relentlessly dull.
Scott Thurman captures not only the fear and anti-intellectual resentment and insecurity that govern the dictations of the far right, but also the rampant unchecked egotism.
Sadly continues the series' downslide, most drearily with a mid-film twist that enables the filmmakers to go about essentially remaking the second entry.
It's less a film than an unimaginatively assembled series of talking heads.
The film is ultimately more concerned with Caveh Zahedi's attempts to pursue a variety of dull passing fancies than with any larger agenda.
As a portrait of a self-pitying drunk's wet dream of inexplicable atonement, it's fairly effective, but as a story meant to take place on some rational version of planet Earth, it's utterly hopeless.
One can't help but sense that underneath the complicated art-house game-playing of Isaki Lacuesta's The Double Steps resides a theme that's sentimental and old-hat.
Pang Ho-cheung can't help but humanize Vulgaria's characters, which is a kiss of death for what's meant to be a farce of escalating obscenity.
Made with considerable reverence, but it doesn't quite manage to tow a tricky tonal line that's required when working with such sensitive and complicated material.
As a sampler course of what it means to court the Michelin honor, Three Stars is enjoyable, but it's simply a collision of details that never entirely converge into a meaningful whole.
movie_title: Drei Sterne - Die Köche und die Sterne (Three Stars) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Paul Lacoste's almost purely observational approach allows him to come about as close to documenting the process of creation as anyone ever has.
After a promising entrapment scene that offers some casually eerie narrative details, the film collapses, lurching awkwardly between a variety of tones and intentions.
The film never really goes soft, as Jordan Roberts never loses sight of the fact that these toxic nincompoops are authentically bad for one another.
It's a prevailing sense of decency that explains why The Bullet Vanishes is such an effective tonic for summer-movie fatigue.
Director Laura Archibald's approach is fatally safe, often turning poets into self-congratulatory windbags.
movie_title: Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Christopher Felver is too reverent to properly convey the invigoratingly profane, angry messiness of the sense of community that Lawrence Ferlinghetti and his peers too briefly brought to life.
It lacks the fire and eccentricity that we want from our stories of adventurers driven by obsessions that could be seen as egotistical or just plain bonkers.
It lacks the fire and eccentricity that we want from our stories of adventurers driven by obsessions that could be seen as egotistical or just plain bonkers.
Writer-director Andy Gillies's film is extremely self-conscious, but in a fashion that generally serves the material.
A one-joke movie--a good joke, yes, but Brandon Cronenberg's agenda clouds the clarity that's needed to fully deliver the punchline.
The film has an engagingly profane, scruffy looseness, a hallmark of Hal Ashby and Robert Towne's careers, that undermines the conventions of the narrative.
The film belongs to a long tradition of horror films that offensively suggest that all atheists might as well hang a Welcome sign up for the devil.
Neil Barsky is aware of how a great and terribly troubling person can reside in the same body, but his occasional eagerness to appoint himself as his subject's latest press agent is dubious.
Down the Shore suggests what might happen if TBS and Bruce Springsteen were to collaborate on a sitcom set in hell.
The "male gaze" that often despicably and hypocritically surfaces in these kinds of films is pointedly absent throughout.
It's eventually obvious that Cory McAbee mistakenly believes that his characters' resolutely dull adventures speak for themselves.
Rebecca Thomas's debut feature is a sensible and humane exploration of youthful curiosity.
Sadly, those looking for any insight into Journey from Ramona Diaz's documentary are going to have to look elsewhere.
The film is ultimately enjoyable despite its faults, at least partially because it represents an earnest, honest attempt to empathize with struggling American working-class women.
The film spins its wheels for almost an hour until collapsing under the weight of exposition that renders the mystery nearly besides the point.
The filmmaker's failure of empathy for those who strive to outlaw medicinal marijuana turns the protestors into hissable puritanical bad guys.
Not much happens in The Victim, but the events that do manage to transpire consistently support a reading of the film as an older man's fantasy of virility.
Ultimately plodding and resolutely old-fashioned, a corporate thriller for folks too square to indulge the possible existence of hungers so strong they must be satisfied at any cost.
The doc is ultimately a dry endeavor that feels closer in spirit to an Afterschool Special than a full-blooded movie.
The film has an exhilarating tossed-off quality that characterized many of the most entertaining works of the French New Wave.
One of the more intimate and revealing looks at American projects ever made; it's assured and empathetic without indulging in fashionable white guilt.
The film has a shambling charm that actively disputes an unspoken notion that a documentary must be well-structured in order to effectively land its points.
Yoav Factor can't decide whether he wants to play his broad scenario as an exaggerated farce or as a heartwarming testament to blood ties.
Convento captures the casually reassuring pleasure, as well as the potentially disconcerting oddness, of seeing something commonplace anew.
The title is apropos, but it's also an understatement.
A Simple Life is moving and well made, but it could use a little emotional grit and, while we're at it, a sense of humor.
The film provides a crisp, succinct answer to a question that nags most Americans: What the hell happened?
movie_title: Heist: Who Stole The American Dream (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Adam Pesce never condescends to any of his subjects, but good intentions alone don't make for a captivating movie.
As an effort in civil duty, The City Dark would earn three sturdy stars, but as a film it's lacking.
These wrestlers have a number of striking similarities which can be boiled down to one true commonality: They all felt like freaks.
The film's aggressively low-budget aesthetic is meant to be lively and rife with integrity.
Writer-director Rafi Pitts manages an atmosphere of choked, ambiguous dread that recalls nothing less than Godard's Alphaville.
After 30 long minutes, I stopped trying to make allowances for its varying ineptitudes, and Carice van Houten's work as the spunky human cat was the only reason I held out that long.
The doc is ultimately more of an educational video than a movie.
movie_title: Bonsai People: The Vision of Muhammad Yunus (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The doc is so obnoxiously simplistic that you find yourself strangely unsympathetic to its objectively inarguable aim to promote greater standards of elder care.
Marc H. Simon's documentary has the thrust of a great American noir or black comedy.
A film relating a story of the Holocaust is destined to provoke a number of adjectives, but "cloying" shouldn't be one of them.
Recalls some of the more annoying entries in the mumblecore subgenre that erroneously believe that every indiscriminate moment in a person's life is worthy of a film regardless of subtext.
Julia Ivanova doesn't judge her subject, refusing to see her through the eyes of a presumably better-off first-world citizen.
movie_title: Family Portrait In Black And White (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The doc is a sly, interesting achievement: It opens as an entertaining sports story and closes as a metaphor for government corruption.
A typical wax-museum reproduction of the American South in which every detail is Southern in bold all caps, and not a single scene over the course of the film's 102 minutes rings true.
Kumaré has a premise that could've been the launching point for one of Sascha Baron Cohen and Larry Charles's satirical outrages.
Knockdown is a tedious narrative shambles that's almost hilariously unaware of its racism and sexism.
Ultimately too concerned with courting the singer's fans to deliver anything more than a theatrical release of a very special episode of VH1's Behind the Music.
Maybe Battle Royale's ultimate punchline is its inexplicable ability to fool some people into taking it seriously.
The documentary is briskly paced, often compelling, but a little soft, as it succumbs to hero worship.
movie_title: Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Elena is a film deeply concerned with class resentment, but the filmmakers' attitude toward their titular character is disconcerting and even shocking.
Some will find the film compelling, but underneath the riddles it's basically a self-important proclamation of "who the hell knows?"
The conclusion is a testament to the fact that authentic justice is probably only attainable by accident.
A home-invasion film like Mother's Day is elongated coitus interruptus.
The script simply isn't in the same league as the images that Andrew Dosunmu and the gifted cinematographer Bradford Young have fashioned.
Phillip Montgomery's film is ironically as undeveloped and busy as the sensational media it criticizes.
D.W. Young navigates his varying moods with an ease that's particularly impressive for a director making his feature debut, but he never capitalizes on his ability to coax down our guard.
Quentin Dupieux has a talent for rendering otherworldly concepts banal in a manner that reflects the stymied desires of his characters.
The film's notion of a caste system is crudely reductive in the manner of a routine future-shock thriller.
There's no beauty to this film, little rhythm, none of the physical grace that action-film fans crave even if they don't know they do.
Like its protagonist, Philippe Falardeau's film gets lost in a haze of incidental cacophony.
The film is shrilly, luridly, dully, and unremittingly ugly, preaching to a choir that it also demonizes.
It attempts to dress up torture-porn tropes with a late-inning switch to science fiction that spectacularly backfires.
It's a testament to Nathan Silver's keen sense of observation that we don't want the film to turn decisively into thriller terrain.
Flames grows tougher, weirder, and more ambiguous, casting much of its early cuteness in a starker light.
Katie Green and Carlye Rubin's film documents the transferrable perversities inherent in familial life.
In the film's best scenes, Jeff Grace displays a delicate understanding of various modes of male fragility.
It's unseemly watching Burt Reynolds, one of the greatest movie stars, beg for sympathy in Adam Rifkin's Dog Years.
Lydia Tenaglia's direction is occasionally flashy and cluttered, but her empathy for Tower is evocative and poignant.
[By the Time It Gets Dark ironically grows] more hypnotic, rapturous, and overpowering, discarding conventional narrative to hunt for wild emotional shard.
movie_title: By the Time It Gets Dark (Dao khanong) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Throughout Queen of the Desert's narrative, there's no sense of danger, of texture, or even of a rudimentary idea of what's truly driving Gertrude Bell.
Salt and Fire is a doodle, suggesting an assemblage of ecological riffs and fantasias that Werner Herzog may have entertained while making Into the Inferno.
Walter Hill and Michelle Rodriguez seem to share Frank's confusion over the precise difference between cosmetic and biological reality.
Joe Swanberg's Win It All understands addicts in a fashion that's unusual for American cinema.
Bruno Dumont's formalism is presently charged with a spark of simultaneously controlled and spontaneous mystery.
Oz Perkins exhibits a committed understanding of the cinematic value of silence and of vastly underpopulated compositions.
The Wizard of Lies bears less of a resemblance to art than a book report.
Steve James's film is a rallying cry, and its weaknesses as art might bolster its strength as reformatory theater.
Director Roberto Andò takes the form of a classical whodunit and bludgeons it with naïve indignation and sanctimony.
Andrew Becker and Daniel Mehrer get close to their subjects only to retreat when things get truly dangerous.

For all its hip ludicrousness, The Little Hours has a point: to almost earnestly riff on how atheism has taken hold of 21st-century America, by rooting our nation's moors in a time of great austerity, sexism, classism, and persecution.
Errol Morris films Dorfman and her work with a rapt attentiveness that maps the nostalgic and regretful stirrings of her soul.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In Okja, a transporting protest fantasy becomes another shrill dust-up in the waging of the culture wars.
The film's thematic organization suggests the cinematic equivalent of a short-story collection, with haunting tangents and stray notes of poetry.

The film has a calming and inevitable quality, and a leisurely sense of pacing that favors image and sound over narrative propulsion, that slows our own biorhythms, fostering our sensorial empathy with the passengers.
Ana Lily Amirpour has learned a few lessons from QT about the disreputable joys of blending kitsch and ultraviolence.
Throughout Harmonium, writer-director Kôji Fukada works in a rapt and lucid hyper-textural style that suggests a merging of the sensibilities of Alfred Hitchcock and Yasujirô Ozu.
Frédéric Mermoud's film makes an elaborate pretense of honoring the traditions of the observational procedural.
The high school diploma is accepted by the film too conveniently as a problem-solving MacGuffin.
The film simplifies Winston Churchill's legacy for the dubious purposes of narrative momentum and emotional lift.
Writer-director David Michôd's film renders existential crises of American entitlement dull and tedious.
As QT's first film as both writer and director, Reservoir Dogs indicates a remarkably fully formed cinematic sensibility.
Lost in Paris abounds in whimsy that, for the most part, isn't irritatingly precious-a feat that's harder to pull off than it appears.
Michelangelo Antonioni's film is an inquiry into the modernist concern of what art is and how it affects life.
Throughout the documentary, the undisguised regret and longing of David Lynch's reminiscences are often startling.
Director Kasper Collins imbues this documentary with an ambiguous, unsettlingly empathetic emotional force.
Fences is a scathing study of how white society destroys a promising black man's sense of self.
Gonzalo López-Gallego's direction isn't confident enough to allow us to ignore The Hollow Point's contrivances.
Frank & Lola occasionally benefits from the weird energy shared between Michael Shannon and Imogen Poots.
Johnny Ma's Old Stone is a lean, nasty entry in a subgenre that could be termed the bureaucratic noir.
Though the film strives to be audacious and galvanizing, it's easily shaken off as an exercise in stunted necrophilia erotica.
It has an artisanal intensity that prevents it from turning into a smug and predictable exercise in political revision.
Trollhunters blends the tropes associated with Guillermo del Toro with the anonymous tics of generic fantasy.
The film has an eerily WTF arbitrariness that should be the domain of more films in the genre.
The busy-ness of its conceit grounds Werner Herzog in a documentary procedural form that's surprisingly conventional by his standards.
In terms of formal orchestration, Creepy is as sublime as any prior Kiyoshi Kurosawa film.
It collapses into repetition and unintended self-parody, as it's devoid of the subtext and empathetic audacity.
With The Handmaiden, Park Chan-wook has made a gigantic leap as an artist, but he retreats to lurid cartoonishness just as he's earned your trust.
The film pushes through one story point to the next, occasionally prizing velocity over texture.
Mark Duplass and Sarah Paulson have extraordinary chemistry, painting a cumulative portrait of the fragility and rareness of being truly in sync with a partner.
The plaintive plain-spokenness of the interviewees, the way they matter-of-factly speak of atrocity, is transcendent and intensely haunting.
Alice Lowe evinces a knack for locating society's most awkward pressure points, and a willingness to punch them.
A Monster Calls is both governed and straitjacketed by director J.A. Bayona's competent impersonality.
Director Michael Dudok de Wit is drawn to transcendental refinement, seeking to provide us refuge from the excess of our world.
The pacing is so humorless and funereal that it squelches the possibility of heat or conflict arising between the characters.
Mike Ott and Nathan Silver's Actor Martinez has a ghostly, tremulous quality that's bound to get under the skin.
Julia Ducournau exhibits a clinical pitilessness that's reminiscent of the body-horror films of David Cronenberg.
Bart Freundlich alternates somewhat arbitrarily between his various plots, leaving a lot of loose ends in the process.
The Rosses share David Byrne's interest in the minutiae of habitats and the comforting enclosure they provide along with the discomfiting constriction of anonymity.
Boo Junfeng casually reinvigorates the prison drama, boiling its elements down to their primal essence.
The film is seemingly terrified of boring us, offering one elaborate montage of catch and release (or of survey and flee) after another.
These shorts follow female protagonists as they wrestle with exclusion and implicit social standards that may or may not extend to their male counterparts.
What distinguishes Stray Bullets from so many other low-budget crime films is Jack Fessenden's sense of quietness.
Rings is unsure as to whether it's a sequel to the other entries in the series or a contemporary reboot.
The film is in love with the tropes it ridicules, and it doesn't take long for that love to dwarf any possibility of critique.
The film celebrates the unbridled force of energy for its own sake.
Asghar Farhadi's film yields a tonal and emotional friction that's simultaneously tragic, transcendent, and comic.
The efforts of a slumming cast dwarfed by clichés and opportunistically scattershot class pity.
Bits of editorializing dialogue throughout James Franco's In Dubious Battle suggest the resonant film that might've been.
One of the most ambiguous, neurotic, and disturbing of all American films receives a revelatory new restoration, with supplements that ably grapple with its chaos.
By design, the film is intensely preachy. And this preachiness serves a therapeutic purpose, offering jolting possibilities for empathy.
The film is a trim farce with no blood flowing under its skin, as it's all construction, setup, and payoff.
The film shows no interest in the inner workings of a relationship that's defined by unusual circumstances.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the Fade comes to life when it dramatizes the distraction tactics necessary to excusing terrorism.
Scott Cooper's film moves at a funereal pace, implicitly celebrating its sluggishness as a mark of integrity.
Gilles Paquet-Brenner's film is ultimately a genre item that operates on alternately prestigious and campy autopilot.
The film arrives at a place of qualified peace that cauterizes the emotional wounds of Paul Thomas Anderson's cinema.

The Shape of Water has been made with a level of craftsmanship that should be the envy of most filmmakers, but the impudent, unruly streak that so often gives del Toro's films their pulse has been airbrushed away.
Before I Wake's images have a pleasing straightforwardness that parallels the openness of the young protagonist's longing for love.
Brian Smrz never contrasts the film's violence with stillness, allowing the audience to enjoy a sense of foreboding escalation.

Shiota understands a pivotal strand of the American screwball comedy; that it's often a male fantasy of relief from male expectations, hence the dominant female charters who sort out the men's neuroses.
movie_title: Wet Woman in the Wind (Kaze ni nureta onna) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sweet Virginia doesn't have much of a point, as its characters are reductive variables in an inevitable equation of carnage.

Unhinged even for Takashi Miike, Ichi the Killer suggests a bloody and ejaculate-stained Rorschach inkblot, reveling in ultraviolence that can be interpreted to flatter any adventurous audience's sensibilities.
Erik Nelson's film straddles a fine and admirable line between lurid sensationalism and sober humanism.
Blade of the Immortal is a work of robust genre craftsmanship that's informed with a sly sense of self-interrogation.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In its visceral purity, the film drags male toxicity up into the light, offering it as a cure for itself.
Sion Sono, allergic to subtlety, is terrified that we won't notice his detonation of Nikkatsu's sexploitation traditions.
The Awakening often feels as if it's starting all over again from scene to scene, drinking in Belle as she wanders one shadowy corridor after another.
The disappointment of The Belko Experiment, then, is that it shifts so abruptly into horror-film terrain that it fails to examine the way this office has brainwashed these characters.

Sam Hoffman respects his characters and evinces curiosity about their lives-and these qualities aren't to be taken for granted. But he isn't willing to disrupt his familiar and tightly structured plot.
The transcendence that the film offers isn't to be taken lightly considering the near impossibility of living professionally as an artist.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One feels in the film's punishing bleakness a yearning for transcendence.
In the context of screenwriter Alex Ross Perry's other work, the sledgehammer preachiness of Nostalgia almost scans as a failed hipster joke.
One misses the prismatic structure of the 15:17 to Paris book, which fuses multiple points of view and which is reduced by Dorothy Blyskal's script to cut-and-pasted bromides.
Brian Crano is as skittish as his protagonists are about the particular contours of their dilemma. To put it bluntly, Permission is a sex film without the sex.

Alex Ross Perry's characters are shrewd enough to recognize the irrational contours of their lives, which they diagnose and chew over in some of the most inventive, twisty, and richly ironic dialogue in modern American cinema.
The film's mixture of sensationalism and self-conscious artiness is experimentally disingenuous at best.
On Body and Soul's fusion of romance, comedy, ultraviolence, and political commentary has the logic of a lucid dream.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Like Me is exhilarating because of Robert Mockler's willingness to deviate from his satire so as to surprise himself with seemingly spontaneous emotional textures and tangents.
Writer-director Brian Taylor's Mom and Dad invests a hoary conceit with disturbing and hilarious lunacy.
For liberals, The Final Year might become a kind of metaphorical marriage video that's watched by divorcees who yearn of that initial hint of paradise.
Babak Najafi's Proud Mary is a so-so action melodrama with an insulting whiff of generic blaxploitation stylistics.
Júlia Murat's Pendular abounds in exquisite displays of negative space, reminding one that there's few artistic elements as inherently appealing, visually, as a symmetrical image.
Ziad Doueiri's film is well acted and staged with periodic liveliness, but its earnestness grows wearying.
The Cage Fighter isn't sentimental about the notion of an aging sports hero who needs one more day in the proverbial sun, recognizing that desire as macho folly.
Thomas Jane's dramatization of rage is haunting and shrewdly comical in its overt and ultimately moving über-manliness.
Richard Turner is a charismatic subject who demands more than a conventionally entertaining documentary.
Alexandre Bustillo and Julien Maury's anonymous work here could've been overseen by any hipster looking to make a mark at Platinum Dunes.
Twenty-six years after its release on Independence Day weekend in 1991, it's difficult not to watch Terminator 2: Judgement Day through a scrim of irony.
Lemon by Chuck Bowen 1.5 Stars Self-absorption is Janicza Bravo's focus, though--as in other smug and mock-ironic comedies--it's a topic that's less examined than indulged.
Mapping the intersection between history and emotion, Michael Almereyda finds himself in Alain Resnais terrain.
Sunao Katabuchi displays a vivid, shattering awareness of how domestic routines can spiritually ground one during a time of demoralizing chaos.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The premise of Michael Winterbottom's series has devolved from moderately diverting to actively stifling.
Unforgiven brought the revisionist revenge film into the 1990s and, by extension, the 21st century.
Though far more elegant in execution than most Rob Zombie-imitating films, Jackals smugly wears its violent tediousness as a badge of honor.
The seeming miracle of Columbus is its mixture of formal precision with a philosophical grasp of human mystery.
The film is so humorless and in love with its own obviousness that it grows laughable.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is history that Americans should know, and Bainbridge and Maiorana approach their film as an introductory survey course, which undercuts Rumble's aesthetic intensity. F
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A preoccupation with the totemic materiality of cinema runs through Michael Almereyda's documentary.
Heroin is to Landline what abortion is to Robespierre's Obvious Child: a dangerous little variable planted to strategically unsettle the pervading cutesiness.
One of the most beautiful and mysterious of all existentialist adventure films receives a deservedly lush and subtle transfer.
One of the film's great qualities is its casualness and willingness to be simply human and to not let sociological politics dominate.
There's a tough and mysterious film within Strange Weather, though it doesn't quite escape the strictures of a busy and studiously weird narrative that's governed by formula screenwriting.
Goon: Last of the Enforcers faces an uphill climb that's inherent to retreads, as it's almost impossible for the film to honor its predecessor without lapsing into contrived and preordained formula.
With its dull mixture of indifferently staged exposition and action, it suggests a primitive side-scrolling video game.

The film offers an oxymoronic parable that's been utilized countless times by cinema, in loose reiterations of A Christmas Carol: The protagonist must learn humility after learning that the world revolves around him.
78/52 comes to life when riffing on the psychosexual perversity of Psycho, which changed cinema's relationship with sex and violence.
Director Natalia Leite's ambition and accompanying uncertainty give the film its unruly and resonant energy.
The film presents patterns in suicidal people while according them humanity, which isn't a small accomplishment.

Blade Runner 2049 has been made with impeccable craftsmanship and taste, yet the film is so terrified of disreputability that it renders itself dead from the waist down, unable to derive pleasure even from a theoretically kinky robot three-way.
Andrei Konchalovsky's film is more than an exercise, as pitiless moments accumulate with enraged relentlessness.

Mike Flanagan is an un-ironic humanist, which is rare in the horror genre. And this admirable quality trips him up in the film's second half, which pivots on Jessie learning to stand up to diseased masculinity.
John Carroll Lynch's Lucky is an impeccably acted yet sentimental film that's bashful about said sentimentality.
Dorota Kobiela and Hugh Welchman's film is driven by an off-putting and oxymoronic fusion of reverence and egotism.
It predictably utilizes Facebook to superficially spit-shine another wanly Americanized J-horror retread.
First They Killed My Father is less interested in global politics than in offering an intensely experiential tapestry of war and invasion as witnessed by a child.
In the film, Hong Sang-soo simultaneously positions filmmaking as the ultimate act of atonement and evasion.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ex Libris suggests a college course and a guided tour that have been wedded together as a work of prismatic humanist art.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Agnieszka Holland and Kasia Adamik's Spoor is a tree-hugging, animal-loving film with a stinger in its tail.
Hong Sang-soo's The Day After homes in on the similarities between job interviews and dates, mining them for a comedy of romantic alienation and autobiographical rumination.
Initially colorful, the script's lurid and overripe dialogue eventually grinds the film to a halt.
A civics lesson in the film tethers a promising tale of artistic toil to the strictures of melodrama.
The film changes gears whenever one is lulled into believing that it has finally settled into a recognizable narrative pattern.
Throughout, filmmaker Bill Morrison mixes documentarian detail with an ecstatic sense of poetry.
The film blends the Bard with National Geographic, failing to make a case for the inexplicability of their union.
One wishes that S. Craig Zahler had more explicitly faced the cultural demons lingering within his premise, attempting to exorcise them.
Stephen Winter's film doesn't earn the gall it evinces by pissing on Shirley Clarke's masterpiece.
Both Olivia Wilde and Luke Wilson understand the greatest pain of loss to be rooted in its searing inexpressibility.
There's satiric potential here, but Eli Roth's sense of humor abandons him when his hero isn't about to get down with the get down.
One can chart the very moment that Victoria's existence slips out of the routine into the nightmarish, and there's no escape by temporal omission.
The film doesn't add up to much, but it's a diverting tour of Takashi Miike's anything-goes, splatter-paint sensibility.
Asthma inevitably becomes another film about a man airing out his traumas and hitting all the requisite marks on his path to healing.
Ariel Kleiman fashions an erotic atmosphere of dusty sensuality that complicates our judgement of this world, but he takes shortcuts.
Aesthetically, the film cunningly suggests life that exists solely within an academic experiment, closed off from chaos that isn't manufactured.
Director Daniel Barber uses a bleak and unresolved portion of American history to justify indulging typical genre-film nihilism.
It makes an occasionally spirited pretense of injecting the tensions of the United States's educational system into a familiar zombie-siege scenario.
One watches the film with an escalating sense of disbelief and horror, as Warren Jeffs is steadily revealed to be an even greater monster than we initially take him for.
Coming Home is a film in which everyone's dreams are irrevocably broken, the pieces too small to grasp, let alone pick up.
The setup is so familiar that frustration sets in before the title has barely faded from view.
Director Jason Lei Howden has a flair for punchlines that are funny for reasons that are essentially impossible to describe.
Slacker and even less involving than the similarly terrible global kill-fest Last Knights, but easier to watch for the inadvertent camp value of two of the prominent performances.
Everyone heals, or doesn't heal, on cue, and the initial pathos of the narrative is dulled by the architecture of its through lines.
It captures the frustration and the longing of forever wanting more and better at the expense of casualness of being.
Chummy, often amusing slapstick goofiness merges with hard, jarring violence.
Sweaty Betty is a reminder that poetry comes in all shapes and sizes, and that art ultimately dictates its own terms.
It inelegantly attempts to infuse a standard revenge western with the gravitas of a war veteran's coming-home odyssey.
In Chimes at Midnight, Orson Welles is at the height of his powers while reveling in the poetic force of Falstaff's weakness.
Anomalisa's highpoint is one of the most remarkably moving sex scenes in all of American cinema, and the irony of it involving bland puppets is hardly lost on Kaufman and Johnson.
Too much of Noma is composed of gorgeous pillow shots, which grow static and fussy, appearing to exist almost apart from the subject matter.
Time and again, the filmmaker cuts the money shot meant to theoretically cap a sequence.
The filmmakers exhibit no interest in watching the story's central wolves wiggle out of the trap they've potentially set for themselves.
