Arlo is a collection of insecurities that have been calculatedly assembled so as to teach children the usual lessons about bravery, loyalty, and self-sufficiency.
It grounds us so effectively in Joplin's emotional realm as to partially rekindle the social transcendence that her voice must have represented for its owner.
A blunt satire of the dehumanization inherent in social media that also gets off on said detachment.
The actors have the showmanship to chew the lurid, shopworn material up to bits, savoring it like a Royale with cheese.
Alison Bagnall and her talented leads appear to effortlessly achieve a tone that's tricky to sustain, one that abounds equally in absurdism and empathy.
Scott Mann's Heist gets by on chutzpah, growing more diverting with every ludicrous plot twist.
The film doesn't quite earn Gene Jones's performance, but it engenders considerable goodwill for allowing him to give it.
The film is one long funereal slog in which the main character discovers something about herself that's almost immediately apparent.
Every beautiful, resonant image in writer-director Alex Ross Perry's film is fraught with neurotic, diaphanous riddles.
Craig William Macneill's film is a sporadically frightening slow burn with a fatally overlong fuse.
David Gordon Green stages even fleeting tonal palate cleansers with a self-consciousness that parallels Al Pacino's acting.
Christophe Gans's telling of Beauty and the Beast abounds in impersonal and unsatisfying sumptuousness.
movie_title: Beauty And The Beast (La belle et la bête) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: At least it doesn't make the biopic mistake of attempting to check off every moment of a man's life over the course of a few hours' worth of running time.
The film's subtitle is apropos, as this is a decidedly locked-down and lead-footed talk-o-rama.
Adam Driver's characteristically exceptional, though Saverio Costanzo admittedly serves the film to him on a platter, as he's the only element in the film to which one can positively respond.
As in Rodney Ascher's previous film, Room 237, the subject of obsession is complemented by a despairing attempt to process it, corral it, and somehow conquer it.
It's perched uneasily on a fence separating a rote comic sketch film from something weirder, stranger, and less engaged with offering reassuring domestic homilies.
Appropriately, the images in the film, the most fluidly beautiful and resonant of Nathan Silver's career thus far, suggest flashes of memory relived from the vantage point of the future.
Andrew Bujalski seizes upon physical training as a resonant metaphor for the work and risk that are inherent in cultivating significant interpersonal connections.
Nightingale is first an intellectualized puzzle, and a portrait of a man losing his mind a very distant second.
Tom Six has achieved the seemingly impossible: He's made a film even less watchable than The Human Centipede II.
It has a problem that's familiar to competently made, sporadically involving crime procedurals: It's just good enough to inspire wishes that it were better.

The filmmakers attempt to acknowledge the pain of warfare within the framework of a redemptive story that lends it an unforgivably patronizing sense of closure.
Samuel Fuller's a master of unpretentious hot-house poetry, and that theoretical contradiction of terms gives one an idea of the irresolvable, elegantly compact flourishes that abound in his films.
David Hackl often shoots his bear in fashions that accent its lumbering, powerful grace, even during its death rattle.
Ken Loach's staging is so calm and sober that it turns his story into an expertly photographed yet weirdly remote rebellion tale.
The filmmakers maintain a tone that's mostly ideal for the contemporary equivalent of a drive-in movie: of reverent, parodic irreverence.
Reminiscent of Woody Allen's great, under-sung Manhattan Murder Mystery, it utilizes a pulp conceit as a shorthand for the regrets that bubble up in a marriage.
The filmmakers never really answer inevitable questions: What's the point of these fussy allusions?
It grows increasingly hopeless as it contrasts the alien paradise of the opening with the wastelands that resemble corporate dump sites.
The film introduces a promising romantic pentagon, only to let it float away unfulfilled into studiously benign coming-of-age clouds.
It elegantly evolves from an absurdist comedy into a remarkably wounded and uprooted story of friends who're beginning to tire of their shared social cocoons.
The payoff is a huge and telling visual howler, summarizing the entire plot with a blithe indifference that will inevitably mirror the audience's.
The narrative derives much of its tension from the unsentimental ambivalence Jon Watts displays toward the story's two pre-teen boys.
Writer-director Alex R. Johnson's film is the rare thriller that resounds with an authentic ring of chaos.
Daniel Augusto relies on familiar tropes pertaining to the sexy, rebellious rock-star artist who does things his own way.
Director Jack Heller's film may take the notion of implication over illustration a bit too far.
It suggests that Kris Swanberg has taken notes on what a film concerned with pregnancy should include without actually making it.
The film offers a veritable smorgasbord of dated, only-in-the-movies clichés about the debt-ridden working class.
Takashi Murakami has invested the film with the same sort of primal pop-art aesthetic that distinguishes much of his art.
The formalism fashions effective textural shortcuts to behavioral understanding that the remarkable cast fills in with chilling, convincing finesse.
The film is just another fantasy of living only the good portions of the life of an artist.
The film ultimately boils down to people bludgeoning one another in unimaginative close-ups.
With the film, director William Monahan offers audiences a bundle of fetishes dressed up as an existentialist thriller about the class system.
It alternates awkwardly between shrill, borderline misogynistic sex farce and desperately gory, pun-rife creature feature.
It joins its American cousin in the scrapheap of family dramedies that no one watches, unless by default out of boredom on TBS or TNT.
The film does nothing satiric or fleetingly parodic with the notion of a world united in the midst of alien annihilation.
It infuses an outdoorsy survival tale and a coming-of-age story of friendship with Taika Waititi's penchant for distaff flakiness.
Noah Buschel shows that formula can be repurposed to serve empathetic ends without losing its self-actualizing appeal.
It movingly posits acting as a metaphor for the search for connection, through visceral texture rather than platitude.
The film communicates a sense of pastiche unpredictably giving way to a raw and primordially intimate emotional realm.
It offers no conclusions, routinely alternating between episodes that contrast exhilaration with exploitation and damnation.

movie_review_blurb: The film covers The Texas Chainsaw Massacre by way of Rob Zombie, Quentin Tarantino, and Ti West.
Jon Watts does nothing with the scarily funny notion of a respectable professional who suddenly refuses to shuck a party costume.

Its openly mercenary ethos initially scan as a bracing lack of pretense in a market crammed to the gills with insidious faux-sentimentality, but its overstuffed relentlessness proves almost equally tedious.

movie_review_blurb: Like Hitchcock, De Palma reveals himself to be guided by an unusual mixture of intuition and intellectualization.

Julio Medem's film has enough hanky-courting plot mechanics for three remakes of Beaches.
Even the film's lapses inform it with a free-associative sense of portent, evoking the stupid things we inexplicably do in our most personal nightmares.
Steve Hoover's documentary affords one an unusually intimate glance at the collapsed infrastructure of the former Soviet Union.
The lack of ambiguity reflects Benoît Jacquot's treatment of the text, which is devoid of either formal obsessiveness or a contemporary hook.

movie_review_blurb: This enterprise is so listless that one can't even work up a proper head of self-righteous steam over the spooky Native American clichés that drive the plot.
The film insufficiently connects the book's prophecy with its present-day, real-world forms of realization.
Maïwenn fashions a bracing film about co-dependency, capturing the erotic contours of subservience and flattery.
The film attains a chilly existential quality as Matt Johnson's character discerns the weight of his actions.
The film has the emotional fatuousness of uncertain softcore erotica.
The political resonance of Frank Sinatra's sleepwalking is unsubtly reactionary.
The political resonance of Frank Sinatra's sleepwalking is unsubtly reactionary.
Leyla Bouzid displays considerable talent for dramatizing how young people eroticize peril and risk due to a lack of experience.
movie_title: As I Open My Eyes (À peine j'ouvre les yeux) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Charles Burnett bridges theatrical dialogue, portentous omens, and presentational acting with masterful grace.
It offers a visual reprieve from the cumbersomely mechanized aesthetic of so much contemporary fantasy.
It relies less on in-camera stunts than editing that renders vague gibberish of the altercations.
The film has been executed with a sense of formally stylish and thematically symmetric panache.
Jean-François Richet's film shrewdly capitalizes on Mel Gibson's off-screen embarrassments and controversies.
The film's images have a loose, rough, textured liveliness that honors the spirit of Chinatown Fair.
It offers lively and layered images that reveal the chefs both as individuals and components of a larger social organism.
One comes to distrust Gleason's pathos, because it always appears to be selling something.
It displays an intimate chemical understanding of the exhausting and unrelentingly impotent agony of failure.
Underneath the impersonal formal beauty and good acting is a familiar moral about self-imposed limitations.
Throughout Alex and Benjamin Brewer's film, Nicolas Cage holds the screen with his distinct timing and expressive force of being.
It occasionally and promisingly suggests an obsessive and free-associative paean to regret.
Chad Archibald doesn't quite land Bite's transition over from claustrophobic character study into full-blown monster movie.
As preachy and repetitive as The Little Prince can be, it offers enough moments of poetry to keep it flirting with greatness, or at least goodness.
Everything in the film is understood to be a subsumed sex act, with actual sex serving as a contextualizing catharsis.

The legacy of Syd Field's screenwriting manual hangs over 10 Cloverfield Lane, as it does all of Abrams's productions, which never even accidentally cast a whiff of subtext or authorial personality.

The imagery fails to express either the characters' or the filmmakers' obsessions or synchronicities.

A curiously unsentimental director of romantic comedies, Julie Delpy sees romance for the work that it primarily is.
It has an appealingly inventive, unruly genre party streak running down its figurative back.
movie_title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Travis Zariwny predictably scrubs all the edges and eccentricities down, however, fashioning another impersonally polished cover jam.
Standoff isn't quite inspired, but it coasts on unexpected modesty of professionalism.
When Bo Mikkelsen springs his traditional yet cathartic climax, it's earned because the violence matters truly as violation.
Every moment in writer-director Grímur Hákonarson's strange and wonderful film is imbued with mystery and revealing dignity.
Southbound is yet another contemporary horror film that belongs to seemingly every era but its own.
Jordan Galland confidently perches the film right on the razor's edge separating absurdist comedy from horror.
Writer-director Robert Budreau strip-mines the life of an amazing musician for the purpose of mounting yet another comeback story.
Erika Frankel's documentary is finally revealed to be a story of prolonged adjustment to retirement, and a poignant illustration of sublimated redemption.

The director's greatest asset, though, is Lindon's sad, weathered, haunted face, which invests the film with omniscient heartache, offering evidence of the sense of self that's lost in the bureaucratic labyrinth that many of us call home.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ricky Gervais's film hopscotches through a variety of premises, looking for jokes that never arrive.

An admirably bizarre and beautiful genre mixtape, but Anders Thomas Jensen's empathy for his characters gradually impedes his imagination.

movie_review_blurb: The film is taken with comfy gags that celebrate these men's ownership of pop culture, filtering them through a lens of unrevealing caricature.

The film's aesthetic is striking, but feels almost intangibly derivative, most obviously suggesting an austere cover of Repulsion.

Jerzy Skolimowski's formal control over the material is so masterful that the textual particulars are revealed to be beside the point.
Denys Arcand fashions a commandingly leisurely pace that allows us to follow these people who walk a tightrope separating ecstasy from misery.

An interestingly offbeat black comedy...The Weather Man is quite edgy for a big-studio release in 2005.
Still good for a few chuckles, but I find it somewhat overrated.
Stay away.

More of a witty buddy movie in Western clothes.
movie_title: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969)

movie_review_blurb: A smart and mature romantic comedy that's funny at times and surprisingly touching...Claire Danes gives a luminous, deeply-felt performance.

A frequently hilarious comic revenge fantasy that struck a cord with people from all walks of life.

Tight, terse and tough. The great Walter Hill once again proves he has few equals when staging intense confrontations.
A wacky cornpone comedy with some big laughs.
A very well-executed farce, and Brooks' most underrated movie.

Much underrated...One of the best spy thrillers of the 1960s.

A mature and elegiac fantasy done with feeling and sincerity that really captures the mystique of old-time baseball.
Sam Mendes' Jarhead is the perfect companion piece to Clint Eastwood's underrated Heartbreak Ridge.
Rivals The Dead Zone as Cronenberg's most satisfying and accessible work to date.
Deliciously entertaining trash.

Robert Aldrich's Hustle is an honest and profoundly sad movie about how the legal system favors those with money, power and connections over those who don't. One of Burt's best and most underrated films.
The Weinstein's new company gets off to a good, if unspectacular, start with this solidly efficient thriller.
Too long, too muddled, too inconsistently paced. A documentary on the History Channel could provide all of this information in less than half the time with a lot more clarity.
One of the best biopics of recent years.
The nicest thing that can be said about this stoner comedy is that it's not the worst of its lowbrow kind.
A slight, but amusing character-driven buddy comedy.
Even though some of its special effects are now dated, Santa Claus: The Movie is a touching tale that deserves to be rediscovered by younger generations.
It's bad, but not painfully bad like Boll's previous two...BloodRayne is just an ordinary, formulaic sword-and-sorcery B movie with one hot sex scene.
A lame, formula sports comedy so tame and lazily executed that it doesn't even succeed on an exploitation level. Burt Reynolds deserves better, much better.
An absorbing and eerie study of paranoia and psychological torment.
A touching little gem.
A quirky delight with Bill Murray at his droll best.
An idiotic remake of John Carpenter's crackerjack B thriller from 1976. Panders to the lowest common denominator by changing the original's street-gang villains to white cops.
A severely overlooked, exceedingly well-done version of an oft-told tale...One of the best films of 2005.
An infuratingly glib star vehicle that plays like Prizzi's Honor for morons.
A sickening, socially-irresponsible glorification of depraved and sadistic behavior...The worst film of 2005.
Annoyingly glib...Drowns in its own jokiness.
Theron gives a powerful, chameleon-like performance in this disturbing but very sad film that shows how harsh the world can seem to people living on the fringe of society.
Probably played better on stage, but it still makes a good night's entertainment...Silly fun.
A sharp and funny 1977 comedy has been dumbed-down by turning it into a lame, overly broad Jim Carrey vehicle.
A bland, lackluster piece of instantly forgettable comic fluff.
Kurt Russell is perfect as hockey coach Herb Brooks in a true story that still manages to be rousing and inspirational despite its inherent predictability.
Infuratingly lazy and insultingly smug. My choice for the worst film of 2004.
The biggest guilty pleasure of 2004. An entertaining throwback to the kind of hardcore vigilante films Charles Bronson used to star in.
Incredibly intense, unflichingly realistic and powerfully moving...One of the all-time great cinematic achievements...God bless Mel Gibson.
Jackson's competent remake is certainly worth a look, but it's ultimately a Kong too long and too much.
A likable little underdog-triumphs drama from Canada... This is a case where my idealistic side won out over my cynical side.
Convoluted, disjointed and extremely dull...amounts to a bunch of ciphers having esoteric conversations about who knows what.
An innocuous, but overly broad comedy made somewhat palatable by the likable performances of its leads.
A comic noir that feels like a direct-to-DVD movie that could have easily starred Matthew Modine, Dennis Hopper and Gina Gershon.
An ultimately moving, universally human story about the pain caused when certain stigmas within society prevent people from expressing who they really are.
This passable dramedy plays like a Hallmark Hall of Fame telefilm with fart jokes.
An absorbing, understated thriller until it totally self-destructs in the final reel with a twist we've seen too many times in recent years.
A truly frightening chiller. A definite classic of the horror genre.
Constantine is one of those excruciatingly awful movies where you check your watch every few minutes hoping the agony will soon end.
Worse than you can imagine... see 1997's The Relic instead.
Million Dollar Baby is a masterful piece of work by Eastwood that stays with you long after leaving the theater.
Elektra isn't the Carmen Electra story, but after a while, you'll wish it were.
Often playing like an unwanted sequel to Dragonfly, White Noise makes little sense.
For those who aren't Darin aficionados, the reason to see this biopic is another outstanding performance by Spacey.
Meet the Fockers isn't quite as funny as its predecessor, but it definitely has its moments.
[Easily] one of the better films of 2004, but a good deal of this is oddly unmemorable for a Scorsese film.
It's ironic Blade: Trinity has Triple H in its cast because the film itself is entertaining in the same cheesy, trashy way of a good wrestling grudge match.
While Alexander certainly isn't great, it's not nearly as bad as many would have you believe.
Barely a step above the dismal The Big Bounce from earlier this year.
The gripping, bloodcurdling Saw is the best serial-killer thriller since Bill Paxton's Frailty.
Just like Ocean's Twelve, Be Cool is an abysmal sequel that makes you want to angrily boo the screen when it's over.
A pleasant surprise.
I really wanted to love Ladder 49, and am disappointed that I can only give it a modest recommendation.
For a movie that begins on such a strong note, by the time the end credits appear, it's become, well, rather forgettable.
The fast-paced Cellular is an amalgam of familiar elements with one original plot device thrown together into a very entertaining stew.
...easily the best mainstream release of the summer... an example of first-rate B moviemaking.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Tries so hard to be clever and surprising by withholding information that it ends up being a confused mess.
Harlin's film doesn't even work on the level of entertaining schlock like Peter Hyams' devil thriller End of Days.
Open Water is a very simple film, but an effective one nevertheless.
A poorly paced kidnapping drama that seems to think it's so prestigious that it doesn't need to generate much suspense.
Garner and Rowlands are so effortlessly wonderful that they make The Notebook worth seeing.
Paranoid left-wing propaganda from beginning to end... Moore should be proud of himself. He's made a film America-haters everywhere will love.
Premise of the original was far-fetched enough without writer Paul Rudnick and director Frank Oz turning everything into an over-the-top cartoon.
Tristan & Isolde is the first pleasant surprise of 2006...Kevin Reynolds is a pretty good director when he's not associated with Kevin Costner.
...so ineptly and annoyingly filmed that it should be used in filmmaking classes... to demonstrate how not to make a movie.
Although overplotted, too contrived, and seldom plausible, Hostage nevertheless succeeds as a taut, furiously paced and hard-edged variation of Desperate Hours.
Yet another lame, entirely predictable sequel with no reason for existing other than to make a quick buck.
A pointless wallow in sadism... Willis, Rourke, and Boothe have all done way cooler tough-guy movies for Walter Hill.
An interesting study of an unrepentant louse.
A sincere and moving film...easily one of the best of 2005 thus far.
A first-rate thriller before it crashes and burns in the final act...The solution to the mystery is a real groaner and a politically correct cop out.
A hit or miss spoof of Communism saved by zany performances by Brooks and DeLuise.
Joins titles like Flashback, Bulletproof and Nothing To Lose as one of the most instantly forgettable odd-couple movies ever produced.
A riveting drama.
A good B movie. A Sound of Thunder once again proves that nobody, possibly with the exception of Paul Verhoeven, does sci-fi thrillers better than Peter Hyams.
Years ago, The Cave would have made an adequate bottom half of double bills. But at today's ticket prices, this is a wait-for-cable movie if there ever was one.
Tight...Taut...Gripping...Craven's most suspenseful film since The Hills Have Eyes.
An OK late-summer time killer.
Stupid enough to make Smokey and the Bandit Part 3 and Cannonball Run 2 suddenly seem like paragons of wit and high comedy.
A high-energy sci-fi thriller that's smarter, edgier and more exciting than the usual action-packed summer blockbuster.
Serviceable, but ultimately pointless because not a second of this remake tops anything in the original.
Plays like a slightly raunchier variation of the lackluster 1989 Mark Harmon comedy Worth Winning.
Works best as a study of how a nice, beautiful woman is forced to deal with a succession of creepy, dishonest men.
Almost good enough to make you forget its director is an overrated egomaniac and its star is a self-righteous nut.
Land of the Dead is easily the worst of Romero's four zombie movies, and clearly should have never been made.
Turgid... Tiresome... it's the lack of a dynamic villain that kills Batman Begins.
Ron Howard's Cinderella Man is the best American film since another movie that revolved around a boxer, Clint Eastwood's Oscar-winning Million Dollar Baby.
The 1974 version had a sense of realism that's missing from the comically exaggerated remake. However, I don't remember the original having as many laugh-out-loud moments.
Despite having its release date postponed numerous times over the last two years, Mindhunters turns out to be much better than expected.
Monster-in-Law delivers the most laughs of any comedy since Meet the Fockers.
A historical epic totally destroyed by the infusion of contemporary political correctness and left-wing revisionist history.
Sydney Pollack has been a hit or miss director for 40 years. Unfortunately, The Interpreter is one of his misses.
With the new Bay-produced remake of The Amityville Horror, a middling horror film from 1979 has been remade into something truly atrocious in 2005.
Sahara is an Indiana Jones rip-off so dull that it gives me newfound respect for Cannon Films' 1985 version of King Solomon's Mines.
Features many good scenes that feel authentic, but is interspersed with awkward 'movie moments' that don't ring true.
Undeniably exciting and much better than a movie with this many young, buff bodies should be.
One of the great unsung films of the 1970s. It's so good you come away wishing James William Guercio had done more films.
The off-beat A Fine Madness succeeds on the level of breezy lightweight entertainment.
A pastiche of other kidnapping thrillers such as Ransom, Don't Say A Word, Hostage and Desperate Hours, but still manages to sustain interest.
Laughable...We can only hope a sequel called The Number 46 doesn't get made.
A first-rate production from top to bottom...Beatty has never been more electrifying on screen.
Derivative in the extreme, but some good stunt work and humorous touches make it a lot more tolerable than it could have been.
The ill-conceived Hannibal Rising plays sort of like how Death Wish might have turned out had Charles Bronson's vigilante been a bloodthirsty cannibal.
This fish is swimming with laugh-out-loud moments.
I have a not-so-subtle message for a creatively bankrupt Hollywood: STOP DOING CRAP REMAKES OF PERFECTLY FINE HORROR FILMS FROM THE '70s and '80s.
Cohen takes the slasher/serial-killer genre and puts a unique spin on it while adding plenty of gallows humor.
A highly cinematic blast for those who can stomach its brutality...Like Glengarry Glen Ross with guns.
An embarrassing cliché-fest.
Gives you more reason than ever to love Black's death scene in 1997's The Jackal.
Helen Mirren makes an amazing on-screen transformation into Queen Elizabeth II...Michael Sheen also bears an uncanny resemblence to Tony Blair.
Intelligent and totally absorbing...The most underrated film of '06.
Breach follows The Good Shepherd as the second outstanding spy-thriller released by Universal within the last two months. Shepherd was terrific. Breach is even better.
A perfect companion piece to American Beauty, and just as good.
Every bit as average as III, IV and V...What could possibly be next, Rocky vs. Michael Myers?
Had Gibson followed the cue of other less self-important variations of The Most Dangerous Game, and cut to the chase more quickly, Apocalypto would have been a far more satisfying experience.
Harmless...Plays out predictably...OK entertainment for kids.
A movie that grows on you...Underneath layers of anger, sarcasm, profanity and booze, Bad Santa ultimately reveals a soft heart.
The man with the license to kill has become the man with the license to bore.
Guilty pleasures don't get much guiltier than The Seduction.
Suspenseful and supersexy.
Still plays like a more commerical variation of the superior Year of the Dragon, but Black Rain has aged nicely, and is a strong film in its own right.
This cynical World War II film does manage to explore a unique aspect of war. Namely, the selling of war to the public through manufactured, exaggerated or sanitized feel-good stories.
An absorbing, tension-filled and intelligently-written drama...Taps has aged like fine wine.
A great Western...If there's any justice, director Hill and producer/star Duvall will find themselves holding Emmy Awards for this superior piece of work.
Ermey again easily steals the show as the redneck 'sheriff' from hell.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Tough Enough is a countrified Rocky wannabe that just isn't good enough.
While seldom less than totally engrossing, it doesn't come close to the greatness of Scorsese's GoodFellas and Casino, and pales in comparison to Joanou's State of Grace.
The second film in the last 12 months about the never-solved Zodiac killings...Fincher's is the more ambitious, thorough and better of the two.
The song [Pop! Goes My Heart] is a lot of fun, but ends up being the only memorable thing in a middling rom-com that needed a wittier script.
Another sexed-up Hitchcockian thriller from Brian De Palma. Plays much better today than it did in 1984.

The end result of Rambo IV is akin to that of The Dead Pool, the fifth (and probably final) Dirty Harry movie. Yes, it is the least of the series, but years later, fans of the character will be glad it exists.
An inept, choppy, painful-to-watch mess that looks like it was thrown together by rank amateurs.

Gets a little too Hollywood for its own good, but the biggest pleasure here comes from the moments where two of our best actors (Jack Nicholson and Morgan Freeman) simply talk to one another about life.
Hideous beyond words ... Zombie has made the white-trash scuzbucket version of Halloween in which most of the characters are made to be as unkempt and sleazy-looking as he is.

A good, not great, movie that benefits from nice period detail and some strong performances (especially Hayek and Leto), even if the real-life Beck was a heavyset, homely mess not anywhere near as attractive as Hayek.
Wildly entertaining ... Skillfully walks a fine line between black comedy and intense drama ... It's one of the year's best.
The third weak sequel in a creaky franchise that should have remained dormant.
Did about a third of the business of its highly successful predecessor, and contains only about a third of the laughs.
Has some sporadic laughs, but Ben and especially his roommates are just too gross to be the kind of charming free spirits Apatow thinks they are.
Friedkin's Bug is a claustrophobic, unsettling, intense and extremely well-acted parable about paranoia.
If ever a movie epitomized the term 'overplotted,' it is Mr. Brooks.
The film is most interesting in its portrayal of Warhol as a cold-hearted user.
Ponsoldt's debut is full of quiet heartache, and effectively establishes a consistent melancholy tone. And Nolte is exceptional.

A tough, entertaining homage to the kind of gritty '70s crime film that long ago gave way to a slicker yet tamer form of action movie ... Both the studio's cut and Helgeland's cut work about equally well.
Just misses ranking in the upper echelon of mob movies.
Starts out strong ... But after the 42 minute point, it turns into the action movie equivalent of Regarding Henry.
Shooter is a real stinker.
A character-driven crime thriller ... The Lookout is definitely worth a look.
A pleasant spring surprise.
The Reaping will end up doing for Swank's career what Bless the Child did for the career of another Oscar-winning actress, Kim Basinger -- nothing.

The films seldom rise above the cheesy level of the very "B" movies they're emulating, but Grindhouse is a fun throwback to what it felt like to see exploitation movies at the nabes, drive-ins and inner-city theaters during the '70s and early '80s.
The kind of trite material that seems better suited for the small screen than the big screen.
A respectable straight-to-DVD movie that was headed for the 'pleasant surprise' category before self-destructing with a terrible, out-of-the-blue ending.
A comically ghastly B-movie delight.
Made me long for the days when epics were photographed with the beauty and clarity of Lawrence of Arabia, Ben-Hur and Spartacus.
A handsomely-mounted, muscular, red-blooded Old West adventure ... One of the most stunning films to look at in recent years.
A high-spirited cocktail of action, comedy and romance that's one of those rare movies with something for almost everyone.
A tiresome rehash.
Zaillian has made a flawed but good film that's better than 90 percent of the stuff that gets produced nowadays.
Bug-eyed Marty Feldman steals the show as Igor, pronounced 'Eye-gor'.
A servicable little B movie made to exploit New York City's famous 1977 blackout.
Basic Instinct 2 is something the original never was -- boring...An obvious front-runner for the 2006 Razzies and Stinkers.
Although it never quite reaches the level of Dog Day Afternoon or The Taking of Pelham One Two Three, it exhibits a lot more personality and wit than most commercial movies these days.
A lurid, but never less than watchable thriller dominated by Wings Hauser's intense performance as a vicious pimp.
A very well-crafted suspense-thriller that unfolds with one dramatically tense scene after another. Hopkins is superb.
Relentlessly predictable and painfully unfunny...A total failure.
A bloody good time...Increases the gore level substantially, but thankfully director Aja stays close to the original's blueprint and keeps the suspense quotient high.
Contrived to an excruciating degree and mawkishly emotional, 16 Blocks is a manufactured and predictable action-thriller that conveniently forgets all logic.
Could have been a good exploitation flick if it didn't get carried away with piling on the plot twists.
Mark Bussler's Johnstown Flood is an excellent documentary about one of the worst tragedies to occur in America during the 1800s.
Some of the humor has become very politically incorrect 25-plus years later. And God love it for that.
Mel Brooks reached his comedy peak with this riotous spoof of Alfred Hitchcock thrillers.
An often very funny sex comedy.
A great film of uncommon truth.
An underrated, hilarious comedy with a lot of heart.
The formula was starting to become tiresome by now. And can somebody please explain how Rocky suddenly became more articulate in this one despite more punches to the head?
A very good sequel even though the result of the climactic Balboa vs. Creed rematch is pretty much a foregone conclusion. This is where the series should have ended.
It's sometimes hard to remember what a great film the original Rocky is because its reputation has been hurt by too many unnecessary sequels.
Predictable and corny. When the Soviet fans as well as the Soviet government officials stand up and cheer Rocky at the end, you can't help but roll your eyes in disbelief.
A glorified made-for-Lifetime-cable movie.
A prime piece of machismo.
The original has just the right mix of toughness and humor. Burt Reynolds was born to play incarcerated quarterback Paul Crewe.
A smart, well-written and entertaining post-sexual revolution infidelity comedy.
A solid entry in the overcoming-great-odds-to-become-a-champion biopic.
While it's not up to the Sellers ones from the '60s and '70s, like the Sellers-less Curse of and Son of, it definitely has its moments.
It's pretty much impossible not to love The Dude.
Brooks proved that increasing the vulgarity level doesn't necessarily translate into more laughs. Gag after gag falls flat in this potty-mouthed dud.
This moving film is the crowning achievement of Cliff Robertson's career.
The Sentinel could easily pass for a generic straight-to-DVD release if it wasn't for the presence of Michael Douglas.
This painfully unfunny spoof rivals Dracula: Dead and Loving It as Brooks' worst film.
The Black Dahlia case was already the basis for an excellent, infinitely-better fictionalized film built around it, 1981's True Confessions starring Robert De Niro and Robert Duvall.
An immensely likable, wonderfully-performed film.
This certainly won't be a favorite of Gloria Steinem.
Poor Dr. Loomis' nerves are pretty much shot at this point, leading to some unintenionally hilarious moments.
movie_title: Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Although this is just more of the same old same, Halloween 4 is directed with some skill by B-movie specialist Dwight H. Little.
movie_title: Halloween 4: The Return of Michael Myers (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Pleasant and often amusing without ever recapturing the charm of A Christmas Story.
The Hard Corps is more grounded than most in its genre, and has a ring of truth to it.

When asked my opinion after a screening of World Trade Center, I was momentarily at a loss for words, a testament to the film's potent impact...Ranks second only to the devastating United 93 as the most powerful film of 2006 to date.
The Descent only works marginally better than last August's similar creature feature, The Cave.
Talladega Nights is so sub-moronic and witless it makes Stroker Ace look like a sublime exercise in sophisticated comedy.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A liberating little ode to dysfunctional family unity and nonconformity that may occasionally make you cringe, but will ultimately touch your heart.
Miami Vice isn't just a terrible movie. It's a terrible movie that looks like absolute crap.
Cheesy B movies tend to be more fun when they aren't so keenly aware of their cheesy B-movie status.
This stupid spoof of organized crime is about as appealing as week-old spaghetti.
movie_title: The Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight (1971)

movie_review_blurb: A comedy only Dr. Kevorkian could have loved.

One of the most gripping and deeply upsetting films I've ever seen. I honestly left the theater shaking with a combination of anxiety, anger and sadness I haven't felt since the days immediately following 9/11.
Petersen's Poseidon has more fireballs and rushing water, but nothing even approaches the entertainment value of Gene Hackman and Ernest Borgnine constantly yelling at one another in the original.
A solid, underrated horror film.
Bad enough to offend even an atheist.
It's a bird. It's a plane. It's Superscientologist!
Not a typical, formulaic, feel-good romantic-comedy...Plays a bit like Best Friends for a younger generation.
In this era of unnecessary and pointless remakes, The Omen is unequivocally the most unnecessary and totally pointless remake since Gus Van Sant's Psycho.
Drab looking, underwhelming and inferior to all four of the Superman films that starred Christopher Reeve...But at least it's better than Supergirl.
As tame as it is lame...The only thing that offended me about this movie is how it wasted two hours of my life.
A riveting, high-testosterone nail-biter.

Rocky loses his fortune, moves back to the old neighborhood and neglects his son while training an ultimately ungrateful young boxer. A manufactured attempt to capture the spirit of the original. What's intended as high drama is cloying and silly.
Another reason to abolish the now-abhorrent [Sundance] festival altogether.
A turgid, rotten bore that pretty much signals the death of "art" cinema as we know it.
Miller's confident, technically astounding direction produces challenging ideas at every turn.
Watching it feels like whiplash, and afterwards it doesn't feel like you've benefited at all from sitting through it.
movie_title: The Source: The Story of the Beats and the Beat Generation (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The film backhands [Zellweger] by deeming Bridget as imperfect, essentially stripping the character of any pride in her physical appearance.
As the film quickly loses perspective of Chopper Read's alleged crimes and lifestyle, it begins to slowly glorify him as an icon of self-made celebrity.
An infectious bubblegum spirit keeps the film watchable even when it crashes and burns.
Or, ten movies that nobody wanted to see, starting with a giant metal robot and working our way through a martyr, a flower, a comedian, and more...
What makes Shadow Magic a mixed bag, both emotionally and thematically, is its burden of debt to mass appeal.
Shows stretch marks from the start.
Daldry can piece together a competent montage sequence, but he has no idea how to hold your attention without resorting to inspid, watery melodrama.
The glimpses of paradise are so intoxicating that it's easy to ignore the cliches and enjoy the drama anyway.
A complex, difficult, unyielding vision of memory and personal experience.
A hilarious screwball masterpiece.
movie_title: Crna macka, beli macor (Black Cat, White Cat) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: As ponderous and pointless as a supernatural thriller can possibly get.
Clint, for all his good intentions and graceful aging, is in danger of overstaying his welcome.
Nothing that hasn't been said a million times before.
Registers so little that you might as well be watching a blank screen.
A memo to Chow Yun-Fat: Get back to Hong Kong on the double!
Kudos to Michelle Pfeiffer and Treat Williams.
movie_title: The Deep End of the Ocean (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Don't let yourself watch this on a Sunday--or any other day, for that matter.
movie_title: Don't Let Me Die on a Sunday (2000)

movie_review_blurb: So depressing that you can't even relish just how awful it really is.
What's ultimately best about The Third Miracle is how small and quiet a film it is.
Amateurish in the worst possible way and sorely lacking ideas or any sign of intelligent life.
Best used by Planned Parenthood as a pro-contraceptive, pro-choice advertisement--the idea of hauling kids to this junk is enough to make any prospective parent think twice.
Titanic Town has a few too many quiet moments, most of which go nowhere in particular.
At its best when focusing on its motley crew of characters.
Concepts of viewing that are often dealt with subconciously are brought to a blinding light by the Maysles Brothers.
Is an extra 50 minutes of bad footage reason enough to re-release an already problematic movie? I wouldn't think so.
Rififi is most important for its 30-minute-long heist sequence.
The film's cast does little to offset Harrison's insecurity behind the camera.
It's loaded with pretension, and it comes dangerously close to being little more than an exasperating stunt--and in the end that's what's so great about it.
For every moment that works in Kikujiro, there's at least one that doesn't, and they often happen at the same time.
The film does little to accept or understand the views it chooses not to share.
Scarcely funny or interesting, much less shocking or provocative.
[Hunt] chooses early emotional depth to fulfill later parts of the movie--a master stroke, as it turns out.
Norton's presence is what gives the film its edge.
[Barreto] finds the right tone for every scene, be it light or heavy, funny or dramatic.
It's less about being good and more about existing to suck dollars out of wallets.
Impressions of love, loss, dedication, and perseverance transcend cinematic boundaries and actually mean something.
There's a definite thrill to be gained from watching elements of genre trash invade such a film.
The real meat of the movie comes in the many intimate moments that Blaustein's camera catches.
Gleefully plunges through the silliness with remarkable conviction; there's a thrill to be had. Time and money are rarely wasted in such entertaining and inoffensive ways.
Winds up as a disappointment due to its languid pacing and a plastic sensibility as to what constitutes film art. In other words, it's typically French.
A masterpiece of simplicity.
In going out of their way to make the characters shocking and graceless, the filmmakers forgot that it's necessary for the audience to enjoy spending time with the characters.
Writer-director Peter Mullan never seems clued in as to how hilariously atrocious Orphans is.
Someone Like You is made of plastic emotions--they're so meaningless they practially come with their own disposable Styrofoam wrapping.
[Has] the most lopsided and nauseating cast of male pigs since Ridley Scott conned his way to a so-called feminist victory in Thelma and Louise.
Like watching This Boy's Life with a laugh track superimposed.
A whirlwind of bad gay jokes and mistaken motives.
Manages to avert complete fallout and be marginally entertaining.
movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Both accomplished in its direction and marred by freshman mistakes.
Lightweight material to be sure, but it's fun just the same.
Interesting only in how precious little rationality it features.
Neither the embarassment some made it out to be nor the pleasant surprise that sometimes becomes of films befallen with an early bad reputation.
So disrespectful to the art of cinema that sitting through it shows its purveyors some form of respect they don't bother to return.
It's impossible to be engaged by the film on any level other than visceral because Hark doesn't bother with connecting the dots of his story.
movie_title: Time and Tide (Shun liu Ni liu) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Has a lot of charm, which accounts for its success.
The only documentary of late not to resort to righteous emotional pandering or talking head syndrome.
Though there's nothing in it that could be considered offensive, including its occasional stabs at post-modernism, as a film experience it fails to exist.
A vociferously overblown spectacle that unites a classical musical form with Luhrmann's obsessive pop culture pilfering and whirligig stylistic pastiche.
The ultimate American film maudit from the '70s.
Kollek's screenplay and a concise, adventurous cast amply demonstrate the film's reason for being by playing up the quirky oddness of the film's many frivolous details.
Campbell's rugged visuals (aided immeasurably by cinematographer David Tattersall) pull the film through the clichés and make it marginally exciting.
Far better than most swill heading for shelter under comparisons to Merchant-Ivory or Masterpiece Theatre.
At once a horror film, a black comedy, and a peculiar ode to the art of filmmaking, Shadow of the Vampire is best appreciated as a straight-faced fantasy.
Few films stoop as low as Pay it Forward under the guise of upright seriousness.
What was a film worth taking the time to divine value from becomes the biggest, and most expensive, waste of time in several years.
Always interesting in a morbid and curious sort of way.
Builds to the kind of derisorily bittersweet finale that earmarks productions that are infatuated with their own beliefs.
More of a young turk provocation than a measured and mature intercession on rage and despair, but it certainly achieves the unsettling effect Noe intended.
movie_title: Seul Contre Tous (I Stand Alone) (One Against All) (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Another invaluable artifact of cinema history that should be required viewing for anyone with even an ounce of interest in the development of the art form.
movie_title: The Wide Blue Road (La Grande strada azzurra) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The musical scenes in The Fantasticks crackle with intimacy.
What crashes Party's potentially freewheeling sense of merriment is the choice by Cumming and Leigh to shoot it in DV.
Junkyard filth masquerading as an important history lesson.
Bui has no sense of pacing or momentum.
A story that isn't as yawn-worthy as it is wholly unconvincing, both as a premise and a recognizable representation of something real and tangible.
movie_title: The Young Girl and the Monsoon (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Salient images fly free, thanks to Jordan's acute visual sense.
Lacks a punch that Mendelsohn's rough direction and the uneasy black-and-white photography can't provide.
