[Kovács] gives a virtuoso performance, one that calls to mind the fraught sensuality of Catherine Deneuve in Repulsion and the steely innocence of Audrey Hepburn in Wait Until Dark.
Scenically beautiful, rhythmically uneven comedy.
A big-screen reality show that flashes plenty of [nudity] but little integrity.
Zippy, stylish fun.
Though engaging from beginning to end, be warned that this is also harrowing, utterly depressing stuff.
While there's little verve to the filmmaking -- the camera work and color scheme are equally nondescript -- the actors are gifted charmers and make all the destiny stuff easy to take.
Goes down easy.
Glover's performance turns out to be shockingly emotional, drawn as daringly close to the bone -- within this story's limited thematic range -- as Anthony Perkins' work in Hitchcock's seminal film.

Although time considerations have forced screenwriter Brian Hohlfeld to strip away the subtle complexities of Milne's plotting, he's managed to retain the aching melancholy of animal characters whose persistent self-doubt has a human resonance.
Poorly lit and tone-deaf.
Moviegoers aren't likely to be sold on the absurd plot twists doled out by screenwriter James Vanderbilt.
This impressive debut feature from writer-director Anders Thom as Jensen is decidedly offbeat.

In this unenlightening, dramatized account of Gacy's crime spree, first-time writer-director Clive Saunders, working with television writer David Birke, displays little genuine interest in why Gacy killed.
Those who can forgive the director's pretensions will discover some fine filmmaking.
Schumacher ... tries to hide Cohen's logic-free plotting behind swooping camera moves and multipanel split screens, but to no avail.
Amiable but not especially funny.
Sometimes the predictability of a romantic comedy is reassuring, and sometimes it makes you want to scream, as with this witless wonder.
Fans of Louis Sachar's superb 1998 young-adult novel will be delighted to know that his debut screenplay richly embellishes the book's good parts.
Powerful war satire.
For these gifted directors and their fine ensemble, the notion that every life forms into a mosaic of intimate, largely unobserved details is the story most worth telling.
If none of it is particularly original or insightful, it's nonetheless executed with skill and economy.
Director Kristen Coury has made a technically polished first film, but her sense of comic timing and sexual politics is strictly borscht belt.
As so often happens in queer moviemaking, the attempts at raucous humor distract from the lovers.
Heartfelt yet overly schematic.

Having won first and second place in some sort of TV talent show, Kelly Clarkson and Justin Guarini get to play movie star, a bonus all America should immediately vote to have removed from the prize bin.
Wise and moving adaptation of Dodie Smith's beloved 1948 novel.
One wishes the turns of Carlos' life felt more like life and less like a movie.
Unexpectedly moving documentary.
After a zippy first hour, the wackos wear out their welcome and the director, perversely, fails to show the big concert.
While it's Dave's madly humming brain that propels the film, Davis, whose every glance is a short story in itself, makes Dana's internal crisis equally resonant.
Well-rounded collection of gay-themed shorts.
[A] horribly misguided movie.
Mindless yet impressively lean spinoff of last summer's bloated effects fest The Mummy Returns.
Running Scared is decently acted and divertingly brutal, but it's also a giant step backward for its maker.
Even the director's flat-footed moves can't quell Martin and Latifah, whose combined energy is fearsome and sometimes most amusing.

Ultraviolet and the recent Resident Evil films mark this compelling Russian beauty as the unofficial queen of Xbox-ready junk movies, which are fast becoming the new century's equivalent of radioactive bug flicks.
[A] pitch-perfect, deeply affecting film ...
Athale has a flair for guy-pal banter; here, the talk is funny and profane, silly and profound, often in the same breath.
It's all very predictable, very Hollywood. Storytelling cliché, it would seem, knows no borders.
By calling on his leads to underplay nearly every moment, Hartigan calls into question our deeply ingrained instinct, as moviegoers, to witness a steady parade of amped-up emotions.
Lowery isn't a Malick and he's certainly no Kazan, but he's his own man, and a filmmaker to watch.
A stirring film that's part documentary, and part promotional tool.
Overlong but amusing ...

Writer-director Christian Vincent and co-writer Étienne Comar, aided by Frot's quiet intensity, imbue Hortense's quest to pull off culinary miracles with an urgency that's almost absurdly compelling, and all the more entertaining for it.
It's a noble effort, but by wading into the murky waters of who acted heroically, and who, perhaps, did not, Ryan loses touch with the mountain itself ...
This bilingual romantic comedy is overly long and has a paper-thin plot, but it's too sweet-natured to dislike.
Aided by capable if unnecessary 3D effects, Petty displays a flair for staging violent action, but he's trapped inside a broad comic set-up that doesn't mesh with the story's innate meanness.
There are many things absent from this found-footage horror movie, including suspense, logic, and originality.
Bridging the Gap is gorgeous and weird.
The filmmakers do find a clever way to incorporate Roba's original Boule et Bill art into the plot, yet any one of those classic doodles has more vibrancy than this unappealing adaptation.
To use a phrase from the film, The Armstrong Lie is a "myth-buster." It's wholly necessary, brilliantly executed, and a complete bummer.
Handles serious issues with a light touch, and should resonate with adolescents.
In this entertaining documentary, the coolest kids in town sing the praises of cartoonist Gahan Wilson, whose work is a brilliant fusion of the personal and the political.
movie_title: Gahan Wilson: Born Dead, Still Weird (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Although the film's final twist undercuts all that has come before, Some Velvet Morning is provocation of the most artful kind.
Girl fight! If that phrase makes your pulse quicken, Raze may be the movie for you. Or, it may cure you forever of the desire to see women growl, bite, and brawl.
Devlin's script tips its hand so early on that Devil's Due lumbers toward a woefully flat, predictable ending, and the unwelcome promise of something truly demonic - sequels.
Destined for a long life in museums and history classes alike, this is cinema as art, and a classic.
If the onscreen serial killer isn't having fun, how can we?
The film's gorgeous, hand-drawn animation is as lovingly detailed as the drawings a girl mouse named Celestine is secretly making about an imaginary mouse and bear friendship.
Dark House is one nutty horror movie, but what's crazier still is how well it works - until it doesn't.
So melodramatic and relentlessly grim that any passion [Shurchin] feels for the material isn't reflected onscreen.
A compelling but ultimately unsatisfying film.
Should please those who own Shaun of the Dead on Blu-ray, and can quote one-liners from The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (the novel, not the film).
A thriller whose storytelling ingredients are so familiar that one could watch it with the sound off and still know what's going on.
Writer-director Calvin Lee Reeder, making his feature debut, isn't interested in satisfying the conventional expectations of an audience.

As social insight, End of Watch is useless, but as engrossing entertainment, it's irresistible, thanks to Ayer's gift for dialogue, the relentless pacing set by film editor Dody Dorn, and gorgeous performances by Gyllenhaal and Peña ...

Smiley's face, or lack of one, is the single creepy effect in the limited trick bag of first-time writer-director Michael Gallagher, age 24, who otherwise relies, again and again, on false-scare musical shrieks to make audiences jump.
Evocative ...
In families, this fascinating film suggests, acknowledging or denying the darker truths of one's legacy is a choice that must be made again and again, each and every day.
Screenwriter Christopher Landon, along with co-directors Henry Joost and Ariel Schulman, make a truly lame attempt at establishing a supernatural mythology to explain all this ...
Billy Jack meets Rob Zombie meets John Waters in this trippy, gory, not-as-fun-as-it-should-be genre mash-up from writer-director Ward Roberts.
Jeff Orlowski's beautiful yet sobering documentary about the world's rapidly melting ice caps.
This hopelessly muddled horror movie takes place in a United Kingdom public housing high-rise so dingy and bleak you might feel that razing it would be a mercy.
Logic is rarely the point in movies like this (and the novels that inspire them). There's much to enjoy here ...
Stallone looks great (even if his face doesn't quite move when he talks), while Hill brings lean economy to the film's bloody, unapologetic mayhem.
A remarkably assured debut.
So tame and so completely boring that to call it a horror film is to insult the genre.
Boseman and Kittles somehow push past the blather to reveal the inconsolable grief and fury that so often haunts our vets.
So witty, riveting, and drop-dead gorgeous that moviegoers may forget to notice that they can't hear the dialogue.
A feel-good story about an autistic man's quest for independence, The Story of Luke is a charming little film in need of a bit more grit.
Maddeningly shallow-maybe that's the point-but McGuinness does have talent.
The plotting as a whole feels fresh, as does the emphasis on women strong enough to defend themselves.

Although it takes Nathan a bit too long to get his characters to Van Nuys, knowing in advance that Dave is likely to snap not only creates suspenseful dread, but ultimately makes the moviegoer complicit in the violence (which is believably haphazard).
Papa Cronenberg must be proud, but be advised: If there's a blood test in your future, book it before seeing this movie.
The movie is eerily photographed, but never suspenseful or scary, and eventually, events descend into goat-sacrificing silliness.
There are some decent shootouts, but the movie's strongest assets are the soulful performances ...
Director Ryûhei Kitamura (The Midnight Meat Train) is too talented for material this retro-junky, but he and screenwriter David Cohen keep the action coming hard and fast ...
Aftershock is incompetently made and morally muddled, but since talent, morality, and Mr. Roth have never been on speaking terms, we're not exactly surprised.
Making his feature debut, Swiss-born writer/director Baran bo Odar has turned Jan Costin Wagner's 2007 novel The Silence into a taut, beautifully acted thriller.
In her pitch-perfect feature film debut, writer-director Eliza Hittman explores the terrible uncertainties of adolescence, and in the process reclaims the word "girls" for its rightful owners.
Watermark is a documentary filled with images both beautiful and wrenching, yet the film as a whole is a disappointment.
Stamm brings such a deft touch to these tonal transitions that it's hard to believe he directed the dreadful 2010 hit The Last Exorcism.
Shimosawa's debut feature boasts an elegant visual style and a mystery plot with so many absurd twists that the film becomes enjoyable high melodrama.
The road-trip drama Who's Driving Doug is earnest but not overly sweet - a blessing for a film with built-in sentimentality traps.
Heaven Can Wait may be 73 years old, but it's vibrant and alive, and teaching us anew the central language of film.
The 93-year-old is a legend with a zillion stories - so why is the new documentary about his life so unsatisfying?
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Since no terrorist group or nation state has ever claimed credit for Stuxnet, Gibney can only hypothesize about its origins, but he makes an alarmingly lucid (if circumstantial) case for the culpability of the United States and Israel.
In his lovely new film, Argentine director Daniel Burman mixes reality with fiction in inventive ways.
movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It wouldn't work at all if the filmmaker hadn't lucked into an actor as gifted as Jessup.
Bates is a shameless ham throughout, but when she works her magic on Trotter's end-of-movie speech to Gilly, resistance is futile.
[A] painfully dull film ...
Most of the turns of plot feel organic, ours to discover, as long as we're paying attention.
A bit disjointed but also vibrant and loving, much like its subject.
Proves only that what is repellent in French is equally so in English.
A last-minute flurry of action and a final plot twist aren't enough to redeem this busy but tedious thriller.
Slightly uneven yet deeply affecting ...
The need to tell a story and the desire not to collide in Live Cargo, the narratively uneven but visually exquisite debut feature from writer-director Logan Sandler.
[A] beautifully produced but dramatically wobbly epic.
So full of movie clichés and high melodrama that it's sometimes hard not to giggle - and one should never laugh at the prime minister.
Unlocked feels like a 1970s-style conspiracy thriller, which makes it a perfect fit for the 76-year-old Apted, whose wonderfully varied career includes the James Bond flick, The World Is Not Enough.

Both a thriller and meditation on the loss of innocence, Super Dark Times is rich with the minutiae of a bygone era ... but Phillips and screenwriters Ben Collins and Luke Piotrowski press hard against the instinct for nostalgia.
Why does Tom of Finland play like an over-cited term paper? The film is jammed with incident and detail but there's little flow to the storytelling ...
This kind of narrative inexactitude might drive some viewers crazy, but there's an emotional truth to it, too.
A disappointment.
Recognition (and compensation) proved elusive in Lamarr's lifetime, but in this marvelous documentary, a brilliant woman - "I'm a very simple, complicated person" - finally gets her due.
For his revolutionist's passion and for allowing Tyson to once again fill the screen with her glory, Tyler Perry is my new hero.

All that's ever mattered about The Lion in Winter are Hepburn and O'Toole, and the pleasure we take from watching two masters inspire each other to greatness. Scenery chewing has rarely been so artful.

The movie sends mixed messages. It's hard, but gooey, too. Trick 'r Treat showed that Dougherty has a mean streak (with wit), but with Krampus, he's clearly been charged with delivering a wide-appeal PG-13 film.
Led by the honorably dour Firth and the charisma-free Harington, MI-5 is convoluted and dull ...
These "kids" turn out to be wiser than their years - wiser than most of us, probably - as they both win and lose with an enviable grace.
Less a director's return to form than an essay in solipsism and self-pity run amok.
Teerink paints a portrait of an intensely modest man who relished the idea of other artists carrying out his ideas, and, in the process, extending a given idea further than he himself had imagined.
Six years after his debut feature, The New Twenty, writer-director Chris Mason Johnson returns with a film that's less polished but braver.
Hellion offers Paul his most adult screen role so far, and he's very fine, but the movie belongs to Wiggins, a newcomer whose innate gifts are a perfect echo of Paul's.
Very Good Girls is a film one wants to like but can't. It just doesn't work.
Watching the hopelessly vapid get taken out, one by one, has never been more depressing.
Writer-director Matthew Weiner, creator of the magnificent Mad Men, has made a feature film - theoretically a comedy - that's just shy of terrible.

If filmmakers were put on trial for hackery, a good prosecutor might ask director Miller why The Prince contains no discernible prince but does feature a closing-credit shout-out to "Prince Yoohanhwesa."
Its heart lies in the noirish past of both movies and literature.
Decades apart in age, Caille and Bouquet both exemplify artful restraint - deciphering their tiniest gesture is a deeply rewarding experience.
The film's finale is wild and daring and so perfectly executed that it marks Wright as one of the film year's most audacious new voices.
The scary Halloween house at your local amusement park is child's play compared to the "extreme haunts" that fill this uneven but intriguing found-footage horror flick.
Three visually impaired teenage boys from India who play chess at the championship level are the subject of this slow-moving yet soulful documentary.
Hard to categorize -- horror-comedy? mystery-thriller? -- but lots of fun to watch.
A viewer may not connect, emotionally, with every number, and may even dislike a few, but that, too, the film suggests, is the nature of flamenco. We bring to it whoever we are in the given moment.
Esmail frames his lovers against landscapes that are richly textured and swooningly romantic, but they prove unworthy of the fuss.
We Are Kings is that rare thing: a film about musicians where you actually look forward to the next song.
If the kids think this is the scariest thing ever, then so be it.
It's all pure hokum, perfect for a Shirley MacLaine remake, but it's lovely to see Lafont carrying a film so effortlessly.
The filmmakers don't appear fully committed to the idea of a zombie apocalypse, so no sense of dread (or suspense) ever takes hold.
Thanks to Ashton's brilliant, career-defining performance, we're made to see that the only thing worse than doing evil deeds is being nice enough to feel guilty about them.
Hellions is unsettling, but in all the wrong ways.
Movement and Location is an original and intelligent immigrant drama with a title so academic (and uncommercial) that you might want to give the filmmakers a firm talking-to.
The Russian Woodpecker is very much like Fedor himself -- eccentric as hell, smart as a whip, and, at the end of the day, a heartbreaker.
An overlong but deeply felt film about a dying woman trying to connect with her granddaughter.
Too odd to be funny, too cold-hearted to be tragic, Hick is an infuriating muddle.

Making their screen debuts, young Spevack and Weinstein give the film's most natural performances and provide its little bit of warmth, but it seems time to petition Collette, a truly gifted actress, to take a long hiatus from playing bitter single moms.
Why resist?
After memorably sealing Ryan Reynolds in a coffin in Buried, screenwriter Chris Sparling's attempts to make a two-ATM vestibule equally claustrophobic are less inspired...

The sorority girls are so interchangeable, and so uninteresting, that I got to wishing that Morgan and all those who tred the lucrative horror remake market would take the time to create a bonafide heroine whose survival we could cheer.
... never-hilarious but often-quite-amusing ...
The all-Polynesian cast bring so much energy and glee to the telling that one can only smile and hope they all profit wildly from the American remake that's reportedly in the works.
Antibodies is fairly riveting, thanks to Alvart's command of craft and tone. He's a director to watch.
Perry has great casting instincts, and in Elba and Union he's matched two gifted, equally gorgeous actors, both of whom seem ready to make sparks fly. If only their director would let them.

This is a decidedly bizarre movie, nicely photographed and designed -- someone spent some money -- but built entirely around dialogue so stilted and unrevealing that it's little wonder poor [actor Adam] LaVorgna screams it.
movie_title: The Boy Who Cried Bitch: The Adolescent Years (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Interesting, well-acted debut feature from writer-director Russell Brown.
Clichéd though it may be, this movie was clearly made with love.
The filmmaker is good with actors, and in Hall, she has a lead with such innate authority that you can't take your eyes off him, even when he's manhandling flapping waterfowl.
Americanizing Shelley isn't original, or the least bit believable, but it's so lovingly made that one's usual resistance to such clichés falls away.
No amount of neck nuzzling or back arching can make us believe there's real heat rising between these two.
Amy's sin never for a second rings true, and eventually grows tiresome.

This is director Asghar Farhadi's third feature, and it's brilliantly assured, both in the fluidity and unexpected stylishness of the camerawork and in the subtlety with which Farhadi and co-writer Mani Haghighi explore the complexities of modern [Iran].

After all these years and all the complex fight scenes [Chan's] been in, the basics are plenty satisfying. He's still the Gene Kelly of martial arts. Tucker and Ratner can't even begin to match Chan's grace, but to their credit, they seem to know it.
The only thing more boring than a vampire with moral issues about biting people in the neck is a werewolf who'd rather become fully human than howl at the moon once a month.
Marigold is saved from the predictability of its setup by the enthusiasm of its cast, color-drenched sets and costumes, and full-on musical numbers staged outdoors on a beautiful seaside stage.
It's hard to get too worked up about a film whose very title announces its maker's intent.
That one can't quite decide if these charming men are heroes or villains is a mark of Johnson's calm, even approach to an issue seemingly fueled by emotions run amok.
Bishop has chops; someone give this man a meeting.

First-time screenwriter Albert Leon appears to have turned for music industry insight not to his famous producer (who has no excuses) but to other music-themed movies (Mariah Carey's Glitter, perhaps?).
I kept wishing for a rewrite that sent the Satanists packing and pulled the love story hiding within Wennekers' script to the fore.
The Mist made me want to scream, but for all the wrong reasons.
Director Andrew Brendan Shea can't seem to decide if he's making a thriller, a boozy blue-collar melodrama or a religious parable.
Superb.
A fresh take on an oft-told tale.
Some unsettling moments here, but the evil ghost itself is a predictable one-trick pony.
While Driving Lessons' writer-director, Jeremy Brock, sticks to the all-too-familiar template of such tales, he's given [Julie] Walters her best role since Educating Rita.
Gulager and screenwriters Marcus Dunstan and Patrick Melton have come up with some wittily nasty moments.
The film drags in the homestretch, as the filmmakers needlessly shuffle characters around the city.
A Year Without Love isn't a sex movie (so don't expect one), but a studied examination of how one man folds jarring events into the everyday fabric of his life.
movie_title: A Year Without Love (Un Ano sin amor) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The photography and period detailing are excellent, and Taub, who displays real feeling for the innocent bystanders of war, finds the occasional small, surprising moment.
Adam & Steve is uneven, but it's a relief to see a gay romance that isn't about ab-perfect 20-year-olds, and which features lovers played by two long out-of-the-closet actors.

Screenwriter James C. Strouse (in whose hometown the film was shot) provides so few clues to the source of Jim's malaise, or that of his entire sad-sack family, that the movie remains rudderless and not the least bit believable.
There, the music shifts from Lena Horne to hip hop Gershwin remixes, and on to a dance-off finale and closing credit sequence that's the only rousing part of this movie.
When Do We Eat? may strike a chord with those struggling to reconcile traditional faith and modernity, though few are likely to buy Ira's post-high transformation into a loving husband and father.
Kinky Boots is diverting, but it's only worth shouting about thanks to Ejiofor's quietly subversive take on what has become a stock movie character.
Mountain Patrol: Kekexili is sometimes slow going, yet it builds in power as nature begins to take its toll on the patrol, and its cumulative effects are haunting.
[An] overcooked reinterpretation of Chekhov's The Three Sisters.
Formulaic but innocuous.
... a film that makes studying Latin-root flash cards seem like a cool afterschool activity ...

... while some may bail early, those who stay to the end are likely to dwell on Zahedi's unwavering (some would say unrelenting) belief in his own artistry, as well as the film's many funny, quotable lines ...
... uneven teen sports drama ...
David Zeiger's superb documentary about the Vietnam War era's GI protest movement is jammed with incident and anecdote and moves with nearly as much breathless momentum as the movement itself.

As director, Scott Marshall displays an unsurprising flair for selling a joke, but also a fine sense of dramatic pacing and, even better, a gift for brevity, neither of which, it could be argued, are innate skills of his famous filmmaking family.
The latest film to be drawn from Phyllis Reynolds Naylor's best-selling young-adult trilogy about a frisky West Virginia beagle with a knack for bringing people together.
Nasty yet taut slice-and-dice-'em horror flick.
Kevin Bacon (Sedgwick's husband) can't seem to decide if he's making a film about a loving eccentric or a sociopath.
Hall's heart lies not in guns and chases but in finding redemption for his city-ravaged characters.
[A] charming documentary from first-time director Patrick Creadon.
It's as if the filmmakers lost their nerve when it came time to write the kind of intimate, revealing conversation that can make a sex toy unnecessary.

[You can] feel the filmmakers yearning to have Beowulf and Grendel go all Rambo on each other. Instead, they keep pulling back for more Old English angst, as if they're torn between commerce and winning the approval of their high school English teacher.
Yes, this is another faux rock documentary, but one so dramatically and visually textured that it reinvents that decidedly worn genre.
A film free of political fury, but full of activist optimism, this tame but heartfelt documentary is a fine companion piece to a day at the science museum.
It's a shame that [Director Dan] Cox resorts to such Rove-style foolishness.
It's impressive, actually, that Lawrence lets this film's supporting players steal so much of his show -- as movie stars go, he must be a pretty secure guy.
The flashback sequences are vibrant and intense, and the film's long closing shot is so dense with feeling for a nation and its people that Bose deserves to be noted as a filmmaker to watch.
The filmmakers deserve credit for being serious-minded, but they might have hinted at the top of the film that all would not be well in the end.
Whatever it was about Hideous Men that so deeply affected Krasinski the college student has been lost in translation.
These actors are good at what they do -- like those soccer players that dodge and weave with effortless grace.
The fact that its old-school scares caused seemingly jaded 20-somethings at a recent midnight screening to squirm in their seats suggests that there's hope for the world after all.
Whether Ryan means this as art or exploitation, I can't say, but it's definitely a theme more disturbing than the buzzword in the film's title.

Hannah Free is as predictable as a Hallmark Channel movie, although there's undeniable pleasure to be had from watching Gless mumble and grumble and generally chew the scenery. Cagney lives, and she's as cranky as ever.
Handsomely produced but dramatically inert.

Holbrook is as unsentimental as Abner himself, and the beauty of his work here lies in his refusal to soften the character's hard edges. Regrettably, Teems's editorial choices in the film's homestretch waste that discipline.
A word of advice: Do not invite the Strobbe family over for Christmas dinner, as they're likely to leave the house strewn with beer bottles and broken furniture.
The weird turns that Davy's life takes always feel emotionally honest, thanks in no small measure to Geraghty's achingly true performance.
Reportedly drawing on their own romantic relationship, Wein and Lister-Jones have co-written a low-budget romantic comedy that's smart and lively and, in the end, quite affecting.
A brave actor if not a technically dazzling one, Brosnan gives a moving performance, but he's constantly undercut by the predictability of Allen's woes.
White on Rice glows with warmth.White on Rice glows with warmth.
Bloody and gory, but in a friendly way, this is a movie for old-school horror fans who understand that, sometimes, bad is good.
movie_title: The Black Waters of Echo's Pond (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Duke appears to be aiming for a Tyler Perry-style mix of the taboo and the saintly, but his touch is so leaden that one ends up giggling, not weeping.

Sounds trashy, sounds silly, but first-time director Nicolo Donato, who wrote the screenplay with Rasmus Birch, and a superb ensemble refuse to wink, resulting in a film that constantly subverts expectation.
Horny horror-movie revelers tend to deserve what's coming to them, a sentiment French-born director Alexandre Aja embraces with maniacal glee in a third-act massacre that's downright ruthless.
Miraculous, cinematically dramatic escapes abound in these stories, but there's no triumph in the eyes of the tellers -- only guilt, remorse and pain.
By the time Crowley begins literally ripping Marybeth's posse apart, one is too numbed-out to cheer the gruesome ingenuity of the old-school special effects. Die, Victor, die. Please.
Though one senses that the movie in Morris-Burkes head makes more sense than the movie onscreen, his technical virtuosity and thematic ambition mark him as a filmmaker of promise.
Newt and company are here to warn of an Obama-Pelosi socialist takeover that can be stopped by voting out the fiscally Satanic Democrats in next month's election.
It is creepy enough to make you hope the theater parking lot is brightly lit.
If the grand finale isn't as resonantly scary as the original's, maybe that's just because, try though we might, we're no longer impressionable kids.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Dead, with its vast, pitiless landscapes and moral seriousness, is Night of the Living Dead reimagined as a Sergio Leone western. It's a knockout.
Brutal and bloody and utterly unnerving...
Decidedly amoral.
[A] refreshingly quirky comedy.
Get Low is a pleasure to watch.

After a first hour that plays like a bad TV show, Sommers hits his groove with an over-the-top Paris chase sequence that, in turn, leads to an underwater finale that's absurdly overproduced, momentarily diverting, and then instantly forgettable.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Zombie has talent to burn, but he's slumming here, and one suspects that he knows it.
Rowe displays new authority and confidence, as if lately he's been looking in the mirror and seeing himself, rather than that other, more famous blond.
Furman stages the final foot chase with brio, but one wishes that he'd found a way to stay at home with Felix and Marina, who don't need guns to thrill.
There's nothing scary in there, but here's a shudder-inducing fact: McCormick and Cardone are currently collaborating on a remake of the witty and nearly perfect 1987 thriller, The Stepfather.

Hellboy II doesn't have much on its mind, but few will care, since del Toro and his stellar Pan's Labyrinth team, including Oscar-winning cinematographer Guillermo Navarro, stage one virtuoso set piece after another.
This low-budget horror comedy arrives via a lively trailer and a witty print ad, yet the film itself never quite takes off.
Creating an ingenious mad bomber isn't quite the thrill it used to be.

This snail-paced film might as well take place in the 1950s, since it seems to have been inspired by one those Hollywood melodramas in which one company employs the entire town, and the only places free of corruption are the church and the local diner.
Light, best known for her TV-sitcom work, turns a cliché -- the zealot with a secret pain of her own -- into an achingly sad woman; it's one of the year's best performances.

Lafferty is all about expletives and sexual innuendo of the frankest kind, some of it so raunchy (and unfunny) as to make one wonder if the parents of the film's many child actors bothered to read the script.
Often quite funny.
Energetic and unapologetically biased.
Splinter earns our respect while delivering 82 minutes of lean, mean fun.
It could be said that Harris and his co-writer, Robert Knott, haven't done a whole lot of writing, but as Cole himself might say, there's no need to get all fancy with what's plain and true.
The movie version gives really good swoon.
Let's call this the gooiest movie of the year (so far).
Well produced but overlong, Growing Out feels like a labor of love made by young filmmakers in need of a stern screenwriting professor.

We've seen it all before, but that doesn't diminish the accomplishment of first-time directors (and brothers) Charles and Thomas Guard, who clearly believe that a creaking door is scarier than a gouged-out eyeball.
Next time, spring for a cab.

movie_review_blurb: The one unforgivable flaw of resurrecting Beauty and the Beast in 2017 is that we've already had another movie handle the monster love story better. It's called Shrek.
Though the final sequence of events is oddly paced and difficult to follow, [Kevin] Phillips succeeds by using the language and logic of teenagers to tell this story.
But Lucky is also very sweet-even though Lucky's convinced that death will plunge him into a void of nothingness, he still gets up each morning and keeps living.
Ingrid Goes West's attempt to deliver a topical dark comedy about social media fails to portray mental health with the nuance required when you're making a movie about an unhinged woman.
Though it's risky to make a film with sadistic murderers as the protagonists, this duo is disarmingly likable. And they're funny.
One of [Fatih] Akin's greatest accomplishments with In the Fade is how he forces viewers to bear witness to Katja's raw, inescapable pain.
The Insult works best when Doueiri spends time examining the root system of hate.
Though this story needs no embellishment, Bay can't help himself.
It's a commendable tribute, and as someone who has watched the race and enjoyed it before, I feel all the more ready to shout myself hoarse on the sidelines now.

As the lost piece of an intricate puzzle, Rogue One satisfyingly presses into its rightful place in the series' universe. Filling in that blank space might never have seemed necessary, but, once you've seen it, there's no denying the richness added.

Even with Smith involved, Catch and Release isn't the sort of film a guy would generally go to see alone, but it does make for a decent date movie. She'll enjoy the romantic elements and he'll likely find it unobjectionably entertaining.

Like all great documentaries, this one transcends its subject matter, so that in the end, it's not just about two guys who play videogames, but about the nature of competition, how we cope with winning and losing and what that tells us about ourselves.

movie_review_blurb: There is a fun film in there somewhere, especially for those who know what they're getting into and are willing to just go with it. If you're not bothered by naked men frolicking and jokes about prison rape, then this is the film for you.
The strength of this film is its visual presentation. The characters are well designed and they move with the necessary precision and grace.

A pop-culture cocktail that is fun, funny and deliciously offbeat.

Imperfect though it may be, In Bruges has charms that are difficult to resist, much like the city for which it's named.

Simply the best teen drama, or coming of age film, I've seen in years. Perfectly performed by young actors with an incredibly mature balance of naturalism and spark, the film is funny, immensely charming, moving, and inspiring. I left with goosebumps.

Full of mixed messages and strange symbolism, its weirdness is also its (limited) charm ... Trippy, confusing, strangely slow and contained, it certainly exists in its own bonkers world, and, as such, is, at least, an odd original.

At 4 hours, it's too much. But at 2x2, it's worth it. Von Trier promises a 5 1/2 hour cut. He doesn't move on ... [obsessed by] men and women, sex and violence. He's a one-theme director, and he's absolutely, resolutely, and wonderfully one of a kind.

Henson would, once again, be proud, of this very funny, very silly, extremely well-made, colourful, joyous movie ... It's all great fun, and it's all very, very Muppet.

A fairytale for adults, this is Anderson's über-film thus far, utilising the entire breadth and astonishing depth of his imagination to bear exquisite humour and life in every single, immaculately composed shot.

Solid, beautifully shot and acted, leisurely paced costume drama that can't hide ... that its central love affair is illicit. What I found fascinating was its depiction of just how an affair was run in such a situation - in those days, among such people.

It's Byrne who steals the movie. She is one funny actor, bringing fresh stylings to every film she does.
Fading Gigolo is a fading film memory in an instant, but, for Allen devotees, cosy and snug while you suck on it.

Every good movie offers its own pleasures. Roman Polanski's adaptation of David Ives' play offers us a unique set of them: the moments an actor transitions ... The script ... is good, but what you're really watching is the acting.

If you ... will consider going to a Godzilla movie, this one is worth your while. Edwards borrows the Spielbergian style in every way - from camera moves to use of music to the gradual rolling out of the big effects - and it's the right choice.

Glazer's Sexy Beast and Birth were idiosyncratic but Under The Skin trumps them triumphantly, being compelling, weird, intensely disturbing and ultimately bizarrely moving. Many of its images are shockingly vivid for me two weeks after having seen it.

movie_review_blurb: There is a thrilling and disturbing story here, with a fully realised and exotic milieu, heroes, villains, a compelling story arc, and gasp-inducing twists and turns.

A thriller, but, like the films of Asghar Farhadi, offers a depth of emotional engagement far beyond your average ... indeed, far beyond your average "straight drama". Its thrills are thrilling, but its drama is intense, moving, and extremely rewarding.
The subject matter is ripe for a bold, original, dark and funny treatment, but director Jon S. Baird has so obviously tried to ape the style of Danny Boyle's Trainspotting that it's embarrassing.
Crossing Sweeny Todd with Tucker and Dale Vs Evil, the Cairns boys deliver a lot of laughs, nice and realistic dollops of sticky gore, and quite a lot of heart to boot.

Incoherent to the point of being incomprehensible, Ridley Scott's new film The Counselor, from a first-time (terrible) screenplay by novelist Cormac McCarthy, represents a low point for both of these highly acclaimed artists. It's a total mess.
It is a brutal, frank, painful and highly meticulous look at an ordinary man undergoing a very modern crisis amidst a very simple life.
Four of the five characters are really unlikeable, and the effect is of being trapped in a small place with five hideous people yelling at you - it's crushing, oppressive and claustrophobic.
The production design is terrific, revelling not just in period detail but in all of Liberace's excesses, and, typically, Soderbergh's camera and use of music are never anything other than top notch.
It certainly doesn't break the mould, but coming-of-age drama The Way, Way Back, from writer / directors Nat Faxon and Jim Rash, is sweet, gently funny, and full of terrific attention to detail.

A bloody good movie, a ripping yarn, a dark dystopian future sci-fi, full of action, astonishing imagery, a superb score (Ryan Amon), great performances (with one exception) and such an assured sense of style that I was continually bowled over.

As much an examination of contemporary Chinese character, ambition and taste as it is of the Chateaux and wines of Bordeaux ... globe-trotting, hugely informative and thoroughly entertaining ... crafted with as much care as the wines we see onscreen.

It contains some of the most inspiring, moving, goosebump-inducing moments, scenes and speeches that I've seen thus far this year, but also some truly cringeworthy ones. It's as though two different creative teams made the film, and only one was good.
If anything, Maisie as a character is a little too indefatigable; once in a while, you'd love her to throw a huge screaming tantrum and let her wretched parents know just what children they're being.

Carruth's second feature proudly follows his debut Primer (2004) in its audacity, intellect and astonishing originality. Carruth does not make films for fools, but nor does he try and fool anyone; if you're willing to look, it's all there.
A serious misfire, unfunny, unexciting, uninvolving and, perhaps the worst sin of all, incredibly self-indulgent to the detriment of the audience's enjoyment.
It's a quiet movie of small rewards, made by a whole lot of talented people taking a risk and pulling it off with humble aplomb.
In A Better World won this year's Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film -- the most obviously deserving award of the night. Completely, unquestionably recommended.

This is a B picture that aspires to nothing else, and it's quite a good one. Brett Ratner directs with no particular flair, but he sets an easygoing, comfy tone, and maintains it. I look forward to the inevitable franchise.
I liked the mood of Stoker: gothic, dark, strange and melancholy. It's like a really creepy Sunday afternoon.
A true original, depicting a culture rarely filmed, observed with a respectful but never overly reverential eye.
Excruciating dialogue is only the tip of the iceberg of this film's dunderheadedness, but it's the sin that keeps on giving throughout the way too many 108 painful minutes it takes to get through it.
Dror Moreh's documentary is remarkable not for stylistic innovation but for the very fact it exists.
Would be a moving and sweet depiction of the growing bond between a father and his adopted son if it weren't actually about mass murder.

A drippy romance, spending the vast majority of its time in private, two-hander scenes imagining inane dialogue between a dead Princess and a famously reclusive, private surgeon; it only exists because it knows neither of them is going to complain.

If I found a lamp, and a genie came out and granted me three wishes, I'd use one to raise Kubrick so I could take him to Gravity ... No element is out of place, no intention unrealized ... unity of time, place and character ... a work of the highest art.
Wildly inconsistent in tone, it is impossible to know whether the film aspires to comedy; it's certainly not funny.

Playing out as much in the boardrooms of the Danish parent company as it is on the cargo vessel itself, the film is a real eye-opener: when this stuff happens, there's no-one to call for help ... A Hijacking is an exercise in precise filmmaking.
Denis Villeneuve's Prisoners is a nasty piece of work. Indeed, it is about as bleak and unforgiving as mainstream, studio moviemaking gets.
What lifts this atmospheric and affecting film from its genre limitations are its milieu, its striking visual style and its truly enjoyable, low-key performances.

Hartley's remake is extremely faithful to the original, and what is most fun about it is the style and tone ... Donaggio's bold, over-the-top, old-school horror score reminds us that we are in an homage, and to enjoy the ride as such.
From the first shot to the last, you feel that tremendous security you get when you are sure that the filmmaker is in total control of his material.

Often inspired, sometimes lethargic adaption of a French graphic novel, funded mainly by the Korean government and starring a panoply of British thespians and [Captain America himself]. An awesome 90 minute movie lurks within these very bloated 126.
Unfortunately - very unfortunately - A Dame To Kill For offers nothing new and feels terribly, sadly, redundant.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: No-one shoots a Parisian car chase like Besson, and he's capable of a garishly vulgar set piece; the set-up of the movie - the opening twenty or so minutes - is quite excellent. It's total EuroTrash, but with a Scarlett sheen.

It's not helped at all by a cold script that really doesn't invite us to feel for any of the myriad characters, really indulgent editing, and a too-obvious soundtrack desperate to tell us what to think and, always worse, how to feel.

King is obviously a true fan and he's made a true and wonderful Paddington movie ... The themes and concerns of Michael Bond's original series of books and television shows are all there, and the personalities are too.
A true original, and a totally awesome entertainment, all the more so if you like your satire as bitter and black as a Turkish espresso.
This dark, haunting and cold tale is more of a comic horror movie for all ages than a happy children's story.

Rough, wild and wooly, and kids are gonna love it. But, the longer it goes, the more it strays from the original musical, and the more there is for fans to dislike ... This Annie never goes to the White House. She's too enamoured with her penthouse.
It's gently funny, it's compelling, the performances are excellent, and it flies in the face of conventional romantic films, always carving its own path. Satisfying, charming and recommended.
Much more about friendship and loyalty than it is about killing a foreign leader or even making fun of one ... As satire it is very broad; as broad comedy it is surprisingly, and pleasingly, smart.
It's hard to make the workings of the scientific mind dramatic, but unfortunately The Imitation Game doesn't even try.
Tremendously, gorgeously life-affirming and soul-stirring ... The film is impeccably constructed, making bold choices which are followed through with integrity and conviction.
If it only exists for Sondheim fans, it exists well for them. Supposedly the man himself is happy with it, and so he should be. It treats his work with complete reverence, respect, and love.

Hugely ambitious, rambunctious, loud and thrilling; it takes risks at every step, and while not all pay off, most do in spades. It's not always funny but when it is, it's hilarious. It is also highly original - and that always deserves credit.

Cooper's performance is totally precise. The gradations he and Eastwood have chosen to show - of Kyle's character, personality and disease - are perfectly graded ... and if that isn't exactly the man Chris Kyle was, it's an indelible movie character.
You'll be entertained and, to whatever degree, you will not only learn something, you might have your whole understanding of the universe altered. Pretty good for ninety-nine minutes.
Jean-Marc Vallee follows up The Dallas Buyer's Club with Wild, another strong, urgent, raw piece of filmmaking that offers an Oscar-nominated turn for its lead actor, in this case Reese Witherspoon.
An extremely cold, creepy and brilliant examination of the spookiest edges of the male psyche.
The most surprising thing about The Theory of Everything, which looks from the outside like a movie about Stephen Hawking, is that it's a movie about Jane, his first wife.
While the bounteous fight sequences have verve and style, the rest of the film does not.

Vital, urgent, and breathtaking ... It is brilliant because it captures an intimate moment of history that will reverberate through the ages; a moment that would not have been captured had not a connection been made.
